Headline: Factbox: Biden is the last person standing in the 2020 Democratic presidential race
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden emerged as the Democrat who will challenge Republican Donald Trump in the U.S. presidential election after Senator Bernie Sanders ended his bid for the party's nomination on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump removes top coronavirus watchdog, widens attack on inspectors general
Article: President Donald Trump removed the inspector general who was to oversee the government's $2.3 trillion coronavirus response, a spokeswoman for the official's office said on Tuesday, fueling concerns in Congress about oversight of the relief package.

Headline: Long lines and frustration as Wisconsinites vote during coronavirus pandemic
Article: Despite a last-minute court battle and a stay-at-home order, thousands of Wisconsin voters on Tuesday braved the coronavirus outbreak to wait 6 feet (1.8 m) apart in lines for hours and cast ballots in the state's presidential primary and local elections.

Headline: 'I own it:' U.S. Navy secretary resigns over handling of coronavirus-hit carrier
Article: Acting Navy Secretary Thomas Modly resigned on Tuesday after he faced mounting backlash for firing and ridiculing the commander of a U.S. aircraft carrier who pleaded for help stemming a coronavirus outbreak onboard.

Headline: Most Americans, unlike Trump, want mail-in ballots for November if coronavirus threatens: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Most Americans, including a majority of Republicans, want the government to require mail-in ballots for the Nov. 3 presidential election if the coronavirus outbreak still threatens the public this autumn, a Reuters/Ipsos poll found.

Headline: House panel asks Trump's acting spy chief to explain spate of firings
Article: The House Intelligence Committee chairman on Tuesday called on U.S. President Donald Trump's acting spy chief to explain the removals and resignations of top intelligence officials and whether he ever tried to block probes by the intelligence community's recently fired internal watchdog.

Headline: Pentagon chief accepts acting Navy Secretary's resignation
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper said on Tuesday that he had accepted Acting Navy Secretary Thomas Modly's resignation.

Headline: White House spokeswoman Grisham switches to first lady's staff
Article: In a White House communications shakeup, press secretary Stephanie Grisham announced plans to leave on Tuesday and administration officials said she was expected to be replaced by a spokeswoman for President Donald Trump's re-election campaign, Kayleigh McEnany.

Headline: Acting Navy secretary offers to resign over handling of carrier crisis
Article: Acting U.S. Navy Secretary Thomas Modly has offered his resignation after coming under fire for his handling of a crisis involving the captain of a coronavirus-stricken aircraft carrier, a U.S. official and a congresssional aide told Reuters on Tuesday, speaking on condition of anonymity.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers introduce bill to fund oil purchase for emergency reserve
Article: A bipartisan group of U.S. lawmakers introduced a bill on Tuesday providing $3 billion to buy oil for the national emergency reserve as a way to help energy companies hit by the plunge in crude prices.

Headline: More high-profile lawmakers line up behind Biden's campaign
Article: Joe Biden's presidential bid won endorsements from two prominent members of Congress on Tuesday, support that could help the Democrat in his campaign for the party's nomination.

Headline: Pelosi says U.S. administration wants more funds for coronavirus relief: CNN
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin called her to ask Congress for more money to help small businesses hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic, and said she agreed an existing program for small businesses "really needs money right away, because of the demand."

Headline: South Africa tour commissioner predicts difficult future for golf
Article: South Africa's Sunshine Tour has created a fund for players and caddies to provide financial assistance for the next two months, but commissioner Selwyn Nathan said the financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic could take the game back 20 years.

Headline: Trump campaign spokeswoman McEnany to become White House press secretary: CNN
Article: A spokeswoman for President Donald Trump's campaign, Kayleigh McEnany, will become the new White House press secretary, CNN reported, in the latest shakeup of the president's communications office.

Headline: Wisconsin's Supreme Court orders primary to proceed as planned on Tuesday
Article: The Wisconsin Supreme Court put the state's chaotic presidential primary back on track, ruling on Monday that Democratic Governor Tony Evers cannot postpone in-person voting to June despite the coronavirus crisis.

Headline: U.S. Supreme Court limits absentee voting in Wisconsin
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday granted a Republican request to limit absentee voting in Tuesday's Wisconsin presidential primary amid restrictions on residents because of the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers seek probe of trade in products needed for pandemic fight
Article: Citing concerns about severe supply disruptions, senior U.S. lawmakers on Monday called for an expedited investigation by the U.S. International Trade Commission into specific imported products needed to combat the new coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Wisconsin's Supreme Court rules governor cannot push back Tuesday's election: AP
Article: Wisconsin's Supreme Court on Monday ruled that Democratic Governor Tony Evers cannot postpone the state's presidential primary scheduled for Tuesday despite the coronavirus crisis, the Associated Press reported.

Headline: Citing coronavirus, Wisconsin mayors urge postponement of Tuesday's election
Article: Nine Wisconsin mayors, including those representing the state's five largest cities, on Sunday urged the state's top public health official to postpone Tuesday's primary election due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: 'He's a total disgrace': Trump defends firing U.S. intel watchdog
Article: President Donald Trump on Saturday defended his decision to fire the top watchdog of the U.S. Intelligence Community, saying Michael Atkinson did "a terrible job" in handling the whistleblower complaint that triggered an impeachment probe of Trump last year.

Headline: Outgoing U.S. intel watchdog fired by Trump says he acted appropriately
Article: Michael Atkinson, the outgoing top watchdog of the U.S. Intelligence Community, on Sunday said he was fired by President Donald Trump for acting impartially in his handling of the whistleblower complaint that triggered an impeachment probe of the president last year.

Headline: Biden says coronavirus may force Democrats to hold 'virtual' presidential convention
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination, said on Sunday the party may be forced to host a "virtual" nominating convention in August due to concerns about the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Wisconsin set to hold in-person voting in presidential primary
Article: Wisconsin is set to hold in-person voting next week after the state's legislature on Saturday declined to take up an effort delaying the presidential primary due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Democrats say Trump pick for coronavirus recovery watchdog is not independent enough
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's pick for the new watchdog overseeing $2.3 trillion in coronavirus-related fiscal spending is not independent enough to do the job, congressional Democrats said on Saturday.

Headline: Trump says will ask Congress for more small business funds if money runs out
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Saturday he would ask Congress for more money to make loans to small businesses struggling with the economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak if the original $349 billion allocated in a fiscal stimulus bill runs out.

Headline: Trump fires intelligence official involved in his impeachment probe
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump notified Congress on Friday that he is firing the inspector general of the U.S. intelligence community who was involved in triggering an impeachment probe of the president last year.

Headline: Supreme Court postpones April oral arguments over coronavirus
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Friday postponed oral arguments scheduled for April as a result of the coronavirus pandemic and is considering alternative options for handling the various outstanding cases.

Headline: Wisconsin Republicans reject governor's call to delay Tuesday's primary and vote by mail
Article: Republican legislative leaders in Wisconsin rejected Democratic Governor Tony Evers' call on Friday to cancel in-person voting and delay next week's presidential primary, saying it must proceed despite fears about the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Kennedy granddaughter, great-grandson missing in Chesapeake Bay
Article: The granddaughter of the late Robert F. Kennedy and her young son were missing on Friday after drifting out into the Chesapeake Bay on a canoe, Maryland Governor Larry Hogan said.

Headline: Trump taps Kavanaugh ally for seat on influential appeals court
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday announced plans to nominate a vocal ally of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh to an influential federal appeals court in Washington.

Headline: Republican leader McConnell says another coronavirus bill is coming
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Friday the U.S. Congress will work on another coronavirus relief bill, with healthcare topping the list of priorities.

Headline: Defense Secretary Esper backed firing of carrier captain Crozier
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper backed the Navy's firing of the commander of a coronavirus-striken aircraft carrier, the Pentagon said on Friday, amid a backlash from Democrats in Congress as well as the crew of the vessel, who hailed their captain as a hero.

Headline: Anyone near Trump or Pence will be given rapid coronavirus test: White House
Article: With the coronavirus contagion spreading, the White House said on Friday that anyone expected to be near President Donald Trump or Vice President Mike Pence will be given a rapid COVID-19 test out of an abundance of caution.

Headline: Ex-White House candidate Buttigieg forms PAC to support 'forward-thinking' Democrats
Article: Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, whose presidential campaign became a top fundraiser in the crowded Democratic primary, is forming a political action committee aimed at creating a new pipeline of leaders for the party, the campaign said on Friday.

Headline: Pelosi wants more for small business and individuals in next U.S. coronavirus legislation
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday that $350 billion in already-passed coronavirus legislation was not enough for small businesses, and she wants more money in next bill being developed now in the Democratic-run House.

Headline: Biden: Trump administration showed 'poor judgment' in removing warship commander
Article: Democratic presidential contender Joe Biden said on Thursday that the Trump administration showed "poor judgment" in relieving the commander of an aircraft carrier who sought stronger measures to control a coronavirus outbreak onboard.

Headline: Judge rejects delay of Wisconsin's presidential primary despite coronavirus fears
Article: A federal judge refused on Thursday to postpone next week's U.S. presidential primary in Wisconsin, but extended the time for absentee voting amid widespread worries about health risks from the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Trump negative for coronavirus again, says wearing masks okay
Article: President Donald Trump said he underwent a second coronavirus test on Thursday, using a new diagnostic that produced a result in less than 15 minutes, and it determined he has not been infected.

Headline: Democrats delay presidential convention until August, citing coronavirus
Article: The Democratic Party on Thursday postponed its U.S. presidential nominating convention by a month until August, citing the coronavirus health crisis that has upended daily life and caused many states to postpone their primaries.

Headline: White House likely to advise people in coronavirus hot spots to wear masks
Article: The White House is expected to issue guidance for people in areas hard hit by the coronavirus to wear face coverings to help stop the spread of the disease, an administration official said on Thursday.

Headline: Trump administration awards $25 billion in emergency transit funding
Article: The Trump administration said on Thursday it was allocating $25 billion in emergency funding grants to public transportation systems facing a massive falloff in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Trump campaign tells Sessions to stop promoting himself as Trump ally
Article: President Donald Trump's presidential campaign told Senate Republican candidate Jeff Sessions on Thursday to stop promoting himself as a Trump ally, lashing out at the former U.S. attorney general, whom the president soured on.

Headline: Democrats want FCC to reject Trump campaign threat to broadcasters
Article: Two top Democrats in Congress on Thursday asked Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Chairman Ajit Pai to reassure broadcasters the agency will not revoke their licenses for airing advertisements critical of President Donald Trump.

Headline: Pelosi announces select committee to oversee U.S. coronavirus relief
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Thursday she will form a bipartisan select committee on the coronavirus crisis to oversee the spending of $2.3 trillion that Congress has approved to respond to the pandemic.

Headline: Democrats delay presidential convention until Aug. - Politico
Article: U.S. Democrats have delayed their presidential nominating convention in Wisconsin by more than a month to Aug. 17, after the party's leading candidate, Joe Biden, said the massive gathering should be rescheduled amid the deadly coronavirus pandemic, news outlet Politico reported on Thursday.

Headline: Trump considers canceling domestic flights to coronavirus hot spots
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he was considering a plan to halt domestic flights to coronavirus hot spots inside the United States as the country struggles to contain a pandemic projected to kill at least 100,000 people.

Headline: Political rivals Biden, Trump may talk about coronavirus
Article: Aides to Joe Biden, the likely Democratic nominee to run against President Donald Trump, will arrange a call for the rivals to discuss the country's response to the deadly coronavirus pandemic, the campaign for the former vice president said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. Social Security recipients to automatically get coronavirus money
Article: U.S. Social Security recipients will not have to file a tax return to receive a payment from the federal government to help offset the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, the U.S. Treasury Department said on Wednesday.

Headline: Pelosi wants 'vote by mail' provisions in next U.S. coronavirus bill
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Wednesday she wants to virus-proof the November election by including funding to boost voting by mail in the next pandemic response plan being put together by Democrats in the House of Representatives.

Headline: Challengers rev their engines to fight Trump's auto emissions weakening
Article: Just two months after taking office, President Donald Trump in March 2017 traveled to Michigan to announce that he would undo ambitious vehicle emissions standards mandated under his predecessor Barack Obama, portraying the reversal as a boost to the U.S. auto industry centered in the Midwestern state.

Headline: Trump warns Iran against possible 'sneak attack' on U.S. in Iraq
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that Iran or its proxies planned a sneak attack on U.S. targets in Iraq, and warned they would pay a "very heavy price" but gave no details.

Headline: U.S. senators join calls for Americans to don masks to slow coronavirus spread
Article: Two U.S. senators joined a growing call on Wednesday for Americans to cover their mouths and noses when they venture outside, as health officials consider recommending that everyone in the country don face masks to limit the spread of the coronavirus.

Headline: Democrats urge U.S. Treasury not to delay $25 billion in grants to airlines
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi urged the U.S. Treasury on Wednesday not to hold up $25 billion in cash grants approved by Congress last week to airlines for payroll costs.

Headline: Trump warns Americans of a tough two weeks ahead in coronavirus fight
Article: President Donald Trump warned Americans on Tuesday of a "painful" two weeks ahead in fighting the coronavirus, with a mounting U.S. death toll that could stretch into the hundreds of thousands even with strict social distancing measures.

Headline: Japan 'on the brink' as it struggles to hold back coronavirus
Article: Japan will ban entry to foreigners from 73 countries and ask everyone arriving from abroad to quarantine themselves for two weeks as it struggles to contain the coronavirus, with a senior minister warning the country had been pushed "to the brink".

Headline: Pelosi urges U.S. Treasury not to delay $25 billion in grants to airlines
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi urged the U.S. Treasury on Wednesday not to hold up $25 billion in cash grants approved by Congress last week to airlines for payroll costs.

Headline: Democrat Sanders calls on Wisconsin to postpone Tuesday primary
Article: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders on Wednesday called on Wisconsin to postpone its April 7 primary, citing the risk from the novel coronavirus.

Headline: House Democrats propose $10 billion for health centers in infrastructure plan
Article: Senior Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives said on Wednesday they would include $10 billion for community health centers on the front lines of fighting the coronavirus outbreak as part of an infrastructure bill aimed at responding to the crisis.

Headline: What's in the $2.3 trillion U.S. coronavirus rescue package
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump signed the largest federal stimulus package in history into law on March 27 to help cope with the economic downturn inflicted by the coronavirus pandemic and shore up medical providers on the front lines of the outbreak.

Headline: Historic $2.2 trillion coronavirus bill passes U.S. House, becomes law
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives on Friday approved a $2.2 trillion aid package - the largest in history - to help cope with the economic downturn inflicted by the intensifying coronavirus pandemic, and President Donald Trump quickly signed it into law.

Headline: Loss of taste and smell key COVID-19 symptoms, app study finds
Article: Losing your sense of smell and taste may be the best way to tell if you have COVID-19, according to a study of data collected via a symptom tracker app developed by scientists in Britain and the United States to help monitor the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: What you need to know about the coronavirus right now
Article: Here's what you need to know about the coronavirus right now:

Headline: U.S. small businesses wait impatiently for government aid that could be slow to come
Article: As soon as New York officials began detailing their response to the coronavirus, Matt Preis knew his staff might be in trouble.

Headline: Coronavirus delays leave thin slate of Democratic presidential contests in April
Article: The coronavirus pandemic has dramatically reshaped the Democratic presidential nominating calendar, forcing many states to curtail in-person voting or delay primary contests to May or June in an attempt to limit the health risks.

Headline: With Republicans wary of more coronavirus spending, Trump urges infrastructure plan
Article: U.S. Republican lawmakers signaled caution on Tuesday over Democratic plans to prepare another large spending bill to battle the coronavirus crisis, even as President Donald Trump called for $2 trillion in spending, this time on infrastructure.

Headline: With 2020 race all but halted over coronavirus, Biden quietly widens lead over Trump: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden has quietly expanded his lead over President Donald Trump among registered voters, even as the rapidly spreading coronavirus has all but sidelined the former vice president's campaign, according to a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll released on Tuesday.

Headline: Senators urge U.S. airlines to issue ticket refunds after bailout
Article: Nine Democratic U.S. senators on Tuesday urged the chief executives of 11 major airlines to issue full cash refunds to customers canceling flights during the coronavirus pandemic after Congress approved a massive rescue package for the hard-hit industry.

Headline: Trump calls for $2 trillion infrastructure bill to help economy during coronavirus crisis
Article: President Donald Trump on Tuesday said the U.S. Congress should pass a $2 trillion spending plan to update the country's roads, bridges and other infrastructure, calling for it to be included in the next bill lawmakers are currently drafting to respond to the coronavirus crisis, which they refer to as "Phase 4."

Headline: U.S. House Speaker Pelosi will not take coronavirus test
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Tuesday she does not plan to be tested for coronavirus despite her proximity to the latest lawmaker diagnosed with the illness.

Headline: Pelosi urges stronger U.S. federal response to coronavirus
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday urged the Trump administration to do more to implement widespread testing for the coronavirus and deliver critical supplies to combat the outbreak, saying there needed to be a more coordinated response.

Headline: Trump says coronavirus guidelines may get tougher; one million Americans tested
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that federal social distancing guidelines might be toughened and travel restrictions with China and Europe would stay in place as he urged Americans to help fight the coronavirus with tough measures through April.

Headline: First U.S. military service member dies from coronavirus
Article: The first U.S. military service member has died from the coronavirus, the Pentagon said on Monday, as it reported another spike in the number of infected troops.

Headline: U.S. senators urge coronavirus delay to June 1 USMCA trade deal start date
Article: A bipartisan group of 19 U.S. senators urged the Trump administration to push back the planned June 1 start date for the new U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact, saying the short lead time would add to pressures on U.S. companies due to the spread of the coronavirus.

Headline: Six members of U.S. Congress diagnosed with coronavirus
Article: At least six members of the U.S. Congress have announced that they have contracted the novel coronavirus, and more than 30 others are or were self-quarantining in hopes of limiting the spread of the pandemic.

Headline: U.S. Congress eyes next steps in coronavirus response
Article: Three days after passing a $2.2 trillion package aimed at easing the heavy economic blow of the coronavirus pandemic, the U.S. Congress was looking on Monday at additional steps it might take as the country's death toll approached 3,000.

Headline: Trump says guidelines to slow coronavirus spread may get tougher
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that he may toughen up current guidelines aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus, which has killed more than 2000 Americans.

Headline: Doctor recommended no action for U.S.' Pelosi after coronavirus contact
Article: The U.S. Congress' attending physician recommended U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi take no particular action after she was in contact with Representative Nydia Velazquez, who has been diagnosed with coronavirus infection, Pelosi's spokesman Drew Hammill said on Monday.

Headline: U.S. House Democrats chart next coronavirus aid bill
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives has begun work on a fourth coronavirus bill targeting a slew of crisis issues from short supplies of medical equipment and protective gear to enhanced worker protections, infrastructure needs and additional payments to individuals, Democratic lawmakers said on Monday.

Headline: Partisan divide returns in U.S. Congress on coronavirus next steps
Article: Fresh partisan divisions flared on Sunday on the next steps for the U.S. Congress in dealing with the coronavirus crisis, with the top House of Representatives Republican casting doubt on the need for more economic stimulus legislation while House Speaker Nancy Pelosi signaled she plans to move forward with it.

Headline: U.S. House not expected to meet sooner than April 20, Hoyer says
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives is not expected to meet again in regular session sooner than Monday April 20, House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, a Democrat, advised members on Monday.

Headline: Pelosi to discuss worker, patient safety in next coronavirus response bill on Monday
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi will hold a news conference call at 3 p.m. (1900 GMT) on Monday to discuss the planned fourth coronavirus response bill, focusing on how to meet worker and patient safety needs, according to her office.

Headline: Trump brags about high TV viewership of coronavirus briefings
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday bragged about the millions of people tuning in to view his daily press briefings on the coronavirus pandemic, saying on Twitter that his average ratings matched a season finale of "The Bachelor."

Headline: New York's Cuomo postpones primary election as coronavirus cases keep growing
Article: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo said on Saturday he was postponing the state's April 28 presidential primary to June 23 as its number of coronavirus cases climbed to 52,318 and deaths to 728.

Headline: With eye on election, Trump in high-stakes balancing act over coronavirus response
Article: President Donald Trump offered a preview of his re-election campaign playbook last year when he visited the building site of a multi-billion-dollar cracking unit in western Pennsylvania, hailed as one of the largest construction projects in the country.

Headline: U.S. House will have panel overseeing coronavirus aid law expenditures: Pelosi
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Friday the House will set up a panel to oversee expenditures under the $2.2 trillion coronavirus relief law.

Headline: Factbox: 'Mr. No': Meet the U.S. congressman who requested a formal vote to delay the coronavirus bill
Article: U.S. Representative Thomas Massie enraged President Donald Trump and leaders of Congress by trying to delay a planned Friday voice vote on a $2.2 trillion coronavirus economic rescue plan, drawing calls from the White House to throw him out of the Republican Party.

Headline: Coronavirus aid deal is no panacea for coming U.S. state budget woes
Article: A massive federal spending bill aimed at deflecting the economic harm caused by the spreading coronavirus does not address the billions of tax dollars U.S. states stand to lose as major parts of the nation have shut down.

Headline: Coronavirus emerges as major threat to U.S. election process
Article: U.S. election officials looking to construct a safe voting system in a worsening coronavirus pandemic are confronting a grim reality: there may not be enough time, money or political will to make it happen by the November election.

Headline: Trump, Michigan governor trade jabs as state's virus cases mount
Article: President Donald Trump and Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan took fresh swipes at each other over the spread of the coronavirus, escalating a war of words as the state braces to become one of the hardest hit by the pandemic.

Headline: Pelosi says House to approve coronavirus bill on Friday
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday the House of Representatives will approve the coronavirus economic relief bill on Friday, likely after a three hour debate.

Headline: Trump attacks Republican lawmaker threatening delay of economic stimulus
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday criticized a Republican congressman who is considering tactics to delay a House of Representatives vote on a massive coronavirus stimulus bill, calling Representative Thomas Massie a "third-rate grandstander."

Headline: U.S. airlines to dash for cash grants, not loans, even with potential government stake
Article: U.S. airlines are preparing to tap the government for up to $25 billion in grants to cover payroll in a sharp travel downturn triggered by the coronavirus, even after the government warned it may take stakes in exchange for bailout funds, people familiar with the matter said.

Headline: World's ailing airlines appeal for aid as U.S. offers $58 billion
Article: Global airlines urged the world's major economies to act quickly to prevent irreversible damage to an industry that has seen demand decimated almost overnight by the coronavirus crisis.

Headline: U.S. House leaders determined to pass $2.2 trillion coronavirus bill
Article: Leaders of the U.S. House of Representatives are determined to pass a $2.2 trillion coronavirus relief bill on Friday, or at the very latest on Saturday, hoping to provide the quickest help possible as deaths mount and the economy reels.

Headline: U.S. House sets Friday debate for coronavirus aid bill
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives will begin a two-hour debate on a sweeping, $2.2 trillion coronavirus aid bill at 9 a.m. (1300 GMT) on Friday but it was not clear whether the measure would be able to pass on a voice vote, the House Majority Leader's office said late on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox: Latest on the spread of the coronavirus around the world
Article: Leaders of the Group of 20 major economies pledged to inject $5 trillion in fiscal spending into the global economy to blunt the economic impact of the coronavirus and "do whatever it takes to overcome the pandemic."

Headline: Senate passes $2 trillion bill for 'strange and evil' coronavirus crisis
Article: The U.S. Senate on Wednesday unanimously backed a $2 trillion bill aimed at helping unemployed workers and industries hurt by the coronavirus epidemic, as well as providing billions of dollars to buy urgently needed medical equipment.

Headline: Factbox: What's in the $2.2 trillion Senate coronavirus rescue package
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday unanimously approved an unprecedented stimulus package to alleviate the devastating economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Democratic group defies Trump, ramps up ad blasting coronavirus response
Article: Democratic super PAC Priorities USA said on Thursday it planned to expand its use of an advertisement critical of President Donald Trump's response to the coronavirus pandemic despite the Trump re-election campaign's efforts to stop it.

Headline: EU lawmakers back suspension of airline slots rule until October
Article: European lawmakers overwhelmingly agreed on Thursday to suspend until Oct. 24 a rule requiring airlines to use at least 80% of their flight slots to keep them the following year so as to ease an industry crisis unleashed by the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: IATA urges G20 to support airline industry
Article: The International Air Transport Association on Thursday urged the group of the 20 major economies to act quickly to prevent irrecoverable damage to the airline industry that has been shaken by the coronavirus crisis.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers who tested positive for the coronavirus
Article: Three members of the U.S. Congress have tested positive for the new coronavirus, and more than two dozen others have said they are self-quarantining in hopes of limiting the spread of the pandemic.

Headline: U.S. Senate approves big rescue for struggling aviation sector
Article: The U.S. Senate voted late Wednesday 96-0 to give the U.S. aviation industry $58 billion in a coronavirus-rescue package, half in the form of grants to cover some 750,000 employees' paychecks, in a badly needed lifeline for an industry facing the worst travel downturn in history.

Headline: Pilots' union criticises UK's coronavirus job retention scheme
Article: The union representing British pilots has described the government's scheme to retain jobs through the coronavirus outbreak as confusing, lacking detail and taking too long to help those who are being laid off now.

Headline: U.S. envoy blames China for endangering world with coronavirus
Article: The U.S. ambassador to London has said China had endangered the world by suppressing information about the coronavirus outbreak thus allowing it to spread far beyond the Communist republic's borders.

Headline: What you need to know about the coronavirus right now
Article: Here's what you need to know about the coronavirus right now:

Headline: U.S. Senate approves $2-trillion coronavirus economic, medical aid bill
Article: The U.S. Senate on Wednesday unanimously passed a $2-trillion bill aimed at helping unemployed workers and industries hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, as well as providing billions of dollars to buy urgently needed medical equipment.

Headline: U.S. Senate poised to vote on passage of $2 trillion coronavirus bill
Article: The U.S. Senate is scheduled to begin voting shortly on an historic $2 trillion bill to stimulate the sagging economy and rush federal funds to medical centers struggling to respond to the coronavirus outbreak.

Headline: Massive coronavirus response bill nears passage in U.S. Senate
Article: The $2 trillion coronavirus economic stimulus bill gained more than the 60 votes needed to pass the U.S. Senate on Wednesday, as voting on the emergency legislation continued.

Headline: U.S. senators make progress toward voting on $2 trillion coronavirus bill
Article: A last-minute obstacle to passage of a $2 trillion coronavirus economic stimulus bill in the U.S. Senate was in the process of being resolved and would likely clear the way for prompt approval of the measure, Senator Lindsey Graham said on Wednesday.

Headline: House ready to act swiftly once Senate votes on coronavirus bill, Pelosi says
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives could take up a coronavirus economic relief bill as soon as it clears the Senate, Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Wednesday, although she did not provide a specific timeline.

Headline: Trump says he will sign coronavirus relief package right away
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he would sign a $2 trillion legislative package to address the economic impact from the coronavirus pandemic into law immediately after it is passed and encouraged lawmakers to bring it over the finish line.

Headline: Forget politics. Majority of Republicans, Democrats now agree coronavirus is 'serious threat': Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Seven in 10 Americans now consider the coronavirus pandemic to be "a serious threat to me and my family," according to a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll that shows how wide, bipartisan segments of the country feel their lives have been turned upside down by the health crisis.

Headline: Spokesman for U.S. Senator Grassley: Coronavirus bill language not 'drafting error'
Article: Disputed language in the U.S. coronavirus relief bill about unemployment benefits was "not a drafting error," a spokesman for Senate Finance Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley said Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. Republican lawmaker urges State Department to boost diplomacy on oil price war
Article: A top Republican lawmaker urged a U.S. State Department official on Wednesday to press ahead with diplomatic efforts to end the oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia that is harming U.S. oil producers.

Headline: Factbox: What's in the $2 trillion U.S. Senate coronavirus rescue package
Article: U.S. senators were set to vote on Wednesday on a $2 trillion bipartisan package of legislation to alleviate the devastating economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: U.S. Senator Sanders threatens to put hold on Senate aid bill
Article: U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders said on Wednesday he was prepared to put a hold on a $2 trillion Senate coronavirus economic relief bill unless a group of Republican senators drop their objections to language on jobless benefits in the legislation.

Headline: White House's Kudlow: problem with Senate bill's language 'will be worked out'
Article: White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow told Fox News in an interview on Wednesday that a problem with language on jobless benefits in a U.S. Senate coronavirus aid bill "will be worked out."

Headline: Biden calls Trump's Easter back-to-business goal 'catastrophic'
Article: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden said on Wednesday that potential efforts by President Donald Trump to re-open American businesses in time for the Easter holiday could be "catastrophic."

Headline: Three Republicans call for layoff language fix before Senate coronavirus bill vote
Article: Three Republican U.S. senators on Wednesday said the Senate should not vote on a $2 trillion coronavirus stimulus bill until legislative language that they say would encourage layoffs is fixed or fresh guidance issued from the Labor Department.

Headline: No. 2 House Democrat pledges 24-hour notice before stimulus vote
Article: The No. 2 Democrat in the U.S. House of Representatives told colleagues in a letter on Wednesday that he was committed to providing 24 hours notice before the House votes on a $2 trillion stimulus bill the Senate appears poised to approve.

Headline: Latest on the spread of the coronavirus around the world
Article: The highly contagious coronavirus, which causes a respiratory illness called COVID-19, has caused entire regions to be placed on lockdown and in some places soldiers are patrolling the streets to keep consumers and workers indoors, halting services and production and breaking supply chains.

Headline: Schumer: help for health system, local governments in coronavirus package
Article: Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said on Wednesday the coronavirus legislation deal agreed to in the Senate includes $130 billion for the U.S. health care system and $150 billion to help state and local governments deal with the pandemic.

Headline: House speaker Pelosi says Democrats will review coronavirus bill
Article: House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Wednesday the coronavirus relief legislation agreed in the U.S. Senate goes a long way toward meeting the needs of the American people and House Democrats will now review the bill.

Headline: U.S. Senate to pass massive coronavirus bill on Wednesday: McConnell
Article: The U.S. Senate will move to pass a massive coronavirus bill on Wednesday aimed at providing economic relief for individuals and companies amid the ongoing outbreak, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said.

Headline: What you need to know about the coronavirus right now
Article: Here's what you need to know about the coronavirus right now:

Headline: U.S. Congress, negotiators reach deal on $2-trillion coronavirus aid package
Article: U.S. senators and Trump administration officials have reached an agreement on a massive economic stimulus bill to alleviate the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, the negotiators said on Wednesday.

Headline: Negotiators reach agreement on massive U.S. coronavirus response bill: Trump aide
Article: U.S. senators and Trump administration officials have reached an agreement on a massive economic stimulus bill to alleviate the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, White House official Eric Ueland said early on Wednesday.

Headline: Instant View: U.S. government agrees stimulus package in response to coronavirus pandemic
Article: U.S. senators and officials in U.S. President Donald Trump's administration have reached an agreement on a massive economic stimulus bill to alleviate the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, White House official Eric Ueland said early on Wednesday.

Headline: Factbox: Latest on the spread of the coronavirus around the world
Article: The United States could become the global epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday, as India announced a full 24-hour, nationwide lockdown in the world's second-most populous country.

Headline: Mnuchin hopes deal is 'very close' on $2-trillion coronavirus aid package in U.S. Senate
Article: The U.S. Treasury secretary and the Senate Democratic leader voiced confidence late on Monday for a deal to be reached soon on a far-reaching coronavirus economic stimulus package that had been stalled in the U.S. Senate as lawmakers haggled over it.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers nearing deal for massive aviation sector bailout: sources
Article: U.S. lawmakers are nearing agreement on a $61 billion rescue package for the aviation sector that would include $25 billion in payroll grants for passenger airlines weathering a sharp falloff in travel demand amid rising coronavirus outbreaks, three people briefed on the matter said.

Headline: Pelosi says she's optimistic coronavirus relief deal can be reached on Tuesday
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she was hopeful that lawmakers could finalize a coronavirus economic stabilization bill on Tuesday, but that a vote may not be able to be held until Wednesday.

Headline: Fed may finance medical response and more under U.S. House bill
Article: The U.S. Congress is considering authorizing the Federal Reserve to pay the tab as local governments ramp up shipments of testing equipment, masks and ventilators desperately needed to diagnose coronavirus cases, treat patients and keep medical personnel safe.

Headline: Trump is prepared to use emergency act if needed, says VP Pence
Article: President Donald Trump is prepared to use the Defense Production Act but industry has been stepping forward, U.S. Vice President Mike Pence said on Fox News on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. Congress wrestles with mechanics of voting in coronavirus crisis
Article: Even as the U.S. Congress works on a massive relief bill to stem the toll of the coronavirus pandemic that has sickened three of its members, its leadership is wrestling with how the chambers can continue to function in an era of social distancing.

Headline: U.S. to reduce Afghan aid by $1 billion after Pompeo fails to break impasse
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Monday announced a $1 billion cut in U.S. aid to Afghanistan after he failed to convince Afghan President Ashraf Ghani and his political foe to end a feud that has helped jeopardize a U.S.-led peace effort.

Headline: McConnell says lawmakers very close to a deal on coronavirus bill
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said lawmakers were very close on Tuesday to a deal on an economic package that will provide relief for Americans and businesses during the coronavirus outbreak.

Headline: House Speaker Pelosi sees 'real optimism' for coronavirus deal in next few hours: CNBC
Article: Democratic U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that later on Tuesday Congress could soon reach a deal to pass an economic relief package for the fallout from the coronavirus crisis.

Headline: U.S. negotiators say have not reached coronavirus stimulus deal, but close to it
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer said they had not reached an agreement on Monday on a sweeping coronavirus stimulus deal, but had made progress.

Headline: Biden battles for attention as coronavirus threatens to blunt Democrat's momentum
Article: Joe Biden's presidential campaign installed a television studio in his basement over the weekend so the Democratic front-runner could demand bolder action from President Donald Trump on the coronavirus crisis and speak directly to the country.

Headline: Dumped amid coronavirus, former Bloomberg campaign aides sue for pay and benefits

Headline: Suspected coronavirus case among White House press corps - press group

Headline: Trump signs order against hoarding, price gouging in fight against coronavirus
Article: President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday to prevent hoarding and price gouging of supplies needed to fight the deadly coronavirus, a spokeswoman said.

Headline: Secretary of State Pompeo to meet Taliban in Doha: State Department
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will meet Taliban officials in Doha on Monday on his way back from a one-day trip to Afghanistan as part of efforts to salvage a historic deal signed with the insurgent group in February.

Headline: Mnuchin urges U.S. Congress to pass $2 trillion economic relief bill
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Monday urged the Senate to quickly pass an economic relief bill that has grown to $2 trillion, saying it would keep small businesses, airlines and other firms from shedding workers as the coronavirus halts commerce.

Headline: Coronavirus relief bill slows in U.S. Senate, talks continue
Article: The U.S. Senate's drive to pass a $1-trillion-plus coronavirus response bill remained stymied late on Sunday, as Democrats held out for more money to help state and local governments and hospitals, while Republicans urged quick action to give financial markets a sign of encouragement.

Headline: Senate GOP virus bill aids U.S. transport sector; offers airlines loans, not cash
Article: A Senate Republican coronavirus stimulus package would provide financial aid to U.S. airports, transit systems and passenger railroad Amtrak, but $50 billion for struggling U.S. airlines would be a loan, not a cash payout, the proposal showed.

Headline: As talks drag on, U.S. Senate sets second vote on Monday on coronavirus bill
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, frustrated over the deadlock on a major coronavirus response bill, late on Sunday announced a procedural vote will be held early on Monday on a bill that senators already rejected.

Headline: Biden to start considering running mates, consulted Obama
Article: Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden said on Sunday he needed to start vetting possible running mates "in a matter of weeks" and that he discussed the pick with former President Barack Obama.

Headline: U.S. Senate to vote on coronavirus relief bill on Monday: McConnell
Article: The U.S. Senate will vote on a massive economic relief bill on Monday, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Sunday, adding that negotiations were continuing with Democrats on the legislation.

Headline: Member of U.S. Vice President Pence's office tests positive for coronavirus
Article: A member of U.S. Vice President Mike Pence's office has tested positive for the coronavirus but neither President Donald Trump nor Pence have had close contact with the individual, Pence's press secretary Katie Miller said in a statement on Friday.

Headline: U.S. candidate Biden was vastly outspent by Sanders in February

Headline: Progress in U.S. coronavirus economic stimulus talks amid major disagreements: Schumer
Article: Negotiations on a possible $1 trillion coronavirus economic stimulus bill were moving ahead, but agreement by a deadline at midnight on Friday deal was becoming elusive with several major issues dividing congressional Republicans and Democrats, Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer said.

Headline: U.S. Senator Toomey says Senate vote on aid package likely early next week: CNBC
Article: Republican U.S. Senator Pat Toomey told CNBC on Friday that a vote in the Senate on a coronavirus economic aid package is likely to take place early next week.

Headline: Bloomberg to transfer $18 million to Democratic National Committee
Article: Billionaire media mogul Mike Bloomberg will transfer $18 million to the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and several of the field offices from his 2020 presidential bid to state parties, his campaign announced on Friday.

Headline: Senate Republicans introduce new coronavirus bill
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Thursday introduced a massive new legislative package to combat the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, saying Republicans would soon begin negotiations with Democrats aimed at brokering a deal to pass it.

Headline: U.S. Senate will seek deal on $1 trillion coronavirus economic aid package
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell introduced emergency legislation on Thursday to stem the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, and Republicans and Democrats agreed to meet on Friday to seek an agreement.

Headline: Trump says he would support government taking stake in certain companies
Article: President Donald Trump on Thursday opened the door to a radical shift in the U.S. government's relationship to private industry as the coronavirus outbreak upends the nation's economy, saying he would back the government taking stakes in certain companies.

Headline: Senate Republican proposal rejects grants for U.S. airlines, could get equity
Article: A Republican proposal introduced in the U.S. Senate on Thursday would grant up to $58 billion in secured loans to help passenger and cargo airlines hit by the coronavirus crisis, but bar cash grants and could result in the government getting equity stakes.

Headline: Mnuchin urges Congress to pass massive economic relief bill by next week
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Thursday urged Congress to move quickly to pass a $1 trillion economic relief measure by early next week, saying he expects bipartisan support for the bill to get cash payments to Americans during the coronavirus crisis.

Headline: Trump says he will enter Saudi-Russia oil fray at appropriate time
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday said he would get involved in the oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia at the appropriate time, saying low gasoline prices were good for U.S. consumers even as they were hurting the industry.

Headline: U.S. Representative Tulsi Gabbard ends Democratic presidential bid, endorses Biden
Article: U.S. Representative Tulsi Gabbard, an Iraq War veteran who campaigned to end "forever wars," dropped her long-shot bid for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday and endorsed front-runner Joe Biden in a video posted to Twitter.

Headline: U.S. Democratic leader Schumer says concerned Trump's $1,000 check plan insufficient
Article: U.S. Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer on Wednesday warned of an economic recession as the coronavirus spreads through the country and called for a broader cash payment than Trump's push for $1,000 checks.

Headline: Biden's wins in U.S. states that matter most set stage for duel with Trump
Article: With Bernie Sanders on the ropes in the race for the Democratic Party nomination, Joe Biden can turn his attention now to a November matchup against Republican Donald Trump, backed by momentum in states that decide U.S. presidential elections.

Headline: Factbox: Biden, Sanders the last two standing in 2020 Democratic presidential race
Article: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders are the last White House candidates standing in the Democratic race to challenge Republican Donald Trump in November, after U.S. Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii on Thursday ended her longshot bid and endorsed Biden.

Headline: Senate Republicans aim to unveil new coronavirus bill details
Article: Republicans in the U.S. Senate are aiming to unveil details of a massive new coronavirus bill later on Thursday that is intended to help the U.S. economy weather the ill-effects of the growing outbreak, according to a Republican lawmaker.

Headline: U.S. Senate passes one coronavirus aid package while working on another
Article: The U.S. Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation on Wednesday providing billions of dollars to limit the damage from the coronavirus pandemic through free testing, paid sick leave and expanded safety-net spending.

Headline: Explainer: What's in the U.S. coronavirus aid bill that just passed Congress?
Article: The U.S. Senate passed a more than $100 billion coronavirus aid package on Wednesday, sending it on to President Donald Trump who is expected to sign it into law. Lawmakers are already working on another stimulus effort in response to the widening outbreak in the country.

Headline: Nearly half Irish coronavirus cases in Dublin, growth rate eases
Article: Nearly half confirmed cases of coronavirus in Ireland are in the capital Dublin, the health department said on Wednesday in its first detailed regional breakdown of figures as the daily growth rate eased.

Headline: Dow loses almost all that it gained during Trump's presidency

Headline: Sanders to 'assess his campaign' after another round of bruising losses: statement
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders plans to talk with supporters to "assess his campaign" after bruising losses to Joe Biden in the most recent round of voting, his campaign said in a statement on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump to nominate U.S. health official for WHO Executive Board: White House
Article: President Donald Trump intends to nominate Assistant Secretary for Health Brett Giroir to be the U.S. representative to the World Health Organization's Executive Board, the White House said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump ratchets up criticism of China over coronavirus
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday ratcheted up his rhetoric against China over the coronavirus, saying Beijing should have acted faster to warn the world and dismissing criticism that his labeling it the "Chinese virus" was racist.

Headline: Trump to nominate permanent director for White House budget office
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump intends to nominate the current acting director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, Russell Vought, to take the post on a permanent basis, the White House said on Wednesday.

Headline: House lawmaker calls for freezing consumer and business credit payments
Article: All payments on mortgages, credit cards, small-business loans and other consumer debt would be indefinitely suspended under a plan unveiled on Wednesday by a senior Democratic House lawmaker in response to the coronavirus outbreak.

Headline: Congress sends Trump multibillion-dollar coronavirus aid bill
Article: The U.S. Senate on Wednesday passed legislation providing more than $100 billion to confront the growing coronavirus outbreak by financing free testing for the virus, expanded paid sick leave, additional food aid and other urgently needed steps.

Headline: Pentagon says still looking at how U.S. may respond to attack on American forces
Article: The Pentagon said on Wednesday it was still looking at how it may respond to any attack on American forces, days after three American troops were wounded in a rocket attack on an Iraqi base north of Baghdad.

Headline: Senate's McConnell says Republicans nearing pact on big economic stimulus bill
Article: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Wednesday that Republicans were nearing an agreement on larger economic stimulus legislation to support the coronavirus-hit U.S. economy.

Headline: Sanders denies report he will end White House campaign after losses to Biden
Article: Bernie Sanders' U.S. presidential campaign on Wednesday swiftly denied a report that he was abandoning his White House bid after bruising losses to Joe Biden in the most recent round of Democratic Party nominating contests.

Headline: Senate to pass coronavirus bill, stay to work on more aid: McConnell
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell expects the chamber on Wednesday to pass an economic relief bill already approved by the House of Representatives, and then work on legislation aimed at aiding small businesses, giving Americans money directly and helping some industries during the coronavirus crisis.

Headline: In Illinois U.S. House primary, liberal Democratic challenger Newman beats Lipinski
Article: Liberal Democrat Marie Newman beat incumbent Dan Lipinski in a U.S. House of Representatives primary race in Illinois on Tuesday, according to news reports.

Headline: Coronavirus hits Florida economy in threat to Trump's re-election hopes
Article: Since the coronavirus outbreak hit Florida this month, Uber driver Nelson Aliaga has lost a third of his business.

Headline: State visit by Spanish royal couple postponed: White House
Article: The April 21 state visit by Spain's King Felipe VI and Queen Letizia to the White House has been postponed as both countries work on their response to the coronavirus, the White House said on Wednesday.

Headline: Joe Biden edges closer to Democratic nomination with blowout wins
Article: Joe Biden coasted to blowout victories in Tuesday's three Democratic presidential primaries, expanding his nearly unbeatable lead in the race to challenge President Donald Trump in November and increasing pressure on rival Bernie Sanders to end his campaign.

Headline: At a glance: Democratic presidential primary results and state delegate counts
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden extended his lead in the delegate race for the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday, sweeping the day's contests with wins in Arizona, Florida and Illinois as the country grappled with the coronavirus.

Headline: A majority of Democrats look to Biden, not Sanders, during a crisis: poll
Article: Most voters in Democratic presidential primaries in Illinois, Florida and Arizona said they trusted Joe Biden to handle a major crisis more than Bernie Sanders, according to Edison Research, as many lined up on Tuesday to vote despite the coronavirus outbreak.

Headline: Trump wants to send Americans $1,000 checks to cushion virus economic shock
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump announced a plan on Tuesday to send money to Americans immediately to ease the economic shock from the coronavirus crisis and said military-style hospitals will likely be deployed to virus hot zones to care for patients.

Headline: The White House wants to give you $1,000. Here's how it could work
Article: As the coronavirus threatens to push the global economy into recession, the Trump administration is rolling out an unusual idea: handing out free money.

Headline: Former California congressman Hunter gets 11 months in corruption case
Article: Former U.S. Representative Duncan Hunter, who pleaded guilty to a charge of campaign finance fraud, was sentenced on Tuesday to 11 months in federal prison in a corruption case that ended the California Republican's once-promising political career.

Headline: Russian firm says it will sue U.S for $50 billion after meddling case dropped
Article: A Russian firm accused of meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election said on Tuesday it planned to file a $50 billion lawsuit against the United States after a U.S. federal judge dismissed the criminal case against it.

Headline: Pompeo hopes China will reconsider move against U.S. journalists
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Tuesday he regretted China's decision to rescind the press credentials of more U.S. journalists and hoped Beijing would reconsider, citing a need for transparency about the coronavirus.

Headline: Trump administration mulls checks for Americans to support economy
Article: President Donald Trump's administration is considering sending checks to Americans so they have cash to spend during the coronavirus crisis and it has increased the amount of tax payments that can be deferred, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin said on Tuesday.

Headline: Senate Democratic leader urges passage of coronavirus relief bill
Article: The U.S. Senate should pass legislation on Tuesday already backed by the House of Representatives to start providing some economic relief amid the ongoing coronavirus crisis, U.S. Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump officials urge U.S. Senate to pass House coronavirus bill and pursue more economic stimulus
Article: President Donald Trump's administration and leading Republicans urged the Senate on Monday to swiftly back a House-passed coronavirus aid plan and seriously consider massive new economic stimulus legislation that was still under development.

Headline: Pompeo conveyed 'strong U.S. objections' to Beijing over COVID-19 accusations
Article: A war of words between China and the United States showed no signs of let up on Monday, with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in a phone call with a top Chinese diplomat expressing "strong U.S. objections" over what Washington sees as Beijing's efforts to shift blame for the spread of the coronavirus.

Headline: Coronavirus leads Ohio to delay election despite judge's refusal
Article: Ohio will postpone its presidential nominating election planned for Tuesday, despite a judge's refusal to endorse a postponement, because the public health emergency caused by the coronavirus makes it too dangerous, Governor Mike DeWine said.

Headline: China says Trump's 'Chinese virus' tweet smears China
Article: China's foreign ministry said on Tuesday that U.S. President Donald Trump's tweet calling the coronavirus a "Chinese virus" smears China and said Beijing strongly opposes Trump's usage of the words.

Headline: Coronavirus prompts Ohio to postpone primary election despite judge's refusal
Article: Ohio will postpone Tuesday's presidential nominating election despite judge's refusal to shut it down, citing a public health emergency caused by the threat of the coronavirus, Governor Mike DeWine said on Twitter.

Headline: U.S. Senator Schumer wants at least $750 bln to combat coronavirus, help economy
Article: U.S. Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer will propose legislation totaling at least $750 billion to combat the coronavirus outbreak and help the economy, his office said in a statement on Monday. He will present the package as early as Tuesday, the statement said.

Headline: Ohio judge denies request to postpone voting on Tuesday - local reports
Article: An Ohio judge has denied a request to delay the state's Tuesday primary elections until June 2nd amid coronavirus concerns, according to local news reports.

Headline: Factbox: Biden vows to pick woman for a running mate. Here are some potential names
Article: During Sunday night's debate, former Vice President Joe Biden vowed to select a woman as his running mate if he becomes the Democratic nominee for president.

Headline: Biden projected to win Washington state's Democratic presidential primary
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden is projected to win the Democratic presidential primary in Washington state, Edison Research said on Monday.

Headline: Mnuchin seeks 'big number' for additional coronavirus U.S. stimulus package
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, speaking to reporters on Monday after a meeting with Senate Republicans, said he was seeking a "big number" for an additional stimulus package intended to prop up the economy amid the coronavirus outbreak, but he did not elaborate.

Headline: Mnuchin meeting with Senate Republicans to discuss coronavirus bill 'and more' - source
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is in a closed-door meeting on Monday with Senate Republicans to discuss existing legislation responding to the coronavirus outbreak "and more," a source familiar with the meeting said.

Headline: Results or revolution? Biden, Sanders present dueling visions while blasting Trump's coronavirus response
Article: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders blasted President Donald Trump's handling of the coronavirus outbreak during Sunday's Democratic debate, and offered competing visions for how they would lead in a time of crisis that has upended the daily lives of Americans.

Headline: Three takeaways from the Biden-Sanders presidential face-off
Article: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders faced off on Sunday in what was possibly the final debate of the 2020 Democratic presidential nominating contest, with their ideological differences laid bare amidst the national crisis over the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Factbox: Biden, Sanders focus on coronavirus crisis in first one-on-one Democratic debate
Article: Democratic presidential contenders Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders faced off on Sunday in their first one-on-one debate, a key moment before votes in four states on Tuesday that could give Biden an insurmountable lead in the party's White House race.

Headline: Democratic White House contender Biden says he would pick a woman as vice president
Article: Democratic presidential contender Joe Biden, who had hinted he might choose a woman as his vice presidential running mate if he is picked as the party's nominee, committed to doing so during his debate with rival Bernie Sanders on Sunday.

Headline: Debate in the time of coronavirus: An elbow bump greeting for Biden and Sanders
Article: Joe Biden smiled and reached his elbow out to touch his rival Bernie Sanders' arm on Sunday, an unusual greeting that started a Democratic presidential debate during the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: U.S. eyes aid for airlines; sees no domestic travel curbs for now
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Sunday said he was in close touch with Congress about helping U.S. airlines weather a massive downturn in business due to sweeping travel restrictions aimed at containing the coronavirus.

Headline: Mnuchin says U.S. coronavirus aid bill cost should be significant, not huge
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Sunday officials will have a better idea this week of the total cost of a coronavirus aid package, but predicted it will likely be "significant but not huge."

Headline: Trump considering full pardon for ex-adviser Michael Flynn
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Sunday he is considering a full pardon for his former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, who had pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about dealings with Russia's ambassador before Trump took office.

Headline: Biden gets backing from largest U.S. teachers union
Article: U.S. Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden has won the backing of the National Education Association, the largest U.S. teachers union with 3 million members.

Headline: Democrat Biden tacks left, backs Warren bankruptcy plan with student loan relief
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Biden has endorsed former rival Elizabeth Warren's plan to reform consumer bankruptcy laws including allowing relief of student loan debt, incorporating proposals by the party's progressive wing into the moderate frontrunner's campaign.

Headline: Georgia delays presidential nominating election due to coronavirus
Article: Georgia elections officials have delayed the state's presidential primary set for March 24 until May 19 because of the coronavirus, the state's top election official said Saturday.

Headline: U.S. House passes coronavirus bill funding free tests, sick leave
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed a coronavirus aid package early on Saturday that would provide free testing and paid sick leave, in a bid to limit the economic damage from a pandemic that has shuttered schools, sports arenas and offices.

Headline: Trump says he's attending meetings on COVID-19 at White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said that he is attending White House meetings on Saturday on the COVID-19 outbreak caused by the coronavirus and would issue a "full report later."

Headline: Exclusive: Fewer poll workers, coronavirus, spark fears of election day woes in Ohio Democratic primary
Article: Nearly a quarter of Ohio's counties are deploying fewer poll workers for the state's Democratic primary on Tuesday than they have in previous presidential election years, raising concerns from voting-rights advocates who say the reductions could lengthen lines at the polls.

Headline: Factbox: What's in the coronavirus U.S. stimulus bill?
Article: Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives and the Trump administration are close to a deal on a coronavirus economic aid package, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told reporters Friday morning.

Headline: U.S. court to rehear House bid for testimony from ex-White House counsel McGahn
Article: A U.S. appeals court on Friday said it would reconsider a recent decision dismissing a Democratic-led congressional panelâ€™s lawsuit seeking to enforce a subpoena for testimony from former White House Counsel Donald McGahn.

Headline: Next week's Democratic primaries to proceed despite coronavirus, Louisiana delay
Article: Louisiana on Friday became the first U.S. state to postpone its presidential nominating contest because of the coronavirus pandemic, while four states holding their primaries next week said those elections would go forward as planned.

Headline: Four states holding U.S. Democratic primary votes plan to go forward on Tuesday
Article: Arizona, Illinois, Ohio and Florida will hold primary votes on Tuesday as planned, election officials in the four states said in a joint statement, despite growing government cancellations as officials try to stem the spread of the coronavirus.

Headline: Coronavirus crisis offers Biden, Sanders a chance to bridge Democratic Party's divide at Sunday's debate
Article: After all the rancor of the Democratic presidential race, front-runner Joe Biden has a chance in Sunday's debate to extend an olive branch to Bernie Sanders and his fervent supporters in a bid for party unity before the general election fight.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers near deal with White House on coronavirus aid bill
Article: U.S. lawmakers and the White House neared agreement on a coronavirus economic aid package, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Thursday, adding she hoped to announce a deal on Friday.

Headline: Coronavirus poses new challenge to Trump's re-election bid
Article: President Donald Trump faced one of the gravest threats of his political career as the coronavirus pandemic spread, leaving fellow Republicans to worry that the White House's response and the hit to the economy would harm his re-election prospects.

Headline: U.S. surveillance program to expire after renewal stalls in Senate
Article: U.S. government surveillance tools fiercely opposed by privacy advocates and defended by intelligence agencies will expire after legislation renewing them stalled in the Senate on Thursday, although passage is expected next week.

Headline: U.S. coronavirus stimulus package stuck in Congress over paid sick leave
Article: As schools close, offices clear out, and sporting events are canceled across the United States, a familiar Washington problem - partisan gridlock - threatened on Thursday to derail the U.S. government's ability to contain the economic damage from the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: U.S. Senate confirms Danly to FERC, widening panel's Republican majority
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday easily confirmed James Danly as a Republican member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, with three Democrats supporting him even though the approval widened the Republican majority on the panel.

Headline: U.S. House leaders unveil coronavirus bill; Capitol tours suspended
Article: Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday unveiled a broad package of proposals to help Americans affected by the coronavirus outbreak, while officials suspended public tours through the Capitol building.

Headline: U.S. senators seek to ban federal employees from using TikTok on their phones
Article: Two Republican senators on Thursday introduced a bill aimed at banning federal employees from using Chinese social media app TikTok on their government-issued phones, amid growing national security concerns around the collection and sharing of data on U.S. users with China's government.

Headline: Democrats change presidential debate location due to coronavirus
Article: The U.S. Democratic Party on Thursday said it will hold its upcoming debate between presidential contenders Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders in Washington DC rather than in Arizona to reduce cross-country travel as the nation confronts a deadly coronavirus outbreak.

Headline: First online U.S. census kicks off amid coronavirus fears
Article: U.S. residents will begin receiving census forms in the mail as early as Thursday as the federal government kicks off its once-a-decade count of the population, a gargantuan effort crucial to guiding U.S. political and economic policy but which experts fear will be complicated by the spread of coronavirus.

Headline: Exclusive: White House told federal health agency to classify coronavirus deliberations - sources
Article: The White House has ordered federal health officials to treat top-level coronavirus meetings as classified, an unusual step that has restricted information and hampered the U.S. governmentâ€™s response to the contagion, according to four Trump administration officials.

Headline: Democrats swap virtual campaign events for rallies in coronavirus crisis
Article: Democratic presidential contender Joe Biden on Wednesday canceled political rallies in Florida and Illinois due to concerns about the coronavirus pandemic and replaced them with what his campaign called "virtual events" in the two states.

Headline: U.S. House backs extension of FISA surveillance law
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives approved legislation on Wednesday to extend a divisive set of government surveillance tools, a major boost for efforts to reauthorize the program before it expires on Sunday.

Headline: Sanders vows to remain in White House race despite more losses to Biden
Article: A resolute Bernie Sanders said on Wednesday he would stay in the Democratic presidential race despite a series of big losses to front-runner Joe Biden, promising to keep up the public pressure for his sweeping economic and social justice proposals.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers seek to tighten ban on forced-labor goods from China's Xinjiang
Article: Leading U.S. lawmakers proposed legislation on Wednesday aimed at preventing goods made from forced labor in China's Xinjiang region from reaching the United States.

Headline: U.S. senator threatens tech companies, says don't block his child abuse bill
Article: Senator Lindsey Graham criticized tech companies on Wednesday for opposing a bipartisan bill aimed at curbing child sexual abuse material online and said he would consider a more punitive step if he is unable to get the legislation passed.

Headline: U.S. Senate Republican delays vote on subpoena in Hunter Biden probe
Article: A Republican U.S. senator said on Wednesday he would delay a committee vote on whether to issue a subpoena in an investigation of Democratic presidential contender Joe Biden's businessman son, Hunter Biden.

Headline: The revolution that wasnâ€™t: Bernie Sanders' second presidential bid falls to earth
Article: Michigan voter Monique Dooley believed in Bernie Sandersâ€™ forceful message of support for Americaâ€™s working class.

Headline: What gave Biden the edge over Sanders? Five takeaways
Article: Joe Biden was quickly declared the winner in nominating contests in Michigan, Missouri, Mississippi and Idaho on Tuesday, giving him perhaps unstoppable momentum toward winning the Democratic nomination to challenge U.S. President Donald Trump in November.

Headline: At a glance: Democratic primary results, state delegate counts
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden scored sweeping victories on Tuesday, winning at least four of the six states holding contests in the race to select the Democratic nominee who will take on Republican President Donald Trump in the November election.

Headline: In blow to ex-attorney general Sessions, Trump endorses challenger in Alabama
Article: In a blow to former attorney general Jeff Sessions' attempt to reclaim his seat in the U.S. Senate, President Donald Trump on Tuesday endorsed his challenger for the Republican nomination in Alabama, Tommy Tuberville.

Headline: Ho-hum turnout from Sanders' coalition as Biden takes key states: exit poll
Article: With their candidate on the ropes, supporters of Bernie Sanders again failed to show up when it mattered on Tuesday as Democrats held six presidential nominating contests, including the big prize of Michigan, according to exit polling by Edison Research.

Headline: In crushing blow to Bernie Sanders, Joe Biden scores big Michigan win
Article: Joe Biden rolled to commanding victories in pivotal Michigan and two other states on Tuesday, taking a big step toward the Democratic Party's presidential nomination and dealing a stinging blow to rival Bernie Sanders' fading White House bid.

Headline: Democratic presidential candidates scrap plans over coronavirus crisis
Article: Democratic presidential candidates Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders canceled primary election-night rallies on Tuesday, bowing to guidance from public officials over the coronavirus outbreak, and the party said the next debate between the two would have no audience.

Headline: Former Democratic candidate Andrew Yang endorses Joe Biden's presidential run
Article: Andrew Yang, the businessman who ended his bid for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination last month, on Tuesday endorsed Joe Biden's run for president.

Headline: Democrats' Phoenix debate to have no live audience amid health worries
Article: Democratic presidential contenders Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders will have no live audience when they debate each other in Phoenix on Sunday due to health concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, party spokeswoman Xochitl Hinojosa said.

Headline: Russia stoking U.S. racial, social differences ahead of election: sources
Article: American intelligence and security officials on Tuesday will brief Congress about how Russia has been using social media to stoke racial and social differences ahead of this year's general election, three sources familiar with the presentations said.

Headline: U.S. candidate Biden ramps up spending on Facebook ads
Article: U.S. presidential candidate Joe Biden more than tripled his weekly spending on Facebook advertising in the run-up to Tuesday's nomination contests, another sign the former vice president is ramping up his campaign.

Headline: Bernie Sanders cancels Cleveland rally over coronavirus concerns
Article: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders has canceled a rally set for Tuesday night in Cleveland over concerns about holding large public gatherings during the coronavirus outbreak, his campaign spokesman said.

Headline: In setback for Trump, court says House panel can get Russia report material
Article: A U.S. appeals court on Tuesday dealt a setback to President Donald Trump's administration, ruling that the Justice Department must provide a Democratic-led congressional panel grand jury material redacted from former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Headline: Democratic PAC to defend Biden with ad campaign in latest sign of party backing
