Headline: Trump planned visit to grieving El Paso stokes debate about his rhetoric
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump, whose rhetoric about an immigrant "invasion" has alienated many in the predominantly Hispanic city of El Paso, will visit the grieving Texas border town on Wednesday after a gun massacre that killed 22 people.

Headline: Democratic hopeful Warren outlines $85 billion rural broadband plan
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren outlined on Wednesday her plan to bring high-speed internet to rural and Native American communities through an $85 billion federal grant program.

Headline: Trump says he wants to strengthen gun background checks
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he wanted to strengthen background checks for gun purchases, a policy response to two recent mass shootings that was notably absent from proposals he put before the American people in televised remarks on Monday.

Headline: Huntsman, U.S. envoy to Moscow, resigns amid talk of possible Utah political run
Article: The U.S. ambassador to Russia, Jon Huntsman, has resigned from his post after two years as Washington's envoy to Moscow, the State Department said on Wednesday, amid speculation he plans to run for Utah governor.

Headline: Trump says talks with South Korea under way over defense costs
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday discussions have begun with South Korea, aimed at getting the country to pay more for the cost of maintaining U.S. troops in the region to guard against any threat from North Korea.

Headline: Progressive candidate concedes in New York City Democratic primary
Article: The Democratic primary race for Queens district attorney finally came to end an end on Tuesday with political newcomer Tiffany CabÃ¡n, a progressive backed by U.S. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, conceding victory to Melinda Katz, the establishment favorite candidate.

Headline: Presidential hopeful Klobuchar woos rural votes, vows help for farmers
Article: U.S. presidential hopeful Amy Klobuchar on Wednesday will propose help for American farmers including looser restrictions on biofuels and student loan forgiveness, the latest effort by a Democratic candidate to woo rural voters who backed Republican Donald Trump.

Headline: 8chan owner called before Congress, as latest host drops site
Article: Online message board 8chan's fortunes worsened on Tuesday, as it was once again made homeless by a technical services provider and its owner was called to testify to the U.S. Congress after 8chan was linked to a weekend mass shooting in El Paso, Texas.

Headline: Two U.S. senators raise privacy concerns over Facebook's Messenger Kids
Article: Democratic U.S. senators Edward Markey and Richard Blumenthal have written to Facebook Inc questioning whether there was a "worrying pattern" of poor privacy protection for children using its Messenger Kids app.

Headline: Trump condemns white supremacy, vague on gun measures after U.S. shootings
Article: President Donald Trump on Monday proposed tighter monitoring of the internet, mental health reform and wider use of the death penalty in response to two mass shootings over the weekend that left 32 people dead in Texas and Ohio.

Headline: Puerto Rico's new governor faces legal challenge
Article: Puerto Rico's newly installed governor and its Senate president faced off on Tuesday in written arguments submitted to the island's supreme court, which will decide who is in charge of the bankrupt government.

Headline: House Democrats seek Supreme Court Justice Kavanaugh's records
Article: Two Democrats on the U.S. House Judiciary Committee, including the panel's chairman, asked the National Archives on Tuesday for records from Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh's service in the White House under former President George W. Bush.

Headline: U.S. judge dismisses one of two counts against ex-Obama lawyer Craig
Article: A federal judge on Tuesday dismissed one of two counts in an indictment against Greg Craig, a lawyer in former President Barack Obama's administration, who was charged with lying about work he performed in 2012 for Ukraine.

Headline: Ex-FBI agent Strzok sues agency over firing for anti-Trump texts
Article: Peter Strzok, the FBI agent who came under fire from U.S. President Donald Trump and other Republicans for sending text messages that disparaged Trump during the presidential campaign, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday alleging his termination from the job violated his constitutional rights.

Headline: Factbox: Presidential candidates back gun restrictions in wake of mass shootings
Article: Democratic presidential candidates have demanded action on proposals to curtail gun violence in the aftermath of two mass shootings that killed 31 people in Texas and Ohio over the weekend.

Headline: Defying Congress, Trump administration looks to shift billions in foreign aid
Article: President Donald Trump's administration has ordered a review of foreign aid that critics fear could lead to sharp cuts in funds for global health, peacekeeping, narcotics control and other programs despite their having been approved by Congress.

Headline: Biden leads Democrats as minorities favor most electable candidate vs Trump: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Joe Biden maintained his lead for the Democratic presidential nomination as minorities gravitated toward the former vice president and his top rival, U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, in search of the safest bets for beating President Donald Trump in 2020, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll.

Headline: Groups sue to block Trump administration's expansion of rapid deportations
Article: Advocacy groups sued the Trump administration on Tuesday in an effort to block a rule published last month that expands the number of migrants who can be subject to a sped-up deportation process without oversight by an immigration judge.

Headline: Factbox: Who will be Trump's next intelligence chief?
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump promised to move quickly to nominate a successor to Dan Coats, who leaves his position as Director of National Intelligence on Aug. 15.

Headline: Trump vows to help farmers as China halts U.S. agricultural purchases
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday vowed to protect American farmers against China by signaling to provide further aid if needed, a day after Chinese firms stopped agricultural purchases and Beijing threatened more tariffs on U.S. farm products.

Headline: Trump sues California over tax return law
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump sued California on Tuesday over a new law requiring presidential candidates to release their tax returns to run in the state's primary elections.

Headline: Court revives Sarah Palin defamation case vs NY Times over editorial on shootings
Article: A federal appeals court revived former U.S. vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin's defamation lawsuit against the New York Times, over an editorial that she said maliciously linked her to the 2011 mass shooting that seriously wounded Representative Gabrielle Giffords.

Headline: Trump, without evidence, accuses Google of 'very illegal' action ahead of election
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday stepped up his accusations against Google, claiming without offering evidence that the technology company worked to subvert his 2016 presidential campaign and warning he was watching it "very closely" ahead of the 2020 election.

Headline: Mexico president says shootings in U.S. should prompt reflection on arms sales
Article: Mexico's President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said Monday that devastating weekend shootings in the United States, including in El Paso in which Mexican nationals were among the casualties, should lead to reflection about "indiscriminate" arms sales.

Headline: Trump postpones Florida trip in wake of shootings
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will postpone a trip to Florida planned for Tuesday due to the mass shootings in Texas and Ohio over the weekend, a White House official said on Monday.

Headline: Trump to visit to El Paso, Texas, on Wednesday: mayor
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is planning to pay a visit to El Paso, Texas, on Wednesday, four days after a mass shooting that is being investigated by authorities as a hate crime left 22 people dead, Mayor Dee Margo said on Monday.

Headline: Group sues to block California law aimed at forcing Trump to release tax returns
Article: A conservative legal group has filed a lawsuit seeking to block a new California law aimed at forcing Republican U.S. President Donald Trump to release his tax returns, the latest volley over Democrats' efforts to see the former businessman's financial records.

Headline: Obama: Reject language from leaders that 'normalizes racist sentiments'
Article: Former President Barack Obama responded to the weekend mass shootings in Ohio and Texas on Monday with a plea to Americans to reject the language of hatred, fear and intolerance from any of their leaders.

Headline: Trump denounces white supremacy after shootings, cites video games and internet
Article: President Donald Trump on Monday called for urgent action to prevent gun violence and said all Americans must "condemn racism, bigotry and white supremacy" after mass shootings in Texas and Ohio killed 29 people and wounded dozens.

Headline: U.S. seeks to renew Pacific islands security pact to foil China
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Monday negotiations have begun with three Pacific island nations to renew a national security agreement that would help Washington counter growing Chinese influence in the region.

Headline: Zheng wins first WTA title at Silicon Valley Classic
Article: China's Zheng Saisai beat Aryna Sabalenka of Belarus 6-3 7-6(3) Sunday to capture the Silicon Valley Classic and win hermaiden WTA title. Unseeded Zheng powered through the draw with several upset triumphs before finishing it off by defeating second seed Sabalenka. â€œFive years ago was the first time I won my first WTA match here. Now I win my first WTA title - itâ€™s just amazing,â€ Zheng said.

Headline: Biden mounts fierce defense of Obama legacy after debate attacks
Article: Democratic presidential front-runner and former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden mounted a fierce defense of Barack Obama's legacy on Saturday after several of his White House rivals attacked that record in debates this week.

Headline: Trump administration considers September unveiling of healthcare plan: WSJ
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is considering unveiling, as early as September, his healthcare plan as part of his presidential re-election campaign strategy, the Wall Street Journal reported on Saturday.

Headline: U.S. Defense Secretary says he favors placing missiles in Asia
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper said on Saturday that he was in favor of placing ground-launched, intermediate-range missiles in Asia relatively soon, a day after the United States withdrew from a landmark arms control treaty.

Headline: Exclusive: Democrats consider a lawyer and a law professor for commissioner seat at SEC - sources
Article: Democrats are considering an attorney and a law professor to replace Democratic Commissioner Robert Jackson when he steps down from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), expected in coming months, according to three people with direct knowledge of the matter.

Headline: Majority of House Democrats favor starting impeachment proceedings
Article: A majority of Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives now favor launching impeachment proceedings against Republican President Donald Trump, after a California lawmaker on Friday became the 118th Democrat to call for the process to begin.

Headline: Lawmakers urge U.S. to block sales of crowd-control gear to Hong Kong
Article: A bipartisan group of U.S. lawmakers on Friday urged the Trump Administration to suspend future sales of munitions and crowd-control equipment to Hong Kong police which has been accused of using excessive force against anti-government protesters.

Headline: Trump drops spy chief pick Ratcliffe and mulls a replacement
Article: President Donald Trump on Friday dropped his choice of John Ratcliffe to be U.S. spy chief after questions arose about the congressman's lack of experience and possible exaggerations in his resume, marking the latest upheaval over a top national security post.

Headline: Democratic senator warns of Trump involvement in Pentagon contract
Article: U.S. Senator Mark Warner on Friday raised concerns over the Pentagon's decision to put on hold a $10 billion cloud computing contract after President Donald Trump said his administration was examining Amazon.com Inc's bid following complaints from other tech companies.

Headline: U.S. bill raising debt ceiling for farm bankruptcies heads to White House
Article: With farm bankruptcies rising and agricultural debt loads soaring, the U.S. Senate has passed a bill that will make it easier for more farmers with larger amounts of debt to file for bankruptcy protection.

Headline: Trump, EU officials announce deal to sell more American beef to Europe
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump announced a deal on Friday to sell more American beef to Europe, a modest win for an administration that remains mired in a trade war with China, but he said tariffs on European auto exports remain a possibility.

Headline: Trump says auto tariffs never off the table in EU trade talks
Article: President Donald Trump on Friday blasted the European Union for its use of trade barriers and revived his threat to impose U.S. tariffs on European automobiles if he does not see progress in stalled negotiations between the longstanding partners.

Headline: Trump rule restricting asylum seekers struck down by court
Article: A U.S. federal judge on Friday struck down one of President Donald Trump's initiatives to curtail asylum claims, ruling that the government could not reject migrants who had crossed the border illegally.

Headline: Trump says he may name Sue Gordon acting director of national intelligence
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday he might name Sue Gordon as acting director of national intelligence after his first choice to lead the agency, congressman John Ratcliffe, decided to drop out.

Headline: State Department's policy planning chief 'fired': sources
Article: The head of policy planning at the State Department, Kiron Skinner, was fired on Thursday after nearly a year in the job, according to two sources familiar with the decision.

Headline: Senators seek 'serious' fines for antitrust violations
Article: U.S. Senators Amy Klobuchar and Richard Blumenthal introduced legislation on Friday to allow harsher penalties for companies that violate antitrust law, following a Justice Department probe into alleged anticompetitive behavior by big tech.

Headline: Kudlow sidesteps comment on report that Trump could delay, block tariff on Chinese goods
Article: White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow demurred on Friday when asked if U.S. President Donald Trump would delay or stop the imposition of tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese goods if China took some positive actions.

Headline: Trump, Britain's Johnson discussed trade, security, 5G: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump spoke with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson about trade, next-generation 5G mobile networks and global security, White House spokesman Hogan Gidley said in a statement on Friday.

Headline: Will Hurd, sole black Republican in U.S. House, will not seek re-election
Article: Will Hurd, the only Republican African-American member of the U.S. House of Representatives, said on Thursday he would not seek re-election next year.

Headline: 'Lock Her Up!' but no 'Send her Back!' chant at Trump rally in Ohio
Article: President Donald Trump on Thursday briefly renewed his criticism of four minority Democratic congresswomen at his first rally since controversy erupted when a crowd at a rally last month broke into a chant of "Send her back" about a U.S. lawmaker who immigrated to the United States from Somalia.

Headline: Audio reveals Ronald Reagan calling African delegates 'monkeys'
Article: In a recently emerged audio recording from 1971, then-California Governor Ronald Reagan can be heard disparaging African delegates to the United Nations as "monkeys" during a phone call with U.S. President Richard Nixon.

Headline: Puerto Rico vote delay raises uncertainty over next governor
Article: Puerto Rico's next governor remained up in the air on Thursday, just 24 hours before Governor Ricardo RossellÃ³ was due to resign, as the U.S. territory's Senate pushed a vote on his successor to Monday.

Headline: Trump sticks with choice for spy chief despite apparent biographical embellishments
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump signaled on Thursday that he still plans to nominate Representative John Ratcliffe to be the next U.S. spy chief despite worries that Ratcliffe may have exaggerated his achievements as a prosecutor.

Headline: Democratic candidates Biden and Harris chafe at debate limits
Article: U.S. Democratic presidential rivals Joe Biden and Kamala Harris expressed frustration on Thursday with a debate format they said left them little time to explain their views and led to the combative exchanges featured in the first two debate rounds.

Headline: Factbox: House Democrats edge toward pro-impeachment majority
Article: Nearly a majority of Democratic lawmakers in the 435-member U.S. House of Representatives have now said they support starting impeachment proceedings against Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Rising calls for impeachment may not alter House Democrats' course
Article: Mounting support among Democrats in Congress for impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump seems unlikely to change House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's caution on moving ahead with the politically risky move, Democrats said on Thursday.

Headline: Pelosi defends Baltimore, her childhood home, against Trump's attacks
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday defended Baltimore, the city where she grew up, against repeated verbal attacks by President Donald Trump, and she charged that the president's own son-in-law was a "slumlord" there.

Headline: Barack Obama, silent in Democratic nominating contest, omnipresent in debate
Article: Former President Barack Obama was not on the Democratic presidential candidate debate stage on Wednesday night, but he was omnipresent as 2020 hopefuls grappled with the legacy of their party's most popular member.

Headline: From stickers to T-shirts, debate moments inspire U.S. campaign merchandise
Article: Shortly after Wednesday's debate, Democratic presidential candidate Cory Booker's campaign jumped on rival Joe Biden's slip in calling him the "future president" to raise campaign dollars.

Headline: Lurching left in toss-up Wisconsin, a Democrat weighs her choices
Article: Kim Mahoney listened from her reclining living room couch as Democratic presidential candidates debated economic, trade and environmental policies this week, needing only to look to her backyard to see how lofty political pledges can really play out.

Headline: Biden steadies ship while setting up impending clash with Warren
Article: After two sets of Democratic presidential debates, it appears that Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren, at least at the moment, are two high-speed trains on a collision course.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers still plot to push Saudi Arabia on rights, despite Trump
Article: The U.S. Congress left Washington on Thursday without enacting legislation to punish Saudi human rights abuses, but lawmakers said efforts to stop military sales and impose sanctions would continue after their August break.

Headline: Hearing date set in fight over Trump's New York tax returns
Article: A U.S. judge will hear arguments on Aug. 29 in a lawsuit that President Donald Trump filed to block a U.S. House of Representatives committee from obtaining his New York state tax returns, according to a court filing.

Headline: Senate confirms Landau as ambassador to Mexico
Article: The U.S. Senate confirmed attorney Christopher Landau as ambassador to Mexico on Thursday, filling a position important to negotiations on trade and immigration but which has been vacant for more than a year.

Headline: Trump: U.S. will hit $300 billion worth of Chinese goods with 10% tariff
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday he would impose an additional 10% tariff on $300 billion worth of Chinese imports starting Sept. 1, as talks aimed at easing tensions between the world's two largest economies continue.

Headline: Congress approves Trump-backed two-year spending, debt limit deal
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday passed and sent to President Donald Trump a two-year budget deal that would increase federal spending on defense and an array of other domestic programs, significantly adding to rapidly escalating government debt.

Headline: Trump adviser Stone loses bid to dismiss indictment stemming from Mueller probe
Article: President Donald Trump's longtime political adviser Roger Stone on Thursday lost a long-shot bid to overturn a seven-count indictment against him stemming from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe of Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Headline: Senate approves Trump-backed spending, debt limit bill
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday passed legislation supported by President Donald Trump that would suspend limits on U.S. borrowing authority for two years and set government spending at higher levels through September 2021.

Headline: As Democrats squabble, Trump worries some Republicans with his Twitter battles
Article: Some of U.S. President Donald Trump's allies worry his racially charged fights with opponents are hurting his re-election chances even as Democratic rivals make things easier for him by bickering over their own key policies.

Headline: Trump ally Corey Lewandowski considering Senate run in New Hampshire
Article: Corey Lewandowski, a close ally of President Donald Trump, is considering a 2020 run for a U.S. Senate seat in New Hampshire now held by Democrat Jeanne Shaheen, two sources close to Lewandowski said on Thursday.

Headline: Biden faces fierce attacks, fights back in combative Democratic debate
Article: Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden came under heavy fire over healthcare, immigration and criminal justice reform on Wednesday, but fought back against a stage full of rivals eager to knock him off his perch during a contentious debate.

Headline: Factbox: How each candidate performed in the second Democratic debate
Article: The second round of Democratic presidential primary debates laid bare sharp ideological divides as 20 White House hopefuls wrestled with a central question: Between centrist and progressive agendas, what is the best way to defeat Republican President Donald Trump next year?

Headline: Change in New York State law to usher in 'tidal wave' of child sex abuse lawsuits
Article: Thousands of child sexual abuse lawsuits are expected to flow into New York State courts in the coming weeks exposing decades-old misconduct at schools, hospitals, churches and youth clubs, according to lawyers for victims.

Headline: Senate panel backs Nord Stream 2 pipeline sanctions bill
Article: A U.S. Senate committee passed a bill on Wednesday to slap sanctions on companies and individuals involved in building the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline from Russia to Germany that the Trump administration says would strengthen Moscow's economic grip on Europe.

Headline: Biden debate gaffe sends viewers in digital circles
Article: Minutes after Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden bungled his closing statement in Wednesday's debate by telling voters to go to a campaign website that did not exist, a college student was using the URL for a spoof election bid.

Headline: Democratic debate highlights: Biden the favored target
Article: Democratic front-runner Joe Biden was again the main target of his rivals at the second presidential debate on Wednesday, as many of the nine other candidates on stage took aim at his track record on race, criminal justice, immigration and healthcare.

Headline: Democrats pass up chance to dent GM on job cuts in Detroit debates
Article: Detroit-based General Motors Co emerged from two days of Democratic debates in its hometown largely unscathed as 2020 White House hopefuls largely passed up an opportunity to criticize it for significant job cuts in recent months.

Headline: Senators question FAA on aircraft certification
Article: A group of U.S. senators on Wednesday questioned the Federal Aviation Administration oversight of Boeing Co's 737 MAX as the agency defended the longstanding practice of deferring much of the process of certifying new aircraft to manufacturers.

Headline: U.S. federal death penalty protocol faces fresh legal scrutiny
Article: Plans by President Donald Trump's administration to resume executions of inmates sentenced to death for federal crimes is set to face a stiff court challenge, but a judge's decision on the legality of its new protocol for lethal injections may come too late for five men scheduled to die starting in December.

Headline: Senate confirms Craft as ambassador to United Nations
Article: The U.S. Senate on Wednesday confirmed Kelly Craft, a Republican donor who is currently ambassador to Canada, as ambassador to the United Nations, despite opposition from Democrats who criticized President Donald Trump's nominee as too inexperienced for the post.

Headline: Be patient, top Republican senator tells Trump on USMCA trade deal
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump should be patient with House Democrats as they work toward approval of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade agreement, Senator Charles Grassley, the Republican who heads the powerful Senate Finance Committee, said on Wednesday.

Headline: Is Trump the reason the Fed cut rates?
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's repeated calls for easier monetary policy may not be what drove the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates on Wednesday.

Headline: Senate committee backs Hyten for Pentagon post
Article: The U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee on Wednesday backed General John Hyten to be the second-highest ranking U.S. military official, a day after he denied sexual assault allegations against him.

Headline: Senate plans vote on spending, debt limit deal on Thursday: senators
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday aims to pass legislation backed by President Donald Trump that would suspend the limit on federal borrowing for two years while adding billions of dollars in deficit-spending, Republican senators said on Wednesday.

Headline: Moderate Democrats use debate to attack liberal rivals over Trump
Article: Moderate candidates forced their way into the debate conversation on Tuesday night by assailing as "political suicide" the agenda championed by liberal front-runners who have dominated the 2020 Democratic presidential primary race.

Headline: Sanders and Warren defend progressive policies against attacks in U.S. Democratic debate
Article: Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders offered an unabashed defense of their progressive policies during a Democratic presidential debate on Tuesday, as their more moderate rivals criticized their proposals as unrealistic and politically untenable.

Headline: Pro-impeachment ad with Mueller to run during Democratic debates
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's congressional testimony will feature in a television ad advocating for impeaching President Donald Trump, set to run before and after the Democratic presidential debates this week.

Headline: Democratic debate highlights: Moderates assail 'impossible' liberal agenda
Article: The Democratic Party's two leading progressives came under fire on Tuesday from a debate stage stuffed with moderates who said their "impossible" proposals and "wish-list economics" risked keeping Republican President Donald Trump in the White House for four more years.

Headline: Trump says will look to cut defense budget in future: C-Span interview
Article: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he would look to cut defense costs in future budgets after ramping up military spending during his first 2-1/2 years in office.

Headline: U.S. judge tosses Democratic Party lawsuit against Trump campaign, Russia over election
Article: A U.S. judge on Tuesday dismissed a Democratic Party lawsuit arguing that the Russian government, President Donald Trumpâ€™s campaign and WikiLeaks carried out a conspiracy to influence the 2016 U.S. election.

Headline: California governor signs law to force Trump into releasing tax returns
Article: California's Democratic governor signed a law on Tuesday requiring U.S. presidential candidates to release five years of tax returns before they can appear on the state's ballot, a move aimed squarely at Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Racial diversity dispute spurs shakeup at House Democratic campaign arm
Article: The congresswoman who heads the campaign arm for U.S. House of Representatives Democrats has acknowledged mistakes after lawmakers complained about a lack of racial diversity within the organization, and she named a Cuban-American as interim executive director as part of a major staff shakeup.

Headline: Puerto Rico governor taps former U.S. delegate as successor: report
Article: Puerto Rico's embattled governor will name the island's former representative in the U.S. Congress, Pedro Pierluisi, as his new secretary of state and next in line to succeed him when he steps down, El Nuevo Dia newspaper reported.

Headline: Trump billionaire friend aimed to profit from Mideast nuclear deal: Democrats
Article: Tom Barrack, a billionaire friend of U.S. President Donald Trump, pursued a plan to buy Westinghouse Electric Corp even as he lobbied Trump to become a special envoy to promote the building by the firm of nuclear power plants in Saudi Arabia, said a congressional report released on Monday.

Headline: Trump warns China against delaying trade deal as talks resume
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday warned China against waiting out his first term to finalize any trade deal, saying if he wins re-election in the November 2020 U.S. presidential contest, the outcome will be worse for China.

Headline: Defending intelligence pick, Trump says U.S. spy agencies 'run amok'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday defended his choice for the next U.S. spy chief as someone who could "rein in" intelligence agencies that "have run amok," fueling concerns Trump seeks assessments that support his own views.

Headline: Trump says Congress should give 'notice' before requesting state tax return
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's personal lawyers on Tuesday urged a judge to require a House of Representative panel to notify them "at least 14 days before" it makes a request for his New York state tax returns.

Headline: Senate leaders scramble to lift Republican support for budget deal
Article: U.S. Senate Republican leaders, pushing for passage of a two-year federal spending and debt deal, scrambled on Tuesday to pump up support among their membership despite President Donald Trump's backing.

Headline: Trump pick for Pentagon post calls sexual assault claim 'completely false'
Article: The Air Force general picked by President Donald Trump to become the second-highest ranking U.S. military officer on Tuesday vehemently denied sexual assault allegations against him at his confirmation hearing, and received a strong endorsement from a senator who said she was raped while serving in the military.

Headline: Oh Snap: U.S. senator proposes bill to ban Snapchat 'Snapstreaks'
Article: A bill introduced by a U.S. senator on Tuesday aims to curb overuse of social media by banning Snapchat's Snapstreak feature, which encourages users to send photos on the app at least once every 24 hours.

Headline: Pence says clock ticking on USMCA, but Democrats won't be rushed
Article: U.S. Vice President Mike Pence on Tuesday said that a new U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade deal needs to be approved without delay, but Democrats and organized labor said certain provisions must first be improved.

Headline: Trump condemns slavery in Jamestown speech amid controversy over prior incendiary remarks
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump, under fire in Washington for verbal attacks on racial minority lawmakers, condemned American slavery on Tuesday at the 400th anniversary of the first legislative assembly in Virginia and was briefly interrupted by a protesting state legislator.

Headline: Biden's record on race expected to be in crosshairs at second 2020 debate
Article: Joe Biden says he is done being polite when it comes to defending his decades-long record on race.

Headline: Bulk of Trump's U.S. farm aid goes to biggest and wealthiest farmers: advocacy group
Article: More than half of the Trump administration's $8.4 billion in trade aid payments to U.S. farmers through April was received by the top 10% of recipients, the country's biggest and most successful farmers, a study by an advocacy group showed on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. Army colonel says Hyten made false statements about sexually assaulting her
Article: A U.S. Army Colonel on Tuesday maintained the sexual assault accusations she had leveled against President Donald Trump's nominee for second-highest ranking military officer, and accused General John Hyten of making false statements in front of a Senate panel earlier in the day when he denied the charges.

Headline: Trump wants forces reduced in Afghanistan by next U.S. election: Pompeo
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump wants combat forces reduced in Afghanistan by the next U.S. presidential election, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Monday, in comments that underlined the growing pressure from Washington to cut troop numbers there.

Headline: Trump urges Fed to make large rate cut as policymakers meet
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday called on the Federal Reserve to make a large interest rate cut, saying he was disappointed in the U.S. central bank and that it had put him at a disadvantage by not acting sooner.

Headline: Senate fails to override Trump vetoes of bills stopping Saudi weapons sales
Article: The U.S. Senate on Monday failed to override President Donald Trump's vetoes of legislation passed by Congress that would have blocked the sales of certain weapons to Saudi Arabia.

Headline: Harris, Ocasio-Cortez float plan to lift low-income communities in climate plans
Article: U.S. Senator and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris and U.S. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on Monday introduced a bill that would ensure any climate change legislation considered by Congress prioritizes low-income and vulnerable communities.

Headline: U.S. judge blocks Medicaid work requirements in New Hampshire
Article: A federal judge on Monday overturned the Trump administration's approval of a plan by the state of New Hampshire to impose work requirements on people seeking to obtain benefits from the Medicaid health insurance program.

Headline: Warren says U.S. should use trade deals to raise global standards
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren told a town hall in Ohio on Monday that if elected to the White House, she would use the leverage of the United States to raise labor and environmental standards via global trade agreements.

Headline: Kamala Harris releases healthcare policy plan days before Democratic debate
Article: U.S. Senator Kamala Harris on Monday released a "Medicare for All" proposal ahead of a second debate for Democratic presidential candidates, when their differing approaches to healthcare insurance policy are expected to feature prominently.

Headline: Trump signs measure to permanently extend compensation for Sept. 11 responders
Article: Calling emergency first responders "heroes," U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday signed into law a measure authorizing permanent benefits for police, firefighters and others suffering from illnesses connected to their work reacting to the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

Headline: Senators back big jump in federal highway spending
Article: A bipartisan group of U.S. senators unveiled a proposal on Monday to authorize $287 billion in federal government spending over five years to maintain and repair the country's aging highways, bridges and tunnels, but Congress still faces the tough task of finding a way to pay for it.

Headline: New York state decriminalizes pot, stops short of Cuomo's legalization call
Article: New York state on Monday decriminalized recreational marijuana use, meaning possession of small amounts of the drug will be punished with fines rather than jail time, a step short of Governor Andrew Cuomo's goal of legalizing pot.

Headline: Trump presses race as 2020 tactic, draws rebuke from Republican governor
Article: President Donald Trump, again stoking racial divisions, on Monday renewed his attacks on a black U.S. congressman from Baltimore and slammed black civil rights activist Reverend Al Sharpton, drawing a rebuke from Maryland's Republican governor and the black former Republican Party national chairman.

Headline: Pompeo says possible run for Senate seat in Kansas 'off the table'
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Monday appeared to close the door to a potential run in 2020 for a U.S. Senate seat in Kansas saying it was "off the table," but he did not rule out the possibility of a presidential run in the future.

Headline: Trump urges Fed to do more than a 'small rate cut'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday urged the Federal Reserve to go beyond making a "small rate cut" this week, raising pressure on the central bank to lower borrowing costs by more than Wall Street expects.

Headline: Trump rejects racism charge, throws it at black lawmaker
Article: President Donald Trump on Sunday said disparaging comments he made about a prominent African-American lawmaker and his Baltimore district were not racist and, without citing any evidence for his claim, he called the congressman a racist.

Headline: Ratcliffe tapped to replace Coats as U.S. spy chief
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Sunday he would nominate Representative John Ratcliffe, a Texas Republican who strongly defended him at a recent congressional hearing, to replace Dan Coats as the U.S. spy chief.

Headline: Factbox: Four moments to watch for as U.S. Democrats debate in Detroit
Article: Twenty Democratic presidential hopefuls will take the stage in Detroit on Tuesday and Wednesday nights in their second debate of the nominating contest for the November 2020 U.S. election.

Headline: Bernie Sanders visits Canadian pharmacy, talks drug prices
Article: U.S. Senator and Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders joined diabetes patients as they drove across the border on Sunday to buy cheap insulin in Canada, highlighting his argument in favor of federally negotiated prescription drug prices.

Headline: Senior Democrat Nadler: No deadline for Trump impeachment
Article: A senior lawmaker in the U.S. House of Representatives on Sunday rejected the notion that Democrats must decide whether to pursue the impeachment of Republican President Donald Trump before the 2020 election season shifts into high gear.

Headline: Trump says spy chief Coats stepping down, says will nominate Ratcliffe
Article: President Donald Trump said on Sunday the nation's top intelligence official, Dan Coats, would leave his post next month and that he would nominate Republican congressman John Ratcliffe to replace him.

Headline: U.S. judge sets July 29 hearing in Trump lawsuit over tax returns
Article: A U.S. judge will hear arguments on July 29 in President Donald Trump's lawsuit seeking to block a House of Representatives committee from obtaining his New York state tax returns, according to a court filing issued Sunday.

Headline: Factbox: What do U.S. Democrats want from Mueller's grand jury evidence?
Article: The Democratic-led U.S. House Judiciary Committee asked a federal court last week for permission to access grand jury evidence from former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe of Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election.

Headline: Trump tells black lawmaker to clean up 'disgusting, rat and rodent infested' district
Article: President Donald Trump hit out at a prominent African-American critic on Saturday, calling him a "brutal bully" who should concentrate on cleaning up his "disgusting, rat and rodent infested" Baltimore district rather than criticizing the work of U.S. immigration officers on the Mexican border.

Headline: U.S. Supreme Court lets Trump use disputed funds for border wall
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Friday handed President Donald Trump a victory by letting his administration redirect $2.5 billion in money approved by Congress for the Pentagon to help build his promised wall along the U.S.-Mexico border even though lawmakers refused to provide funding.

Headline: Networks invite Democratic presidential candidates to climate change town halls
Article: U.S. cable networks CNN and MSNBC have invited Democratic presidential candidates to participate in televised town hall events in September focused on climate change after activists and some candidates pressured party officials for months to host a debate dedicated to the issue.

Headline: U.S. House panel seeks grand jury evidence to assess Trump impeachment
Article: The Democratic-led U.S. House Judiciary Committee asked a federal court on Friday for access to grand jury evidence from the Mueller probe that lawmakers say they need to determine whether to begin impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump.

Headline: Factbox: Trump impeachment backed by 40% of U.S. House Democrats
Article: Ninety-five Democratic lawmakers in the 435-member U.S. House of Representatives have said they support starting impeachment proceedings against Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: U.S. House Speaker Pelosi all smiles after meeting with Ocasio-Cortez
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez had no hatchet to bury on Friday, playing down tensions after a meeting between the powerful speaker and freshman lawmaker who in recent months has seized the Democratic Party spotlight.

Headline: Craigslist founder, Facebook's ex-security chief team up over 2020 online fears
Article: The project by Facebook Inc former chief security officer Alex Stamos to battle online abuses has received $5 million from Craigslist founder Craig Newmark, the Stanford Internet Observatory said this week.

Headline: U.S. presidential hopeful Harris would spend $60 billion on historically black colleges
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful Kamala Harris on Friday unveiled a plan to invest $60 billion in historically black colleges and universities if elected, the latest effort by the U.S. senator from California to reach out to black voters.

Headline: No 'day in court': U.S. deportation orders blindside some families
Article: Carin, a 39-year-old subsistence farmer from Honduras, crossed the U.S.-Mexico border with her two sons late last year. They had fled after her political organizing led to threats of violence, she said, and intended to claim asylum.

Headline: Ethanol vs. environment: Democratic hopefuls campaign on clashing agendas
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren is a champion of the corn-based ethanol industry when she campaigns in rural towns dotting the U.S. Farm Belt.

Headline: Top U.S. general cautiously optimistic about Afghan peace push
Article: The top U.S. general said on Friday he was cautiously optimistic about efforts to reach a negotiated end to the nearly 18-year-old war in Afghanistan, in remarks that followed talks in Kabul with Afghanistan's president and the top U.S. negotiator.

Headline: Democrat Buttigieg unveils plan to raise pay, expand worker protections
Article: Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg unveiled a plan on Friday to raise wages and strengthen the rights of American workers, including "gig economy" workers such as Uber drivers, and fast-food employees.

Headline: U.S. House passes Trump-backed spending and debt limit bill
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday passed legislation touted by President Donald Trump that would accelerate rising federal budget deficits and suspend limits on Washington's borrowing powers over the next two years.

Headline: U.S. attorney general, state officials discuss big tech firms' effect on competition
Article: Eight state attorneys general met with U.S. Attorney General William Barr on Thursday to discuss the effect of big tech companies on competition, and various antitrust actions are being reviewed, the Texas attorney general's office said in a statement.

Headline: U.S. House panel approves subpoenas for Trump officials' private emails
Article: A Democratic-led congressional committee voted on Thursday to authorize subpoenas for official White House communications sent through private email and messaging services by senior officials in President Donald Trump's administration, deepening a probe into potential violations of government record-keeping laws.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers delay action to hold Trump adviser Conway in contempt
Article: U.S. lawmakers have backed off on plans to hold White House senior adviser Kellyanne Conway in contempt of Congress for defying a subpoena last week as a string of current and former Trump officials spurn congressional oversight.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers denounce Turkey's Russia arms purchase but unsure of next steps
Article: U.S. lawmakers say they are unhappy about Turkey's purchase of a Russian missile defense system but are unsure what President Donald Trump - or Congress - should do next, suggesting efforts to impose sanctions were on the back burner for now.

Headline: U.S. sanctions target food subsidy scam in Venezuela, charges businessman
Article: The United States imposed sanctions on Thursday on 10 people and 13 groups in a Venezuelan food subsidy scheme the U.S. Treasury said lined the pockets of President Nicolas Maduro, his stepsons and others as ordinary Venezuelans suffer food shortages.

Headline: U.S. House passes debt limit and spending bill, sends to Senate
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday approved bipartisan legislation to increase federal spending over the next two years on discretionary defense and non-defense programs and to suspend the limit on government borrowing through July 2021.

Headline: Siemens unit wins $829 million U.S. defense contract: Pentagon
Article: Siemens Government Technologies Inc, a unit of Siemens AG, has been awarded an $829 million contract for energy savings and performance measures at the U.S. naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, the Pentagon said on Thursday.

Headline: Democrats push Trump probe schedule risking campaign clash
Article: A day after former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's high-profile testimony, House Democrats vowed to push forward with an investigation of President Donald Trump that could delay any move on impeachment into the 2020 election campaign season.

Headline: U.S. Senate confirms Milley as chairman of Joint Chiefs
Article: The U.S. Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to confirm four-star Army General Mark Milley as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, President Donald Trump's most senior uniformed military adviser.

Headline: Mueller testimony drew almost 13 million U.S. TV viewers
Article: Almost 13 million Americans watched former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's long-awaited congressional testimony on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election, according to preliminary TV audience data on Thursday, below other recently live televised hearings.

Headline: Drug makers met with Trump to argue against Senate pricing bill
Article: The main pharmaceutical industry lobbying group said on Thursday it and some drugmakers met with President Donald Trump to voice opposition to a bipartisan U.S. Senate bill that aims to lower prescription drug prices.

Headline: U.S. Senate panel advances Saudi sanctions measure
Article: The U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday backed legislation that would impose sanctions on the Saudi royal family and block some weapons sales, pushing back against President Donald Trump's close ties to the kingdom.

Headline: Pompeo, Ghani agree to 'accelerate efforts' to end war in Afghanistan: State Department
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Afghanistan's President Ashraf Ghani agreed that it was time to "accelerate efforts" to end the war in Afghanistan, the State Department said on Thursday.

Headline: U.S. judge blocks Trump's latest sweeping asylum rule
Article: A federal judge in San Francisco on Wednesday blocked the Trump administration from enforcing a new rule that aimed to bar almost all asylum applications at the U.S.-Mexico border.

Headline: White House to fight ruling that blocks new asylum restrictions
Article: The White House will fight a federal judge's decision blocking the Trump administration from enforcing a new rule that aimed to bar almost all asylum applications at the U.S.-Mexico border, it said on Thursday.

Headline: Senate panel to vote next week on sanctions on Russia-to-Germany gas pipeline
Article: A U.S. Senate committee is due to vote next week on a bill that would slap sanctions on companies and individuals involved in building the Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline from Russia to Germany that the Trump administration says would strengthen Moscow's economic grip on Europe.

Headline: U.S. Senate committee backs Trump nominee to be U.N. ambassador
Article: The U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday backed Kelly Craft, currently the U.S. ambassador to Canada, as President Donald Trump's envoy to the United Nations.

Headline: U.S. Democrats and Republicans canâ€™t even agree on the weather: Reuters/Ipsos
Article: Only 200 miles separate Michael Tilden and Miranda Garcia in rain-soaked Iowa. But they are worlds apart when it comes to their opinion of the weather.

Headline: Exclusive: White House preparing order that would cut drug prices for Medicare: sources
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is considering a sweeping executive order that would cut prices on virtually all branded prescription drugs sold to Medicare and other government programs, according to two industry sources who had discussions with the White House.

Headline: Mueller says Trump was not exonerated; Trump declares victory
Article: Former Special Counsel Robert Mueller emphasized on Wednesday he had not exonerated Donald Trump of obstruction of justice, as the president has claimed, but his long-awaited congressional testimony did little to add momentum to any Democratic impeachment ambitions and Trump heartily declared victory.

Headline: Senators to unveil carbon tax bill to generate $2.5 trillion in 10 years
Article: Two Democratic U.S. senators will unveil a bill on Thursday to curb climate change by slapping a fee on oil, natural gas and coal and delivering most of the revenues to low- and middle-income Americans, one of the lawmakers said.

Headline: Explainer: What Google, Facebook could face in U.S. antitrust probe
Article: The U.S. Department of Justice is investigating whether big technology companies are engaged in anticompetitive behavior, addressing a rising tide of criticism they have become too powerful to the detriment of consumers.

Headline: Trump must face marketing scam lawsuit, escapes racketeering claims: NY judge
Article: A federal judge on Wednesday said U.S. President Donald Trump and his adult children must face part of a lawsuit alleging they used their family name to promote sham marketing opportunities, but dismissed racketeering claims at the center of the case.

Headline: Judge blocks new Trump asylum rule
Article: A U.S. judge in San Francisco on Wednesday stopped the Trump administration from enforcing a new rule that would bar almost all asylum applications at the U.S.-Mexico border.

Headline: Senate sets vote on Trump's Saudi weapons vetoes
Article: The U.S. Senate will vote within days on whether to override President Donald Trump's vetoes of legislation to block the sale of precision-guided munitions to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Wednesday.

Headline: Nadler says House panel to go to court to enforce McGahn subpoena
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee will go to court this week to enforce a subpoena of former White House counsel Don McGahn and will also ask for grand jury material related to former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe, the panel's chairman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Biden, Booker escalate feud over U.S. criminal justice reform
Article: Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden and Senator Cory Booker traded accusations over their criminal justice records on Wednesday, with Booker calling the former U.S. vice president an "architect of mass incarceration" and Biden slamming Newark's "stop and frisk" policing when Booker was mayor.

Headline: Trump, after Mueller testimony to House, says Republican Party had good day
Article: President Donald Trump, reacting to U.S. congressional testimony by former Special Counsel Robert Mueller, said on Wednesday the Republican Party had a good day and reiterated his attacks on the Russia probe as a hoax and witch hunt.

Headline: Factbox: Trump's Twitter thoughts on big tech
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump has long targeted big tech companies like Amazon, Google, Facebook and Twitter in his social media comments, accusing them of working against him and his administration.

Headline: Justice Department will not pursue criminal contempt charges in Census dispute with Congress
Article: The U.S. Justice Department will not pursue criminal charges against Attorney General William Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, after Democrats in the House of Representatives voted to hold them in contempt in a dispute over documents concerning whether to include a citizenship question on the 2020 Census.

Headline: Highlights from former U.S. Special Counsel Mueller's testimony
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller testified on Wednesday to the U.S. House of Representatives about his investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and any possible obstruction of justice by President Donald Trump.

Headline: NTSB chair expects to unveil recommendations on FAA design certification issues
Article: U.S. National Transportation Safety Board chairman Robert Sumwalt told Congress on Wednesday his agency would outline recommendations on the Federal Aviation Administration's airplane design certification procedures by late September.

Headline: Mueller did not subpoena Trump to expedite end of probe
Article: Former Special Counsel Robert Mueller told lawmakers on Wednesday his team decided not to exercise its subpoena powers against President Donald Trump because it wanted to expedite the end of the investigation and a subpoena could have led to a lengthy legal fight.

Headline: Mueller says he 'generally' agrees Trump was not always truthful in written answers
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller said on Wednesday he "generally" agreed with a characterization that Trump's written answers to investigators probing Russian interference in the U.S. election were not always truthful.

Headline: Mueller hearings on Russia investigation conclude
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller concluded more than five hours of testimony on Wednesday before the House of Representatives Intelligence and Judiciary committees about his 2-year-long investigation of Russian election meddling.

Headline: Mueller sometimes stumbles in high-stakes Q&A in Congress
Article: When Robert Mueller finally appeared in public on Wednesday to defend his investigation of President Donald Trump, he often struggled with questions and, hours into a long session with U.S. lawmakers, had to correct one of his own answers.

Headline: Trump administration's own study shows food stamp move may hurt poor
Article: A Trump administration proposal to tighten eligibility for food stamps could undercut access to basic nutrition for millions of Americans and hurt some low-cost retailers, according to an analysis conducted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), which runs the program.

Headline: Mueller says he did not seek FBI director job under Trump
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller on Wednesday disputed assertions that he had interviewed with President Donald Trump in 2017 to serve as FBI director a day before he was appointed to oversee the Russia investigation.

Headline: Mueller corrects exchange with lawmaker about decision not to indict Trump
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller said on Wednesday he wanted to correct an exchange with Democratic lawmaker Ted Lieu in which he agreed with Lieu's description of the decision not to indict Trump, saying: "We did not reach a determination as to whether the president committed a crime."

Headline: Highlights from former U.S. special counsel Mueller's testimony
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller testified on Wednesday to the U.S. House of Representatives about his investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and any possible obstruction of justice by President Donald Trump.

Headline: Mueller to lawmakers: Trump wanted him fired over investigation
Article: Former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller on Wednesday said President Donald Trump wanted him fired because of his investigation into possible obstruction of justice as part of the Russia investigation.

Headline: Former Special Counsel Mueller opens hearing by telling Congress his testimony will be limited
Article: Former Special Counsel Robert Mueller began Wednesday's highly anticipated congressional hearing by telling lawmakers he will be limited in what he can discuss about his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

Headline: Factbox: Which U.S. House Democrats want to impeach Trump?
Article: Ninety Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives as of early this week have said they support starting impeachment investigations against Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Former lobbyist Esper sworn in as Pentagon chief
Article: Army Secretary Mark Esper was sworn in as U.S. secretary of defense on Tuesday, hours after being confirmed by the Senate in a strong bipartisan vote that ended the longest period by far the Pentagon had been without a permanent top official.

Headline: Taciturn Mueller faces U.S. Congress on probe of Trump
Article: When Robert Mueller was leading a U.S. Marine Corps platoon in combat in Vietnam, Donald Trump was finishing college and about to go to work for his father, a New York City landlord, having received military draft deferments including for a diagnosis of bone spurs in his heels.

Headline: Explainer: After Mueller, what do U.S. House Judiciary Democrats do about Trump?
Article: Democrats in control of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee hope that Robert Mueller's testimony on Wednesday will boost their wide-ranging investigation of President Donald Trump, but it is not entirely clear where that inquiry is headed.

Headline: Trump sues to block House panel from getting his state tax returns
Article: President Donald Trump on Tuesday sued to block a U.S. House of Representatives committee from obtaining his New York state tax returns, with his lawyer accusing the Democratic-controlled panel of "presidential harassment."

Headline: Senate to vote to confirm FAA nominee Wednesday
Article: The U.S. Senate is set to vote on Wednesday to confirm a former airline executive to head the Federal Aviation Administration.

Headline: House Democrats unveil more 'realistic' climate change plan
Article: A group of U.S. House Democrats on Tuesday unveiled a climate change plan they said featured a "more realistic" goal to cut carbon emissions to net zero by 2050 rather than by 2030 as envisioned under the Green New Deal introduced early this year.

Headline: U.S. coal miners discouraged by black lung meeting with McConnell
Article: A group of coal miners afflicted with black lung disease met with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Tuesday as part of an effort to convince lawmakers to restore a higher excise tax on coal companies to help fund their medical care, but several said the meeting left them discouraged.

Headline: U.S. jury convicts business partner of ex-Trump adviser of secretly lobbying for Turkey
Article: A jury on Tuesday convicted Bijan Rafiekian, who was the business partner of U.S. President Donald Trump's disgraced former national security adviser Michael Flynn, on charges of secretly lobbying for Turkey.

Headline: Senior lawmaker rejects Justice Department limits on Mueller testimony
Article: A day before Robert Mueller's eagerly anticipated congressional testimony, a senior Democratic U.S. lawmaker on Tuesday accused President Donald Trump's Justice Department of arrogance in instructing the former special counsel to limit the scope of his remarks and said it lacked the authority for such a directive.

Headline: Timeline: Big moments in Mueller investigation of Russian meddling in 2016 U.S. election
Article: Here is a timeline of significant developments in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russia's role in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and contacts between President Donald Trump's campaign and Moscow.

Headline: North Carolina 'bathroom bill' settlement approved
Article: Transgender people in North Carolina can use any public restroom in state-run buildings that conforms with their gender identity under a U.S. court settlement approved on Tuesday, in the latest turn of a long-running dispute that divided the state.

Headline: Congress sends Trump permanent renewal of 9/11 responders' compensation
Article: The U.S. Senate on Tuesday passed and sent to President Donald Trump legislation authorizing permanent benefits for police, firefighters and other first responders suffering from illnesses and injuries related to their work in the aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

Headline: Ohio House passes bill to save nuclear power plants
Article: Ohio's Republican-controlled House of Representatives passed a bill on Tuesday to create subsidies to avoid the early shutdown of the state's two nuclear power reactors.

Headline: Trump administration proposed rule would cut 3 million people from food stamps
Article: The Trump administration on Tuesday proposed a rule to tighten food stamp eligibility that would cut about 3.1 million people from the program, U.S. Department of Agriculture officials said, drawing ire from Democratic senators and advocacy groups.

Headline: Mueller report shows evidence Trump committed crimes, House Judiciary chairman says
Article: The top Democrat on the U.S. House Judiciary Committee said Sunday he believes there is "substantial evidence" that President Donald Trump committed high crimes and misdemeanors, and he plans to ask former Special Counsel Robert Mueller to present those facts at a congressional hearing on Wednesday.

Headline: Ahead of House hearing, Republicans sharpen knives for Mueller
Article: Robert Mueller stayed mum for nearly two years in the face of repeated verbal attacks on his integrity by President Donald Trump and his conservative Republican allies in Congress.

Headline: U.S. immigration action that targeted 2,100 people snared just 35
Article: A scant 35 people were taken into custody during a long-threatened U.S. enforcement action that targeted more than 2,100 immigrants who had been ordered deported, the head of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement said on Tuesday.

Headline: Harris introduces Senate bill to decriminalize marijuana, expunge convictions
Article: Democratic White House hopeful Kamala Harris introduced a Senate bill on Tuesday to decriminalize marijuana at the federal level, erase past convictions and use funds from marijuana sales to invest in communities hit by the decades-long "war on drugs."

Headline: Trump's Middle East envoy faces resistance at U.N. Security Council
Article: A plan for peace between Israel and the Palestinians cannot rely on global consensus, inconclusive international law and "unclear" United Nations resolutions, U.S. President Donald Trump's Middle East envoy told the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday, sparking pushback from several countries.

Headline: FBI Director Wray: Russia intent on interfering with U.S. elections
Article: Russia is determined to interfere in U.S. elections despite sanctions and other efforts to deter such actions before the next presidential election in 2020, FBI Director Christopher Wray said on Tuesday.

Headline: Most Republicans plan to tune out Mueller probe: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: When Robert Mueller testifies before Congress on Wednesday about his probe of Russian interference in the 2016 election and possible obstruction of justice by President Donald Trump, a key part of the U.S. public appears likely to tune out - Republicans.

Headline: Senators announce bipartisan proposal to lower drug prices
Article: The top Republican and Democrat on the U.S. Senate Finance Committee announced a proposal to lower prescription drug prices on Tuesday that could save $100 billion in costs to government healthcare programs, and said the committee would vote on the legislation on Thursday.

Headline: Senate leader says he is confident budget deal will pass
Article: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Tuesday he was confident the Senate would pass a newly agreed deal to extend the U.S. debt limit and set federal spending caps for two years.

Headline: Explainer: What can Mueller tell U.S. lawmakers that we do not already know?
Article: When Robert Mueller testifies to the U.S. Congress on Wednesday, Democratic lawmakers are expected to try to pin down the former special counsel on a crucial question: did he intend for them to carry on where he left off in his investigation of President Donald Trump and the Russians?

Headline: U.S. Justice Department tells Mueller to limit congressional testimony
Article: The U.S. Justice Department told former Special Counsel Robert Mueller on Monday he should limit his testimony before Congress this week to discussing his public report on the Russia probe.

Headline: As new U.S. law frees inmates, prosecutors seek to lock some back up
Article: Monae Davis walked out of prison on March 7, thanks to a new law that eased some of the harshest aspects of the United States' war on drugs.

Headline: Biden unveils plan to end racial discrimination in U.S. criminal justice system
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden unveiled a plan on Tuesday to reform the U.S. criminal justice system by lowering incarceration rates, ending the federal death penalty and eliminating racial disparities in how people are sentenced.

Headline: Trump pushes on with immigration crackdown despite legal hurdles
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration pushed ahead with its attempts to crack down on migration at the southern border on Monday, defending in court a virtual ban it imposed on asylum seekers and issuing its second sweeping order within a week.

Headline: Mexican Federal Police accused of harassment at migrant shelter, latest in a series
Article: The Mexican Federal Police harassed migrants and threatened to raid a migrant shelter in Coahuila over the weekend, according to the head of a state agency and the head of the shelter, the latest in a series of similar reported incidents.

Headline: Trump, Congress leaders reach deal on debt limit, spending caps
Article: President Donald Trump and U.S. congressional leaders reached a deal on Monday on a two-year extension of the debt limit and federal spending caps that would avert a feared government default later this year but add to rising budget deficits.

Headline: Trump cites very good talks with Congress on debt ceiling
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that talks with Democrats and Republicans on raising the debt ceiling were going well and that it was important to take care of the military in any spending legislation.

Headline: Trump meets with tech CEOs on Huawei
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump met on Monday with the chief executives of seven technology companies and he agreed with their request for timely licensing decisions from the Commerce Department on blacklisted Chinese firm Huawei Technologies, the White House said.

Headline: Trump agrees to prompt responses to license requests for Huawei sales
Article: President Donald Trump agreed at a meeting with the heads of top technology companies like Google on Monday to make "timely" decisions on requests by U.S. companies to sell to blacklisted Huawei Technologies Co Ltd, the White House said.

Headline: Deep budget cuts put University of Alaska in crisis mode; 'grappling with survival'
Article: The University of Alaska board of regents, facing deep budget cuts exacted by the governor that will eliminate about 40% of the university's state funding, voted at an emergency meeting on Monday to declare the academic equivalent of bankruptcy reorganization.

Headline: Trump tells Pentagon to find better sources of rare earth magnet
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday told the Pentagon to find better ways to procure a rare earth magnet used in specialty motors, warning that the nation's defense would suffer without adequate stockpiles.

Headline: As Mueller testimony approaches, Trump can't look away
Article: President Donald Trump said on Monday he will watch only "a little bit" of Robert Mueller's long-awaited congressional testimony on the results of his 22-month inquiry into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election and renewed his attacks on the former special counsel.

Headline: Trump says deal reached on spending, debt limit
Article: President Donald Trump said on Monday a two-year deal had been reached with congressional leaders to raise the Treasury Department's borrowing authority and to set budget spending caps.

Headline: Explainer: What it would take for Congress to impeach Trump
Article: A dark cloud of impeachment has threatened President Donald Trump for many months, with Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives, where any such effort to remove him from office would begin, divided about whether to proceed.

Headline: Factbox: Which House Democrats want to impeach Trump?
Article: Eighty-nine Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives as of late last week have said they support starting impeachment investigations against Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump, justices pay respects to late U.S. jurist Stevens
Article: President Donald Trump, members of the U.S. Supreme Court and others paid their respects on Monday to liberal Justice John Paul Stevens, who died last week, as his body lay in repose in the courthouse's stately great hall.

Headline: Democratic candidate Warren sees U.S. economic downturn; urges quick steps
Article: Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren on Monday warned of "serious" signs that the U.S. economy could skid into a downturn either this year or next, as she proposed a series of steps to minimize the risk.

Headline: Exclusive: Air Force suspends fee payments to landlord Balfour Beatty following Reuters report
Article: The U.S. Air Force has suspended paying incentive fees at all 21 military housing bases operated by landlord Balfour Beatty Communities following a Reuters-CBS News report that the company falsified maintenance records at an Oklahoma base to help it qualify for millions of dollars in bonuses.

Headline: 'Apologize to America,' Trump tells Democratic congresswomen
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday stepped up his attacks on four Democratic congresswomen who have criticized his policies, calling on them to apologize as he himself faced charges of racism.

Headline: U.S. says Venezuelan plane aggressively shadowed a U.S. military aircraft
Article: The U.S. military on Sunday accused a Venezuelan fighter aircraft of "aggressively" shadowing a U.S. Navy EP-3 Aries II plane over international airspace, a fresh sign of growing hostility between the two countries.

Headline: U.S. has 'bigger problems' than plastic straws - Trump
Article: With plastic straw bans gaining popularity to protect the environment, President Donald Trump on Friday posed the question: What about other plastic dining items?

Headline: Trump relished rally chant, Ocasio-Cortez tells constituents in Queens
Article: U.S. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said on Saturday that President Donald Trump relished a chant by the crowd at a campaign rally this week that called for a Democratic congresswoman to be sent back where she came from.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers demand Puerto Rico governor resign as protests roil island
Article: Several U.S. Democratic presidential candidates and lawmakers on Friday demanded Puerto Rico's governor step down over offensive chat messages, as thousands on the Caribbean island staged a seventh day of protests to seek his resignation.

Headline: Joe Biden compares Trump to segregationist George Wallace
Article: Joe Biden, a former U.S. vice president and Democratic presidential candidate, compared Republican President Donald Trump on Friday to the late George Wallace, a prominent supporter of racial segregation.

Headline: Trump renews attacks on Democratic congresswomen
Article: President Donald Trump renewed his criticism of four minority women lawmakers on Friday, saying that they had said horrible things about the United States, and defended himself from criticism over his comment that they should leave the United States if unhappy.

Headline: U.S. State Department says concerned by reports of Chinese interference in South China Sea
Article: The U.S. State Department said on Saturday it is concerned by reports of China's interference with oil and gas activities in the South China Sea, including Vietnam's long-standing exploration and production activities.

Headline: NSA contractor sentenced to prison for huge theft of classified U.S. data
Article: A former National Security Agency contractor was sentenced in Maryland to nine years in prison on Friday for stealing huge amounts of classified material from U.S. intelligence agencies over two decades though officials never found proof he shared it with anyone.

Headline: Ex-Trump aide Hicks denies involvement in hush money talks: lawyer
Article: An attorney for former White House Communications Director Hope Hicks denied on Friday that she was involved in discussions during the 2016 presidential campaign about a hush-money payment to a porn star who claimed to have had a sexual encounter with President Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump offers to help ease tension in Japan-South Korea dispute
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday offered to help ease tensions in the political and economic dispute between Japan and South Korea, which threatens global supplies of memory chips and smartphones.

Headline: Democratic lawmakers slam Trump's latest border initiatives
Article: U.S. Democratic lawmakers on Friday called President Donald Trump's latest anti-immigration initiatives "unacceptable" and warned his administration against misappropriating funding authorized only for humanitarian use.

Headline: More Puerto Rico protests planned as governor resists calls to resign
Article: Massive and at times violent protests in Puerto Rico showed no sign of stopping as labor unions on Thursday organized a Friday march to keep up pressure on the governor to resign, while dozens of guns were stolen in a raid on police firearms center.

Headline: U.S. intelligence chief creates election security position
Article: Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats, who has drawn criticism from President Donald Trump for assessments that countered his policies, said on Friday he was creating a new position to focus solely on U.S. election security.

Headline: In battleground Florida, Republicans shrug off Trump's tweet 'kerfuffle'
Article: An immigrant to the United States, Suzanne Vale took no offense at Republican President Donald Trump's tweet this week telling Democratic congresswomen they are free to "go back" to their ancestral homes if America is not to their liking.

Headline: Trump says Britain's Johnson would do 'great job' as prime minister
Article: U.S. President Trump said on Friday he was looking forward to working with Boris Johnson, the front-runner to be Britain's next prime minister, and believes Johnson will work out Brexit.

Headline: Trump to nominate Scalia's son for labor secretary
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday he intends to nominate Eugene Scalia, the oldest son of the late Supreme Court justice Antonin Scalia, to be secretary of labor.

Headline: U.S. hits four Venezuelan military officers with sanctions after captain's death
Article: The United States on Friday stepped up its response following the death of a Venezuelan navy captain, sanctioning four top officials in Venezuela's military counterintelligence agency, the U.S. Treasury Department said.

Headline: Trump says will not use U.S. debt ceiling to negotiate spending deal with Congress
Article: President Donald Trump said on Friday he could not imagine using the United States' debt ceiling as a tool to negotiate a spending deal with lawmakers in Congress, saying the government's credit rating was sacred.

Headline: House Democrats to focus Mueller testimony on Trump's conduct
Article: When former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller appears in Congress on Wednesday, House Democrats will try to focus his testimony on clear examples of conduct by President Donald Trump that would lead to criminal charges against any other American.

Headline: Second 2020 Democratic debate to feature Biden-Harris rematch
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden and U.S. Senator Kamala Harris will have the chance for a re-match on the second night of the second round of Democratic presidential debates later this month in Detroit, CNN announced on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox: What to watch for at the second U.S. Democratic presidential debate
Article: When the Democratic candidates vying for the 2020 presidential nomination convene for the second round of debates this month, there will be one new face and the opportunity for another combative exchange between the two top-tier candidates.

Headline: Trump disavows 'send her back' rally chant, many Republicans alarmed
Article: President Donald Trump tried to distance himself on Thursday from supporters' chants of "send her back" at a rally where he blasted Somalia-born U.S. Representative Ilhan Omar, as Republicans worry the incendiary mantra could set the tone for the 2020 campaign.

Headline: UK's Javid says 'send her back' chant at Trump rally unacceptable
