Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Wednesday President Donald Trump was moving closer to impeachment with his effort to thwart congressional subpoenas and obstruct lawmakers' efforts to oversee his administration.

Headline: Zimbabwe court says main opposition leader illegitimate, party to challenge ruling
Article: Zimbabweâ€™s High Court on Wednesday declared Nelson Chamisa an illegitimate leader of the main opposition MDC party and ordered the movement to convene an extraordinary congress to choose a new leader after a month.

Headline: Trump blasts report on his business losses, calls accounting a 'sport'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump defended himself on Wednesday following a media report that said his businesses had lost more than $1 billion from 1985 to 1994, saying he had leeway with his taxes as a real estate developer.

Headline: White House defies Congress on McGahn subpoena as Trump battles Democrats
Article: President Donald Trump's struggle with Democratic lawmakers intensified on Tuesday, with the White House directing former counsel Don McGahn not to comply with a congressional subpoena and the chair of the House Judiciary Committee threatening to hold him in contempt.

Headline: Justice Department may advise Trump to claim privilege over Mueller report
Article: The U.S. Justice Department threatened on Tuesday to completely withhold Special Counsel Robert Mueller's unredacted report from Congress if House Democrats decide to move ahead with plans to hold Attorney General William Barr in contempt.

Headline: Facebook executive meets with U.S. lawmakers to discuss privacy
Article: With a multibillion-dollar settlement looming for Facebook over user privacy violations, Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg met with U.S. lawmakers on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to discuss legislation to protect users of the social network, officials said.

Headline: Trump briefs Republican senators on emerging U.S. immigration plan
Article: President Donald Trump and aides on Tuesday briefed a group of Republican senators on a merit-based immigration plan that would let more highly-skilled workers into the United States and fewer low-skilled workers, a senior administration official said.

Headline: Top Democrat in U.S. Senate wants hearings before any impeachment effort
Article: The top Democrat in the U.S. Senate said on Tuesday that Congress should thoroughly investigate the findings of Special Counsel Robert Mueller before deciding whether to move forward with impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump.

Headline: Senate's McConnell: 'Case closed' on Mueller probe, but top Democrat sees 'cover-up'
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Tuesday sought to slam the door on further investigations of President Donald Trump by declaring "case closed" after a two-year probe of Russia's meddling in the 2016 elections, even as House Democrats' war with the White House intensified.

Headline: U.S. Democrats question Trump administration over Ukraine ambassador
Article: Two senior U.S. Democrats questioned President Donald Trump's administration on Tuesday over the departure of the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine months before the end of her expected three years in Kiev.

Headline: Explainer: How hard-hitting are U.S. Congress subpoenas, contempt citations?
Article: U.S. Attorney General William Barr faces the prospect on Wednesday of a vote by a U.S. House committee to hold him in "contempt of Congress." What does that mean?

Headline: Ex-lawyer Cohen reports to prison, blasts Trump for 'injustice and lies'
Article: Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's former personal lawyer, took a parting shot at his former boss - denouncing "xenophobia, injustice and lies" - before reporting to a U.S. federal prison on Monday to begin a three-year sentence.

Headline: Gun control takes center stage in 2020 Democratic presidential race
Article: U.S. Senator Cory Booker on Monday released a sweeping plan to curb gun violence by creating a national licensing program and repealing a law that gives gun manufacturers legal immunity, becoming the latest Democrat in the 2020 presidential race to make gun control measures a feature of their campaign.

Headline: House panel issues report citing Barr for contempt
Article: The U.S. House Judiciary Committee on Monday issued a report citing Attorney General William Barr for contempt over a panel subpoena seeking Special Counsel Robert Mueller's full unredacted report on his Russia investigation.

Headline: Factbox: Tweets tell story of souring Trump, Cohen relationship
Article: President Donald Trump and his former personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, have both used Twitter to spar with enemies over the last decade. Cohen, 52, is due to report to federal prison in New York state on Monday to begin serving a three-year sentence for crimes including illegal hush payments to women on Trump's behalf.

Headline: Second deadline for DOJ to give Congress full Mueller report expires
Article: A second congressional subpoena deadline for U.S. Attorney General William Barr to provide lawmakers with an unredacted copy of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation report expired at 9 a.m. EDT (1300 GMT) on Monday.

Headline: Trump says Special Counsel Mueller should not testify on Russia probe
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Sunday that Special Counsel Robert Mueller should not testify in Congress about the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, after saying on Friday it was up to the Justice Department's top official.

Headline: Bernie Sanders promises help for family farms, rural residents on trip to Iowa
Article: U.S. presidential contender Bernie Sanders unveiled a plan on Sunday to help family farmers and rural residents, promising to break up corporate agricultural monopolies and invest heavily in social and economic programs in struggling rural communities.

Headline: Trump says he, Putin discussed new nuclear pact possibly including China
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said he and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed on Friday the possibility of a new accord limiting nuclear arms that could eventually include China in what would be a major deal between the globe's top three atomic powers.

Headline: House Democrats seek to intervene against Trump lawsuit over bank subpoenas
Article: Two committees of the Democrat-controlled U.S. House of Representatives on Friday asked to intervene in a lawsuit filed by President Donald Trump, his three oldest children and the Trump Organization seeking to block House subpoenas seeking financial records from Deutsche Bank AG and Capital One Financial Corp.

Headline: Pressure grows on Attorney General Barr over Mueller
Article: President Donald Trump and a senior U.S. House Democrat tightened the screws on U.S. Attorney General William Barr on Friday over the Mueller report, making new demands on him after an already tough week for the Justice Department chief.

Headline: Trump says he will decide over next week whether to let McGahn testify for Congress
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday said he will decide in the coming days whether he will allow former White House lawyer Don McGahn to testify before U.S. lawmakers or whether he will invoke executive privilege to block his testimony.

Headline: U.S. judges order Ohio to revamp Republican-drawn gerrymandered districts
Article: A panel of three federal judges on Friday ruled that Ohio's Republican-drawn congressional map is an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander and ordered the state to revamp it before the 2020 presidential election.

Headline: Exclusive: Trump administration proposal would make it easier to deport immigrants who use public benefits
Article: The Trump administration is considering reversing long-standing policy to make it easier to deport U.S. legal permanent residents who have used public benefits, part of an effort to restrict immigration by low-income people.

Headline: Trump says had 'long and very good' talk with Russia's Putin
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday said he had a "very productive" call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on issues ranging from North Korea, Ukraine and Venezuela to trade and nuclear weapons.

Headline: Trump, Democrats cross swords over powers as 2020 election looms
Article: Congressional Democrats and President Donald Trump are locked in a constitutional showdown over their powers to investigate him, exchanging threats that present risks for both sides as they head into the 2020 election.

Headline: State Department OKs nearly $6 billion in weapons sales to Gulf allies
Article: The U.S. State Department has approved a possible $6 billion worth of weapons sales to Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates in three separate packages, the Pentagon said on Friday after notifying Congress of the certification.

Headline: Trump says did not raise election meddling with Putin in phone call
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday that he discussed "the Russia Hoax" with Russian President Vladimir Putin but did not raise with him concerns about Russian meddling in U.S. elections.

Headline: Trump says he, Putin discussed nuclear deal that would reduce weapons
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday following his call with Russian President Vladimir Putin that Moscow and Washington were discussing a nuclear deal that would reduce the number of weapons.

Headline: Exclusive: Foreign government leases at Trump World Tower stir more emoluments concerns
Article: The U.S. State Department allowed seven foreign governments to rent luxury condominiums in New York's Trump World Tower in 2017 without approval from Congress, according to documents and people familiar with the leases, in what some experts say could be a potential violation of the U.S. Constitution's emoluments clause.

Headline: Senate judiciary chair offers Mueller opportunity to testify
Article: The Republican chairman of the U.S. Senate judiciary committee, Lindsey Graham, on Friday offered U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller the opportunity to testify before his committee about any misstatements Attorney General William Barr might have made about Mueller's investigation.

Headline: Civil rights groups sue Tennessee over law imposing new penalties on voter registration
Article: Civil rights groups in Tennessee have asked a federal court to block enforcement of a new state law that threatens to impose new penalties on voter-registration groups if they file too many incomplete forms.

Headline: Democrats ramp up pressure on Trump as Pelosi accuses Barr of 'crime'
Article: Democrats intensified their pressure on President Donald Trump's administration on Thursday as U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused Attorney General William Barr of committing a crime by lying to lawmakers and a key committee chairman threatened to hold Barr in contempt of Congress.

Headline: Cracks appear in U.S. bipartisan unity on Venezuela
Article: President Donald Trump's tough approach to Venezuela has won broad support from both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. Congress, but this rare display of bipartisan consensus is starting to show signs of strain as the crisis in the OPEC nation drags on.

Headline: Democrat Inslee tries to separate from pack with campaign climate plan
Article: Washington Governor Jay Inslee on Friday outlined a plan to achieve 100% clean electricity, zero-emission new vehicles and zero-carbon buildings and retire the U.S. coal power plant fleet by 2030, aiming to position himself as the most aggressive Democratic candidate on climate change.

Headline: Maine Senate rejects ending religious exemptions for vaccinations
Article: An effort to end all non-medical exemptions for childhood vaccinations in Maine was in limbo on Thursday after the state Senate voted to amend it to allow parents to keep opting out on religious grounds.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. seeks to challenge China's electric-vehicle supply chain dominance
Article: A U.S. senator plans to introduce legislation on Thursday to streamline regulation and permitting requirements for the development of mines for lithium, graphite and other electric-vehicle supply chain minerals, part of a plan to offset China's dominance in the space.

Headline: Stung by snubs, House Democrats weigh fines for U.S. attorney general
Article: Some U.S. House Democrats on Thursday said they might seek to invoke a dormant congressional power to impose fines on Attorney General William Barr after he refused to provide them with an unredacted copy of the Mueller report.

Headline: Baltimore mayor quits amid questions over $500,000 book deal
Article: Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh, whose home and offices were raided by federal agents last week as part of an investigation into her financial dealings, abruptly resigned on Thursday.

Headline: Explainer: How powerful are Congress subpoenas, contempt citations?
Article: U.S. House Democrats threatened on Thursday to hold Attorney General William Barr in "contempt of Congress" for not complying with a subpoena to hand over an unredacted version of the Mueller report. What does that mean?

Headline: Rights groups sue over U.S. decision to hold asylum seekers without bond
Article: Immigrant rights groups asked a U.S. court on Thursday to reverse a Trump administration decision that allows asylum seekers who cross the border illegally to be held without bond.

Headline: Moore, under fire, withdraws from bid for Fed post
Article: Economic commentator Stephen Moore has withdrawn from consideration for a seat on the U.S. Federal Reserve Board after weeks of criticism about his political partisanship, shifting views on interest rate policy, and sexist comments about women.

Headline: Biden's rise in 2020 race catches Trump's eye, unnerves his allies
Article: Joe Biden's rapid emergence as front-runner in the race for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination has caught the attention of President Donald Trump and unnerved some of his allies, who believe Biden is a potentially dangerous rival.

Headline: Facebook bans Alex Jones, other extremist figures
Article: Facebook Inc said on Thursday it was banning Alex Jones and other controversial U.S. political personalities for violating the social media company's policies on "dangerous individuals and organizations."

Headline: Trump Fed pick says he would win Senate backing if debate were over policy
Article: President Donald Trump's pick for a Federal Reserve Board seat, economic commentator Stephen Moore, said on Thursday he would win the Senate's needed backing for the post if the debate over his prospective nomination were about policy, Bloomberg Television reported.

Headline: Trump says he's not inclined to let former counsel McGahn testify to Congress
Article: President Donald Trump said on Thursday he did not believe he would allow former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify to committees in Congress, saying McGahn had already spoken to the special counsel on the Russia probe.

Headline: Factbox: More than 20 Democrats, two Republicans vie for presidential nomination
Article: The largest Democratic field in the modern U.S. political era is competing for the party's 2020 presidential nomination.

Headline: House Democrats press probe of Trump security clearances
Article: The former head of the White House office for security clearances told U.S. congressional investigators that he loosened clearance procedures for new hires over the objections of career officials, a congressional aide said on Thursday.

Headline: Senate upholds veto of Yemen resolution in victory for Trump Saudi policy
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday sustained President Donald Trump's veto of a resolution demanding an end to military support for the Saudi-led coalition waging war in Yemen, in a victory for the White House's policy of continued backing for the kingdom.

Headline: White House letter blasts Mueller report, says Trump has right to instruct advisers not to testify
Article: President Donald Trump has the right to instruct advisers not to testify before congressional oversight probes related to the Russia investigation, the White House said in a letter that blasts Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report as deeply flawed.

Headline: House backs Paris agreement in first climate bill in a decade
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday passed its first climate-change bill in a decade, voting 231-190 to require that Trump administration keep the United States as a party to the Paris Climate Agreement.

Headline: House panel chairman warns Barr over testimony, Mueller report
Article: Democratic U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler on Thursday urged Attorney General William Barr to comply with the panel's demands to testify before it and to release Special Counsel Robert Mueller's full report on the Russia inquiry.

Headline: House chairman gives Barr more time to release full Mueller report
Article: The Democratic head of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee on Thursday said the panel would make one more good faith attempt to negotiate with U.S. Attorney General William Barr over the release U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's full, unredacted report.

Headline: With a wing and a drumstick, Democrat uses poultry props to chide Barr
Article: When Attorney General William Barr refused to appear at a hearing in the U.S. Congress on Thursday, one Democrat decided it was thigh time to act against what he saw as fowl behavior.

Headline: Congress displays political art of the empty chair after Barr no-show
Article: Political theater sometimes calls for props. On Thursday Democrats on the U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee pulled out a classic: the empty chair.

Headline: Pelosi says Barr committed a crime by lying to Congress
Article: U.S. House of Representatives' Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday accused Attorney General William Barr of lying to Congress, telling reporters, "That's a crime."

Headline: Trump Fed pick Moore withdraws from consideration
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's pick to fill a seat on the Federal Reserve, economic commentator Stephen Moore, withdrew from consideration on Thursday after weeks of criticism about his shifting views on interest-rate policy and sexist comments about women.

Headline: Not so fast: Trumpâ€™s Alaska drilling study slammed by U.S. wildlife regulator
Article: (This April 26 story corrects spelling of name in paragraph 6))

Headline: Florida teachers can arm themselves under new gun bill
Article: Florida's legislature on Wednesday passed a bill allowing teachers to carry guns in the classroom, expanding a program launched after the deadly high school shooting in Parkland with the aim of preventing another such massacre.

Headline: Democratic Senator Bennet of Colorado joins crowded 2020 field
Article: U.S. Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, whose political career has centered on improving the American education system, on Thursday became the latest Democrat to join the sprawling field of candidates seeking the party's 2020 presidential nomination.

Headline: Barr cancels second day of testimony, escalating battle with U.S. Congress
Article: Attorney General William Barr on Wednesday canceled plans to testify before the House of Representatives about his handling of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation, further inflaming tensions between U.S. President Donald Trump and Democrats in Congress.

Headline: Explainer: Can Trump use executive privilege to block congressional probes?
Article: Like numerous U.S. presidents before him, Donald Trump could cite the legal doctrine of "executive privilege" to try to block congressional investigators from getting access to certain documents and witnesses they are seeking.

Headline: Facebook settlement with U.S. may include privacy oversight: Politico
Article: Facebook Inc and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) are negotiating a possible settlement that would require the company to create an independent privacy oversight committee and take other steps to safeguard users, Politico reported on Wednesday, citing a source.

Headline: Official says White House never told him to change a security clearance decision -source
Article: The former head of White House security clearances told congressional investigators on Wednesday he was never instructed to change a security clearance determination by anyone at the White House, a source familiar with his closed-door interview said.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers drafting privacy bill argue about pre-empting California
Article: U.S. lawmakers drafting online privacy legislation zeroed in on a major point of contention on Wednesday of whether their federal law should pre-empt stringent regulations recently passed by California that could hurt corporate profits.

Headline: Defying Congress, Attorney General Barr to skip Mueller hearing
Article: Defying the U.S. Congress, Attorney General William Barr will not attend a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Thursday on his handling of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation report, said panel Chairman Jerrold Nadler, accusing Barr of being afraid to testify.

Headline: Barr will be subpoenaed if he fails to appear at House hearing: Democrat
Article: U.S. Attorney General William Barr will be subpoenaed if does not appear for a hearing of the House of Representatives Judiciary Committee on Thursday, Democratic Representative Hakeem Jeffries said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump seeks huge boost in emergency funds for migrant surge
Article: The Trump administration on Wednesday asked Congress for $4.5 billion in immediate emergency funding, saying a surge in Central American children and families claiming asylum at the U.S. southern border had drained government resources.

Headline: U.S. military not given orders to prepare for war in Venezuela
Article: The Pentagon on Wednesday appeared to downplay any active preparations to directly intervene in Venezuela to topple President Nicolas Maduro, but acknowledged detailed contingency planning as political turmoil in the oil-rich nation deepens.

Headline: House panel adopts aggressive format for Barr hearing
Article: The Democratic-led U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee voted on Wednesday to adopt a more aggressive questioning format for a hearing set for this week with Attorney General William Barr.

Headline: Mueller should testify to Congress if he wants: White House adviser
Article: U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller should testify in front of Congress about his report into Russian interference in the 2016 election and whether President Donald Trump obstructed justice, White House adviser Kellyanne Conway said on Wednesday.

Headline: Factbox: Crowd of U.S. Congress committees investigating Trump
Article: More than half a dozen committees of the U.S. Congress are investigating President Donald Trump, who is refusing to cooperate with most of them since the April 18 release of the Mueller report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, setting up a likely court battle.

Headline: Lawmaker says he is trying to nail down a date for Mueller to testify
Article: The Democratic chairman of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee said on Wednesday he was seeking to nail down a date to have Special Counsel Robert Mueller testify to Congress about his investigation into Russian election interference and attempts by President Donald Trump to impede the probe.

Headline: DOJ misses House subpoena deadline for full Mueller report: aide
Article: The U.S. Justice Department missed a Wednesday subpoena deadline for providing the House Judiciary Committee with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's unredacted report on his investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, a Democratic congressional aide said.

Headline: House panel seeks Justice Department probe of Trump backer Prince
Article: (This April 30 story has been refiled to remove extraneous punctuation and fixing typo in thirteenth paragraph.)

Headline: Trump sets Twitter ablaze after firefighters union backs Biden
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump fired off dozens of retweets from purported firefighters, their families and acquaintances on Wednesday, in his latest assault on Joe Biden, the newest Democratic candidate for the 2020 presidential nomination.

Headline: Most Democrats say age is not just a number for White House candidates: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: As Democrats weigh a field of 20 White House hopefuls that includes candidates who would be the youngest or oldest president ever elected, new Reuters/Ipsos polling shows age could be a liability at either end of the spectrum.

Headline: Deadline expires for DOJ to give Congress full Mueller report
Article: A congressional subpoena deadline for the U.S. Justice Department to provide lawmakers with an unredacted copy of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation report expired at 10 a.m. EDT (1400 GMT) on Wednesday.

Headline: Democrats' suit against Trump over foreign payment can proceed: judge
Article: A U.S. federal judge ruled on Tuesday that Democrats in Congress can move forward with a lawsuit accusing President Donald Trump of violating the law by accepting gifts or payments from foreign governments through his businesses.

Headline: Trump to meet with Republican senators on U.S. shipping rules
Article: President Donald Trump is set to meet with Republican senators on Wednesday over a proposal to waive rules that only U.S.-flagged ships can move natural gas from American ports to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Northeast.

Headline: Mueller complained to Barr about his summary of Russia probe: Washington Post
Article: Special Counsel Robert Mueller complained in a letter to Attorney General William Barr that his four-page summary of Mueller's Russia report "did not fully capture the context, nature, and substance" of the investigation's conclusions, the Washington Post reported on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump, Democrats agree to spend $2 trillion on U.S. infrastructure
Article: President Donald Trump and Democratic leaders agreed on Tuesday to spend $2 trillion on U.S. roads, bridges, power grids, water and broadband infrastructure, while leaving the thorny details of how to pay for it all to another meeting in three weeks.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers struggle to draft online privacy bill
Article: U.S. lawmakers drafting a bill to create rules governing online privacy hope to have a discussion draft complete by late May with a Senate committee vote during the summer and are intensifying efforts, but disputes are likely to push that timetable back, according to sources knowledgeable about the matter.

Headline: Trump weighs labeling Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist group
Article: President Donald Trump is working to designate the Muslim Brotherhood a foreign terrorist organization (FTO), the White House said on Tuesday, which would bring sanctions against Egypt's oldest Islamist movement.

Headline: Five ways Trump's moves to stem asylum seekers have hit hurdles
Article: Grappling with a ballooning number of mostly Central American families seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border, President Donald Trump has suggested increasingly bold steps to limit protections for this group and stem their entry into the United States.

Headline: Turkey's AK Party: U.S. move against Muslim Brotherhood would damage democracy in Middle East
Article: The spokesman for Turkey's ruling AK Party said on Tuesday that if the United States designated the Muslim Brotherhood a foreign terrorist organization, it would hamper democratization efforts in the Middle East and serve militant groups like Islamic State.

Headline: As Fed meets, Trump calls for sharp rate cut, stimulus
Article: President Donald Trump, in perhaps his most unorthodox statement yet on monetary policy, called for the U.S. Federal Reserve to act as if the country was back in the throes of recession, with sharp interest rate cuts and renewed "quantitative easing" to pump trillions of dollars into the economy.

Headline: Senators blast 'insane' Trump plan for aid cuts, seek Venezuela plan
Article: Republican and Democratic U.S. senators blasted President Donald Trump's proposal for a 23 percent cut in the U.S. budget for foreign aid and diplomacy as "insane" and "short-sighted" on Tuesday, and said it would not pass.

Headline: With Biden in, crowded 2020 Democratic field starts to get feisty
Article: The 2020 Democratic White House race, until now a cordial affair with no personal attacks and few policy disputes, is starting to get scrappy.

Headline: Oprah 'quietly figuring out' how to wield her political clout in 2020
Article: Media mogul Oprah Winfrey, whose opinions can get millions of fans to try a new diet or turn a book into an international best-seller, is figuring out which Democratic candidate she will endorse in the crowded 2020 U.S. presidential race.

Headline: Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood says it will continue 'peaceful' work regardless of Trump moves
Article: Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood said on Tuesday it would continue to work in line with "our moderate and peaceful thinking" regardless of moves by U.S. President Donald Trump's administration to designate it a foreign terrorist organization.

Headline: Trump, Democratic leaders to meet on drug prices soon: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will meet with congressional Democratic leaders soon to discuss drug prices, the White House said on Tuesday following infrastructure talks with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer.

Headline: Republican Senator Ernst 'unlikely' to back Moore for Fed
Article: U.S. Republican Senator Joni Ernst on Tuesday said she was "very unlikely" to back fellow Republican President Donald Trump's pick for a seat on the U.S. central bank, according to a CNN reporter on Twitter.

Headline: Trump says he is monitoring Venezuela situation
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday said he is monitoring the situation in Venezuela very closely and reiterated U.S. support for its people as Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido moved further to oust President Nicolas Maduro.

Headline: Prosecutors oppose giving unredacted Mueller report to Trump adviser Stone
Article: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday opposed a bid by President Donald Trump's longtime adviser Roger Stone to obtain unredacted portions of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election to help his defense against criminal charges brought by Mueller.

Headline: Trump, Democrats agree to $2 trillion on infrastructure: Schumer
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump agreed with Democratic leaders on Tuesday to spend $2 trillion on roads, bridges, water, broadband and power grids, Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer said on Tuesday after a White House meeting.

Headline: Escalating fight, Trump sues Deutsche Bank, Capital One over Democratic subpoenas
Article: President Donald Trump, his three oldest children and the Trump Organization have sued Deutsche Bank AG and Capital One Financial Corp to try to block them from responding to U.S. congressional subpoenas issued by Democrats seeking financial records.

Headline: Trump directs officials to toughen asylum rules
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump directed officials to toughen rules for asylum seekers on Monday, including by introducing a fee for their applications and barring those who entered the country illegally from working until their claims are approved.

Headline: Foxconn chairman travels to White House to discuss Wisconsin: source
Article: The chairman of Apple supplier Foxconn will travel to the United States on Tuesday for a meeting in the White House that is believed to be related to an investment in Wisconsin, according to a source with direct knowledge of the matter.

Headline: Trump sues Deutsche Bank and Capital One to block House subpoenas
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump, three of his children and seven of his companies filed a federal lawsuit Monday against Deutsche Bank and Capital One Financial Corp to block the banks from complying with federal subpoenas investigating his financial dealings.

Headline: Explainer: Probes spawned by Mueller target Trump business, others
Article: Numerous investigations spun out of U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe are still alive and kicking, presenting potential ongoing legal and political risk for President Donald Trump, some of his former advisers and others.

Headline: Georgia Democrat Abrams rules out U.S. Senate run, says not 'best' role
Article: Georgia Democrat Stacey Abrams, a rising Democratic Party star who narrowly fell short of becoming the first female black U.S. governor, said on Tuesday she would not run for the U.S. Senate in 2020 because it was not "the best role" for her.

Headline: White House says will reappoint Puerto Rico oversight board
Article: The White House said on Monday it will ask the U.S. Senate to confirm the current members of Puerto Rico's federally created financial oversight board after creditors of the bankrupt island successfully challenged the appointments on constitutional grounds.

Headline: House panel chairman says Barr must testify Thursday
Article: U.S. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler said on Monday that Attorney General William Barr must testify before his panel on Thursday, despite Barr's reported objections to a more aggressive format for questions planned by Democrats.

Headline: Rod Rosenstein, U.S. deputy attorney general who appointed Mueller, submits resignation
Article: U.S. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who appointed Special Counsel Robert Mueller in May 2017 to investigate links between the Russian government and President Donald Trump's campaign, said on Monday he was resigning from his post.

Headline: Senators urge regulators to quickly approve drone identification rules
Article: Two U.S. senators on Monday urged U.S. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao to finalize a long-delayed rule that would require the remote identification of unmanned aircraft systems, or drones.

Headline: New York officials hit back at Trump over backing NRA
Article: New York's governor assailed President Donald Trump on Monday for backing the National Rifle Association in its dispute with the state, accusing the U.S. leader of being afraid of the powerful gun lobby.

Headline: At first 2020 event, Biden sets up battle with Trump over union vote
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden made clear on Monday at his first event as a presidential candidate that he stands ready to battle President Donald Trump for the support of the blue-collar workers who were key to Trump's election in 2016.

Headline: Attorney general balks at closed-door testimony on Mueller findings
Article: U.S. Attorney General William Barr objects to testifying before the House Judiciary Committee in a closed session dedicated to redacted portions of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia report, a congressional Democratic aide said on Sunday.

Headline: U.S. should pay North Korea hospital bill for student prisoner who died: ex-envoy
Article: The former U.S. diplomat who secured the release from North Korea of American Otto Warmbier said on Monday Washington should honor its pledge to pay Pyongyang $2 million for the student's hospital care.

Headline: Pentagon approves 320 more personnel to Mexico border
Article: The U.S. military said on Monday it would send about 320 Defense Department personnel to the border with Mexico in roles that would increasingly put them in contact with migrants, including driving them in vehicles and "monitoring" their welfare.

Headline: Democratic presidential candidate O'Rourke lays out $5 trillion climate plan
Article: U.S. presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke on Monday laid out one of the most detailed climate policies so far in the crowded Democratic field, calling for a $5 trillion investment in clean energy technology and infrastructure over 10 years with a goal of reaching net-zero emissions by 2050.

Headline: Democrats insist on 'substantial' new revenue for U.S. infrastructure
Article: A day before heading to the White House to meet with President Donald Trump, top Democrats in Congress on Monday said a bill to boost U.S. infrastructure must be funded with "substantial, new and real revenue" to meet massive needs across the country.

Headline: Trump administration eyes more aid to farmers if necessary: White House aide
Article: The Trump administration is ready to provide more federal aid to farmers if required, a White House adviser said on Monday, after rolling out up to $12 billion since last year to offset agricultural losses from the trade dispute with China.

Headline: Trump nemesis Avenatti pleads not guilty in bank fraud case
Article: Lawyer Michael Avenatti, known for his battles with U.S. President Donald Trump, pleaded not guilty on Monday to federal charges that he allegedly stole millions of dollars from clients and failed to pay taxes.

Headline: Migrant youths seeking legal status sue Trump administration in new challenge
Article: Young migrants in New Jersey who are seeking legal status in the United States after allegedly suffering abuse or neglect in their home countries sued the Trump administration on Monday, saying it is unfairly denying their claims.

Headline: Democrat O'Rourke accuses Trump White House of dictating Fox News content
Article: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke attacked the close ties between Republican President Donald Trump and Fox News on Sunday, saying the White House has "free rein, almost" over what is broadcast on the cable television network.

Headline: Democratic presidential contender Hickenlooper aims to fight monopolies
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful John Hickenlooper, a two-time former governor of Colorado, called on Friday for beefing up U.S. anti-trust laws, part of a business-friendly yet progressive agenda he hopes will set him apart among 20 candidates seeking the party's presidential nomination.

Headline: FBI, IRS raid on Baltimore mayor prompts calls for resignation
Article: U.S. authorities on Thursday executed search warrants at the home and offices of Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh, Maryland's Republican governor said on Thursday, prompting further calls for the Democratic city leader to resign.

Headline: Former Senator Lugar, nuclear nonproliferation champion, dies at 87
Article: Centrist Republican Richard Lugar, a soft-spoken foreign policy powerhouse who championed nuclear nonproliferation during 36 years in the U.S. Senate, died on Sunday at age 87.

Headline: Former U.S. deputy attorney general: If Trump was not president, he would be indicted
Article: Former top Justice Department official Sally Yates said on Sunday that if Donald Trump were not president, he would have been indicted on obstruction charges in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

Headline: U.S. envoy signed North Korea document to pay for Warmbier's care: Bolton
Article: The United States signed a document agreeing to pay North Korea for the care of American Otto Warmbier but never paid the $2 million Pyongyang demanded, White House national security adviser John Bolton said on Sunday.

Headline: House panel to interview ex-White House security clearance chief
Article: The Democratic chairman of a congressional committee has put off holding a former White House security clearance chief in contempt until after the panel interviews him about decisions made on some of President Donald Trump's advisers.

Headline: Trump's Fed pick Moore not planning to drop out of Fed consideration: interview
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's pick to fill a vacant seat at the Federal Reserve said on Sunday a smear campaign was being waged against him, after past writings and comments about women sparked renewed criticism by Democratic lawmakers.

Headline: Democratic presidential candidates seek union support at workers' forum
Article: Six Democratic presidential hopefuls declared their support for American workers and a $15 federal minimum wage on Saturday as they seek the backing of labor unions in their battle to become the candidate to take on Republican President Donald Trump next year.

Headline: Oliver North steps down as NRA president amid dispute over 'damaging' information
Article: Retired U.S. Marine Lieutenant Colonel Oliver North will step down as president of the National Rifle Association, North said on Saturday, adding he was being forced out due to his allegations that NRA leaders engaged in financial improprieties.

Headline: Democratic 2020 candidate Moulton says Sanders, Warren too liberal to beat Trump
Article: U.S. congressman Seth Moulton, one of 20 Democrats running for president, criticized rivals Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren on Friday, saying they were so liberal they risked handing President Donald Trump a second White House term.

Headline: Trump pulling U.S. out of U.N. arms treaty, heeding NRA
Article: President Donald Trump told the National Rifle Association on Friday he was pulling the United States out of an international arms treaty signed in 2013 by then-President Barack Obama but opposed by the NRA and other conservative groups.

Headline: White House consents to congressional interview of ex-staffer on security
Article: The White House said on Friday it has consented to a former staffer appearing before a congressional panel for an "on the record interview," accompanied by his lawyers, regarding security clearance policies and procedures.

Headline: Biden raises $6.3 million in first 24 hours of campaign
Article: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden raised $6.3 million in the first 24 hours of his campaign, providing a stronger showing than any of his rivals.

Headline: Pentagon to send more troops to Mexico border, some in contact with migrants
Article: The Pentagon said on Friday that it expected to send about 300 additional troops to the border with Mexico including roughly 100 cooks who would hand out meals, breaking with past policy to avoid troops coming in contact with migrants.

Headline: Trump says U.S. paid no money to North Korea over Warmbier
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday said the United States did not pay any money to North Korea as it sought the release of Otto Warmbier, a day after a report said Trump had approved a $2 million bill from Pyongyang for the American student's care.

Headline: Senator Warren offers military housing bill to boost inspections, transparency
Article: Senator Elizabeth Warren and other Democratic lawmakers on Friday proposed a bill that offers new protections for U.S. military families facing unsafe housing, following a series of Reuters reports revealing squalid conditions in privately managed base homes.

Headline: Under fire, former U.S. V.P. Biden says he did not treat Anita Hill badly
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden, in his first interview as a Democratic presidential candidate, insisted on Friday that he did not treat law professor Anita Hill badly during confirmation hearings for Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas held almost 30 years ago.

Headline: Factbox: Crowd of U.S. Congress committees investigating Trump
Article: At least half a dozen committees of the U.S. Congress are investigating President Donald Trump, who is refusing to cooperate with most of them since the April 18 release of the Mueller report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, setting up a likely court battle.

Headline: Trump vows to withdraw from international arms trade treaty
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday vowed to revoke the United States' status as a signatory of the Arms Trade Treaty, saying he would ask the U.S. Senate not to ratify the pact signed by his Democratic predecessor Barack Obama.

Headline: Factbox: Trump stonewalls House Democrats on multiple probes
Article: President Donald Trump is flatly refusing to cooperate in numerous U.S. congressional probes of himself and his administration, taking a defiant stance that could trigger protracted court fights with House of Representatives Democrats.

Headline: Pompeo aims to lift State Dept. morale with 'ethos' statement
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, hoping to boost workforce morale, unveiled an "ethos" statement on Friday that some former officials viewed with skepticism, partly because an early draft had language they saw as an admonition not to leak to the media.

Headline: Like Trump, Democrat Buttigieg bills himself as a turnaround expert
Article: Four years ago, Donald Trump campaigned in small towns like Marshalltown, Iowa, vowing to restore economic prosperity to the U.S. heartland.

Headline: Trump denies telling White House counsel to fire Mueller from Russia probe
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump denied on Thursday that he had ordered then-White House counsel Don McGahn to fire Special Counsel Robert Mueller from the Russia investigation, moving to undermine McGahn's credibility ahead of a possible congressional testimony.

Headline: UK opposition leader Corbyn says won't attend Trump state dinner
Article: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, said on Friday he had turned down an invitation to a state dinner which will be one of the highlights of U.S. President Donald Trump's visit to Britain in June.

Headline: U.S. judge blocks new Trump abortion rule for health clinics
Article: A federal judge in Washington state on Thursday blocked a Trump administration rule that would prohibit taxpayer-funded family planning clinics from referring patients to abortion providers.

Headline: Explainer: What does it take to remove a U.S. president from office?
Article: The "i word" - impeachment - is swirling around the U.S. Congress since the release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's redacted Russia report, which painted a picture of lies, threats and confusion in Donald Trump's White House.

Headline: Democratic hopeful Hickenlooper to take on monopolies in economic plan
Article: Democratic presidential hopeful John Hickenlooper, a former governor of Colorado, will release an anti-monopoly plan in California on Friday that could challenge the dominance of such companies as Amazon and Google, his campaign told Reuters.

Headline: U.S. judges order Michigan to revamp Republican-drawn districts in gerrymandering case
Article: A panel of federal judges on Thursday ordered Michigan's Republican-controlled legislature to redraw nearly three dozen state and U.S. congressional districts, ruling that the existing lines illegally dilute the power of Democratic voters.

Headline: Explainer: Congress no longer runs a jail, so just how powerful are its subpoenas?
Article: The U.S. Congress does not arrest and detain people for ignoring its subpoenas anymore, but it still has significant power to demand witnesses and documents, and Republican President Donald Trump is putting that power to the test.

Headline: Stephen Moore, Trump's pick for Fed, says he is not withdrawing
Article: Stephen Moore, U.S. President Donald's Trump pick to fill a vacant seat at the Federal Reserve, says he will continue to pursue his nomination even as a trail of his dismissive comments about women and the Midwest have sparked renewed criticism by Democratic lawmakers.

Headline: Former VP Biden's 2020 bid reshapes White House race
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden entered the 2020 Democratic presidential field on Thursday as an instant front-runner, drawing momentum away from other leading candidates and putting new pressure on underperformers to find ways to stay relevant.

Headline: House Democrats demand documents on Trump's DHS purge
Article: The chairmen of three U.S. House committees sought documents on Thursday related to recent Trump administration firings of top Department of Homeland Security officials, escalating tensions between congressional Democrats and the White House over immigration policy.

Headline: White House to Congress: top Trump immigration aide won't testify
Article: The White House has refused a request for President Donald Trump's top immigration aide to testify to Congress, its latest salvo against efforts by Democratic lawmakers to examine the policies of the Trump administration.

Headline: Inspector General clears acting Pentagon chief in probe
Article: The U.S. Defense Department's inspector general on Thursday concluded acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan did not seek preferential treatment of Boeing Co, his former employer, while at the Pentagon. The decision potentially opens the door for U.S. President Donald Trump to formally nominate Shanahan to be defense secretary.

Headline: Former Vice President Biden enters 2020 presidential race
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden on Thursday formally announced his entry into the race for the Democratic party's presidential nomination for the 2020 election.

Headline: Two years and 448 pages later, some Mueller fans ask: was he tough enough?
Article: Many left-leaning Americans regarded Special Counsel Robert Mueller as a paragon of courage and toughness, an unflinching prosecutor who would stop at nothing to ensure justice was served to President Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump immigration plan may increase visas for highly skilled workers: sources
Article: A merit-based immigration proposal being put together by White House senior adviser Jared Kushner could lead to an increase in U.S. visas for highly skilled workers, sources familiar with the effort said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump says he is holding big Pharma accountable in opioid fight
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump touted progress in the fight against opioid abuse on Wednesday and promised to hold drugmakers accountable for their part in the crisis, a day after his administration brought its first related criminal charges against a major drug distributor and company executives.

Headline: House panel chair accuses Trump of 'massive' obstruction; Trump vows to fight
Article: The Democratic chairman of the U.S. House Oversight Committee on Wednesday accused President Donald Trump of a "unprecedented, and growing pattern of obstruction" after he ordered federal employees not to comply with congressional investigations.

Headline: Pompeo sees 'bumpy' North Korea talks, but hopes for several more chances
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Wednesday that U.S. talks with North Korea would be "bumpy," but expressed hope there would be several more chances to discuss how to move forward to the country's denuclearization.

Headline: Moore, under fire from Democrats, remains Trump's Fed pick
Article: Despite new criticism from top Democrats for comments denigrating women and the Midwest, economic commentator Stephen Moore still has the backing of U.S. President Donald Trump for a seat at the Federal Reserve Board.

Headline: Trump renews threat to close Mexican border, send more troops
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday again threatened to close part of the southern border and send more "armed soldiers" to defend it if Mexico did not block a new caravan of migrants traveling toward the United States.

Headline: Former U.S. vice president Biden to announce 2020 election run on Thursday
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden will announce on Thursday that he is seeking the Democratic Party's presidential nomination for the 2020 election, a source familiar with the plans said on Tuesday.

Headline: House oversight chairman cites 'massive' obstruction by Trump, Barr
Article: The Democratic chairman of the House Oversight Committee accused the Trump administration of a "massive, unprecedented, and growing pattern of obstruction" for ordering federal employees not to comply with congressional investigations.

Headline: Minorities, older adults boost Biden atop 2020 Democratic field: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Former Vice President Joe Biden, expected to declare his run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday, leads all other candidates in the race and draws his strongest levels of support from minorities and older adults, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos public opinion poll.

Headline: U.S. federal judge to block Trump's new abortion rule: media, activists
Article: A federal judge in the U.S. state of Oregon will block a move by the Trump administration to cut off federal money to family planning clinics that offer abortion or refer women to abortion providers, activists and media reports said late on Tuesday.

Headline: After Trump tweet, UK spy agency says claim it spied on Trump is utterly ridiculous
Article: Britain's main eavesdropping agency on Wednesday said allegations that it had been asked by the Obama administration to spy on Donald Trump after the 2016 presidential election were utterly ridiculous and should be ignored.

Headline: Democrats to press star witness of Mueller report to repeat performance in Congress
Article: Donald McGahn, the former White House counsel described in the Mueller report as repeatedly standing up to President Donald Trump, could become a star witness again if congressional Democrats get their way in their investigation of whether Trump used his office to obstruct justice.

Headline: U.S. Interior Department watchdog to probe six senior officials
Article: The Interior Department's inspector general's office confirmed on Tuesday it is investigating whether six high-level agency officials violated federal ethics rules by interacting with former employers or clients while working on official business.

Headline: Mnuchin says he cannot meet deadline to turn over Trump tax returns to House panel
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Tuesday he cannot comply with a demand by a House of Representatives committee to turn over President Donald Trump's tax returns "until it is determined to be consistent with law."

Headline: Trump opposed to aides testifying to Congress on Mueller report: Washington Post
Article: President Donald Trump is opposed to current and former White House aides testifying to congressional committees on Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia report, the Washington Post quoted him as saying on Tuesday.

Headline: House panel to vote on holding White House ex-official in contempt
Article: A U.S. House committee will vote on holding a former White House security director in contempt for failing to appear for questioning on allegations the Trump administration inappropriately granted clearances to some of the president's advisers, the panel's chairman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Treasury's Mnuchin misses congressional deadline to hand over Trump tax returns
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin failed to meet a final congressional deadline on Tuesday for turning over President Donald Trump's tax returns to lawmakers, setting the stage for a possible court battle between Congress and the administration.

Headline: Supreme Court poised to give Trump victory on census citizenship question
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court's conservative majority on Tuesday appeared poised to hand President Donald Trump a victory on his administration's plan to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census, a move opponents call a Republican effort to deter immigrants from taking part.

Headline: Trump orders administration officials not to attend White House correspondents dinner
Article: President Donald Trump, who bemoaned his treatment by the news media in a flurry of tweets on Tuesday, has barred members of his staff and administration from attending the White House Correspondents' Association dinner on Saturday, officials said.

Headline: Trump to meet Democrats on $1 trillion infrastructure push on April 30: sources
Article: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer will meet with President Donald Trump on April 30 at the White House to discuss the fate of proposals to boost U.S. infrastructure repairs by at least $1 trillion, according to a congressional aide and an administration official.

Headline: Trump 'not inclined' to give tax returns to House panel: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is unlikely hand over his tax returns to lawmakers despite a final deadline from the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, a White House spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Judge sets May 14 hearing in Trump bid to block Congress demand on his finances
Article: A U.S. judge on Tuesday said he would hear oral arguments on May 14 in a lawsuit brought by President Donald Trump seeking to block a congressional subpoena for information about eight years of Trump's personal and business finances.

Headline: IRS fails to meet congressional deadline for Trump tax returns
Article: A deadline for the U.S. Internal Revenue Service to turn President Donald Trump's tax returns over to a congressional tax oversight committee expired on Tuesday without lawmakers receiving the documents, a committee aide said.

Headline: Explainer: Can Democrats get hold of the full Mueller report?
Article: Congressional Democrats have taken legal action to obtain the full Russia report by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, without redactions, as well as other evidence he uncovered in his 22-month investigation but there are obstacles in their way.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers press Trump administration on Central American aid
Article: The Republican and Democratic leaders of the U.S. House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee urged the Trump administration to reconsider its plan to cut aid to Central America, warning in a letter released on Tuesday that it could lead to increased Chinese influence.

Headline: Trump's tax law to boost incomes more in Republican states: researchers
Article: A 2017 tax overhaul championed by President Donald Trump will cut household taxes more in Republican-leaning states than in states that lean Democratic, according to research published by the U.S. central bank on Tuesday.

Headline: Kushner says Mueller probe damaged U.S. more than Russia did
Article: White House advisor and President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner said on Tuesday that Robert Mueller's special counsel investigation of Russia's role in the 2016 election harmed U.S. democracy more than Moscow's interference did.

Headline: Israeli minister condemns Sanders' remarks on 'racist' Netanyahu government
Article: An Israeli cabinet minister condemned U.S. Democratic Party presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders on Tuesday for describing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government as racist over its treatment of Palestinians.

Headline: Trump to review new immigration proposal in coming days: Kushner
Article: Top advisers to President Donald Trump will present him with a proposed immigration plan in coming days that will cover border security and immigration reform, his senior adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner said on Tuesday.

Headline: Israel to name new town on Golan after Trump: Netanyahu
Article: Israel said on Tuesday it would name a new community on the Golan Heights after U.S. President Donald Trump as an expression of gratitude for his recognition of its claim of sovereignty over the strategic plateau.

Headline: Kushner says Trump Middle East plan to be unveiled in June
Article: President Donald Trump's long-delayed proposal to break a deadlock in finding a resolution to the conflict between the Israelis and Palestinians is to be unveiled after the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan ends in June, White House senior adviser Jared Kushner said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump to make state visit to Britain in June
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will make a state visit to the United Kingdom in June, Buckingham Palace announced on Tuesday, a trip Britain hopes will cement transatlantic relations but one that immediately prompted criticism and promises of protests.

Headline: Trump criticizes Twitter in tweet, urges 'fairer' social media
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday called for the creation of "more, and fairer" social media companies in response to discrimination he said he has faced as a Republican from Twitter Inc.

Headline: Trump will travel to France, meet with Macron in June: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump and his wife will travel to France on June 6, where Trump will meet with French President Emmanuel Macron, the White House said in a statement on Tuesday.

Headline: Democratic presidential candidates divided over impeaching Trump
Article: A group of Democratic presidential candidates were divided on Monday over whether Republican President Donald Trump should be impeached, reflecting a broader split in the Democratic Party over how to react to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report into Russian election meddling.

Headline: Mexico flags U.S. border delays as harmful to both countries
Article: Mexico's Foreign Ministry said on Monday that speeding up the flow of goods on the U.S. border is a matter of urgency and that slowdowns are detrimental to both economies, after bottlenecks have held up trade following a row over migration.

Headline: House panel chair subpoenas ex-White House counsel McGahn on Mueller inquiry
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler on Monday subpoenaed former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify before the panel in its investigation of possible obstruction of justice by President Donald Trump.

Headline: On staff following orders, Trump says: 'Nobody disobeys me'
Article: President Donald Trump dismissed questions from reporters on Monday about his staff's reluctance to carry out his orders and the chances of impeachment proceedings in the U.S. Congress, days after the Mueller report highlighted both issues.

Headline: Trump sues to block Congress subpoena for his financial records
Article: President Donald Trump on Monday filed suit to keep U.S. lawmakers from obtaining his financial records, the first salvo in what promises to be an escalating legal battle with Democrats in Congress.

Headline: Democrats to continue probes of Trump amid no consensus on impeachment
Article: U.S. House Democrats are divided over whether to proceed directly to impeach President Donald Trump after Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe, but they can still hold Trump accountable without impeachment, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Monday.

Headline: Elizabeth Warren proposes canceling billions in student loan debt
Article: U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the 2020 presidential election, wants to cancel billions of dollars in student loan debt and make college cheaper for students going forward.

Headline: Congressman Moulton enters Democratic 2020 presidential race
Article: U.S. Representative Seth Moulton entered the 2020 Democratic presidential race on Monday as a long-shot contender in a contest that now includes almost 20 candidates.

Headline: Top Democrat on U.S. House Oversight Committee says Trump lawsuit has no legal basis
Article: Elijah Cummings, chairman of the U.S. House Oversight Committee, criticized as "baseless" a lawsuit filed on Monday by President Donald Trump to try to block subpoenas from the committee seeking years worth of financial documents from the president.

Headline: Companies warn Trump: Census citizenship question could be costly
Article: (This April 17 story corrects the tenth paragraph to show DeVere Kutscher is no longer executive director of the Census Business Coalition.)

Headline: Top Democrats leave open option of Trump impeachment after Mueller report
Article: Top congressional Democrats left the door open on Sunday to the impeachment of U.S. President Donald Trump, but said they would first need to complete their own investigations into whether he obstructed justice in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe.

Headline: Vulnerable House Democrats tread carefully in wake of Mueller report
Article: Vulnerable House Democrats, mindful of President Donald Trump's continued strength among Republican voters, are using caution in how they respond to the special counsel's report, which detailed Trump's efforts to thwart the investigation into Russian efforts to help him win the White House.

Headline: Republican Romney says he is 'sickened' by Trump's behavior during Russia probe
Article: Former Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney said on Friday he was "sickened" by the dishonesty of U.S. President Donald Trump and people around him as portrayed in a report on Russia's attempts to influence the 2016 election.

Headline: Trump approval drops 3 points to 2019 low after release of Mueller report: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: The number of Americans who approve of President Donald Trump dropped by 3 percentage points to the lowest level of the year following the release of a special counsel report detailing Russian interference in the last U.S. presidential election, according to an exclusive Reuters/Ipsos public opinion poll.

Headline: Mueller report strengthens resolves on both sides of political spectrum
Article: After months as volunteer activists demanding that U.S. President Donald Trump be impeached, Eileen and Michael O'Brien sat on their couch on Thursday, cracked open a laptop and began to read the 448-page special counsel report that liberals have dreamed would make impeachment a reality.

Headline: Top Democrats in Congress reject Barr's proposal to limit Mueller report access
Article: Top Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives and Senate on Friday rejected Attorney General William Barr's proposal to allow them access to a less-redacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation report.

Headline: Democrats make legal bid for all Russia probe evidence, Trump poll numbers drop
Article: Congressional Democrats on Friday took legal action to get hold of all of U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's evidence from his inquiry into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, as the probe's findings hit President Donald Trump's poll ratings.

Headline: Trump lawyers reviewed Mueller report for 10 hours before it was made public
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's personal lawyers spent at least 10 hours reviewing Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian meddling in the 2016 election before it was made public, two of the lawyers told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: Barr releases Mueller's report - and feels the heat
Article: Attorney General William Barr could have buried Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia report deep in the recesses of the U.S. Justice Department and simply told the public that President Donald Trump would not face criminal prosecution.

Headline: Biden to announce U.S. presidential run on Wednesday: report
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden plans to make a widely expected announcement of his candidacy for the presidency in a video on Wednesday, the Atlantic reported on Friday, citing sources close to Biden's top aides.

Headline: Supreme Court girds for fight over Trump census citizenship question
Article: Sitting on a working-class commercial strip in the shadows of an above-ground rail line, a group called Make the Road New York's busy street-level offices are easy to miss. But its mission to support and advocate for immigrants is front and center.

Headline: House Judiciary Committee issues subpoena for full Mueller report
Article: U.S. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler issued a subpoena on Friday to obtain the full Russia investigation report by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, saying he cannot accept a redacted version that "leaves most of Congress in the dark."

Headline: Kremlin says Mueller report shows no evidence of Russian meddling
Article: The Kremlin said on Friday that U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's long-awaited report did not contain any evidence the Russian state had meddled in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Headline: House panel chairman expected to issue subpoena for full Mueller report: source
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler is expected to issue a subpoena on Friday for Special Counsel Robert Mueller's full Russia investigation report and underlying evidence, a source familiar with the matter said.

Headline: Russia shrugs off Mueller report: agencies
Article: Russia's foreign ministry on Friday dismissed the findings of the long-awaited report by U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller and said it had failed to present any evidence of Russian meddling in U.S. elections, Russian news agencies reported.

Headline: Pelosi declines to comment on possibility of Trump impeachment
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday declined to comment on whether Congress might launch impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump, saying it was not appropriate to criticize him while abroad.

Headline: Rights group condemns U.S. 'vigilante' treatment of migrants on border
Article: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Mexico on Thursday called for state authorities to investigate a small group of armed U.S. citizens who they alleged are illegally detaining migrants entering the United States.

Headline: Trump backer Erik Prince's account of Russian banker contact differs from Mueller report
Article: Erik Prince, founder of the now defunct Blackwater security firm and a supporter of Donald Trump's 2016 presidential run, appears to have misled the U.S. Congress on details of contact he had with a Russian banker in January 2017, Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report released on Thursday shows.

Headline: In unflattering detail, Mueller report reveals Trump actions to impede inquiry
Article: (Advisory: Story includes language that might offend some readers.)

Headline: Mueller report leaves Democrats in a quandary
Article: Democrats clamored for the speedy release of U.S. Special Counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s findings of his probe into whether President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign colluded with Russia. Now they finally have them, they are confronted with a choice - stay on the attack or move on.

Headline: How Mueller's decision on obstruction helped save Trump
Article: The U.S. Attorney General decided that President Donald Trump did not obstruct a probe into whether his campaign colluded with Russia, but some legal experts said prosecutors laid out a wealth of evidence to the contrary and that they intended to leave that determination to Congress.

Headline: Mueller finds no conspiracy, but extensive Trump-Russia contacts

Headline: Mueller reveals Trump's staff, associates sometimes ignored him
Article: U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's 448-page report released on Thursday detailed more than just Oval Office arguments and Trump Tower meetings.

Article: Some U.S. lawmakers will be able to read a less-redacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report beginning next week, the Justice Department said in a letter on Thursday to the chairmen of the House and Senate judiciary committees.

Headline: Explainer: Five ways Trump's moves to stem border surge have hit hurdles

Headline: U.S. court upholds most of California's 'sanctuary' migrant laws
Article: The Trump administration lost a court bid on Thursday aimed at striking down California's "sanctuary" statutes that prevent local law enforcement from helping the U.S. government's crackdown on illegal immigration.

Headline: House Democratic leader Hoyer: impeachment 'not worthwhile': CNN

Headline: Factbox: New revelations from the Mueller report

Headline: House Democrat Nadler sees evidence of obstruction in Mueller report
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler said on Thursday that Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation report outlines "disturbing evidence that President Trump engaged in obstruction of justice and other misconduct."

Headline: Top Democrats say Mueller report undercuts Barr claims on Trump obstruction
Article: The two top Democrats in Congress said on Thursday that Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report undercuts claims by Attorney General William Barr that President Donald Trump did not obstruct justice in the federal Russia probe.

Headline: Mueller report provides intimate scenes from the Trump White House
Article: (Note: Story includes language throughout that will offend some readers.)

Headline: Factbox: Long-awaited Mueller report is finally out. Now what?

Headline: Trump curses Mueller appointment: 'This is the end of my presidency'
Article: (Advisory: Story includes language that might offend some readers.)

Headline: White House counsel refused Trump's order to fire Mueller - report

Headline: Factbox: Guilty pleas, indictments abound in Trump-Russia probe
Article: Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russia's role in the 2016 U.S. election has ensnared dozens of people, including several advisers to President Donald Trump and a series of Russian nationals and companies.

Headline: Factbox: Five things to look for in Mueller's Trump-Russia report
Article: Attorney General William Barr has provided only a glimpse of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on the inquiry into Russia's role in the 2016 U.S. election, with many details expected to emerge when the document is released on Thursday.

Headline: Instant View: Reaction to Mueller's report on Russia's role in 2016 U.S. election
Article: Key reaction to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's long-awaited report on Russia's role in the 2016 U.S. election, released on Thursday:

Headline: Mueller report does not conclude Trump committed crime but does not exonerate him
Article: Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election did not conclude President Donald Trump committed a crime but also did not exonerate him, Mueller's report said.

Headline: Report says Trump foresaw end of presidency when told of special counsel investigation: report

Article: Evidence from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation indicates President Donald Trump intended to encourage his former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, "not to cooperate with the government," according to Mueller's report.

Headline: Trump says Muller report found 'no collusion, no obstruction'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday he was a "having a good day" following the release of the Mueller report, adding, "It's called no collusion, no obstruction."

Article: The report from Special Counsel Robert Mueller said there is "substantial evidence" that President Donald Trump fired FBI Director James Comey due to his "unwillingness to publicly state that the president was not personally under investigation."

Headline: Factbox: Five things Attorney General Barr revealed about the Mueller report

Headline: Barr says redactions to Mueller report were not made due to executive privilege

Headline: Barr says Mueller probe did not establish Trump coordination with Russia

Headline: Barr says Mueller did not uncover evidence Trump obstructed Russia probe

Headline: Timeline: Big moments in Mueller investigation of Russian meddling in 2016 U.S. election

Headline: Factbox: Smoke or fire? Contacts between Trump campaign and Russia

Headline: Trump adviser visits Moscow for Kremlin talks

Headline: Trump aide Stephen Miller asked to testify on immigration to House panel

Headline: Some U.S. lawmakers to see less-redacted version of Mueller report: prosecutor

Headline: White House, Justice Department officials discussed Mueller report: media

Headline: Trump lifts ban on U.S. lawsuits against foreign firms in Cuba
Article: The Trump administration is lifting a long-standing ban against U.S. citizens filing lawsuits against foreign companies that use properties seized by Cubaâ€™s Communist government since Fidel Castroâ€™s 1959 revolution, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Wednesday.

Headline: Kushner urges 'open mind' on upcoming Mideast plan: source

Headline: Hints, but no proof of crime, in Mueller's hunt for a Trump-Russia conspiracy

Headline: Factbox: Five things to look for in Mueller's Trump-Russia report
Article: Attorney General William Barr has provided only a glimpse of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on the inquiry into Russia's role in the 2016 U.S. election, with many details expected to emerge when the document is finally released.

Headline: Trump wishes 'no ill will' with tweet on Muslim lawmaker: White House
Article: President Donald Trump did not wish any harm in his Twitter post criticizing Democratic congresswoman Ilhan Omar's comments on the 9/11 attacks, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said on Sunday.

Article: North Dakota Republican Governor Doug Burgum signed legislation on Wednesday making it a crime for doctors to perform a second-trimester abortion using instruments like forceps and clamps to remove the fetus from the womb.

Headline: Mexican labor bill nabs key Congress vote, spurred by Pelosi warning
Article: (This April 11 story corrects to include dropped word 'not' in paragraph 6)

Headline: Trump, in talks with South Korea's Moon, says sanctions on North Korea to stay in place
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday expressed a willingness to hold a third summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un but said in talks with South Korean President Moon Jae-in that Washington would leave sanctions in place on Pyongyang.

Headline: SoftBank picking its battles with U.S. national security committee

Headline: White House's Kudlow supports Fed's Powell and Cain nomination

Headline: U.S. EPA chief defends big energy projects, says climate not top priority
Article: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency will unveil a proposal to speed state-level permitting decisions for energy infrastructure projects soon, the agencyâ€™s chief told Reuters on Thursday, blasting states that have blocked coal terminals and gas pipelines on environmental grounds.

Headline: Text: Transcript of Reuters interview with EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler

Headline: U.S. attorney general's 'spying' remarks anger Democrats

Headline: U.S. House Democrats blame Trump for worsening border crisis

Headline: U.S. Senate leader McConnell notes Republican worries over Cain serving on Fed

Headline: U.S. Senate leader McConnell still weighing response to Saudi journalist's death

Headline: In leaky White House, Trump team keeps Middle East peace plan secret

Headline: McConnell calls for bipartisan U.S. immigration legislation

Headline: Trump to hold event Friday on 5G, rural broadband: White House

Headline: South Korea's Moon to seek inter-Korean summit soon to facilitate nuclear talks

Headline: U.S. Senator Grassley seeks DOE information on small refinery waivers: letter

Headline: U.S. presidential hopeful Warren proposes new corporate profit tax

Headline: U.S. Senate votes to confirm lobbyist Bernhardt as Interior Secretary

Headline: Trump says he is discussing potential further meetings with North Korea's Kim

Headline: Ex-Obama White House Counsel expects to be charged over Ukraine work: statement

Headline: Explainer: What might be blacked out of Mueller's Trump-Russia report?

Headline: Beto O'Rourke's past support for charter schools scrutinized in 2020 White House bid
