Article: The governor of Illinois vowed on Tuesday to seek tighter gun control measures after learning the man who shot five co-workers dead last week was wrongly granted a firearms permit but never forced to surrender his weapon.

Headline: Bernie Sanders seeks U.S. presidency again in 2020
Article: U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont progressive whose 2016 White House campaign garnered fervent grassroots support and pushed the Democratic Party sharply to the left, said on Tuesday he would again seek the party's presidential nomination in 2020.

Headline: Trump confident he will prevail against lawsuits over emergency declaration
Article: President Donald Trump expressed confidence on Tuesday that he would prevail against a lawsuit filed by 16 U.S. states seeking to block his declaration of a national emergency to fund a wall along the U.S. border with Mexico.

Headline: North Carolina poll workers admit improperly running early results
Article: North Carolina poll workers told election officials on Tuesday they illegally viewed early election results last year, the latest evidence in a probe of voting irregularities in a still unsettled congressional race.

Headline: Former Trump adviser Stone ordered to appear in court over Instagram posts
Article: Roger Stone, a former political adviser to U.S. President Donald Trump, was ordered on Tuesday to appear in court this week over Instagram posts that chastised and appeared to threaten the judge presiding over his criminal trial.

Headline: Bernie Sanders faces new challenges in crowded 2020 U.S. presidential race
Article: Bernie Sanders is back for another White House run, but this one promises to be far different than the improbable 2016 presidential campaign that made the Vermont senator a political force.

Headline: Democrats drop lawsuit against former acting attorney general
Article: Three Democratic U.S. senators on Tuesday dropped a lawsuit that challenged the appointment of former acting attorney general Matthew Whitaker, who stepped down from his post last week when the Senate confirmed William Barr to the position.

Headline: Republican backlash against Trump EPA pick fueled by 'biofuel reset'
Article: EPA acting administrator Andrew Wheeler rejected a proposal from his staff that would have reduced the ambition of the nationâ€™s biofuel policy over the next three years, arguing the targeted range it included for annual ethanol consumption was too low, according to two sources familiar with the matter.

Headline: Trump's 'relentless attack' on FBI prompted memoir by former official: NPR
Article: Former top FBI official Andrew McCabe decried the "relentless attack" he said U.S. President Donald Trump has launched against the agency, according to released excerpts of an interview with NPR's Morning Edition, to be aired early Monday.

Headline: Ginsburg gets back to business in return to U.S. Supreme Court
Article: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, returning to the bench for the first time since undergoing lung cancer surgery in December, jumped right into the fray on Tuesday, posing the first question in oral arguments as is her custom.

Headline: U.S. states sue Trump administration in showdown over border wall funds
Article: A coalition of 16 U.S. states led by California sued President Donald Trump and top members of his administration on Monday to block his decision to declare a national emergency to obtain funds for building a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

Headline: Vice President Pence picks familiar face for chief of staff
Article: U.S. Vice President Mike Pence has chosen a familiar White House figure for his new chief of staff: Marc Short, who was President Donald Trump's top legislative aide until he left in July.

Headline: U.S. top court rejects ex-congressman's appeal in spending scandal
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected a bid by Republican former congressman Aaron Schock, who resigned in 2015 amid questions about spending on his lavish "Downton Abbey"-inspired Washington office, to escape charges accusing him of defauding the government while a member of the House of Representatives.

Headline: U.S. presidential hopeful Warren urges universal childcare, 'ultra-millionaire' tax
Article: U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat running for president, on Tuesday proposed a universal childcare program, paid for by a tax on high-net-worth individuals, to help families unable to find affordable care.

Headline: Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein to step down in March: official
Article: Rod Rosenstein, the U.S. deputy attorney general who appointed a special counsel to investigate possible ties between Russia and President Donald Trump's campaign, is expected to step down by mid March, a Justice Department official said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox: Democratic presidential contenders jump into 2020 fray
Article: U.S. Democrats, anxious to get started on their quest to recapture the White House in 2020, are lining up to launch campaigns in what is quickly becoming a crowded field of presidential contenders.

Headline: No need for Shinzo Abe: Trump already nominated for Nobel Peace Prize
Article: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is not saying whether or not he nominated Donald Trump for this year's Nobel Peace Prize, but the question may be moot: the U.S. president has been put forward by others for the prestigious award.

Headline: Bernie Sanders launches second Democratic U.S. presidential bid
Article: U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders, the progressive populist who mounted a fierce challenge to front-runner Hillary Clinton in the 2016 White House campaign, said on Tuesday he would again seek the Democratic Partyâ€™s presidential nomination in 2020.

Headline: Former Trump adviser Stone apologizes to judge after photo post
Article: President Donald Trump's former adviser Roger Stone apologized on Monday after posting on Instagram a photo of the judge overseeing his trial for allegedly making false statements to Congress, obstruction and witness tampering.

Headline: Presidents Day protests decry Trump's emergency declaration
Article: Activists in Washington, Chicago and dozens of other U.S. cities protested on Monday's Presidents Day holiday against President Donald Trump's declaration of a national emergency to secure funding for a U.S.-Mexico border wall.

Headline: Official cites 'unlawful' balloting in U.S. congressional vote
Article: A Republican operative directed an unlawful absentee ballot scheme in North Carolina's 9th congressional district and tried to hide the evidence, an election official said on Monday at a hearing that could lead to a new vote in the disputed contest.

Headline: Exclusive: Air Force to push Congress for military housing tenant bill of rights
Article: Aiming to grant military families far greater say to challenge hazardous housing, the U.S. Air Force told Reuters Monday it will push Congress to enact a tenant bill of rights allowing families the power to withhold rent or break leases to escape unsafe conditions.

Headline: Trump policies unite allies against him at European security forum
Article: In 2009, then U.S. Vice President Joe Biden came to Munich to "press the reset button" with Russia. A decade later he came again to offer the world better relations, this time with his own country.

Headline: Japan's PM nominated Trump for Nobel Peace Prize on U.S. request: Asahi
Article: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe nominated U.S. President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize last autumn after receiving a request from the U.S. government to do so, the Asahi newspaper reported on Sunday.

Headline: U.S. Senator Rubio warns Venezuela's Maduro not to act against opposition
Article: U.S. Senator Marco Rubio, visiting the Colombia-Venezuela border on Sunday, warned Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro of severe consequences if he takes action against the country's opposition leader and self-declared president or U.S. citizens.

Headline: Venezuela denies EU lawmakers entry given 'conspiratorial motives'
Article: Venezuela denied a group of European Parliament deputies entry into the country on Sunday, arguing they had "conspiratorial motives" for flying to Caracas in the throes of a political crisis.

Headline: California tells Trump that lawsuit over border wall is 'imminent'
Article: California will "imminently" challenge President Donald Trump's declaration of a national emergency to obtain funds for a U.S.-Mexico border wall, state Attorney General Xavier Becerra said on Sunday.

Headline: Pompeo to visit Kuwait next month, says Kuwait's deputy foreign minister
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will visit Kuwait next month to hold the third round of strategic dialogue between the two countries, Kuwait's state news agency quoted the deputy foreign minister, Khaled Al-Jarallah, as saying on Sunday.

Headline: Weld says six more years of Trump 'antics' would be bad for America
Article: Former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld, the first Republican to challenge President Donald Trump for their party's presidential nomination in 2020, said on Sunday that six more years of Trump's "antics" in the White House would be bad for America.

Headline: Ex-congressman Weiner released from prison after sexting scandal
Article: Anthony Weiner, the disgraced former congressman who helped play a role in Hillary Clinton's defeat in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, has been released from federal prison after serving about 14 months for exchanging sexually explicit texts with a 15-year-old girl.

Headline: Acting Pentagon chief not decided yet on funding border wall
Article: Acting U.S. Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan said on Saturday he had not yet determined whether a border wall with Mexico was a military necessity or how much Pentagon money would be used.

Headline: Trump's choice for U.N. ambassador withdraws: State Department
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's choice for ambassador to the United Nations, Heather Nauert, has withdrawn from consideration for the job for family reasons, the State Department said on Saturday.

Headline: Trump declares emergency for border wall, House panel launches probe
Article: President Donald Trump on Friday declared a national emergency in a bid to fund his promised wall at the U.S.-Mexico border without congressional approval, an action Democrats vowed to challenge as a violation of the U.S. Constitution.

Headline: Mueller seeks tough sentence for ex-Trump campaign chairman Manafort
Article: Prosecutors for Special Counsel Robert Mueller urged a federal judge in Virginia on Friday to impose a strict prison sentence for President Donald Trump's former campaign manager Paul Manafort, after a jury last year convicted him on eight counts of bank and tax fraud.

Headline: Joe Biden says will decide soon whether to run for presidency
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden, a Democrat, said on Saturday he had not yet decided whether to run for president in 2020 but would do so "in the near term".

Headline: Legal challenges to Trump emergency declaration face uphill battle
Article: Democratic lawmakers, states and others mulling legal challenges to President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration to obtain funds to build a U.S.-Mexico border wall face an uphill and probably losing battle in a showdown likely to be decided by the conservative-majority Supreme Court, legal experts said.

Headline: California, New York promise legal challenges to Trump's emergency declaration
Article: California and New York suggested on Friday they would take legal action against President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration aimed at freeing up billions of dollars in funds to build a wall along the U.S. border with Mexico.

Headline: Trump to nominate Satterfield ambassador to Turkey
Article: President Donald Trump intends to nominate David Satterfield, a veteran diplomat with deep experience in the Middle East, to be U.S. ambassador to Turkey, the White House said on Friday.

Headline: U.S. transport official is top candidate to replace Rosenstein: sources
Article: U.S. Transportation Department Deputy Secretary Jeffrey Rosen is the leading candidate to replace Rod Rosenstein as deputy attorney general to serve alongside new Attorney General William Barr, two administration officials told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: U.S. judge issues gag order in trial of former Trump adviser Stone
Article: Self-described "dirty trickster" Roger Stone will still be able to speak about his upcoming criminal trial under a gag order issued on Friday, but the U.S. judge handling the case warned the former adviser to Donald Trump that he might want to choose his words carefully.

Headline: Mueller says searches yielded evidence of Stone-WikiLeaks communications
Article: U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller disclosed for the first time on Friday that his office has evidence of communications between Roger Stone, a longtime adviser to President Donald Trump, and WikiLeaks related to the release of hacked Democratic Party emails.

Headline: Trump to nominate Jeffrey Byard as U.S. emergency management chief
Article: President Donald Trump intends to nominate Jeffrey Byard, a senior official at the U.S. Federal Emergency Management Agency, to be its administrator, replacing Brock Long who said this week he was resigning, the White House said on Friday.

Headline: Texas landowners file first lawsuit to block Trump's national emergency declaration
Article: Three Texas landowners and an environmental group filed the first lawsuit on Friday challenging President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration aimed at freeing up billions of dollars to build a wall along the U.S. border with Mexico, the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen said.

Headline: Senate inquiry to probe Russian agent's meetings with Treasury, Fed
Article: The U.S. Senate Finance Committee has launched an inquiry into meetings in 2015 between top Obama administration officials, a Russian central banker and Maria Butina, who has pleaded guilty to conspiring to work as a Russian agent to influence American foreign policy.

Headline: U.S. Supreme Court to decide legality of census citizenship query
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court will decide the fate of a fiercely contested plan by President Donald Trump's administration to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census, agreeing on Friday to an expedited review of a judge's ruling blocking the plan.

Headline: House panel announces emergency declaration probe in letter to Trump
Article: A key committee in the U.S. House of Representatives announced on Friday it was launching an immediate investigation into President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration, saying his move to fund his promised wall at the U.S.-Mexico border raised constitutional and statutory issues.

Headline: White House spokeswoman Sanders says she was interviewed in Russia probe
Article: White House press secretary Sarah Sanders said on Friday she had been interviewed by the special counsel investigating Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Headline: Trump puts on a few pounds, enters obese range: medical report
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump has gained weight over the past year and is now in the obese range, although he remains in "very good health overall," according to results of an annual presidential physical examination conducted last week.

Headline: Philadelphia beats U.S. appeal in sanctuary city case
Article: A federal appeals court said on Friday the Trump administration cannot cut off grants to Philadelphia for its refusal to cooperate with immigration authorities seeking to deport immigrants who are in the country illegally.

Headline: After Auschwitz visit, Pence accuses Iran of Nazi-like anti-Semitism
Article: U.S. Vice President Mike Pence accused Iran of Nazi-like anti-Semitism on Friday, maintaining his harsh rhetoric against Tehran just a day he attacked European powers for trying to undermine U.S. sanctions on the Islamic Republic.

Headline: Trump, in proclamation, says military help needed due to 'gravity' of emergency
Article: President Donald Trump, in a proclamation on Friday declaring an emergency at the U.S. border with Mexico, said he need to call upon the military for assistance "because of the gravity of the current emergency situation."

Headline: Trump makes his case for Nobel Peace Prize, complains he'll never get it
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump made the case on Friday that he deserves to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his work on North Korea and Syria, but complained he probably would never get the honor.

Headline: White House eyes $8 billion in overall wall funds from emergency: official
Article: The Trump administration has identified roughly $8 billion in U.S. government funds that President Donald Trump could tap to pay for work this year on his proposed U.S.-Mexico border wall under a national emergency, a top U.S. White House official said on Friday.

Headline: Massachusetts ex-governor first Republican to challenge Trump for 2020
Article: Bill Weld, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts, said on Friday he will challenge U.S. President Donald Trump for their party's presidential nomination in 2020, saying the country was in "grave peril."

Headline: U.S. derides Venezuela's accusation of lacing aid with poison
Article: The United States scoffed on Friday at Venezuela's accusation that it was poisoning humanitarian aid, and urged allies to stop the "decrepit, dictatorial regime" of President Nicolas Maduro from chairing U.N. arms talks.

Headline: Top Democrats say Trump is shredding Constitution with emergency declaration
Article: The two top Democrats in the U.S. Congress on Friday said President Donald Trump was violating Congress' constitutionally granted power of the purse by issuing an emergency declaration to obtain funds to build a border wall, and they threatened potential legal action.

Headline: U.S. and Iceland boost trade ties, discuss Arctic security
Article: The United States and Iceland have agreed to set up formal economic channels to boost trade and business investment, the countries' top diplomats said on Friday.

Headline: U.S. sanctions five Venezuelans, ratcheting up pressure on Maduro
Article: The U.S. Treasury Department on Friday imposed sanctions on top Venezuelan security officials and the head of Venezuelan state oil company PDVSA as it ratcheted up pressure on embattled Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro over an election it says was illegal.

Headline: Maduro understands Venezuelans are rejecting him: Pompeo
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Friday Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro's invitation to a U.S. envoy for talks in Caracas "demonstrates his increasing understanding that the Venezuelan people are rejecting him and his model of governance".

Headline: Trump set to declare border emergency, sign shutdown-averting bill
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump was poised on Friday to declare a national emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border, a move that Democrats vowed to challenge as an unconstitutional attempt to fund his proposed border wall without approval from Congress.

Headline: Trump vows emergency declaration over wall, agrees to shutdown-averting bill
Article: President Donald Trump vowed on Thursday to declare a national emergency in an attempt to fund his U.S.-Mexico border wall without congressional approval, a step likely to plunge him into a battle with Congress over constitutional powers.

Headline: Senate passes border security bill, sends to House
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday voted overwhelmingly to avert another partial government shutdown with bipartisan spending legislation that funds new barriers for part of the U.S.-Mexico border, but not the $5.7 billion that President Donald Trump sought for a wall.

Headline: Explainer: Trump risks legal fight with emergency threat on wall
Article: President Donald Trump will almost certainly face legal challenges over his decision to declare a national emergency to get additional funding for a U.S.-Mexico border wall, circumventing the power of Congress to set spending policy.

Headline: House advances border security funds toward final passage
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday approved the rules for debating a bill to avert another partial federal government shutdown by funding several agencies but denying President Donald Trump's demand for $5.7 billion to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border.

Headline: Singapore to Hanoi: The bumpy diplomatic road since Trump and Kim first met
Article: It's been the better part of a year since U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un stood face to face for the first time at their unprecedented summit in Singapore.

Headline: House passes border security bill, sends to Trump
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday approved a bipartisan border security bill aimed at averting a government shutdown and sent it to President Donald Trump, including new barriers for part of the U.S.-Mexico border but not the $5.7 billion he sought.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers want more information on Saudi journalist's death
Article: Republican and Democratic members of the U.S. Senate asked the Trump administration on Thursday to tell them more about the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at a Saudi consulate last year, days after a missed deadline for a detailed report on his death prompted an angry bipartisan backlash.

Headline: U.S. trade envoys to meet China's Xi, no decision on deadline extension
Article: The Trump administration's top two negotiators in trade talks with China will meet on Friday with Chinese President Xi Jinping, but there has been no decision to extend a March 1 U.S. deadline for a deal, White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow said on Thursday.

Headline: Explainer: What's at stake in U.S.-China trade talks
Article: U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin are in Beijing this week as Chinese and American negotiators try to hammer out a trade deal to ease a trade war and avert an increase in U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods scheduled for March 2.

Headline: Democratic debates could feature as many as 20 candidates
Article: Democrats, anticipating a sprawling 2020 presidential field, are planning to hold prime-time debates in June and July on back-to-back evenings to make room for as many as 20 candidates.

Headline: Trump's firing of FBI head Comey triggered probe: ex-official McCabe
Article: Former top FBI official Andrew McCabe said he began an obstruction of justice and counterintelligence investigation involving U.S. President Donald Trump and his ties to Russia after Trump fired bureau Director James Comey in May 2017, CBS News reported on Thursday.

Headline: Pelosi threatens possible legal action over expected Trump emergency declaration
Article: The top Democrat in the U.S. Congress said on Thursday she might file a legal challenge if President Donald Trump declares a national emergency to secure funds to build a wall along the U.S. southern border, as the White House has said he would.

Headline: Trump declaring border emergency would be 'lawless act': Sen. Schumer
Article: In unusually harsh language, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said on Thursday that if President Donald Trump declares a national emergency to build a border wall, he would be committing "a lawless act" and warned that Congress would take steps to stop him.

Headline: Trump to sign border security bill, declare national emergency: McConnell
Article: U.S. Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell said on Thursday that President Donald Trump told him he would sign a bipartisan border security bill and at the same time declare a national emergency to make available additional funds for a wall along the southern border.

Headline: Senate confirms William Barr as U.S. attorney general
Article: The U.S. Senate confirmed William Barr as attorney general on Thursday, installing a seasoned lawyer with decades of Washington experience to head the Justice Department and putting him in charge of overseeing Special Counsel Robert Mueller's long-running probe of whether President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign colluded with Russia.

Headline: U.S. senator Rubio says buyback tax bill a couple of weeks away
Article: U.S. Republican Senator Marco Rubio said on Thursday that he could be ready in the next couple of weeks to introduce legislation that would treat corporate stock buybacks as dividends for tax purposes.

Headline: Pence, at summit, lashes out at Europeans over Iran
Article: U.S. Vice President Mike Pence accused European powers on Thursday of undermining Washington's crack down on Iran by trying to break U.S. sanctions against Tehran, in remarks that were likely to further strain transatlantic relations.

Headline: Trump to receive update on border security bill: official
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will receive an update on border security legislation agreed to by Republican and Democratic lawmakers on Thursday morning, a White House official said.

Headline: U.S. judge rules ex-Trump campaign chief breached plea deal
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's former campaign manager Paul Manafort breached his plea agreement with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office by lying to prosecutors about matters which are material to its Russia probe, a judge ruled on Wednesday.

Headline: Democrats swear off big money, but will it hurt their 2020 White House chances?
Article: Senator Elizabeth Warren issued a pointed campaign finance challenge to fellow Democratic U.S. presidential contenders at her official 2020 White House election launch.

Headline: Trump considers 60-day extension for China tariffs deadline: Bloomberg
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is considering a 60-day extension of the Mar. 1 deadline for higher tariffs on Chinese imports, Bloomberg said on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

Headline: Congress negotiators finish drafting border security bill: aide
Article: U.S. lawmakers late on Wednesday completed writing a border security bill that was expected to deny President Donald Trump's request for $5.7 billion to help build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border, with the Senate and House of Representatives expected to vote on the bill Thursday.

Headline: House Democrats eye Mueller filings for Trump probe
Article: Newly empowered Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives plan to use court documents from Robert Mueller's Russia probe to conduct hearings on President Donald Trump without waiting for the special counsel's final report, according to lawmakers and aides.

Headline: Republican senators pressure Trump's EPA pick over biofuels
Article: Five Republican senators are warning President Donald Trump's new pick to run the Environmental Protection Agency, Andrew Wheeler, that their support for his nomination may hinge on his biofuels policy.

Headline: U.S. Republican Senator Rubio pushes plan to tax stock buybacks
Article: Republican U.S. Senator Marco Rubio said on Wednesday he will soon introduce legislation that would tax corporate stock buybacks like dividends, aiming to spur business investment, create more jobs and boost wages.

Headline: Senators vow urgent reform to correct 'unacceptable' military housing conditions
Article: U.S. Senators scolded real estate executives and Pentagon leadership over "unacceptable" conditions in privatized military housing on Wednesday, vowing urgent reform to protect service families from widespread health and safety hazards in base homes.

Headline: Trump to give speech on Venezuela on Monday in Miami
Article: President Donald Trump will give a speech on Venezuela in Miami on Monday and voice support for Venezuela's National Assembly President Juan Guaido, whom the United States considers the legitimate president of that country, a White House official said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. senators to try again to pass Russia sanctions bill
Article: A bipartisan group of U.S. senators introduced a bill on Wednesday that would impose stiff new sanctions on Russia over its meddling in U.S. elections and aggression against Ukraine, the latest congressional effort to push President Donald Trump to ratchet up Washington's response to Moscow.

Headline: House Democrat questions accuracy of Whitaker's testimony
Article: The top Democrat on the U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee on Wednesday accused acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker of giving incomplete and contradictory testimony when he appeared before the panel last week, and ordered him to clarify his answers.

Headline: U.S. House backs measure to end U.S. support for Saudis in Yemen war
Article: The Democratic-led U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday approved a resolution that would end U.S. support for the Saudi Arabia-led coalition in the war in Yemen, as many lawmakers sought to push President Donald Trump to toughen his policy toward the kingdom.

Headline: Democratic lawmakers say U.S. military action in Venezuela 'not an option'
Article: Democratic lawmakers on Wednesday said Congress would oppose U.S. military intervention in Venezuela and challenged the credibility of President Donald Trump's special envoy, Elliott Abrams, over his past embrace of American covert action.

Headline: U.S. posts another budget deficit as tax revenues sag
Article: The U.S. federal government ran a $14 billion budget deficit in December as revenues sagged following last year's tax cuts even as the economy appeared strong, Treasury Department data showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Senate Democrats press Trump for China IP, tech transfer commitments
Article: Seven U.S. Democratic senators urged President Donald Trump on Wednesday to press China for a trade deal that fully addresses the technology transfer and intellectual property concerns outlined by U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer.

Headline: Senator Graham says Trump is inclined to sign funding deal
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is inclined to sign bipartisan legislation to fund the government as long as its provisions on a border wall and bed spaces for illegal immigrants are as he expects, a Republican senator close to the White House said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump says will look for 'land mines' in funding bill
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he will look for "land mines" in a government funding bill, though he also said he does not want to close the government for the second time this winter.

Headline: Former Trump lawyer Cohen to testify to Congress before entering prison: CNBC
Article: President Donald Trump's former personal lawyer Michael Cohen will testify before three congressional committees before he enters jail on March 6, CNBC reported on Friday, citing Cohen's lawyer Lanny Davis.

Headline: Former Trump lawyer Cohen to testify in public hearing: attorney
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen will testify in a public hearing before Congress where he plans to talk about why he decided he could no longer defend the actions of his former boss, Cohen's attorney said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump dislikes border security deal but Republicans urge support
Article: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he was unhappy with a deal struck by congressional negotiators on border security that denied him funds for his promised U.S.-Mexican border wall, but did not reject it outright as fellow Republicans urged his support.

Headline: Senate panel delays vote on nominee to lead immigration agency
Article: The U.S. Senate Homeland Security Committee postponed a vote on Wednesday on whether to approve Ronald Vitiello, President Donald Trump's nominee to lead the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency.

Headline: Apple, Walmart, IBM CEOs join White House advisory panel
Article: The chief executives of Apple Inc, Walmart Inc, IBM Corp and other major companies are joining a Trump administration advisory board that hopes to prepare U.S. workers to deal with job training issues and the worforce shift brought by artificial intelligence and automation, the U.S. Commerce Department said on Wednesday.

Headline: House to vote on government funding bill late Thursday: lawmaker
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives will vote on bipartisan legislation to fund the government, including border security, on Thursday, House Democratic Caucus Chairman Hakeem Jeffries said, adding that he expects most Democrats to back the bill.

Headline: Trump will likely sign government funding deal: source
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is likely to sign a bipartisan government funding deal as it stands now, a source familiar with the situation told Reuters, adding that Trump could still change his mind.

Headline: Trump weighing all options for full border wall funding: spokeswoman
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is weighing every possible option to find money to build his wall along the southern U.S. border, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders told Fox News in an interview on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump to sign border security deal to avert government shutdown: CNN
Article: Donald Trump plans to sign the border security deal reached by congressional negotiators in order to avoid another partial shutdown of the federal government, CNN reported on Wednesday, citing two sources who had spoken with the U.S. president.

Headline: California Governor Newsom swipes at Trump, cuts water, rail projects
Article: California Governor Gavin Newsom said on Tuesday he would scale back massive water and rail projects pushed by his predecessor and had assembled a team of lawyers to protect wildfire victims and ratepayers as utility PG&E enters bankruptcy proceedings.

Headline: Republican Senate leader hopes to act on border bill soon
Article: U.S. Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell on Tuesday welcomed a border security deal reached by a bipartisan group of lawmakers as "good news" and said he hoped the Senate can act quickly on the legislation to avert a U.S. government shutdown.

Headline: Trump: Another government shutdown unlikely but unhappy about deal
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday said he was not happy about a tentative immigration deal reached by a bipartisan group of lawmakers, but he did not anticipate another partial shutdown of the federal government.

Headline: Senate may confirm Trump attorney general pick as soon as Wednesday
Article: President Donald Trump's attorney general nominee, William Barr, could win confirmation in the U.S. Senate as soon as Wednesday despite Democrats' concerns about how he might handle Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

Headline: U.S. Senate proposal would block Saudi path to atomic weapon in nuclear deal
Article: U.S. senators from both parties introduced a resolution on Tuesday requiring that any deal to share U.S. nuclear power technology with Saudi Arabia block the kingdom from making a nuclear weapon.

Headline: John Dingell, longest-serving member of U.S. Congress, dead at 92
Article: John Dingell, a gruff Michigan Democrat who entered the U.S. House of Representatives in 1955 to finish his late father's term and became a legislative heavyweight and longest-serving member of Congress, died on Thursday. He was 92.

Headline: Republican senators praise spending deal as path to Trump border request
Article: Republican Senate leaders on Tuesday praised a spending agreement reached with Democrats to avert a government shutdown this week, calling it a step toward border security measures sought by President Donald Trump.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers tout U.S.-Japan-South Korea alliance as Seoul, Tokyo feud
Article: U.S. Republicans and Democrats joined together on Tuesday to tout the long alliance between Japan, South Korea and the United States, hoping to reinforce the trilateral relationship amid an intensifying feud between Tokyo and Seoul.

Headline: Republican leader says Senate will vote on Green New Deal
Article: Republican Senate Leader Mitch McConnell said on Tuesday that the U.S. Senate will vote on a "Green New Deal" introduced by Democrats that aims to slash U.S. carbon dioxide emissions to negligible levels in a decade.

Headline: U.S. immigration officers' union opposes Trump pick to lead key agency
Article: A union representing U.S. immigration and customs agents urged the Senate on Tuesday to block confirmation of President Donald Trump's nominee to head the immigration enforcement agency, citing past racially tinged and controversial comments.

Headline: Trump: Democratic lawmaker should resign over Israel lobby comments
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he believes that Democratic U.S. Representative Ilhan Omar should resign after her comments about the pro-Israel lobby in the United States.

Headline: Democratic senators urge administration to reject Sprint, T-Mobile merger
Article: A group of eight Democratic U.S. senators and independent Senator Bernie Sanders urged the Justice Department and Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday to reject a proposed $26 billion merger of T-Mobile US Inc and Sprint Corp.

Headline: Former astronaut Mark Kelly to challenge Republican Arizona senator
Article: Retired U.S. astronaut Mark Kelly, married to former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords, who was wounded in a 2011 mass shooting, said on Tuesday he was challenging Republican Martha McSally for John McCain's former U.S. Senate seat.

Headline: U.S. government shutdown caused 'real harm' to taxpayers: IRS watchdog
Article: The partial U.S. government shutdown in December and January caused "real harm" to taxpayers, with many unable to get help from officials to understand their tax obligations, a government watchdog said.

Headline: Labor unions fear Democratsâ€™ Green New Deal poses job threat
Article: Labor unions say they are withholding support for a Green New Deal unveiled by Democrats last week to transition the American economy away from fossil fuels, arguing the loosely-defined plan could kill jobs if its architects aren't careful.

Headline: U.S. House panel postpones sanctions hearing, cites scheduling changes
Article: The U.S. House Financial Services committee has postponed a hearing planned for Tuesday on the use of U.S. sanctions against countries such as North Korea, Iran, Russia and Venezuela, the panel said, citing scheduling issues.

Headline: O'Rourke, Trump duel over wall, immigration in possible 2020 preview
Article: Potential White House hopeful Beto Oâ€™Rourke accused Donald Trump of fear-mongering on Monday and the Republican president mocked the Democrat as a "young man who lost" in dueling rallies that could preview the tenor of the 2020 election campaign.

Headline: Trump not made decision about border security deal: official
Article: President Donald Trump has not made a decision on whether to accept a congressional deal on border security that is key to averting another partial government shutdown at the end of the week, a White House official said on Tuesday.

Headline: Virginia political crisis in stalemate after impeachment threat
Article: The chaos that has swirled around the Virginia statehouse for more than a week showed no signs of waning on Tuesday, one day after a lawmaker backed down from his threat to seek the impeachment of one of three top-ranked Democrats engulfed in scandal.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers reach tentative deal to avoid government shutdown
Article: U.S. congressional negotiators on Monday reached a tentative deal to try to avert another partial government shutdown on Saturday, but congressional aides said it did not contain the $5.7 billion President Donald Trump wants for a border wall.

Headline: Former Fed Chair Paul Volcker takes Trump to task on taxes, trade
Article: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker warned the Trump administrationâ€™s handling of domestic issues as well as trade talks with China is hurting the United Statesâ€™ long-term prosperity.

Headline: Former Trump lawyer Cohen's Senate testimony postponed due to surgery
Article: Testimony by U.S. President Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen planned for Tuesday before the Senate Intelligence Committee has been postponed as he recovers from a recent surgical procedure, an attorney for Cohen said.

Headline: Trump administration unveils order to prioritize and promote AI
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday signed an executive order asking federal government agencies to dedicate more resources and investment into research, promotion and training on artificial intelligence, known as AI.

Headline: U.S. Senator Shelby says 'agreement in principle' reached on border security
Article: U.S. Republican Senator Richard Shelby, one of the congressional negotiators working on border security funding, said late on Monday that an "agreement in principle" had been reached.

Headline: U.S. lawmaker apologizes after House leaders condemn comments as anti-Semitic
Article: Democratic lawmaker Ilhan Omar apologized on Monday after party leaders condemned her comments about the pro-Israel lobby in the United States as using anti-Semitic stereotypes.

Headline: Trump objects to measure ending U.S. support for Saudis in Yemen war
Article: The Trump administration threatened on Monday to veto an effort in the U.S. Congress to end U.S. military support for the Saudi Arabia-led coalition in the war in Yemen, continuing a stand-off with lawmakers over policy toward the kingdom.

Headline: U.S. presidential candidate Harris says she tried pot - and inhaled
Article: U.S. Senator Kamala Harris, a former prosecutor who is seeking the Democratic Party's 2020 presidential nomination, said on Monday she had smoked marijuana in college and supported its legalization.

Headline: California pulls most National Guard troops from U.S.-Mexico border
Article: California Governor Gavin Newsom on Monday signed an order withdrawing more than two-thirds of the state's National Guard troops from the U.S.-Mexico border, calling claims of an illegal immigration crisis there nothing but "political theater."

Headline: Negotiators try for U.S. border security funding deal Monday: Senator Leahy
Article: U.S. congressional negotiators were working into the night in hopes of striking a deal on funding border security programs through Sept. 30 and averting another round of federal agency shutdowns, Democratic Senator Patrick Leahy said on Monday.

Headline: Virginia Democrats hold fire on impeachment of lieutenant governor
Article: Virginia Democrats pressured Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax to resign on Monday over accusations of sexual assault, which he denies, but held off on pursuing impeachment, with the Republican speaker of the state House urging restraint.

Headline: Trump says Democrats to blame if government shuts down again
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday said Democrats would be to blame if the government shuts down when a temporary funding bill expires on Friday.

Headline: U.S. official blasts Democratic proposal on immigration detention facilities
Article: A Trump administration immigration official on Monday called a Democratic proposal to cap the number of spaces at detention facilities for illegal immigrants "extremely damaging" to public safety, an issue that has complicated talks aimed at heading off another government shutdown.

Headline: Talks collapse on border deal as U.S. government shutdown looms
Article: Talks on border security funding collapsed after Democratic and Republican lawmakers clashed over immigrant detention policy as they worked to avert another U.S. government shutdown, a Republican senator said on Sunday.

Headline: Senator Klobuchar joins Democratic presidential field
Article: U.S. Senator Amy Klobuchar entered the 2020 presidential race on Sunday, becoming the first moderate in an increasingly crowded field of Democrats vying to challenge Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Walter Jones, veteran U.S. congressman from North Carolina, dies at 76
Article: Walter B. Jones, a veteran Republican U.S. congressman from North Carolina, died on Sunday at age 76, his office said, three weeks after suffering a broken hip at his home.

Headline: Virginia official accused of rape will have to resign if allegations are true: governor
Article: Virginia's embattled governor insisted he would not resign over a racist yearbook photo, but said the state's lieutenant governor would have to step aside if sexual assault allegations against him were found to be true.

Headline: Factbox: Democratic presidential contenders jump into 2020 fray
Article: U.S. Democrats, anxious to get started on their quest to recapture the White House in 2020, are lining up to launch campaigns in what is quickly becoming a crowded field of presidential contenders.

Headline: Democrat Schiff questions if Mueller probing Trump-Deutsche Bank link
Article: The Democratic chairman of the U.S. House Intelligence Committee said on Sunday he was concerned that Special Counsel Robert Mueller may not be investigating President Donald Trump's ties to Deutsche Bank AG.

Headline: Booker focuses on race relations in initial 2020 White House swing
Article: U.S. Senator Cory Booker made the nation's complicated history with race relations and racial disparities a focal point at events in the key state of Iowa during his first 2020 presidential campaign swing over the weekend.

Headline: No more congressional talks scheduled to avert shutdown: source
Article: No additional congressional talks were scheduled on border security issues to avert another U.S. government shutdown after negotiations stalled over the weekend, a source familiar with the process told Reuters.

Headline: Armed with new power, Democrats push for stricter gun laws
Article: Democratic lawmakers are pushing stricter gun laws in statehouses across the country, emboldened by sweeping electoral victories in 2018 and confident that public opinion is on their side a year after the school shooting in Parkland, Florida.

Headline: Senator Warren launches 2020 campaign, sounds note of economic equality
Article: U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren, struggling to move past criticism over her claims of Native American heritage, aimed for a fresh start on Saturday with the formal launch of her 2020 presidential campaign, saying that she is fighting for all Americans.

Headline: Virginia governor appears at funeral as pressure grows on his No. 2
Article: Virginia Governor Ralph Northam made his first public appearance on Saturday since defying calls a week ago to step down over a racist yearbook photograph, as his potential successor, a fellow Democrat, resisted growing pressure to quit over sexual assault allegations.

Headline: Trump says North Korea talks productive, summit will be in Hanoi
Article: President Donald Trump said on Friday that U.S. diplomats had a "very productive meeting" with North Korean officials, and he announced his summit later this month with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un would be held in Vietnam's capital, Hanoi.

Headline: Virginia governor vows to stay; calls mount to oust lieutenant governor
Article: Virginia's embattled governor, Ralph Northam, capped a week of political chaos ignited by racial scandals by vowing to stay in office on Friday, while the fellow Democrat in line to succeed him faced a second accusation of sexual assault.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. in direct contact with Venezuelan military, urging defections - source
Article: The United States is holding direct communications with members of Venezuela's military urging them to abandon President Nicolas Maduro and is also preparing new sanctions aimed at increasing pressure on him, a senior White House official said.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers introduce bipartisan bill on cockpit safety
Article: U.S. lawmakers are pushing for stronger aviation security with a bipartisan bill that would require passenger airlines to install secondary security doors between cabins and the cockpit on current aircraft to prevent another Sept. 11-style attack.

Headline: U.S. must prevent air accidents involving drones, lawmaker warns
Article: The commercial drone industry could be torpedoed if there were a serious accident involving a drone and a commercial aircraft, the chairman of the U.S. House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee warned on Friday.

Headline: U.S. appeals court to revisit open carrying of guns
Article: A federal appeals court has decided to reconsider its recent decision that the Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution protects the right to openly carry guns in self-defense.

Headline: Trump may skip deadline for report on Saudi journalist's murder
Article: The Trump administration signaled on Friday it was unlikely to meet a deadline to report to Congress on whether it intends to impose sanctions on those responsible for the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, prompting an angry backlash on Capitol Hill.

Headline: Acting U.S. attorney general snaps at Democrats over Russia probe
Article: Acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker snapped back on Friday at newly emboldened Democrats in Congress who are pushing for information on the special counsel's Russia probe as they try to put President Donald Trump's administration under greater scrutiny.

Headline: Former U.S. President Obama gives Senator Brown advice on candidacy
Article: U.S. Senator Sherrod Brown sought advice earlier this year from former President Barack Obama about running a 2020 presidential bid, the Democrat told voters on Friday at an event in New Hampshire.

Headline: U.S. border security talks progressing: negotiators
Article: U.S. lawmakers negotiating a deal with President Donald Trump on border security funding on Thursday said progress was being made, with Democratic Senator Jon Tester raising the possibility of a successful conclusion to talks as soon as Friday.

Headline: Trump adviser Stone: I'm not Kim Kardashian, don't need gag order
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's longtime adviser Roger Stone on Friday urged a federal judge not to ban him from talking about his criminal case in the Russia probe, saying that unlike Kim Kardashian he was little known to the public and that he did not need a gag order.

Headline: Trump, not especially vigilant on diet, declared 'in very good health'
Article: President Donald Trump was declared "in very good health" by the White House physician on Friday after four hours of examinations in what amounted to a test of whether his doctor's order that he follow a healthier diet has paid dividends.

Headline: Pompeo visit to focus on U.S. concerns over Huawei in central Europe
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will voice concerns about the growing presence of China's Huawei Technologies in central Europe when he visits Hungary, Slovakia and Poland next week, a senior U.S. official said on Friday as Washington tries to bolster ties with a region it acknowledges it has neglected.

Headline: Chief Justice Roberts emerges as key figure on U.S. Supreme Court
Article: Pivotal votes cast by U.S. Chief Justice John Roberts in abortion and death penalty cases have underscored his new standing as the Supreme Court's ideological center and the outsized role he may play in major rulings for years to come.

Headline: Negotiators on U.S. border security funds eye deal by Monday: lawmakers
Article: Efforts in the U.S. Congress to resolve an impasse over border security funding intensified on Friday and were expected to continue over the weekend, as a special negotiating panel aimed to come to a deal by Monday, lawmakers and aides said.

Headline: Whitaker says did not previously discuss Russia probe with Trump, associates
Article: U.S. Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker on Friday said he never discussed Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation with President Donald Trump or his inner circle before he began working at the U.S. Department of Justice.

Headline: Acting U.S. attorney general: No Russia probe talks with Trump, White House
Article: Acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker on Friday said he has not spoken with President Donald Trump or any senior White House officials about the U.S. special counsel's probe into alleged Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Headline: Virginia congressional Democrats hint at path for easing political crisis
Article: Virginia's congressional Democratic delegation has hinted at a possible pathway for easing a week-old political crisis that has embroiled Governor Ralph Northam and two fellow Democrats at the top of the state's executive branch.

Headline: Florida wins its first passing grade on annual gun-safety report card
Article: Florida earned a passing grade for the first time on an annual gun-safety report card compiled by a prominent advocacy group, after the state led all others in bolstering its firearms laws in the year since the deadly Parkland school shooting.

Headline: Acting U.S. attorney general will testify before House panel
Article: Acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker has agreed to testify on Friday before the House Judiciary Committee, the Justice Department said on Thursday, after he threatened to not show up following the panel's warning that it could subpoena him.

Headline: Whitaker to defend Russia probe handling in U.S. hearing: testimony
Article: Acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker will defend his handling of the U.S. special counsel's Russia probe before a U.S. House of Representatives panel on Friday, but will not discuss his communications with President Donald Trump, according to his prepared testimony.

Headline: Acting U.S. Attorney Gen Whitaker to testify before House panel on Friday
Article: U.S. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler said on Thursday that acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker will testify on Friday, after he threatened not to show up following the panel's warning that it could subpoena him.

Headline: No talks between Trump and China's Xi before trade deadline
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday he did not plan to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping before a March 1 deadline set by the two countries to achieve a trade deal.

Headline: Senate committee to consider resolution against Nord Stream 2 pipeline
Article: Republican and Democratic U.S. senators on Thursday unveiled a resolution calling for the cancellation of Russia's Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline, a link under the Baltic Sea from Russia to Germany.

Headline: Trump stokes Democrats' Virginia turmoil as scandal snares Republican
Article: A firestorm of scandals embroiling Virginia's governor and two fellow Democrats at the top of the state's executive branch spread to the Republican leader of the state Senate on Thursday as U.S. President Donald Trump weighed in to stoke the political crisis.

Headline: House panel pledges to work with acting AG on hearing-related concerns
Article: The head of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee said on Thursday the panel was ready to work with acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker to address concerns he might have about answering certain questions at a planned Friday hearing, but he stopped short of withdrawing the threat of an eventual subpoena.

Headline: Democrats float 'Green New Deal' to end fossil fuel era
Article: Democrats on Thursday laid out a "Green New Deal" that would eliminate U.S. greenhouse gas emissions within a decade, an effort to make climate change a central issue in the 2020 presidential race.

Headline: House Democrats question IRS audits of Trump taxes
Article: Democrats in Congress raised questions on Thursday about the Internal Revenue Service's ability to effectively audit President Donald Trump's tax returns, as they began hearings intended to result in obtaining the documents and making them public.

Headline: Mueller eyes Manafort meeting with Russian partner in 2016: court filing
Article: U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller is focused on a meeting at the height of the 2016 presidential campaign between Donald Trump's then campaign chairman Paul Manafort and a business associate prosecutors say has ties to Russian intelligence, according to a court filing on Thursday.

Headline: House panel passes bill targeting OPEC oil supply cuts
Article: A U.S. House of Representatives committee approved a bill on Thursday that would open up the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to antitrust lawsuits, but it was uncertain if the measure would be considered by the full chamber.

Headline: Blackface scandals highlight U.S.'s troubled racial past - and present
Article: The painful history of blackface in America was highlighted this week as two top Virginia Democrats came under fire after admitting to having blackened their faces to resemble African-Americans while in college in the 1980s.

Headline: Principles or power? Virginia political scandal a test for Democrats
Article: The spiraling political crisis in Virginia, which threatens to take out three top state Democrats with racial scandals or sexual assault accusations, poses a stiff test for a party thriving on its growing strength with women and minorities.

Headline: Trump adviser Kushner to visit Middle East on peace plan's economic part
Article: White House senior adviser Jared Kushner will travel to at least five Arab countries in late February to brief diplomats on the economic portion of a long-awaited U.S. peace proposal for the Middle East and seek their support, officials said on Thursday.

Headline: Trump-Kim summit venue shows possibility of moving beyond conflict: State Department
Article: The choice of Vietnam as the venue for a second U.S.-North Korea summit this month shows the possibility of moving beyond conflict and division toward a thriving partnership, the U.S. State Department said on Thursday.

Headline: U.S. calls on Iran to halt space launches that defy U.N. resolution
Article: The U.S. State Department said on Thursday it was aware of reports of a failed Iranian attempt to launch a satellite into space last month and it called on Tehran to halt activities that violate U.N. resolutions.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers renew push for penalties against Saudi Arabia
Article: Republican and Democratic U.S. lawmakers renewed their push on Thursday to penalize Saudi Arabia for the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi and address the humanitarian crisis in Yemen, introducing legislation to bar some arms sales and impose sanctions on those responsible for his death.

Headline: New Zealand PM says exporters could suffer due to U.S.-China trade tensions
Article: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said on Friday that trade tensions between the U.S. and China, which is New Zealand's top trading partner, could affect exporters in the country and hurt its economy.

Headline: Trump confirms he won't meet with China's Xi before March 1 trade deadline
Article: President Donald Trump confirmed on Thursday that he did not plan to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping before a March 1 deadline set by the two countries to achieve a trade deal.

Headline: Democratic Senator Tester says border deal possible this week
Article: U.S. Democratic Senator Jon Tester, a member of the committee trying to reach an agreement on border security, said a deal was possible as early as Friday.

Headline: Senate panel approves Trump attorney general nominee
Article: President Donald Trump's attorney general nominee, William Barr, moved closer to a confirmation vote in the U.S. Senate on Thursday, winning approval from a key committee despite Democrats' concerns about how he might handle Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

Headline: State, city leaders press Congress on U.S. infrastructure needs
Article: U.S. lawmakers heard pleas from state and local officials on Thursday to take urgent action to rebuild the nation's infrastructure and address an estimated $2 trillion in needs over the next decade.

Headline: Republican U.S. senators want Taiwan president to address Congress
Article: Amid tensions between the United States and China, a group of Republican U.S. senators asked House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi to invite Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-Wen to address a joint meeting of the U.S. Congress, an invitation that would anger Beijing if it were extended.

Headline: Acting U.S. attorney general will not testify if House subpoena issued: Justice Department
Article: Acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker will decline to testify before a House of Representatives committee on Friday if Democrats issue a subpoena, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

Headline: Trump-Powell dinner on Monday 'constructive': White House official
Article: This week's dinner between U.S. President Donald Trump and the chairman of the Federal Reserve was "constructive" after a rocky few months, a top White House economic official said on Thursday.

Headline: Senators Warren, Warner question contractors, military on unsafe housing
Article: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has become the latest congressional leader to press for answers from military contractors over Reuters reports describing unsafe housing conditions on U.S. bases, sending letters this week to five large real estate firms seeking detailed information about their operations and profits.

Headline: House panel plans action on gun background check bill next week
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee will take up legislation next week that would require universal background checks for gun buyers, the panel's Democratic chairman said on Thursday.

Headline: Banks weigh whether to embrace or avoid progressive firebrand Ocasio-Cortez
Article: Barely a month into the new Congress, financial lobbyists in Washington are already strategizing how to handle the star power of rookie Democrat lawmaker Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

Headline: Senate panel chief sees no Trump-Russia collusion so far: report
Article: The chairman of the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee said its Russia investigation has found no proof that President Donald Trump's presidential campaign colluded with Moscow, an assertion that congressional sources said puts him at odds with Democrats on the largely bipartisan panel.

Headline: Trump administration proposes exempting some light bulbs from green standards
Article: The U.S. Department of Energy on Wednesday proposed exempting some light bulbs from federal efficiency standards that take effect next year, a move environmentalists said would boost pollution and power bills for consumers.

Headline: Trump nominates critic of global institutions to lead World Bank
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that the World Bank Group should be led by U.S. Treasury official David Malpass, a Trump loyalist and critic of multilateral institutions who has vowed to pursue "pro-growth" reforms at the development lender.

Headline: House Democrats take first step toward tighter gun laws
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives began moving toward tighter gun regulations on Wednesday, holding the first congressional hearing in years on how to stem the epidemic of gun violence that claimed the lives of nearly 40,000 Americans in 2017.

Headline: Justice Department conducting professional misconduct probe in Epstein case
Article: A U.S. Justice Department office is investigating whether department attorneys committed professional misconduct in a criminal case involving a wealthy Florida financier accused of sex crimes, the department said in a letter to a senator released on Wednesday.

Headline: Top Virginia Democrats imperiled by blackface, sex assault scandals
Article: The political crisis in Virginia deepened on Wednesday when the attorney general admitted to wearing blackface in the 1980s at a college party, becoming the state's third high-ranking Democrat caught up in scandal.

Headline: Senator Warren struggles to quiet criticism of her heritage claims
Article: U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren, days from formally launching her 2020 presidential campaign, faced criticism on Wednesday for claiming she was Native American in the 1980s and concern from fellow Democrats over her handling of the issue.

Headline: Democrat Schiff draws Trump ire with House intel probes
Article: The House Intelligence Committee is set to pursue a wide investigation into attempts to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election, including a look at Donald Trump's financial transactions, the panel's Democratic chairman Adam Schiff said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. halts some Cameroon military assistance over human rights: official
Article: The United States said on Wednesday it was halting some military assistance to Cameroon over allegations of gross human rights violations by its security forces in the northwest, southwest and far north regions.

Headline: At least four pharma CEOs to testify at Senate drug pricing hearing
Article: Drugmakers Pfizer Inc, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co and Sanofi SA said on Wednesday that their chief executives plan to testify at a Senate hearing on rising prescription drug prices later this month.

Headline: Republican senators to Trump: Do not terminate NAFTA
Article: Republican senators on Wednesday urged the top U.S. trade negotiator to counsel President Donald Trump against formally terminating the North American Free Trade Agreement as a way to pressure Congress to act quickly to approve a replacement deal.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers criticize Saudi Arabia, ask about weapons restrictions
Article: The chairman of the U.S. House Foreign Affairs Committee said on Wednesday he was troubled by a report that Saudi Arabia transferred weapons to extremist groups in Yemen and questioned whether Congress should consider more restrictions on weapons sales to the Saudi-led coalition.

Headline: Trump says may declare Islamic State defeated next week
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he expected a formal announcement as early as next week that the coalition fighting Islamic State militants has reclaimed all of the territory previously held by the extremist group.

Headline: Elizabeth Warren called herself 'American Indian' on ID card: report
Article: U.S. Democratic presidential contender Elizabeth Warren identified herself as an "American Indian" in hand-writing on her 1986 registration card for the State Bar of Texas, the Washington Post reported on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. might lift sanctions on Venezuelan military who back Guaido: Bolton
Article: The United States would consider lifting sanctions on senior Venezuelan military officers if they recognize the government of self-declared interim president Juan Guaido, White House national security adviser John Bolton said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump says expects announcement soon on recapturing Islamic State territory
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he expected a formal announcement as early as next week that the coalition fighting Islamic State rebels has reclaimed all of the territory previously held by the extremist group.

Headline: U.S. border officials don't share Trump's zeal for border wall: lawmakers
Article: U.S. Customs and Border Protection officials on Wednesday described a multi-pronged strategy for tightening the southern border with Mexico that did not focus mainly on a massive wall President Donald Trump demands, according to lawmakers who attended a classified briefing.

Headline: Trump: Democrat lawmaker Schiff has no grounds to probe his finances
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday the Democratic chairman of the House intelligence committee has "no basis" to investigate his finances.

Headline: On abortion, Trump agenda likely leads to Supreme Court, not Congress
Article: President Donald Trump urged lawmakers in his State of the Union address to put new limits on abortion, but partisan division in the U.S. Congress means the Supreme Court likely will set the agenda on the divisive issue, as it has for decades.

Headline: O'Rourke says will decide on presidential run this month
Article: Beto O'Rourke, the Democratic former Texas congressman whose unexpectedly close but ultimately unsuccessful campaign for U.S. Senate generated buzz about a 2020 presidential bid, said on Tuesday he will decide by the end of the month whether to run.

Headline: Trump's 2020 Democratic rivals pounce to criticize State of the Union speech
Article: Democrats vying to challenge U.S. President Donald Trump in the 2020 election moved quickly to attack his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, saying it lacked substance and did nothing to unite the country.

Headline: Trump's Venezuela envoy to testify to U.S. House panel amid crisis
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's special envoy for Venezuela, Elliott Abrams, will testify in the Democratic-led House of Representatives next week, as Washington presses for a change of government in the South American nation.

Headline: Trump asks U.S. Congress to prohibit late-term abortion
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump called for curbs on late-term abortion in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, citing controversies over the issue in New York and Virginia.

Headline: U.S. Fed chief to discuss economy before House panel on February 27
Article: U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell to testify before the House Financial Services Committee on Feb. 27, the committee's Democratic chairwoman said in a statement on Wednesday.

Headline: With eye on Afghanistan talks, Trump vows to stop 'endless wars'
Article: President Donald Trump told Americans on Tuesday his administration had accelerated talks for a political settlement in Afghanistan and would be able to reduce U.S. troops there as negotiations advance to end America's longest war.

Headline: Former Trump lawyer Cohen congressional testimony postponed
Article: Testimony by U.S. President Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen before the House Intelligence Committee has been postponed until Feb. 28, the panel said on Wednesday, the latest snag over an appearance by Trump's one-time "fixer."

Headline: New Mexico governor pulls National Guard troops from U.S.-Mexico border
Article: New Mexico Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham has ordered most of the National Guard troops deployed at the state's border with Mexico to withdraw, rejecting U.S. President Donald Trump's contention there was a border crisis.

Headline: Shutdown a Trump 'stunt,' says Democrat Abrams in reply to annual speech
Article: Stacey Abrams, who nearly became both the first African-American and first woman governor of Georgia, landed a few jabs against President Donald Trump after his State of the Union address while calling for an economic boost for working and middle-class Americans.

Headline: Despite bipartisan sheen, Trump's speech spoke to his base
Article: Even as he appealed for unity, President Donald Trump made it clear in his State of the Union address on Tuesday that his idea of common ground is having Democrats back his policy agenda and stop investigating his administration.

Headline: Trump says to meet North Korea's Kim in Vietnam in late February
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he would hold his second meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vietnam on Feb. 27-28, while giving himself credit for averting a major war on the Korean peninsula.

Headline: Trump says 'partisan' probes could endanger U.S. economy
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday warned Democrats against engaging in "ridiculous partisan investigations" that he said could contribute to a weakening of the American economy.

Headline: Trump vows to build border wall, warns Democrats against investigations
Article: President Donald Trump vowed in his State of the Union speech on Tuesday to build a border wall, which is a source of a deep partisan divide, and said Democratic attempts at "ridiculous partisan investigations" could damage U.S. prosperity.

Headline: U.S.' Mnuchin, Lighthizer to hold talks next week in China: sources
Article: Senior U.S. and Chinese officials are poised to start another round of trade talks in Beijing next week to push for a deal to protect American intellectual property and avert a March 2 increase in U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods, two people familiar with the plans said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump calls again on Congress to act on aging infrastructure needs
Article: President Donald Trump asked U.S. Congress in his State of the Union address on Tuesday to pass legislation to boost the nation's aging infrastructure, without providing details on how to go about paying for it or how much it would cost.

Headline: Trump: Americans pay too much for prescription drugs: speech excerpt
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that Americans are paying more than people in other countries for prescription drugs, according to excerpts from the State of the Union address.

Headline: Trump to call for immigration system that protects U.S. 'lives and jobs'
Article: President Donald Trump on Tuesday will use his State of the Union address to the U.S. Congress to call for revamping the country's immigration laws, according to excerpts released by the White House.

Headline: Trump to repeat previous calls to action in State of the Union speech: excerpts
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will give his annual State of the Union speech on Tuesday, in which he will outline his administration's priorities for the coming year in front of both congressional chambers and their guests.

Headline: Bipartisan group of lawmakers introduces bill to fight high drug prices
Article: A bipartisan group of U.S. senators re-introduced a bill on Tuesday aimed at helping generic drug companies bring out a cheaper version of pharmaceuticals.

Headline: Virginia governor hangs on amid outcry over racist photo
Article: Embattled Virginia Governor Ralph Northam on Tuesday resisted calls to step down over a racist photo on his 1984 medical school yearbook page, with the state's main Democratic Latino organization joining the chorus urging his resignation.

Headline: Senate passes pro-Israel bill, measure also rebukes Trump
Article: The U.S. Senate passed a Mideast policy bill on Tuesday including a measure that would allow states to penalize businesses that take part in boycotts of Israel and an amendment that breaks with President Donald Trump by opposing any plans for an abrupt withdrawal of troops from Syria.

Headline: U.S. judge dismisses Stormy Daniels' claim against ex-Trump lawyer Cohen
Article: A federal judge has granted adult film actress Stormy Daniels' request to dismiss a defamation claim against U.S. President Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen, while letting her pursue her lawsuit against Trump and Cohen to end a hush money settlement.

Headline: House Democrats want Apple to answer questions on FaceTime flaw
Article: Two key U.S. House of Representatives Democrats on Tuesday asked Apple Inc Chief Executive Tim Cook, to answer questions about a privacy flaw in Apple's group video chat software after a teenager and his mother tried for days to warn the iPhone maker of the bug.

Headline: For Fed chairs, White House summons are typical, though not always welcome
Article: Days after the U.S. Federal Reserve shifted policy along the lines urged by President Donald Trump in a series of critical comments and tweets last year, Fed chairman Jerome Powell turns up at the White House for a steak dinner and an informal audience with the president, seemingly back in his good graces.

Headline: Chicago mayor condemns anti-Muslim emails written by Cubs family head
Article: Chicago's mayor on Tuesday condemned the "ignorance and intolerance" in emails written by Joe Ricketts, head of the family that owns the Chicago Cubs baseball team, in which he expresses anti-Muslim sentiment.

Headline: Prosecutors subpoena Trump inaugural committee for documents
Article: President Donald Trump's inaugural committee said it had received a subpoena on Monday for documents from the Manhattan U.S. Attorney's Office, which is investigating the group.

Headline: U.S. says foreign meddling didn't affect 2018 election systems
Article: Top U.S. officials said on Tuesday that foreign actors did not have a significant impact on computer systems and other equipment underpinning the November 2018 congressional elections, despite reports of hacking attempts.

Headline: House panel readies subpoena to compel Whitaker testimony
Article: The top Democrat on the U.S. House Judiciary Committee said on Tuesday he plans to have a subpoena ready just in case Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker tries to dodge "uncomfortable questions" when he testifies before the panel on Friday.

Headline: Senate environment panel okays Trump's pick to lead EPA
Article: A key Senate committee approved U.S. President Donald Trump's new pick to lead the Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday, putting the former coal lobbyist a step closer to becoming the permanent head of America's top environmental regulator.

Headline: U.S. general says wasn't consulted on Trump's Syria pullout order
Article: The U.S. military commander overseeing American troops in the Middle East told a Senate hearing on Tuesday that he was not consulted ahead of President Donald Trump's surprise decision in December to pull U.S. troops out of Syria.

Headline: Senate breaks from Trump with Syria troop vote
Article: The Republican-led U.S. Senate backed largely symbolic legislation on Monday that broke with President Donald Trump by opposing plans for any abrupt withdrawal of troops from Syria and Afghanistan.

Headline: Trump to choose Treasury's Malpass to lead World Bank: sources
Article: The Trump administration has notified World Bank shareholders that President Donald Trump intends to pick senior Treasury Department official David Malpass as the U.S. nominee to lead the development lender, people familiar with the decision said on Monday.

Headline: U.S. judge sets Manafort sentencing date in Washington case
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's former campaign chairman Paul Manafort will be sentenced on March 13 for attempted witness tampering and conspiring against the United States, according to a court filing on Monday.

Headline: Trump to nominate ex-energy lobbyist Bernhardt to head Interior
Article: President Donald Trump said on Monday he would nominate David Bernhardt, a former energy lobbyist, to be secretary of the interior, the department that oversees U.S. public lands.

Headline: U.S. envoy to hold talks in North Korea on Wednesday
Article: The U.S. special envoy for North Korea will meet with his North Korean counterpart on Wednesday in Pyongyang to prepare for a summit later this month between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, the U.S. State Department said on Monday.

Headline: Congressional negotiators still face unresolved border security issues
Article: With time running down, congressional negotiators on U.S. border security funding have not settled the hot-button issues that confront them, but lawmakers expressed optimism on Monday that a deal could be struck before a Feb. 15 deadline.

Headline: Senator warns of 'war' among Republicans over Trump border wall
