Headline: Still counting: Uncalled U.S. federal and state elections
Article: Democrats took control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the Nov. 6 elections and Republicans held onto a majority in the U.S. Senate, but 12 federal and two state gubernatorial races remain undecided more than a week later.

Headline: Pentagon fails its first-ever audit, official says
Article: The Pentagon has failed what is being called its first-ever comprehensive audit, a senior official said on Thursday, finding U.S. Defense Department accounting discrepancies that could take years to resolve.

Headline: U.S. Senate votes to confirm Fed governor nominee Bowman
Article: The U.S. Senate on Thursday voted to confirm Michelle Bowman to the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors, cementing a majority at the board for officials picked by President Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump's FERC nominee to seek counsel if coal bailout plan returns
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's nominee to join a key panel of independent energy regulators, who helped roll out a Department of Energy (DOE) directive to bail out aging coal and nuclear plants, told senators on Thursday he did not know if he would recuse himself if the issue reappears before the commission.

Headline: U.S. judge refuses Russian firm's bid to dismiss Mueller indictment
Article: A federal judge on Thursday refused to dismiss criminal charges against a Russian company accused by U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller of funding a propaganda operation to sway the 2016 presidential election in Donald Trumpâ€™s favor.

Headline: Trump to nominate handbag designer as new South African ambassador
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump intends to nominate luxury handbag designer Lana Marks as the new ambassador to South Africa, the White House said, almost two years after the last ambassador left under Barack Obama.

Headline: California, New Jersey Republicans concede, Utah representative sues
Article: A Republican U.S. representative of Utah who is trailing her Democratic challenger filed a lawsuit on Wednesday seeking to halt vote counting while two incumbent Republican congressmen in California and New Jersey conceded, more than a week after the U.S. midterm elections.

Headline: Trump aide Ricardel forced out after showdown with first lady
Article: Mira Ricardel, the White House deputy national security adviser, was forced out of her job on Wednesday after President Donald Trump's wife, Melania, said Ricardel did not deserve the honor of working for her husband.

Headline: U.S. Senate's Flake takes a stand on protecting Mueller probe
Article: A lone Republican lawmaker on Wednesday vowed to block judicial nominations in the U.S. Senate until Republican leader Mitch McConnell agrees to hold a vote on a measure to protect a probe into Russia's role in the 2016 presidential election.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Nov 14) - Steelworkers, California Wildfires, Prison Reform
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Mattis defends Mexico border deployment in first troop visit
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis defended the deployment of thousands of troops to the border with Mexico as he traveled there on Wednesday, saying the mission was "absolutely legal" and justified, and that it was improving military readiness.

Headline: U.S. lawmaker says Facebook cannot be trusted to regulate itself
Article: Democratic U.S. Representative David Cicilline, expected to become the next chairman of House Judiciary Committee's antitrust panel, said on Wednesday that Facebook Inc cannot be trusted to regulate itself and Congress should take action.

Headline: As Congress taps leaders, House's McCarthy fends off rival
Article: Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday chose Kevin McCarthy as their party's leader for the new Congress that will convene in January, denying the top post to conservative Jim Jordan.

Headline: China appears to relax North Korea sanctions: report to U.S. Congress
Article: A U.S. congressional commission said on Wednesday that China appears to have relaxed enforcement of sanctions on North Korea and called on the Treasury Department to provide a report on Chinese compliance within 180 days.

Headline: Justice Department calls Trump appointment of Whitaker lawful
Article: The Justice Department on Wednesday defended the legality of President Donald Trump's appointment of Matthew Whitaker as acting attorney general to replace the ousted Jeff Sessions, rejecting the views of critics that the move ran afoul of the U.S. Constitution and federal law.

Headline: Citizenship query will not cause U.S. census undercount: official
Article: The U.S. Census Bureau's top scientist on Wednesday insisted the bureau can get a full count of American residents during the 2020 census, despite the Trump administration's addition of a question on citizenship.

Headline: Manafort business partner Gates still assisting with Mueller probe: filing
Article: Rick Gates, a former business partner of President Donald Trump's ex-campaign chairman Paul Manafort, is still cooperating with several ongoing investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 election, according to a court filing on Wednesday.

Headline: Too close to call: U.S. federal, state elections still in flux
Article: Democrats took control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the Nov. 6 elections and Republicans held onto a majority in the U.S. Senate, but 14 federal and two state governorship races remain undecided more than a week later.

Headline: Trump's baseless voter fraud allegations could hurt U.S. faith in elections
Article: More than a dozen times in the past seven days, President Donald Trump has alleged, contrary to evidence, that the recount of Florida's elections for governor and the U.S. Senate has been marred by fraud.

Headline: Congress watchdog begins inquiry into housing hazards at U.S. military bases
Article: The investigative arm of Congress has launched an inquiry into hazards faced by the occupants of housing on U.S. military bases and the oversight of those conditions by the armed services.

Headline: Top Senate Democrat: Trump should stay out of government funding
Article: Top U.S. Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer said on Wednesday that President Donald Trump should not interfere in lawmakers' negotiations if he wants a smooth government funding process.

Headline: Trump to decide on Homeland Security chief 'shortly': report
Article: President Donald Trump said he would make a decision on the future of U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen soon, the Daily Caller reported on Wednesday, with speculation rampant he would soon replace her.

Headline: U.S. senators introduce bill to rein-in proxy advisers
Article: Six U.S. senators on Wednesday introduced a bill that would require the U.S. securities watchdog to directly regulate firms such as Glass, Lewis & Co and Institutional Shareholder Services, which advise investors on how to vote in corporate elections.

Headline: House Democrat to probe census citizenship question
Article: The lawmaker expected to head the powerful House Oversight Committee in the new U.S. Congress says one of his first priorities will be investigating why President Donald Trump's administration decided to ask about citizenship on the 2020 census questionnaire.

Headline: Trump under pressure from Melania to fire top aide
Article: President Donald Trump was under pressure from his wife, Melania, on Tuesday to fire his deputy national security adviser over what two sources close to the White House said was the way Mrs Trump's trip to Africa was handled.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers expect votes on steps to crack down on Saudi Arabia
Article: U.S. lawmakers said on Tuesday the Senate could vote within weeks on legislation to punish Saudi Arabia over the war in Yemen and the death of a journalist at its consulate in Istanbul.

Headline: House Democrats to probe Trump impact on FBI, Justice: lawmaker
Article: The incoming Democratic chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee intends to investigate President Donald Trump's impact on the integrity of the Justice Department and the FBI, according to a letter sent to top federal law enforcement officials on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. Senator Graham says supports Mueller bill, urges vote
Article: Republican U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham said on Tuesday he supported a bill that would protect Special Counsel Robert Mueller from any politically motivated firings and would urge Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to allow a vote on it.

Headline: White House hit with staff upheavals - again
Article: Another round of upheaval engulfed President Donald Trump's White House on Tuesday, with the future of several senior aides in doubt just a week after U.S. congressional elections.

Headline: U.S. senators alarmed if China gets control of Djibouti port
Article: Two prominent U.S. senators expressed alarm on Tuesday about the military and political consequences if China gains control of a port terminal in Djibouti, and said they were concerned it could further boost Beijing's influence in East Africa.

Headline: Associate of Trump ally expects Mueller contact soon on plea deal
Article: An associate of Roger Stone, a longtime ally of U.S. President Donald Trump, said he was told by the U.S. special counsel probing Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election that he would be contacted this week about a possible plea deal.

Headline: U.S. top court to review Virginia voting districts in race case
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday said it will review for a second time whether Republican legislators in Virginia drew electoral districts in the state in a way that unlawfully diluted the clout of black voters.

Headline: Trump to fire Homeland Security boss, replace chief of staff: source
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to remove Department of Homeland Security chief Kirstjen Nielsen and is considering replacing chief of staff John Kelly in another shakeup of his administration, a source close to the White House said.

Headline: U.S. judge to hold hearing on CNN White House lawsuit
Article: A federal judge said he would hold a hearing on Wednesday on CNN's lawsuit against the Trump administration seeking the speedy reinstatement of press credentials for White House correspondent Jim Acosta, a frequent target of President Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump could answer written Russia probe questions this week: source
Article: President Donald Trump is expected to provide written answers to questions from the special counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election as soon as this week, a person familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

Headline: Days after visit, Trump blasts France's Macron as relations sour
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump attacked his French counterpart on Tuesday in a series of tweets that underscored how much the once-friendly ties between the two leaders have soured, just two days after returning from Paris.

Headline: Trump picks conservative to replace Kavanaugh on appeals court
Article: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he will nominate conservative lawyer Neomi Rao, known for her strong anti-regulatory views, to replace newly appointed U.S. Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh on an influential federal appeals court.

Headline: Trump aide Ricardel 'no longer deserves' to serve: first lady's office
Article: U.S. first lady Melania Trump has asked that the White House sever ties with deputy national security adviser Mira Ricardel, a spokeswoman for the first lady's office said on Tuesday.

Headline: Maryland goes to court to challenge Trump's attorney general pick
Article: The state of Maryland launched a court challenge on Tuesday to the legality of President Donald Trump's appointment of Matthew Whitaker as acting U.S. attorney general, saying the president overstepped his constitutional authority and broke federal law.

Headline: Democrat Sinema wins Senate seat in Arizona
Article: Democrat Kyrsten Sinema defeated Republican Martha McSally to win a close U.S. Senate race in Arizona after last Tuesday's elections, in a Senate pickup for Democrats in a state that had not elected a Democratic U.S. senator for 30 years.

Headline: Factbox: Was Trump's appointment of Whitaker lawful?
Article: Since President Donald Trump's appointment of Matthew Whitaker as acting U.S. attorney general last week, questions regarding the legitimacy of Whitaker's authority have escalated.

Headline: Trump expected to remove DHS head, may replace chief of staff: source
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to remove U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and is considering replacing his chief of staff, John Kelly, a source close to the White House said on Tuesday.

Headline: Mattis to travel to Mexico border on Wednesday
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he would travel to the border with Mexico on Wednesday following the deployment of thousands of troops to bolster President Donald Trump's efforts to crack down on illegal immigration.

Headline: 'Lame-duck' Congress returns, facing budget, Mueller, border wall issues
Article: The U.S. Congress returns on Tuesday for a post-election "lame-duck" session, facing a funding deadline to prevent a partial government shutdown, as well as demands for protections for Special Counsel Robert Mueller and money for a proposed U.S.-Mexico border wall.

Headline: Trump says North Korean missile sites are 'nothing new'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday criticized what he called "inaccurate" media reports that North Korea had not declared an estimated 20 missile bases.

Headline: Trump to replace Homeland Security Secretary Nielsen
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump has decided to replace Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, but has not settled on the timing, the Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday, citing unidentified White House and administration officials.

Headline: President Macron's office says 'no comment' after Trump Twitter attack
Article: The office of French President Emmanuel Macron said it had no comment to make after U.S. President Donald Trump sent a series of messages on Twitter on Tuesday criticizing Macron and France.

Headline: U.S. acting Attorney General will consult with ethics officials on possible recusals
Article: Acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker will consult with ethics officials about any matters that could require him to recuse himself, the Justice Department said on Monday, after critics called on him to step aside from overseeing a Special Counsel probe into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Headline: Stung by trade wars, U.S. farmers hope for quick progress on Farm Bill
Article: U.S. soybean farmer Mike Schlosser does not expect President Donald Trumpâ€™s trade war with China, the single biggest headwind to his business, to end any time soon. But he is among many in farm country who expect at least some good news this year - in the form of a new Farm Bill.

Headline: U.S. court orders Georgia to continue review of governor's race
Article: Georgia voters will wait until at least Friday for the final word on who will be their next governor after a U.S. federal judge ordered state election officials to review provisional ballots cast in last week's election.

Headline: Maryland to seek court ruling over Trump's attorney general pick: NYT
Article: Maryland officials will ask a federal judge for an injunction and argue that Matthew Whitaker is not the legitimate acting U.S. attorney general, the New York Times reported on Tuesday, citing a draft court filing expected in a healthcare lawsuit against the Trump administration.

Headline: Trump could soon fire Homeland Security Secretary Nielsen: Washington Post
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump has told advisers he wants to remove Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen from her post, and could do so in the coming weeks, the Washington Post reported, citing five current and former White House officials.

Headline: U.S. top court rejects Trump administration bid to halt climate trial
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Friday rejected for now a bid by the President Donald Trump's administration to block a trial in a lawsuit filed by young activists who have accused the U.S. government of ignoring the perils of climate change.

Headline: Trump seeks end of Florida recount; Democrats win Arizona Senate seat
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday urged Florida election officials to end a recount and declare his fellow Republicans the winners of disputed races in last week's elections, while Democrats picked up a U.S. Senate seat in Arizona.

Headline: Factbox: Too close to call - U.S. federal, state elections still in flux
Article: Democrats took control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the Nov. 6 elections and Republicans held onto a majority in the U.S. Senate, but more than a dozen races remain undecided nearly a week later.

Headline: How the Florida recount will unfold - and why it matters
Article: Florida elections officials are racing to recount ballots this week after razor-thin voting margins left the state's marquee contests for the U.S. Senate and governor too close to call.

Headline: Associate of close Trump adviser expects to be indicted by Mueller
Article: An associate of Roger Stone, a longtime ally of U.S. President Donald Trump, expects to be indicted by the U.S. special counsel probing Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, he said on Monday.

Headline: Tunisian parliament approves prime minister's cabinet reshuffle
Article: The Tunisian parliament approved on Monday a cabinet reshuffle proposed by Prime Minister Youssef Chahed amid a political and economic crisis.

Headline: Party at Mark's: U.S. congressman offers to put up D.C. newcomers
Article: A leader of the Democratic Party's progressive wing in Congress on Monday extended an invitation meant to reassure new representatives worried about affording Washington rent: "Crash at my place."

Headline: City of San Francisco threatens court action over Trump's acting Attorney General
Article: San Francisco's city attorney on Monday questioned the recent appointment of a new acting attorney general, saying in a letter to the U.S. Department of Justice that his office may take court action if the DOJ does not provide a legal justification for the designation.

Headline: Florida Republican Scott asks that ballots be guarded in Senate race recount
Article: Florida Republican Governor Rick Scott, whose lead has narrowed in the state's U.S. Senate race, filed more lawsuits against local election officials on Sunday, asking a judge to order police to impound voting machines and ballots when they are not in use.

Headline: Democrats to probe Trump actions on AT&T, Amazon: aide
Article: When Democrats take control of the U.S. House they plan to investigate the Trump administration's attempt to block AT&T Inc from acquiring Time Warner, and whether officials sought to punish Amazon.com Inc by prodding the U.S. Post Office to hike shipping prices for the world's largest e-commerce company, a senior Democrat and a congressional aide said on Sunday.

Headline: Democrats urge acting attorney general to step aside from Russia probe
Article: Top Democrats stepped up pressure Sunday on acting U.S. Attorney General Matthew Whitaker to step aside from overseeing a special counsel probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, vowing to order him to testify early next year.

Headline: Florida orders vote recount in Senate, governor races
Article: Florida will hold a machine recount of votes in its neck-and-neck races for the U.S. Senate and governor, officials said on Saturday, setting up a days-long wait for closure in two of the most closely-watched contests of the midterm elections.

Headline: Trump limits asylum from Mexico border, caravans head north
Article: President Donald Trump on Friday effectively suspended the granting of asylum to migrants who cross the U.S.-Mexico border illegally, seeking fresh ways to block thousands of Central Americans traveling in caravans from entering the United States.

Headline: Senate Democrats weigh lawsuit over Trump Justice Department appointment
Article: U.S. Senate Democrats are considering legal action over President Donald Trump's appointment of a new acting attorney general, congressional sources said on Friday, as some outside experts called the move unconstitutional.

Headline: Democrats dig in for Florida recount battle, Trump sends lawyers
Article: Florida's bitter races for the U.S. Senate and governor appeared headed to recounts on Friday as Republican leads narrowed, and President Donald Trump vowed to send in lawyers in a development reminiscent of the state's dramatic 2000 presidential recount.

Headline: California-based appeals court has been thorn in Trump's side
Article: A liberal-leaning California-based federal appeals court that has often ruled against President Donald Trump dealt him another setback this week in a major immigration case and soon could be asked to weigh in on a pipeline project he has championed.

Headline: Federal court asks how Sessions' ouster impacts lawsuit challenging Mueller
Article: A federal appeals court that is weighing a legal challenge to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's authority said Friday it wanted to know whether the sudden ouster of Attorney General Jeff Sessions could impact or change the outcome of how it should rule.

Headline: Democratic lawyer enters Florida recount fight with string of wins
Article: Attorney Marc Elias thinks imperiled Florida Democratic U.S. Senator Bill Nelson can win a recount, similar to his prediction a decade ago in another tight Senate contest.

Headline: U.S. rights groups seek to block Trump asylum order
Article: Civil rights groups said on Friday they had filed a federal lawsuit challenging the legality of U.S. President Donald Trump's newly announced restrictions that would effectively bar illegal migrants from Mexico from qualifying for asylum.

Headline: Trump jabs back at 'Mr. Kellyanne Conway,' an unusual critic
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday took a jab at a conservative lawyer whose critical tweets and editorials have attracted an outsized following because he is married to a top aide to the president.

Headline: Republican senator calls for vote on bill to bar Trump from firing special counsel
Article: U.S. Republican Senator Susan Collins said on Friday that she wants the Senate to vote on legislation to restrict President Donald Trump's ability to fire the special counsel probing Russia's meddling in the 2016 U.S. election and whether Trump's campaign colluded with Moscow.

Headline: U.N. tells Washington to protect refugees after Trump limits asylum
Article: The United States must make sure anyone fleeing violence or persecution can get protection "without obstruction", the U.N. refugee agency UNHCR said on Friday, hours after U.S. President Donald Trump signed an order limiting asylum rights.

Headline: Trump: sending lawyers to contested vote in Broward County, Florida
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday he would send lawyers to expose what he said without evidence was "fraud" in contested voting in Broward County, Florida.

Headline: In memoir, Michelle Obama says she'll never forgive Trump birther claims
Article: Former first lady Michelle Obama will never forgive President Donald Trump for promoting a bigoted conspiracy theory that questioned whether her husband was born in the United States, the Washington Post reported on Friday.

Headline: Schumer asks Trump about Whitaker attorney general appointment
Article: U.S. Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer on Friday questioned the legality of President Donald Trump's appointment of Matthew Whitaker as acting attorney general and sent the Republican president a list of questions about the move.

Headline: Trump says will nominate new ambassador to U.N. by end of the year
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday he would make a decision on nominating a new U.S. ambassador to the United Nations by the end of the year.

Headline: Trump calls court decision on Keystone pipeline political, a disgrace
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday blasted a federal court decision halting the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, saying the U.S. judge in Montana had made a political decision and calling it a disgrace.

Headline: Before he is ousted, Sessions limits U.S. oversight of local police
Article: The U.S. Department of Justice has moved to sharply curtail federal authority aimed at curtailing abuse and civil rights violations at local police departments across the country by directing U.S. attorneys to limit the use of consent decrees and settlement agreements.

Headline: Whitakerâ€™s friendship with Trump aide reignites recusal debate
Article: President Donald Trump's pick for acting attorney general, Matt Whitaker, is a close friend of Trump's 2016 election campaign co-chair, and a former government ethics chief said the friendship makes Whitaker unable to oversee impartially a politically charged investigation into the campaign.

Headline: Recounts, runoffs loom over high-profile elections in Florida, Georgia
Article: High-profile U.S. elections in Georgia, Florida and Arizona remained unresolved on Thursday, two days after the vote, with the prospect of legal challenges, recounts and ballot reviews setting the stage for possible weeks of uncertainty.

Headline: Democrats seek hearings on Trump's ouster of Sessions
Article: Congressional Democrats on Thursday demanded emergency hearings in the U.S. House of Representatives to investigate President Donald Trump's ouster of Attorney General Jeff Sessions, calling the move an effort to undermine a federal probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.

Headline: Key Democratic lawmaker may invite bank CEOs to testify before U.S. Congress
Article: Democrat Maxine Waters, poised to become chair of the U.S. House banking committee, told Reuters on Thursday she would like the heads of the country's biggest banks to testify before the panel as she seeks to ramp up regulatory oversight.

Headline: U.S. court case tests Special Counsel Mueller's power, status
Article: A U.S. Justice Department attorney on Thursday spelled out the circumstances under which Special Counsel Robert Mueller could be fired in a court case that took on new significance this week after President Donald Trump ousted his attorney general.

Headline: California House races hang in balance amid slow vote count
Article: California's pro-Russia congressman, Dana Rohrabacher, is one of four Republican incumbents in the state whose seats are still in danger of falling to Democratic opponents in the U.S. House of Representatives as America's most populous state slowly counts its votes.

Headline: Trump administration moves to curb migrants' asylum claims
Article: The Trump administration unveiled new rules on Thursday to sharply limit migrant asylum claims by barring individuals who cross the U.S. southern border illegally from seeking asylum.

Headline: U.S. appeals court rules against Trump on DACA immigration program
Article: A U.S. appeals court in California ruled on Thursday that President Donald Trump's administration must continue a program begun under former President Barack Obama that protects hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who were brought into the country as children.

Headline: U.S. Republican McHenry to seek senior party post on House finance panel
Article: U.S. Representative Patrick McHenry said on Thursday he was seeking the top Republican position on the House finance panel, and received the backing of a fellow Republican who had been considered the top contender for the role.

Headline: Trade players to watch in Congress after Democrats retake House
Article: The trade landscape in the U.S. House of Representatives will shift significantly next year following Democrats' seizure of control in Tuesday's elections. In the Senate, the Republicans strengthened their majority. Here is a look at key congressional trade players to watch:

Headline: Factbox: Democrats pick up net 32 seats in U.S. House, with some races still undecided
Article: Democrats have gained a net 32 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives after elections on Tuesday, with only seven races still undecided, according to the latest projections by media outlets and data provider DDHQ.

Headline: Newly emboldened Democrats want healthcare protected - and Trump impeached: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Democrats have a clear message for party leaders who will take control of the U.S. House of Representatives next year, according to a Reuters/Ipsos national opinion poll: Protect their healthcare and impeach President Donald Trump.

Headline: Democrats warn Trump after Attorney General Sessions forced out
Article: The ouster of Attorney General Jeff Sessions by President Donald Trump on Wednesday drew sharp criticism from Democrats, who warned Trump against moving to squash a probe of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Headline: Factbox: Can the new U.S. attorney general shut down the Mueller probe?
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's decision on Wednesday to oust Attorney General Jeff Sessions and replace him with a noted critic of Special Counsel Robert Mueller raised immediate fears among Democrats about the future of Mueller's investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Headline: Trump ousts Sessions, vows to fight Democrats if they launch probes
Article: President Donald Trump forced out his attorney general on Wednesday and threatened to fight back if Democrats use their new majority in the U.S. House of Representatives to launch investigations into his administration and finances.

Headline: Democrat beats Republican Karen Handel in Georgia House race
Article: Democrat and gun-control advocate Lucy McBath defeated Republican U.S. Representative Karen Handel in a congressional race in Georgia, racking up another seat for Democrats who won control of the House of Representative in Tuesday's elections.

Headline: For Democrats, U.S. House win moves Pelosi to center stage
Article: Now that the Democrats have won control of the U.S. House of Representatives, they need to choose a leader and that means solving one of their toughest puzzles: Nancy Pelosi.

Headline: Democrat-led House seen backing Trumpâ€™s China trade war, scrutinizing talks with allies
Article: The new Democrat majority in the U.S. House of Representatives is likely to back President Donald Trump's trade war with China and could even egg him on, but will offer tougher scrutiny of his negotiations with allies, trade experts and lawmakers say.

Headline: Battle looms in Congress over money for Trump's border wall
Article: When the U.S. Congress reconvenes on Nov. 13, it will face a deadline less than a month later to fund parts of the federal government and a possible showdown over money for President Donald Trump's proposed U.S.-Mexico border wall.

Headline: Defiant Trump blames media, fellow Republicans for House losses
Article: The day after his party lost its lock on the U.S. Congress, President Donald Trump walked into a White House press conference ready for political combat, name-checking Republicans who he blamed for losing their seats and lashing out at reporters who challenged his assertions.

Headline: Activists call for nationwide protests to protect Mueller investigation
Article: U.S. progressive groups will stage hundreds of protests nationwide on Thursday to demand that President Donald Trump do nothing to hinder an ongoing investigation into Russian meddling to help him win the 2016 U.S. election.

Headline: Loss of U.S. House leaves Republicans more tied to Trump than ever
Article: Republicans' loss of control of the U.S. House of Representatives leaves the party with a more conservative congressional caucus that is even more bound to President Donald Trump and more united around his provocative rhetoric and hardline agenda.

Headline: Factbox: 'You're fired!': how Trump has dismissed White House staff
Article: Before he became U.S. president, Donald Trump was famous for dismissing contestants on his television show "The Apprentice" with a resounding "You're fired!"

Headline: Democrats ready to pursue aggressive Trump oversight: Pelosi
Article: The top Democrat in the U.S. House of Representatives pledged a new era of congressional scrutiny over President Donald Trump on Wednesday, shrugging off White House threats of political warfare if Democrats launch investigations into his affairs.

Headline: Arizona could wait a week to learn who its next U.S. senator will be
Article: Arizona voters may have to wait a week or more to learn whether their U.S. senator is Republican Martha McSally or Democrat Kyrsten Sinema, as some 600,000 ballots remained uncounted as of Wednesday afternoon.

Headline: More candidates, more money and a big bet: How Democrats won the House
Article: The Democratsâ€™ mantra for seizing control of the U.S. House of Representatives took shape within weeks of President Donald Trumpâ€™s stunning 2016 White House victory.

Headline: Republican declares Georgia governor win, Democrat does not concede
Article: Republican Brian Kemp's campaign said on Wednesday he had won Georgia's high-profile governor's race, but Democratic candidate Stacey Abrams vowed not to concede until all ballots were counted.

Headline: Democrats to push for big infrastructure bill with 'real money' in 2019
Article: The incoming head of the U.S. House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee wants the White House to back significant additional federal funds to rebuild crumbling U.S. roads, bridges and airports, as President Donald Trump suggested on Wednesday a deal could be had.

Headline: Factbox: Democrats pick up net 29 seats in U.S. House, with some races still outstanding
Article: U.S. voters went to the polls in congressional elections on Tuesday for all 435 seats of the House of Representatives.

Headline: Privacy, drug price bills have a shot in divided Congress
Article: In a divided U.S. Congress, with Democrats in control of the House of Representatives and the Senate in Republican hands, the number of bills likely to be signed into law falls dramatically.

Headline: Factbox: Republicans gain a net three seats in U.S. Senate, with two races outstanding
Article: Republicans were projected to retain control of the U.S. Senate after voters cast ballots on Tuesday in races to decide 35 of the chamber's 100 seats.

Headline: Women candidates 'tired of waiting' make record gains in U.S. Congress
Article: First-time political candidate Jahana Hayes has a simple explanation for why she - and a record number of other women - ran for seats in the U.S. Congress this year.

Headline: Democrat Evers wrests Wisconsin governorship from Republican Walker: DDHQ
Article: Democrat Tony Evers won the Wisconsin governor's race on Tuesday, ending the conservative Scott Walker's eight years in power, according to data provider DDHQ.

Headline: U.S. House freshman class includes most veterans in nearly a decade
Article: The freshman class of the new Congress will boast the largest number of military veterans in nearly a decade, including a record number of former servicewomen, bolstering a corps of ex-military lawmakers that has been depleted in recent years.

Headline: Top Senate Democrat Schumer: Whitaker should recuse himself from Russia probe
Article: Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said on Wednesday that acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, who was appointed by President Donald Trump after he fired Jeff Sessions, should recuse himself from oversight of the Russia probe.

Headline: Sessions' firing is 'blatant attempt' to end Russia probe: Pelosi
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's firing of Attorney General Jeff Sessions is a "blatant attempt" to undermine and end the special counsel's probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. elections, House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi said on Wednesday.

Headline: How a Democratic U.S. House could alter foreign policy
Article: Democrats will use their new majority in the U.S. House of Representatives to reverse what they see as a hands-off approach by Republicans toward President Donald Trump's foreign policy, and push for tougher dealings with Russia, Saudi Arabia and North Korea.

Headline: Victorious U.S. House Democrats could stymie census citizenship query
Article: With their party set to control the U.S. House of Representatives after Tuesday's congressional elections, Democrats are already looking to halt the Trump administration's efforts to collect citizenship data during the 2020 U.S. Census.

Headline: Acting U.S. attorney general to oversee Russia probe: spokeswoman
Article: Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker will oversee all matters under the Justice Department's purview, including the Russia probe that had been supervised by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, a department spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump would consider regulating social media but urges caution
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said he would consider working with Democrats to regulate social media companies, after he and other conservatives accused companies such as Twitter Inc, Facebook Inc and Alphabet Inc's Google of allegedly stifling right wing views.

Headline: Factbox: Women shatter many barriers in Congress, states in U.S. elections
Article: From New Mexico's Debra Haaland, who became one of the first two indigenous women elected to the U.S. Congress to New York's Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who at 29 became the youngest woman elected to the chamber, American political candidate notched several precedents in this week's elections.

Headline: Factbox: Democratic critics of Trump set to lead U.S. House committees
Article: The Democratic takeover of the U.S. House of Representatives will likely put the leadership of many congressional committees into the hands of some of Republican President Donald Trump's most prominent adversaries on Capitol Hill.

Headline: Pelosi: Democrats won U.S. House on healthcare
Article: Democrat Nancy Pelosi, poised to become the next speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, said on Wednesday her party's victory in congressional elections was due to its determination to preserve the massive healthcare reform law passed during the Obama administration.

Headline: Trump mocks losing Republican candidates for shunning him during campaigns
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday mocked Republicans who avoided campaigning with him before congressional elections and who were not elected during their races, referencing a list of candidates by name.

Headline: Factbox: Democrats to pick up net 28 seats in U.S. House - media/data provider DDHQ
Article: U.S. voters went to the polls in congressional elections on Tuesday for all 435 seats of the House of Representatives.

Headline: Infrastructure, healthcare, judges on U.S. Senate agenda
Article: U.S. Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell said on Wednesday infrastructure, healthcare and judicial appointments would be on the agenda in 2019, after Republicans widened their majority in the Senate but lost control of the House of Representatives in Tuesday's elections.

Headline: Democrat Jon Tester keeps U.S. Senate seat in Montana: media
Article: Democrat Jon Tester, who has represented Montana in the U.S. Senate for more than a decade, overcame a tough election challenge from Republican Matt Rosendale to keep his seat, media outlets reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump praises Interior's Zinke, but vows to look at ethics allegations
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday praised Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, who has come under scrutiny for his use of a security detail, chartered flights and a real estate deal, but seemed to leave open the possibility of replacing him.

Headline: Trump says wants border wall funding, sees possible DACA
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday said he hopes he can work with Congress on immigration to fund his border wall, as well as possibly addressing the thousands of young immigrants living in the United States without legal status.

Headline: Trump says Pence to be his running mate in 2020
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that Vice President Mike Pence would be his running mate once again in the 2020 presidential election, when he hopes to capture a second term in the White House.

Headline: Dead Republican brothel owner wins election in Nevada
Article: A brothel-owning, evangelical Christian-backed Republican candidate who died last month won his race for the Nevada state legislature late on Tuesday, according to state election officials.

Headline: Democratic US senator eyes recount in battleground Fla. race
Article: Democratic U.S. Senator Bill Nelson, seeking to hold onto his seat in Florida, vowed on Wednesday to pursue a recount in his race against his Republican challenger and close Trump ally Rick Scott.

Headline: Democrats pick up 28 seats in U.S. House: media/data provider DDHQ
Article: Democrats won more than the 23 seats needed to take control of the U.S. House of Representatives after U.S. voters went to the polls in Tuesday's midterm congressional election.

Headline: Republican concedes Connecticut's gubernatorial race to Democrat
Article: The Republican seeking the Connecticut governorship conceded the race to his Democratic rival on Wednesday, handing the Democratic party another statehouse win following Tuesday's midterm U.S. election.

Headline: U.S. Rep. Steve King wins re-election despite furor over his views
Article: U.S. Representative Steve King, an Iowa Republican, won re-election late Tuesday despite publicly losing a corporate supporter shortly before Election Day and being criticized by some within his own party for inflammatory remarks on immigration and race.

Headline: Trump says Democrat Pelosi 'deserves' to be House speaker
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday threw his support behind top House Democrat Nancy Pelosi, saying she ought to be U.S. House Speaker, one day after Democrats won enough seats in the midterm congressional election to take control of Congress' lower chamber.

Headline: Trump tastes election defeat but finds some wins at White House watch party
Article: By the time President Donald Trump and his team tucked into hamburgers and hot dogs at a White House election watch party on Tuesday night, he was ready for the bad news.

Headline: Next up? Starting gun sounds on 2020 White House race
Article: Tuesday's elections sounded the starting gun for a long, crowded, expensive and no doubt dramatic race for the presidency.

Headline: Factbox: Potential U.S. presidential contenders in 2020
Article: Buoyed by Tuesday's takeover of the U.S. House of Representatives, Democrats can now turn their attention to the 2020 presidential race.

Headline: Trump to hold news conference on Wednesday after election: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will hold a news conference on Wednesday morning, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said in a post on Twitter, following results from Tuesday's midterm congressional election.

Headline: Germany: 'Europe United' must be answer to Trump's 'America First'
Article: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said on Wednesday that Europe must respond to U.S. President Donald Trump's "America First" agenda of tighter borders, protectionist economic policies and unilateralist diplomacy, with "Europe United".

Headline: It would be wrong to expect policy change from Trump after mid-terms: German minister
Article: It would be wrong to expect policy change from U.S. President Donald Trump after mid-term elections, German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said on Wednesday.

Headline: EU officials hail Trump setback in midterm elections
Article: The European Union's deputy chief executive hailed Democratic victories in the U.S. midterm elections in comments that took a clear swipe at what he called "rudeness" and "racism" under President Donald Trump.

Headline: Republican Rick Scott wins Florida U.S. Senate seat: Fox News
Article: Florida Republican Governor Rick Scott on Tuesday won the state's U.S. Senate election, unseating Democratic incumbent Bill Nelson, Fox News projected.

Headline: Republican Marsha Blackburn wins Tennessee's Senate seat
Article: Republican U.S. Representative Marsha Blackburn was elected to the U.S. Senate from Tennessee on Tuesday, defeating the state's former governor, Democrat Phil Bredesen, to help her party's efforts to keep control of the chamber.

Headline: Republican Senator Cruz holds off challenge by Democrat O'Rourke in Texas
Article: Republican U.S. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas held off an election challenge on Tuesday by Democratic U.S. Representative Beto O'Rourke, keeping his seat in the upper chamber of Congress, according to media projections.

Headline: Republican Braun wins Indiana U.S. Senate race, ousting Democrat: ABC News
Article: Republican businessman Mike Braun won Indiana's U.S. Senate election on Tuesday, unseating Democratic incumbent Joe Donnelly, ABC News projected.

Headline: Women, youth, Hispanics drive Democratic House wins: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Increased support from women, youth and Hispanic voters gave Democrats the boost they needed to take control of the U.S. House of Representatives on Tuesday, according to a Reuters/Ipsos Election Day poll.

Headline: Democrat Jacky Rosen unseats Senator Heller in Nevada
Article: Democratic U.S. Representative Jacky Rosen unseated Nevada's sitting U.S. senator, Republican Dean Heller, in one of the country's closest election contests, data provider DDHQ and CNN projected on Wednesday.

Headline: Factbox: Seven takeaways from the U.S. congressional elections
Article: Tuesday's U.S. congressional elections ended with what might be called a split decision. Democrats gained more than enough seats to take control of the U.S. House of Representatives, but lost ground to Republicans in the U.S. Senate and came up short in some key governor's races.

Headline: Joe Biden leads potential 2020 Democratic field: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden is the early leader for the 2020 Democratic Party nomination, a Reuters/Ipsos Election Day opinion poll found, in a field likely to quickly take shape as candidates seek to challenge Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Eyeing conservative U.S. top court, two states pass abortion measures
Article: Voters in Alabama and West Virginia on Tuesday passed ballot measures that could pave the way for new limits or a full ban on abortion in those states if the conservative-majority U.S. Supreme Court overturns the 1973 ruling that legalized abortion.

Headline: Instant view: Investor reaction after Democrats capture U.S. House majority
Article: Democrats rode a wave of dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump to win control of the U.S. House of Representatives on Tuesday, giving them the opportunity to block Trump's agenda and open his administration to intense scrutiny.

Headline: Minnesota, Michigan send first Muslim women to U.S. Congress
Article: Voters in Minnesota and Michigan on Tuesday elected the first two Muslim women to serve in the U.S. Congress, a former refugee who fled Somalia's civil war and a Detroit-born Palestinian-American.

Headline: Pelosi urges bipartisanship as Democrats win U.S. House
Article: A victorious Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday said Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives will use their newly won majority to pursue a bipartisan agenda for a country that she said has had "enough of division."

Headline: North Dakota voters set to reject marijuana legalization measure
Article: U.S. efforts to legalize recreational marijuana use saw mixed results on Tuesday, as voters in Michigan approved a measure legalizing the drug while North Dakotans looked set to block it.

Headline: Democrat Manchin keeps West Virginia Senate seat
Article: Democratic U.S. Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia won a tough election fight on Tuesday against the state's Republican attorney general, Patrick Morrisey, helping his party keep a narrow foothold in the conservative coal-mining state.

Headline: Republican Hawley unseats Democratic U.S. Senator McCaskill in Missouri: Fox
Article: Republican Missouri Attorney General Josh Hawley won his state's U.S. Senate election on Tuesday, unseating Democratic incumbent Claire McCaskill, Fox News Channel projected.

Headline: Instant view: Democrats take control of U.S. House of Representatives
Article: Democrats rode a wave of dissatisfaction with Republican President Donald Trump on Tuesday to win control of the U.S. House of Representatives where they will seek to keep his agenda in check and open his administration to intense scrutiny.

Headline: Republican DeSantis elected Florida governor
Article: Ron DeSantis won the Florida governor's race on Tuesday, bolstered by the strong support of fellow Republican President Donald Trump.

Headline: Florida approves ballot measure restoring felons' voting rights
Article: Florida voters on Tuesday approved a state constitutional amendment restoring voting rights to some 1.5 million people with felony convictions, ending a system that activists said disproportionately affected poor and black residents.

Headline: A month later, hurricane trips up Florida Panhandle voters
Article: Christy Todd said she is a regular voter in Mexico Beach, the oceanfront Florida Panhandle community nearly obliterated by Hurricane Michael less than a month ago. But she sat out Tuesday's elections.

Headline: Republican DeWine wins Ohio governor's race: NBC News
Article: Republican Mike DeWine won the Ohio governor's race on Tuesday, defeating Democrat Richard Cordray in one of the highest-profile U.S. gubernatorial contests, NBC News projected on Tuesday.

Headline: Intel-drafted U.S. data privacy bill would protect firms from fines
Article: Chipmaker Intel Corp said it is seeking a sponsor in Congress for a U.S. data privacy bill it drafted that would shield companies from fines if they attest to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission annually that they take strong measures to protect consumer data.

Headline: Voter advocates sue over delays at polling sites
Article: Voting rights activists successfully sued Georgia and Texas asking them to extend voting hours in some counties after problems with voting machines led to delays and long lines thanks to a big turnout in U.S. elections on Tuesday.

Headline: Republican Cramer unseats U.S. Senator Heitkamp in North Dakota
Article: Republican U.S. Representative Kevin Cramer on Tuesday unseated Democratic Senator Heidi Heitkamp, who has served North Dakota in the upper chamber since 2013, helping his party's effort to maintain control of the Senate.

Headline: Republicans retain control of the U.S. Senate: U.S. media
Article: Republicans will retain control of the U.S. Senate, American media outlets projected on Tuesday, even as Democrats appeared likely to capture control of the House of Representatives.

Headline: Factbox: Most closely watched U.S. ballot initiatives
Article: Voters in several states voted on Tuesday on ballot measures that could change state laws on a range of divisive social issues, including abortion and marijuana.

Headline: Fox News: Democrats projected to win control of U.S. House
Article: Fox News Channel projected on Tuesday that Democrats will win control of the U.S. House of Representatives.

Headline: U.S. voters targeted with limited 'misinformation' on social media: DHS
Article: The U.S. government has received reports of limited "misinformation" targeting American voters in social media posts on Tuesday, a Homeland Security Department official said as citizens cast ballots in hotly contested congressional elections.

Headline: Russia seen adopting new tactics in U.S. election interference efforts
Article: Russian agents believed to be connected to the government have been active in spreading divisive content and promoting extreme themes ahead of Tuesday's U.S. mid-term elections, but they are working hard to cover their tracks, according to government investigators, academics and security firms.

Headline: Reports of voting tech failure in elections 'sparse': U.S. official
Article: There have been "sparse" reports of voting technology failures in Tuesday's U.S. elections, but so far they have had no significant impact in preventing people from voting, a U.S. Department of Homeland Security official told reporters.

Headline: Democrat O'Rourke takes on big challenge: turning Texas
Article: In one of the biggest challenges for his party in Tuesday's elections, Beto O'Rourke hoped to oust Republican Ted Cruz and become the first Democrat elected to the U.S. Senate from the deeply conservative state of Texas in three decades.

Headline: Pompeo allows sanctions exception for Iran port development
Article: The top U.S. diplomat has granted an exception to certain U.S. sanctions that will allow the India-led development of a port in Iran as part of a new transportation corridor designed to boost Afghanistan's economy, a State Department spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: No signs of breaches in U.S. election infrastructure: DHS chief
Article: There have so far been no signs of breaches in U.S. election infrastructure during voting in Tuesday's congressional elections, U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen said.

Headline: For some in Florida Panhandle, voting takes back seat to hurricane hardships
Article: Sissy Karr, a landlady with 14 rental properties around Panama City, Florida, is a loyal Republican who voted for Donald Trump for president in 2016. But she says she is too busy cleaning up from Hurricane Michael to vote in Tuesday's elections.

Headline: Trump says would prefer softer tone as president but has 'no choice'
Article: Donald Trump said on Monday he wished he had taken a softer tone in his first two years as U.S. president, even as he continued to bash individual Democrats and fan fears over immigration while campaigning on the eve of congressional elections.

Headline: Republican strategists sweat over suburban, women votes in mid-terms
Article: Republican strategists Douglas Heye and Michael Steel were among U.S. political commentators and strategists interviewed by Reuters Global Markets Forum in the past week as investors and analysts searched for insight into the outcome of Tuesday's mid-term elections.

Headline: Two years in, Trump holds stock market bragging rights
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump has taken credit for the stock market's gains during his nearly two years in the White House, and those claims are reasonable given the impact of tax cuts and pro-business policies on investor sentiment.

Headline: Factbox: Fast facts about the U.S. elections
Article: Control of both houses of the U.S. Congress and 36 state governorships are at stake in Tuesday's elections, which are widely viewed as a referendum on Republican President Donald Trump's first two years in the White House.

Headline: U.S. vice president's visit to Japan being arranged for around Nov. 13: sources
Article: The Japanese government is working to arrange a visit to Japan by U.S. Vice President Mike Pence for around Nov. 13, two Japanese government sources said on Tuesday.

Headline: Kremlin declines comment on alleged meddling in U.S. mid-term election
Article: Russian President Vladimir Putin's spokesman on Tuesday declined to comment on allegations of interference in the United States' mid-term elections.

Headline: Hacking allegation shows peril of Georgia Republican's twin election roles
Article: The Republican candidate in Georgia's governor's race, who also oversees the state's elections, accused Democrats on Sunday of trying to hack voter registration systems, a move analysts said highlighted the inherent conflict between his twin roles.

Headline: U.S. networks drop 'racist' Trump ad as critical elections near
Article: NBC, Fox News and Facebook pulled an ad by President Donald Trump's campaign that critics had labeled racist as a bitter election fight for control of the U.S. Congress headed on Monday for an unpredictable finish.

Headline: Factbox: Breaking barriers: U.S. election winners could mark minority firsts
Article: The 2018 U.S. congressional elections prompted a surge of candidates from minority groups that have not had electoral success in the past.

Headline: Trump turns to Supreme Court to wind down 'Dreamer' immigration program
Article: President Donald Trump's administration asked the U.S. Supreme Court on Monday to allow it to end a program introduced by former President Barack Obama that protects thousands of young immigrants who live in the United States without legal status.

Headline: Citizenship query a threat to U.S. census, witness says as trial kicks off
Article: Adding a citizenship question to the 2020 U.S. Census questionnaire will yield a "systemic undercount" of immigrants by frightening some away from responding, warned a witness on the first day of a trial that could shape the U.S. political landscape for a decade.

Headline: For Trump supporters, elections a battle to protect a leader under siege
Article: For many Americans, Tuesday's congressional midterm elections are a referendum on Republican President Donald Trumpâ€™s divisive persona, hard-line policies and pugnacious politics.

Headline: Trump close to naming U.N. envoy, sees more Cabinet changes
Article: President Donald Trump said on Monday he would nominate a new U.S. ambassador to the United Nations by the end of the week and that more changes in his Cabinet may be coming.

Headline: Supreme Court rebuffs challenge to California gun restrictions
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court for a second straight year refused on Monday to hear a challenge to California's limits on carrying handguns in public, dealing another setback to gun rights proponents.

Headline: NBC, Fox News, Facebook pull Trump campaign ad linking immigration, crime
Article: NBC, Fox News and Facebook pulled a campaign ad linking a caravan of Central American migrants and a cop killer, which U.S. President Donald Trump endorsed and CNN deemed "racist," the media companies said on Monday. The primetime TV ads on NBC, paid for by Donald J. Trump for President, ran during a "Sunday Night Football" broadcast.

Headline: Facing long Senate odds, Democrats must first secure New Jersey
Article: For Democrats, Tuesday's New Jersey U.S. Senate election should have been a breeze.

Headline: Trump says China wants to make a deal on trade, he wants right deal
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that China has hurt the United States economically but was ready to make a deal on trade and he was open to a fair agreement.

Headline: As U.S. election nears racist fliers, antisemitic graffiti appear
Article: (This Nov. 2 story removes paragraph 10 to correct that former KKK leader David Duke did not publish tweet in 2018 but on Nov. 2 2017)

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Nov 5) - Dana Rohrabacher, Debbie Stabenow
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: State of play: As election looms, Democratic candidates hold their tongues on Trump
Article: Beyond the vegan meatballs and â€œMedicare For Allâ€ T-shirts, there was something else notable at a Democratic rally last week in the Washington suburb of Bethesda, Maryland: direct, no-holds-barred condemnation of the president.

Headline: Hot economy is cold comfort for Republicans in tight U.S. races
Article: Linda Hults is the sort of Republican who President Donald Trump would expect to reward his party for the hottest U.S. economy in a decade by helping defend its grip on Congress in dozens of tight races across the country.

Headline: Non-stop ads and robocalls: welcome to America's costliest election
Article: Wendy Burke has had enough. Campaign advertisements bombard her favorite TV shows. Dozens of election pamphlets fill her mailbox. Every day, she gets several political calls on her cell phone and more on her landline. Strangers knock at her door seeking her vote.

Headline: Ready for a fight: Voter enthusiasm surges among U.S. Hispanics
Article: Hispanics are more interested in voting this year than in the last U.S. congressional midterm elections in 2014 and their enthusiasm outpaces that of all U.S. adults, according to a Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll released on Sunday.

Headline: Democrats' road to controlling U.S. House runs through Pennsylvania
Article: Donald Trump's stunning 2016 White House win got a major boost from sagging Democratic enthusiasm in Pennsylvania, but now the party is poised for big wins on Tuesday in congressional races in the state that could signal which party controls the U.S. House of Representatives.

Headline: Trump touts economy, Georgia sees racist calls as U.S. vote nears
Article: President Donald Trump touted U.S. economic growth and painted a grim picture on immigration in rallies with Republican candidates before Tuesday's elections as Democratic former Vice President Joe Biden urged voters to reject division.

Headline: Obama warns against fear, Trump touts economy on campaign trail
Article: Former U.S. President Barack Obama warned on Friday against rhetoric he said was meant to sow fear as he campaigned in support of Democratic candidates while President Donald Trump hammered a hardline anti-immigration message to energize Republicans.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Nov 2) - Republican, West Virginia, Jobs
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: 'Cool to vote': Hollywood election telethon aims to get youth to polls
Article: Hollywood celebrities will make a push next week to urge young people to the polls in Tuesday's U.S. elections, when control of Congress and many state governorships are at stake.

Headline: U.S. courts rule against Georgia on voter suppression cases
Article: Two federal courts on Friday issued rulings that order Georgia to allow some 3,000 naturalized U.S. citizens to vote in elections next week and prevent the state from throwing out some absentee ballots.

Headline: Trump supportersâ€™ election test: a movement or a moment
Article: In rally after rally, President Donald Trump exhorts throngs of red-hatted supporters to treat next weekâ€™s congressional elections as a referendum on Trumpism and the grass-roots movement that swept him to power.

Headline: Banks to target moderate Democrats, regulators if U.S. House flips
Article: Financial industry lobbyists say they will focus their efforts on moderate Democrats and regulatory agencies if Democrats take control of the House of Representatives after next week's congressional elections.

Headline: Social media, tech firms use sites to urge U.S. citizens to vote
Article: Criticized by lawmakers and others for being unable or unwilling to stop false and inflammatory information about divisive political issues, social media and tech companies say they are doing more to boost voter turnout for next Tuesday's U.S. congressional elections.

Headline: U.S. top court won't halt trial over census citizenship question
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Friday rejected a request by President Donald Trump's administration to halt a trial set to begin on Monday that will test the legality of the government's contentious decision to ask people taking part in the 2020 national census whether they are citizens.

Headline: U.S. official felt 'obligation' to leak documents on Manafort, others: lawyer
Article: A lawyer for a U.S. Treasury Department employee charged with leaking to a journalist confidential documents on former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and others, said on Friday that his client was motivated by public service.

Headline: U.S. judge strikes down California law restricting federal land sales
Article: A federal judge has declared unconstitutional a California law that restricted the U.S. government's ability to sell or transfer federal land in the state to private entities, handing a victory to the Trump administration.

Headline: Exclusive: Twitter deletes over 10,000 accounts that sought to discourage U.S. voting
Article: Twitter Inc deleted more than 10,000 automated accounts posting messages that discouraged people from voting in Tuesday's U.S. election and wrongly appeared to be from Democrats, after the party flagged the misleading tweets to the social media company.

Headline: U.S. judge refuses to delay suit against Trump over foreign payments
Article: A federal judge on Friday rejected a bid by President Donald Trump's administration to delay a lawsuit alleging that his business dealings have violated a constitutional anti-corruption provision, moving the case toward the crucial evidence-gathering process.

Headline: Trump, Xi upbeat on trade after phone call; U.S. targets more Chinese firms
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who spoke by telephone on Thursday, expressed optimism about resolving their trade dispute ahead of a high-stakes meeting at the end of November in Argentina.

Headline: Trump predicts U.S. will reach a trade deal with China
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday that a lot of progress had been made with China on trade, and he predicted the world's two largest economies would reach a very good deal.

Headline: Democrats seek answers on Trump's role in U.S. FBI headquarters project
Article: Congressional Democrats on Friday asked the White House for more information about planning for a new FBI headquarters and released a government email that they said raises fresh concerns about the Trump administration's handling of the matter.

Headline: U.S., China 'not on the cusp' of trade deal: White House adviser
Article: The United States and China are not close to a deal to resolve their trade differences, the White House's top economic adviser said on Friday, adding that he was less optimistic than previously that such an agreement would come together.

Headline: Citizenship question could hamper U.S. Census response: official
Article: The Trump administration's decision to ask about citizenship on the 2020 Census questionnaire could undermine the quality of the data by discouraging non-citizens from responding, the U.S. Census Bureau's chief scientist said.

Headline: Trump has not sought draft China trade plan: CNBC
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump has not asked U.S. officials to draw up a proposed trade plan for China, White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow told CNBC in an interview on Friday, adding he was not as optimistic as he once was about the two nations reaching a deal.

Headline: U.S., Turkey lift sanctions in sign of easing tensions
Article: The United States and Turkey on Friday mutually lifted sanctions on top government officials, a sign of a thaw in relations that had been chilled by Ankara's detention of an American Christian pastor.

Headline: In West Virginia, Manchin faces tightening polls and a persistent Trump
Article: Democratic U.S. Senator Joe Manchin's re-election race was never going to be easy in conservative West Virginia, a state that President Donald Trump carried by more than 40 percentage points in the 2016 presidential election.

Headline: Economy glides, but fading 'Trump bump' may cast shadow over 2020 race
Article: President Donald Trump's bet that tax cuts and a gush of government spending would smooth the path to a second term may falter as cracks begin to appear in a decade-old recovery.

Headline: Trump promises immigration crackdown ahead of U.S. elections
Article: President Donald Trump said on Thursday his administration planned to require immigrants seeking asylum in the United States to come into the country through a legal port of entry, pushing a hard line on immigration ahead of elections next week.

Headline: Turkey lifts sanctions on U.S. officials, matching Washington's move
Article: Turkey lifted sanctions on Friday on the U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security and Attorney General, the foreign ministry said, minutes after Washington removed two Turkish ministers from its sanctions list.

Headline: Democrat struggles to keep hold on teetering Minnesota district
Article: Minnesota's rural northeast has sent Democrats to the U.S. Congress for all but two of the past 71 years, but its political shift can be seen in roadside billboards thanking Republican President Donald Trump for imposing tariffs on imported steel.

Headline: Explainer: High-stakes state elections will shape U.S. political power
Article: A high-stakes battle over state-level offices is playing out in the Nov. 6 elections, with Democrats and Republicans looking beyond Washington for more political firepower to resist or support President Donald Trump's agenda.

Headline: Young U.S. voter turnout surges, but challenges linger
Article: Early turnout by young voters has surged ahead of Tuesday's congressional midterm elections, powered by gains in states whose voters are pivotal to Democrats' chances of winning back control of the U.S. Congress.

Headline: China says Xi-Trump call was quite positive
Article: China's foreign ministry said on Friday that the previous day's telephone call between Chinese President Xi Jinping and U.S. President Donald Trump was quite positive.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (November 1) - China, Xi Jinping, Illegal immigration
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Ahead of U.S. elections, fears of voter suppression - and efforts to fight back
Article: Clemente Torres has proudly cast his vote in person at Dodge City's lone polling place in every election since he became a naturalized citizen 20 years ago.

Headline: TV titans Trump, Oprah go head to head on U.S. campaign trail
Article: Two former TV stars and political opposites - media mogul Oprah Winfrey and President Donald Trump - took to the U.S. campaign trail on Thursday, five days before elections that will determine whether Trump's Republicans retain control of Congress.

Headline: U.S. voters to decide $76 billion of bonds, taxation limits
Article: Election ballots around the United States on Tuesday will be packed with referendums for billions of dollars of state, local government and school bonds, as well as measures seeking to curb taxation, expand healthcare for the poor and increase school funding.

Headline: Oprah backs Stacey Abrams in historic Georgia governor's race
Article: Media mogul Oprah Winfrey lent her star power on Thursday to Georgia Democrat Stacey Abrams, who is vying to become the first female black governor in the United States, while saying she has no political aspirations of her own.

Headline: U.S. Senator Manchin's social media accounts hacked: statement
Article: U.S. Senator Joe Manchin was notified his social media accounts had been hacked, his office said on Thursday, amid U.S. government warnings of attempts to interfere in next week's congressional elections.

Headline: Democrats, some Republicans blast Trump ad as racially charged
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump faced scathing criticism on Thursday for an advertisement linking Democrats and immigrants to violent crime, with some fellow Republicans blasting it as "sickening" and the most racially divisive political ad in three decades.

Headline: Trump considering U.S. State Department spokeswoman for U.N. ambassador
Article: President Donald Trump on Thursday said he was seriously considering naming U.S. State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert to succeed Nikki Haley as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, adding he would make a decision on the posting soon.

Headline: U.S. State Department spokeswoman under consideration for U.N. ambassador: Trump
Article: President Donald Trump on Thursday said he is seriously considering naming U.S. State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert to succeed Nikki Haley as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, adding he would make a decision on the posting soon.

Headline: Trump says U.S. is finalizing plan to crack down on asylum seekers
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday the United States is finalizing a plan to deny asylum to people who enter the country outside legal ports of entry, as he hardens his stance against a caravan of migrants traveling from Central America.

Headline: China's Xi hopes to push for stable relationship with U.S.: China state media
Article: Chinese President Xi Jinping hopes China and the United States will be able to promote a steady and healthy relationship, Chinese state media reported on Thursday, as the world's two largest economies engage in a bitter trade dispute.

Headline: Trump's final campaign stretch rattled by twin calamities
Article: When Donald Trump met with advisers about his plans for campaign appearances in the final weeks for the battle for control of the U.S. Congress, the president surprised them by insisting they add more events to an already-crowded schedule.

Headline: Leadership upheaval in House awaits Trump after election
Article: President Donald Trump calls one of the top contenders to take over leadership of the U.S. House of Representatives next year "my Kevin" and frequently attacks the other, Nancy Pelosi.

Headline: Explainer: Democratic win of House would put Trump under microscope
Article: If Democrats win control of the U.S. House of Representatives or Senate in the Nov. 6 elections, nearly every aspect of Republican Donald Trump's presidency could face swift examination â€“ from his long-elusive tax returns to possible business ties with Russia and conflicts of interest.

Headline: Democrats up in hard-fought Florida; Republicans close gap in Arizona
Article: Democrats have pulled ahead in Florida's marquee races for the U.S. Senate and governor, a new Reuters opinion poll showed on Wednesday, as President Donald Trump returned to the battleground state in a closing bid to bail out Republicans.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Oct 31): Caravans, Pittsburgh, Stock Market, Immigration
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: U.S. Senate panel examines former Trump aide Bannon's campaign role: sources
Article: The U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee is pursuing a wide-ranging examination of former White House adviser Steve Bannon's activities during the 2016 presidential campaign, three sources familiar with the inquiry told Reuters.

Headline: White House, Republicans see 'swift action' on tax cut plan
Article: The White House and Republican lawmakers said on Wednesday they will take "swift action" next year on a 10 percent tax cut for middle-class Americans, as Republicans battle to retain control of the U.S. House of Representatives in next week's elections.

Headline: U.S. monitoring for foreign election interference: intelligence official
Article: The U.S. government is monitoring for possible foreign interference in Tuesday's congressional elections and is prepared to sanction any company or individual involved in such activity, a senior intelligence official said on Wednesday.

Headline: Oprah jumps into contentious Georgia race, endorses Democrat Abrams
Article: Oprah Winfrey plans to lend her star power to Georgia Democrat Stacey Abrams' quest to become the United States' first black woman governor at a couple of appearances in the state on Thursday.

Headline: Senators urge Trump to suspend nuclear energy talks with Saudi Arabia
Article: Both Republican and Democratic senators asked U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday to suspend civilian nuclear energy talks with Saudi Arabia after the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Headline: Trump contends U.S. Constitution does not cover birthright citizenship
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday the U.S. Constitution does not guarantee the right to citizenship to everyone born in the country, an assertion that runs counter to the long-established legal interpretation of the document.

Headline: Jane Fonda, Amy Schumer among stars to appear on U.S. voter telethon
Article: Hollywood celebrities including Jane Fonda, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Amy Schumer will take part in an online telethon on Monday to urge young people to pledge to vote in Tuesday's congressional midterm elections.

Headline: Once a refugee, Somali-American appears headed to U.S. Congress
Article: Ilhan Omar fled civil war in Somalia and spent four years of her childhood in a refugee camp in Kenya. Now she is poised to win a seat in the U.S. Congress, taking on a president who has tried to prevent people like her from coming to America.

Headline: U.S. House within Democrats' grasp, Senate a long shot
Article: After two years of wielding no practical political power in Washington, the Democratic Party faces a strong chance of winning control of the U.S. House of Representatives in next week's election, with Republicans likely to keep the Senate.

Headline: Special counsel Mueller's team asks FBI to probe 'false claims' against him
Article: Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team has asked the FBI to look into claims that women were offered money to fabricate sexual assault allegations against Mueller, who leads the probe into Russia's attempts to influence the U.S. election in 2016.

Headline: How the U.S. midterm elections could ripple through markets
Article: Gridlock, Blue Sweep or Red Repeat? Wall Street is closely watching the U.S. midterm Congressional elections next week, as policy decisions that could sway the economy, corporate decision-making and consumer spending hinge on the results.

Headline: Privacy, drug price bills have a fighting chance in a post-election U.S. Congress
Article: If Democrats win control of the House of Representatives in next week's elections and create a divided U.S. Congress, as they are seen as likely to do, the number of bills with a chance of passing falls dramatically.

Headline: Big Oil outspends billionaires in Washington state carbon tax fight
Article: The U.S. oil industry has spent a record $30 million to fight a ballot measure in Washington state that would create the nationâ€™s first carbon tax, double what an alliance of green groups and billionaire activists has spent to support it, according to state data reviewed by Reuters.

Headline: Trump ally Kobach in tough battle for Kansas governorship
Article: Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach, a staunch ally of Republican President Donald Trump, is locked in a tight race with state Senator Laura Kelly that could see the state elect its first Democratic governor in eight years, a Reuters poll found.

Headline: Trump says he expects 'great deal' with China, but more tariffs if not
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said he thinks there will be "a great deal" with China on trade, but warned that he has billions of dollars worth of new tariffs ready to go if a deal isn't possible.
