Headline: U.S. general says troop numbers at Mexican border to rise further
Article: The top U.S. general overseeing a deployment of more than 5,200 troops to the border with Mexico said on Tuesday that troop levels would rise further, but declined to say how high or estimate what the operation will cost.

Headline: Trump targets U.S. birthright citizenship as elections loom
Article: With congressional elections a week away, President Donald Trump on Tuesday said he will seek to scrap the right of citizenship for U.S.-born children of non-citizens and illegal immigrants as he tries again to dramatically reshape immigration policies.

Headline: Land O'Lakes ends support for U.S. Rep. King after furor over views
Article: Agricultural dairy cooperative Land O'Lakes pulled its support on Tuesday for U.S. Representative Steve King, an Iowa Republican whose past inflammatory comments on immigration and race drew renewed scrutiny after the massacre at a Pittsburgh synagogue.

Headline: Leading U.S. House Republican sees no future for capital formation bill
Article: A bill that would make it easier for companies to raise capital and go public appears to be going nowhere in the U.S. Senate, a top Republican lawmaker told Reuters on Tuesday, in what would be a blow to corporate lobbyists pushing for the legislation.

Headline: Probe of U.S. Interior Secretary Zinke's conduct referred to DOJ: reports
Article: The U.S. Interior Department's acting inspector general has referred a probe into Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke's conduct to the Justice Department for further investigation, media reports said on Tuesday, citing unnamed sources.

Headline: Republicans focus on defending U.S. Senate in campaign's last week
Article: Republican campaigns took a defensive approach a week before elections to determine control of the U.S. Congress, with the party spending more to try to hold on to previously secure House seats and President Donald Trump preparing a six-day trip focused on Senate races.

Headline: U.S. House Speaker Ryan rejects Trump plan on birthright citizenship: Washington Post
Article: U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan said on Tuesday that it was not possible to end birthright citizenship with an executive order, after President Donald Trump said he was considering such a move, the Washington Post reported.

Headline: Explainer: How a Democratic U.S. House could alter foreign policy
Article: Democrats will try to harden U.S. policy toward Saudi Arabia, Russia and North Korea if they win a majority in the U.S. House of Representatives, while maintaining the status quo on hot-button areas like China and Iran, congressional sources say.

Headline: Trump citizenship plan may not conflict with constitution: Pence
Article: The executive order that President Donald Trump is considering to curb birthright citizenship may not conflict with the U.S. Constitution, Vice President Mike Pence said on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. senator says will offer bill to back Trump birthright citizenship plan
Article: Republican U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham on Tuesday said he would introduce legislation to support U.S. President Donald Trump's plan to limit U.S. citizenship to certain children born in the United States.

Headline: In Trump-won U.S. House districts, Republicans seek a firewall
Article: For months, Republican U.S. Representative Steve Chabot was running about even with Democratic opponent Aftab Pureval in his traditionally conservative southwest Ohio district.

Headline: Factbox: Democrats gain steam in analyst forecasts for U.S. House races
Article: As of Tuesday, there were 65 U.S. House of Representatives races widely seen as competitive or leaning against the incumbent party.

Headline: U.S. top court wary of limiting company power to arbitrate disputes
Article: U.S. Supreme Court justices signaled on Monday they may issue more pro-business rulings giving companies wide latitude to use arbitration to resolve disputes with employees, customers or other businesses rather than the courts.

Headline: Congressional Democrats seek more action on U.S. domestic extremists
Article: Congressional Democrats on Monday called on U.S. law enforcement authorities to do more to track and prosecute far-right extremists after a mass shooting at a Pittsburgh synagogue and the mailing of bombs to critics of President Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump administration asks Supreme Court to halt trial over census
Article: President Donald Trump's administration asked the U.S. Supreme Court on Monday to postpone a trial set for Nov. 5 that will examine the legality of its decision to ask people taking part in the 2020 U.S. census whether they are citizens.

Headline: Elections could put Wall Street's favorite lawmaker in top finance role
Article: Next week's U.S. elections could see Wall Street's favorite congressman assume one of the most coveted roles setting financial policy on Capitol Hill - if Republicans retain control of the House of Representatives.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Oct 29) - Fake News, Brazil, Caravan
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Adelson and Buffett clash in Nevada showdown over electricity
Article: Casino magnate Sheldon Adelson and investor Warren Buffett are set for a desert showdown over electricity next week as the two billionaires' interests collide on election ballots in Nevada.

Headline: Supreme Court turns away Pennsylvania electoral map dispute
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday rebuffed a bid by Republican legislators in Pennsylvania to reinstate a congressional district map struck down by that state's top court as unlawfully biased in favor of Republicans.

Headline: No let-up in anger in U.S. campaigns after spate of violence
Article: WASHINGTON - Anger over the weekend massacre of 11 people at a Pennsylvania synagogue spilled onto the U.S. campaign trail with just over a week to go before elections that will determine control of Congress.

Headline: Former U.S. President Carter wades into heated Georgia governor's race
Article: Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter waded into the heated governor's race in his home state of Georgia on Monday, asking the Republican candidate to step down from his role as the state's top elections official.

Headline: Coal union boosts giving to Democrats as hopes dim for industry revival
Article: The top U.S. coal miners union has put a larger share of its campaign donations behind Democrats ahead of the Nov. 6 elections than in 2016, as dimming hopes for a coal industry revival led by President Donald Trump reinforce fears about the safety of worker pensions.

Headline: Would-be Democratic investigators have crossed swords with Trump
Article: Back when President Donald Trump was just a New York City real estate developer, he did battle over a Manhattan building project with a local U.S. congressman, whom he criticized as "one of the most egregious hacks in contemporary politics."

Headline: State of Play: With congressional election near, Republicans' talk turns Trumpian
Article: U.S. Senator Ted Cruz and Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker last week learned the same lesson many other Republicans have during this congressional election year: One way or the other, it is hard to escape Donald Trump.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 28) - FBI, Democrats, Fake News
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Trump's new tax cut plan probably waits for 2019: lawmaker
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives' leading lawmaker on taxes suggested on Sunday that a new tax cut plan touted by President Donald Trump was unlikely to see action in Congress before 2019, and then only if Republicans keep their majority in Nov. 6 elections.

Headline: Steyer accuses No. 2 House Republican McCarthy of anti-Semitism
Article: Democratic donor Tom Steyer on Sunday denounced as anti-Semitic a now-deleted tweet from Kevin McCarthy, the No. 2 Republican in the U.S. House of Representatives, that said Steyer and two other wealthy donors were trying to buy the November congressional elections.

Headline: Florida man charged after bombs sent to Trump critics
Article: The Florida man suspected of mailing at least 14 pipe bombs to some of U.S. President Donald Trump's leading critics was in custody on federal charges on Saturday, in a case reflecting the rancor of one of the most toxic election campaigns in decades.

Headline: Florida man charged in connection with 14 bombs sent to Trump critics
Article: The man suspected of mailing at least 14 pipe bombs to some of U.S. President Donald Trump's leading critics was arrested on Friday in Florida on federal charges in a case echoing the rancor of one of the most toxic election campaigns in decades.

Headline: Control of U.S. Senate may hinge on possible Mississippi runoff
Article: A crowded U.S. Senate race in Republican stronghold Mississippi could set the stage for weeks of uncertainty over which party ends up controlling the upper chamber of Congress after the Nov. 6 elections.

Headline: Trump says media uses bomb case to score political points against him
Article: President Donald Trump accused the U.S. news media on Friday of using reporting on the suspect in least 14 bombs sent to some of his prominent critics to score political points against him.

Headline: Chinese defense minister to visit Washington next week: Mattis
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said his Chinese counterpart would be visiting Washington next week to continue talks on military relations between the two countries.

Headline: From tweets to bombs, suspect's rage at Trump foes escalated
Article: Long before Cesar Sayoc was arrested on Friday for allegedly sending pipe bombs to critics of U.S. President Donald Trump, the 56-year-old former stripper with a long arrest record threatened to bomb a power company and posted angry rants.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 26): CNN, Twitter, Packages
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: ATP roundup: Federer tested, but moves into Basel semis
Article: Top-seeded Roger Federer had to work for it, but he ultimately beat Frenchman Gilles Simon on Friday to advance to the semifinals at the Swiss Indoors Basel in Switzerland.

Headline: U.S. invites Putin to Washington, but says get out of Ukraine
Article: The White House has formally invited President Vladimir Putin to Washington, U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton said on Friday, returning to an idea that was put on hold in July amid anger in the U.S. over the prospect of such a summit.

Headline: U.S. Democratic campaigns target healthcare as Republican weak spot: Reuters poll
Article: Democratic candidates for the U.S. Congress are closing out the campaign season with an ominous warning: telling voters millions of Americans could lose their health insurance or be forced to pay significantly more if Republicans win.

Headline: Mattis approves U.S. troops at border with Mexico
Article: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis has authorized the use of troops and other military resources at the U.S.-Mexico border, U.S. officials said on Friday, bolstering President Donald Trump's battle against migrants trekking toward the United States.

Headline: Trump says 'Bomb' stuff' slowing Republican momentum at polls
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday that news coverage of the pipe bombs targeting high-profile Democratic politicians and critics of the president had drowned out other stories and slowed Republican momentum ahead of congressional elections.

Headline: Early voting surges ahead of U.S. elections, and complaints follow
Article: Hope Norris showed up two weeks early to vote in Marietta, Georgia, and waited 45 minutes to cast a ballot for Democrat Stacey Abrams, who could become the first black woman governor elected in U.S. history.

Headline: Targets of suspicious packages in the United States
Article: FBI agents used DNA and a fingerprint to arrest a man in Florida suspected of sending at least 14 bombs to critics of U.S. President Donald Trump days ahead of congressional elections.

Headline: Trump to go on eight-state blitz ahead of Election Day
Article: President Donald Trump will campaign in eight states in the final days before Nov. 6 U.S. congressional elections, putting most of his attention on tight races in which Republicans have a shot at winning Senate seats, White House officials said on Friday.

Headline: Package bomb suspect faces up to 48 years in prison, Justice Department says
Article: The man suspected of sending at least 14 parcel bombs to critics of U.S. President Donald Trump faces up to 48 years in prison, the Justice Department said on Friday, correcting a figure cited earlier by Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

Headline: Possibility of other suspects not ruled out in package probe: U.S. official
Article: Law enforcement agencies are still investigating whether other people beyond a suspect now in custody may have been involved in sending suspicious packages that contained explosive material to prominent Democrats and critics of U.S. President Donald Trump, a federal official told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: Woman suing Trump for defamation loses bid for evidence about other women
Article: A former contestant on the television show "The Apprentice" who accused U.S. President Donald Trump in a lawsuit of defaming her by denying her claim that he kissed and groped her against her will, lost a motion to compel Trump to answer requests for evidence related to accusations against him by other women.

Headline: Parcel bomb suspect charged with five federal crimes, in FBI custody: Sessions
Article: U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions said on Friday that Cesar Sayoc, the suspect in a raft of suspicious packages sent to prominent Democrats and others, is in the custody of the FBI and has been charged with five federal crimes.

Headline: Suspicious package sent to Democratic Senator Harris
Article: A suspicious package similar to the parcel bombs sent to prominent Democrats and others this week was mailed to U.S. Senator Kamala Harris, a California Democrat who has criticized Republican President Donald Trump, according to an aide in the senator's office.

Headline: Judge rebuffs Trump administration on census question trial
Article: A federal judge on Friday rejected a bid by President Donald Trump's administration to halt a trial set to start on Nov. 5 testing the legality of its contentious decision to ask people taking part in the 2020 U.S. census whether they are citizens.

Headline: Suspicious package sent to Democratic donor Tom Steyer: CNN
Article: A suspicious package was sent to Californian billionaire Tom Steyer, a Democrat known for his ads calling for the impeachment of Republican President Donald Trump, CNN reported on Friday.

Headline: Trump suggests Twitter is biased against him, provides no evidence
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump suggested on Friday that Twitter Inc was biased against him and accused the social media company of deleting many of his followers and making it harder for users to follow him, without providing evidence.

Headline: Trump pledges to prosecute anyone involved in parcel bombs to fullest extent of law
Article: President Donald Trump said on Friday he had been briefed about the suspect that law enforcement earlier took into custody in relation to the recent spate of suspicious packages sent to prominent Democrats and others, saying the mailer will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

Headline: Man arrested in Florida is principal suspect in packages case: official
Article: The man arrested on Friday in connection with at least a dozen parcel bombs sent to top Democrats and high-profile critics of President Donald Trump is the principal and possibly sole suspect in the case, a federal law enforcement official told Reuters.

Headline: U.S. authorities arrest man in connection with suspected bombs: CNN
Article: Federal authorities have arrested a man in connection with suspected explosives sent in packages to top Democrats, former senior U.S. officials and prominent critics of President Donald Trump, CNN reported on Friday, citing unnamed sources.

Headline: Former U.S. intel chief Clapper: packages are domestic terrorism
Article: Former U.S. Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, who was reportedly the target of a suspicious package found on Friday, said the spate of package bombs mailed to prominent Democrats and other critics of President Donald Trump are clearly acts of domestic terrorism.

Headline: Trump adviser warns more sanctions against Russia could be coming
Article: The United States will do what it deems necessary, including considering more sanctions, to address Russia's interference in its elections and its annexation of Ukraine's Crimea, U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton said on Friday.

Headline: Trump adviser says Russia should 'get out of' Crimea and eastern Ukraine
Article: U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton said on Friday it would be helpful if Russia got out of Ukraine's Crimea and eastern Ukraine, stopped meddling in U.S. elections, and was less intrusive in the Middle East.

Headline: Trump adviser says wants U.S.-Russia strategic talks on Chinese threat
Article: U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton said on Friday that the United States wanted to hold strategic talks with Russia about China's belligerent activity.

Headline: Agents trace bomb found in mailbox at Soros' N.Y. home
Article: Federal agents were piecing together on Tuesday how a small bomb ended up in a mailbox outside a New York home owned by billionaire financier George Soros.

Headline: Democrats tie Trump's rhetoric to spate of suspected bombs
Article: The undercurrent of rage that has been driving U.S. politics for the past few years surfaced on Wednesday in a series of suspected bombs sent to prominent U.S. Democrats and the news outlet CNN less than two weeks before congressional elections.

Headline: Obama, Clinton among targets of suspected bombs ahead of U.S. election
Article: Former U.S. President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton were among the targets of suspected package bombs delivered to several high-profile Democrats and CNN, which the FBI said it was investigating as an act of terrorism.

Headline: Trump may send U.S. troops to Mexico border, but migrants undeterred
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration may send up to 1,000 active-duty troops to the U.S.-Mexico border, officials said on Thursday, as Trump hammered away at the issue of illegal immigration two weeks ahead of congressional elections.

Headline: Suspicious package found addressed to Senator Booker: reports
Article: An eleventh suspicious package has been found in Florida, this one addressed to Democratic U.S. Senator Cory Booker, CNN and MSNBC reported on Friday.

Headline: Special Report: How Republicans are using immigration to scare voters to the polls
Article: The commercial opens with an appeal to fear: a hoodie-wearing man prowling an alley, knife in hand. His face remains hidden but the ad makes it clear: Heâ€™s an illegal immigrant.

Headline: Trump weighing plan to ban entry of migrants at southern border: Washington Post
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is considering a plan to ban entry of migrants at the United States' southern border with Mexico and deny them asylum, the Washington Post reported on Thursday.

Headline: Design of bombs targeting Trump critics came from Internet: source
Article: Investigators believe that the design and instructions for building the bombs sent to several critics of U.S. President Donald Trump this week were taken from the internet, a federal law enforcement official told Reuters on Thursday.

Headline: Senator refers Kavanaugh accuser, Avenatti for criminal probe
Article: U.S. Senate Judiciary Chairman Charles Grassley on Thursday sought a federal probe of Julie Swetnick, who accused Brett Kavanaugh of aggressive sexual behavior before his confirmation to the U.S. Supreme Court, and her lawyer Michael Avenatti.

Headline: U.S. judge in Trump Foundation case rebuffs political bias defense
Article: A New York judge said on Thursday she would not entertain arguments that political bias was behind a lawsuit alleging President Donald Trump unlawfully used his personal charity to help his 2016 election campaign and benefit his businesses.

Headline: U.S. probe of suspicious packages focusing on Florida: source
Article: The U.S. investigation of suspicious packages sent to prominent Democrats and critics of Republican President Donald Trump is focusing on leads in Florida, a federal law enforcement source said on Thursday.

Headline: CIA chief to brief Trump after hearing Khashoggi audio
Article: CIA Director Gina Haspel will brief U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday on the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said after the spy agency chief heard an audio recording of the Saudi journalist's death.

Headline: With record number of women running in U.S. elections, gender gap could boost Democrats
Article: The record numbers of women running for office in the United States this year are mostly Democrats, and their party is banking on their candidacies and a widening gender gap on key issues to achieve big wins in the Nov. 6 elections.

Headline: Americans' anger may help Democrats in Nov. 6 vote: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Article: Ben Chico, 67, a Republican in California, says his annoyance with Democrats morphed into full-blown outrage when he heard they might try to impeach President Donald Trump after the Nov. 6 elections.

Headline: Worried about Trump iPhone eavesdroppers? China recommends a Huawei
Article: China's foreign ministry has some suggestions for the Trump administration if it is worried about foreign eavesdropping on the U.S. president's iPhones: use a Huawei handset instead.

Headline: Trump blames news media as two more suspicious packages are discovered
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump blamed news media outlets on Thursday for stirring up anger and hateful political rhetoric as two more suspicious packages were discovered, addressed to former Vice President Joe Biden and actor Robert De Niro.

Headline: Trump enacts anti-opioid abuse package in rare bipartisan step
Article: Medical treatment will be more widely available to opioid abusers while mailing illicit drugs will be more difficult under a measure to fight drug addiction that was signed into law on Wednesday by U.S. President Donald Trump.

Headline: Republicans push ahead with conservative Trump judicial nominees
Article: A Republican-led U.S. Senate panel on Wednesday held the second of two unusual hearings during a congressional recess in an aggressive push to confirm President Donald Trump's conservative judicial nominees including to a liberal-leaning California-based court he often criticizes.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Oct 24): Immigration, Borders
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: FBI confirms two more suspicious packages addressed to California congresswoman
Article: Two more suspicious packages, similar to those intercepted before reaching U.S. President Barack Obama and other high-profile Democrats, were found addressed to California Congresswoman Maxine Waters, the FBI said on Wednesday.

Headline: Investigators seeking suspicious package addressed to ex-Vice President Biden: official
Article: U.S. federal investigators are trying to track down a suspicious package they believe was addressed to former Vice President Joe Biden, a federal official said on Wednesday.

Headline: White House presses forward with Trump's Space Command
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's planned U.S. Space Command should seek to develop ways for the country's military to operate in outer space, White House advisers recommended on Tuesday, with the government hoping to secure approval for it by 2020.

Headline: U.S. has yet to decide if it will impose new sanctions on Russia: Bolton
Article: The United States has yet to decide if it will impose new sanctions on Russia, U.S. President Donald Trump's National Security Advisor John Bolton said on Wednesday, saying it was in the process of making a decision.

Headline: Factbox: Top Democrats, former U.S. officials sent suspicious packages
Article: Police on Wednesday intercepted suspected explosive devices sent to current and former U.S. politicians, as well as the CNN news channel, days after a bomb was delivered to prominent Democratic Party donor George Soros.

Headline: Ex-N.Y. state Senate leader gets prison in federal corruption case
Article: Former New York State Senate Majority Leader Dean Skelos was sentenced on Wednesday to four years and three months in prison on federal corruption charges, including soliciting bribes and defrauding the public.

Headline: Democrats Schumer, Pelosi say Trump has condoned violence
Article: U.S. Democratic leaders in Congress said on Wednesday that President Donald Trump's call for unity after suspicious packages were sent to leading Democratic figures "ring hollow" because of his past statements that condone acts of violence.

Headline: As Trump rails against Fed, Powell takes to Capitol Hill
Article: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell intensified his outreach to U.S. lawmakers over the summer, a review of his public calendar shows, even as President Donald Trump stepped up his attacks on the Fed and on Powell himself.

Headline: Trump promises thorough investigation into suspicious packages
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that threats of political violence have no place in the United States, promising a full investigation into suspicious packages that were mailed to prominent Democrats and others.

Headline: Congresswoman Waters says her office was target of suspicious package
Article: Democratic U.S. Representative Maxine Waters said on Wednesday that her Washington office was the target of a suspicious package.

Headline: U.S. lawmakers consider bill to ban arms sales to Saudi Arabia
Article: A bipartisan group of lawmakers introduced a bill in the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday that would stop most U.S. arms sales to Saudi Arabia in response to the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, Representative James McGovern said on his web site.

Headline: U.S. wants 'perfect clarity' on Khashoggi case: Pompeo
Article: The United States wants perfect clarity on what happened in the death of prominent Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said in an internal email sent widely to U.S. State Department employees.

Headline: Senators question Google's tardy disclosure of user data exposure
Article: Two U.S. senators said Alphabet Inc's disclosure of user data vulnerabilities at Google+ raised "serious questions" over whether it violated a 2011 consent decree with the Federal Trade Commission, potentially exposing Google to penalties.

Headline: Republicans gain ground in Texas, Nevada U.S. Senate races: poll
Article: Republican U.S. senators hold growing leads in key races in Texas and Nevada, a Reuters opinion poll showed, dampening Democratic hopes of taking a majority in that chamber in next month's congressional elections.

Headline: Facebook, Twitter do not find Chinese meddling in 2018 U.S. elections: Bloomberg
Article: Social media companies Facebook Inc and Twitter Inc have not detected Chinese meddling in the 2018 U.S. elections, Bloomberg reported https://bloom.bg/2AqGNku on Wednesday, citing unnamed press representatives for both companies.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 23): Tax Cuts, Puerto Rico, Tariffs
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: It's all relative: Family blasts Republican running for Nevada governor
Article: A Republican candidate for governor of Nevada ran into some stiff opposition on Tuesday from members of his own family, who urged voters not to pick him as the state's chief executive.

Headline: Congress postpones questioning U.S. Justice official on Trump, Russia probe
Article: Two U.S. congressional committees postponed a closed-door interview with Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein set for Wednesday where he had been expected to face tough questions about whether he discussed secretly recording Donald Trump and potentially removing the president from office.

Headline: Trump adviser tells Putin: We'll quit arms control treaty you're breaking
Article: Washington will press ahead with a plan to quit a landmark nuclear arms control pact despite objections from Russia and some European countries, senior U.S. official John Bolton said on Tuesday, after meeting Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Headline: House Republican tax lawmaker pledges to work toward new Trump tax cut
Article: The top Republican lawmaker on tax policy in the U.S. House of Representatives said on Tuesday that he is working with the White House and Treasury to develop a new 10 percent middle-class tax cut plan that President Donald Trump began touting over the weekend.

Headline: Former Pennsylvania mayor sentenced to 15 years for bribery
Article: A former mayor of Allentown, Pennsylvania, was sentenced on Tuesday to 15 years in prison for bribery and related crimes that prosecutors said he carried out to finance an abortive run for the U.S. Senate.

Headline: Indiana attorney general not charged after groping allegations
Article: Indiana's attorney general will not face criminal charges after four women accused him of groping them at a party, a special prosecutor investigating the sexual misconduct claims said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump says will probably meet with Russia's Putin next month
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he will probably meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin next month, when both leaders will be in Paris for the centenary of the end of World War One.

Headline: Bolton says we're a long way from deploying U.S. missiles in Europe
Article: Washington is a long way from taking decisions about deploying missiles in Europe as a consequence of its planned withdrawal from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) treaty, U.S. national security advisor John Bolton said on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. to formally quit arms control treaty 'in due course': Bolton
Article: U.S. national security advisor John Bolton said on Tuesday a formal notification of the U.S. withdrawal from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty will be filed in due course.

Headline: No decision yet on new sanctions on Russia: White House official
Article: U.S. national security advisor John Bolton said on Tuesday Washington had yet to take a decision on whether to impose new sanctions on Russia.

Headline: Bolton tells Kremlin: 'Don't mess with U.S. elections'
Article: U.S. national security advisor John Bolton said Russian meddling in U.S. elections had backfired on Moscow, providing a lesson to the Kremlin: "Don't mess with American elections."

Headline: Bolton tells Kremlin: 'Don't mess with U.S. elections'
Article: U.S. national security adviser John Bolton said on Tuesday that Russian meddling in U.S. elections had backfired on Moscow, providing a lesson to the Kremlin: "Don't mess with American elections."

Headline: Trump accuses Puerto Rico of using disaster funds for other debt
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday accused Puerto Rico's politicians of using "massive and ridiculously high amounts of hurricane/disaster funding" to pay off other debts, and said he would not allow a bailout with relief money.

Headline: Puerto Rico's revised fiscal plan approved over government opposition
Article: Puerto Rico's federally appointed financial oversight board on Tuesday unanimously approved a revised fiscal reform plan meant to put the bankrupt island on a path toward solvency, but faced opposition from its elected government for being too strict.

Headline: Iowa lawmaker urges EPA to speed up rule expanding ethanol sales
Article: Republican Senator Chuck Grassley said on Tuesday that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency must act quickly to allow year-round sales of higher ethanol gasoline blends if President Donald Trump aims to keep a campaign promise to corn farmers.

Headline: Trump eyeing a 10 percent middle-income tax cut plan
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump, speaking to reporters at the White House as he left on a campaign trip to Texas, said on Monday his administration planned to produce a resolution within two weeks calling for a 10 percent tax cut for middle-income people.

Headline: U.S. targets Russian operatives ahead of election: NYT
Article: The United States has launched a cyber campaign aimed at Russian operatives in an effort to curb misinformation ahead of the Nov. 6 congressional elections, the New York Times reported on Tuesday, in what it said was the first known such operation to protect American elections.

Headline: U.S. top court blocks questioning of Ross in census suit
Article: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday blocked a judge's order forcing Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross to give a deposition in a lawsuit by 18 states challenging a planned question in the 2020 census that would ask respondents whether they are U.S. citizens.

Headline: Judge bars New Hampshire proof of residency requirement for new voters
Article: A New Hampshire judge on Monday put on hold a law requiring some voters to present proof of residency when they register, saying it would lengthen lines at polling places and make it difficult for students, disabled voters and others to cast ballots.

Headline: Trump says transgender policy seeks to 'protect the country'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that transgender issues were in flux and he aims to protect the country after a report that his administration was considering defining gender as male or female based on genitalia at birth drew widespread condemnation.

Headline: Trump lawyer: Manafort said nothing damaging in Mueller interviews
Article: Under an unusual arrangement, Paul Manafort's attorney has kept Donald Trump informed about the former campaign chairman's meetings with prosecutors investigating Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election and, according to Trump's lawyer, Manafort has not said anything damaging about the president.

Headline: Trump's missile treaty pullout could escalate tension with China
Article: A U.S. withdrawal from a Cold War-era nuclear arms treaty with Russia could give the Pentagon new options to counter Chinese missile advances but experts warn the ensuing arms race could greatly escalate tensions in the Asia-Pacific.

Headline: Trump and former rival Ted Cruz rally together in Houston ahead of election
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump set aside his old feud with Senator Ted Cruz on Monday and headlined a packed rally to help the fellow Republican in his tight race in Texas with rising Democratic star Beto O'Rourke just two weeks before the Nov. 6 elections.

Headline: Trump says he remains unsatisfied with Saudi accounts on Khashoggi
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that he was still not satisfied with what he has heard from Saudi Arabia about the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Turkey, but did not want to lose investment from Riyadh.

Headline: Saudi foreign minister pledges full probe into Khashoggi killing
Article: Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said on Tuesday the kingdom was committed to a thorough and complete investigation to get to the truth behind the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Turkey.

Headline: Turkey yet to share information on Khashoggi case with any country: foreign minister
Article: Turkey has not yet shared any information with any country from its probe into the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, the foreign minister said on Tuesday, hours before President Tayyip Erdogan was due to reveal what he has said were details in the case.

Headline: Saudi says finance minister meets U.S. Treasury Secretary
Article: Saudi Arabia's Finance Minister Mohammed al-Jadaan met U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in Riyadh, a statement from the ministry said on Tuesday.

Headline: Businesswoman Olayan says confident Saudi government can resolve Khasoggi affair
Article: Saudi Arabian billionaire Lubna Olayan said on Tuesday she is confident that Saudi government can resolve the affair surrounding the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Oct 22): Caravan, Immigration Laws, Fake news
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: CIA chief to Turkey as officials seek to clarify prince's role in Khashoggi death
Article: CIA Director Gina Haspel was traveling to Turkey on Monday to help investigate the death of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, two sources familiar with the matter said, as security agencies examined what role Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman may have played in the case.

Headline: Trump says he believes Khashoggi's death was 'a plot gone awry': USA Today
Article: President Donald Trump told USA Today in an interview on Monday he believes the death of Jamal Khashoggi was "a plot gone awry," after the journalist died in the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.

Headline: CIA director Haspel travels to Turkey for Khashoggi case: source
Article: CIA Director Gina Haspel is traveling to Turkey on Monday to work on the investigation into the death of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.

Headline: Russia pledges 'balance' if U.S. quits nuclear pact; Trump eyes more weapons
Article: Russia said on Monday it would be forced to respond in kind to restore the military balance with the United States if President Donald Trump carried through on a threat to quit a nuclear arms treaty and began developing new missiles.

Headline: 'Don't throw baby out with bath water,' Germany tells U.S. on INF treaty
Article: Germany will seek NATO's help to maintain a nuclear arms treaty between Russia and the United States, and is ready to take action to force Moscow to comply with the pact, Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said on Tuesday.

Headline: Merkel: No German arms exports to Saudi until killing cleared up
Article: German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday called the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul a "monstrosity" and vowed to halt all German arms exports to Riyadh until the case is cleared up.

Headline: Saudi crown prince meets U.S.'s Mnuchin, Saudi state TV says
Article: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in Riyadh on Monday, Saudi state TV said in a tweet.

Headline: UK foreign minister: Saudi claim on Khashoggi death not credible
Article: British foreign minister Jeremy Hunt said on Monday it was not credible for Saudi authorities to claim that journalist Jamal Khashoggi died in a fight.

Headline: White House aide says we want full details on Khashoggi death
Article: The United States wants to know all the details of how Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was killed and talks on that are continuing with Saudi authorities, U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton was quoted as saying on Monday.

Headline: Trump threatens to build up U.S. nuclear arsenal against China, Russia
Article: President Donald Trump warned on Monday that the United States intended to build up its arsenal of nuclear weapons to pressure Russia and China.

Headline: Trump says U.S. to exit landmark nuclear arms pact, Russia threatens retaliation
Article: President Donald Trump said Washington would withdraw from a landmark Cold War-era treaty that eliminated nuclear missiles from Europe because Russia was violating the pact, triggering a warning of retaliatory measures from Moscow.

Headline: Trump unsatisfied with Saudi Arabia's explanations over journalist
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that he is unsatisfied with Saudi Arabia's explanations of what happened to missing journalist Jamal Khashoggi, but he does not want to lose investment from Riyadh.

Headline: Bolton denies U.S. trying to blackmail Russia over INF treaty: RIA
Article: The United States denies Russian allegations that it is trying to blackmail Moscow by saying it will withdraw from a nuclear arms treaty, U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton was quoted as saying on Monday.

Headline: Bolton says U.S. yet to finalize position on extending START treaty: RIA
Article: The United States has yet to finalize its position on extending the New START arms control treaty which is due to expire in 2021, President Donald Trump's national security adviser John Bolton said on Monday, according to the Russian news agency RIA.

Headline: Republicans fear Democratic 'blue wave' spreading to once-safe districts
Article: The last time U.S. congressional elections were held in this central Virginia district, Meg Sneed voted for the Republican incumbent, Representative Dave Brat. Her friend, Cheryll Lesser, did not vote at all.

Headline: State of Play: Tightening Arizona race threatens Democrats' slim Senate hopes
Article: For most of this year, Democratic U.S. Senate candidate Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona has run what has been viewed widely as one of the best races in the nation. But with less than a month to go to Election Day, there are doubts whether she can make it across the finish line.

Headline: State of Play: Democrats threaten Trump's grip on the Great Lakes
Article: Two years ago, Ohio and other states in the former industrial heartlands of the Great Lakes region catapulted Donald Trump into the White House.

Headline: U.S. in 'fact-finding phase' on Khashoggi: Kushner
Article: White House senior adviser Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, said on Monday the United States is still in a fact-finding phase on the murder of dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi and has its "eyes wide open."

Headline: Black 'lynching' ad illustrates race overtones, anger in U.S. campaign ads
Article: Many political ads in this year's U.S. elections pack an unusually harsh and personal punch - some with racial overtones.

Headline: Kremlin: We'll respond in kind if U.S. develops intermediate missiles
Article: The Kremlin said on Monday that Russia would be forced to respond in kind if the United States began developing new missiles after quitting a landmark Cold War-era treaty.

Headline: Moscow wants U.S. to explain planned exit from arms treaty: RIA
Article: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Monday that Moscow expected Washington to explain its plans to quit a landmark Cold War-era treaty that eliminated nuclear missiles from Europe.

Headline: France's Macron told Trump that nuclear pact is key to Europe's security
Article: French President Emmanuel Macron spoke to U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday to stress the importance of a Cold War-era nuclear treaty Trump said Washington would withdraw from, Macron's office said in a statement on Monday.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Oct 21): Jobs Numbers, Andrew Gillum, Facebook
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: U.S. lawmakers blame Saudi crown prince for Khashoggi murder
Article: Top U.S. lawmakers turned their ire on Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Sunday and said they believed he ordered the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, although the Trump administration maintained a more cautious stance.

Headline: Trump administration trying to define transgender out of existence: NY Times
Article: The government of U.S. President Donald Trump is attempting to strip transgender people of official recognition by creating a narrow definition of gender as being only male or female and unchangeable once it is determined at birth, The New York Times reported on Sunday.

Headline: Kremlin says we want answers from Washington over arms treaty plan
Article: Russian President Vladimir Putin will seek an explanation of why Washington plans to pull out of an arms control treaty when he meets U.S. national security adviser John Bolton in Moscow this week, RIA news agency quoted Putin's spokesman as saying.

Headline: Trump plan to quit arms treaty a mistake: Gorbachev
Article: Former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, a co-signatory of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, said on Sunday U.S. President Donald Trump's plan to quit the treaty was a mistake, Interfax news agency reported.

Headline: German foreign minister: U.S. should consider consequences of leaving nuclear treaty
Article: Germany's Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said the United States should consider the consequences, both for Europe and for future disarmament efforts, of pulling out of an international treaty aimed at eliminating a class of nuclear weapons.

Headline: Russia: U.S. exit from nuclear treaty would be a dangerous step - TASS
Article: Washington's planned withdrawal from the international Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty would be a very dangerous step, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov was quoted as saying by TASS news agency on Sunday.

Headline: New Zealand will not attend Saudi investment summit over Khashoggi death
Article: New Zealand condemns the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi operatives and will not be attending an investment summit in Saudi Arabia, the government said in a statement on Sunday.

Headline: Bolton readies Moscow visit amid U.S. concerns about missile treaty
Article: President Donald Trump's national security adviser, John Bolton, will visit Moscow next week for talks that may include telling Russian officials that the United States plans to withdraw from the landmark Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty.

Headline: Trump says team working on tax cut for middle-income earners
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said the administration was studying a tax cut for middle-income earners that could be rolled out some time around the beginning of November, just before pivotal congressional elections.

Headline: Trump would prefer to pick a woman for U.N. envoy
Article: President Donald Trump said on Saturday he would prefer to pick a woman to take over the job of Washington's United Nations ambassador.

Headline: Alaska's independent governor ends re-election bid, endorses Democrat
Article: Alaska Governor Bill Walker, a political independent, halted his re-election campaign on Friday and endorsed his Democratic challenger, ending a three-way contest in which neither had appeared capable of defeating the Republican front-runner.

Headline: Russian charged with conspiring to interfere in U.S. congressional elections
Article: The U.S. government on Friday charged a Russian national with playing a key financial role in a Kremlin-backed plan to conduct "information warfare" against the United States, including ongoing attempts to influence next month's congressional elections.

Headline: Factbox: How Russians may have acted to interfere with U.S. Congressional elections
Article: A U.S. indictment charging a Russian national with playing a prominent role in a Kremlin-backed plan to conduct "information warfare" to influence the U.S. midterm elections suggested that Russian influence operations have become more sophisticated since a campaign to impact the U.S. 2016 presidential election.

Headline: Trump a reluctant critic of Saudi Arabia despite pressure to act
Article: Six days after Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi disappeared, U.S. President Donald Trump tried to play down the crisis, saying "hopefully that will sort itself out".

Headline: Trump criticized for praising congressman who body-slammed reporter
Article: President Donald Trump reiterated his support for a Montana congressman who body-slammed a reporter last year, even as he came under criticism on Friday from U.S. lawmakers and press organizations.

Headline: Trump backs water projects in U.S. West as election nears
Article: President Donald Trump on Friday threw his support behind speeding up water projects for agriculture and hydropower in the arid U.S. West, a move aimed to help build support for Republicans in tight congressional races in next month's midterm elections.

Headline: 'Guardrails' needed on social media to combat election meddling in U.S.: Senator Warner
Article: The indictment on Friday of a Russian woman on charges of attempting to meddle in U.S. elections shows the need for "guardrails" on social media, the top Democrat on the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee said.

Headline: U.S. says Russia, China, Iran seek to disrupt elections
Article: The U.S. government warned on Friday that Russia, China and Iran were seeking to influence next month's congressional elections as federal prosecutors unveiled charges against a Russian national accused of participating in such a scheme.

Headline: Judge drops some charges against ex-Trump campaign aide Manafort
Article: U.S. prosecutors on Friday agreed to drop criminal charges against Paul Manafort that a jury deadlocked on in August, as a federal judge set a Feb. 8 date for the former Trump campaign manager's sentencing on charges of bank fraud and filing false tax returns.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 19): Mike Pompeo, Texas
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Fed monitoring Khashoggi case, potential oil market impact: Bostic
Article: U.S. Federal Reserve officials are monitoring the case of missing Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the possibility that any sanctions against Saudi Arabia could disrupt oil markets, Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said on Friday.

Headline: Florida's Republicans feel brunt of hurricane in upcoming election
Article: Two days after Katherine Shimonis returned to her home in the Florida Panhandle to find it destroyed by Hurricane Michael, she went to her local post office, which was empty and without power, and shouldered her way through the front door.

Headline: Trump praises U.S. congressman from Montana who body-slammed reporter
Article: President Donald Trump on Thursday heaped praise on a U.S. congressman from Montana who body-slammed a reporter during a campaign for a special election in 2017.

Headline: Trump threatens to send military, shut border as migrants head for Mexico
Article: President Donald Trump threatened on Thursday to deploy the military and close the southern U.S. border if Mexico does not halt a caravan of Central America migrants heading north, raising the risk of huge disruptions to trade.

Headline: U.S. Interior Department watchdog faults Zinke's travel practices: Washington Post
Article: Sending a security detail to protect Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke and his wife on a vacation to Turkey and Greece cost taxpayers more than $25,000, the U.S. Interior Department's watchdog agency has said, according to the Washington Post.

Headline: After ad gaffe, North Dakota's Heitkamp apologizes in Senate debate
Article: North Dakota Democratic U.S. Senator Heidi Heitkamp, facing a tough re-election fight, opened her debate on Thursday with Republican challenger Kevin Cramer by apologizing for a recent ad that named sex assault survivors without their consent.

Headline: Lawmakers to quiz Trump-Russia probe overseer Rosenstein
Article: Republican lawmakers will next week question Rod Rosenstein, the U.S. Justice Department official who oversees a special counsel's investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election and links between President Donald Trump's campaign and Moscow, committee chairmen said on Thursday.

Headline: Two top Trump aides tangle outside Oval Office over immigration
Article: Two of President Donald Trump's top advisers got into a heated exchange outside the Oval Office on Thursday as passions boiled over about how to handle illegal immigration, two sources familiar with the incident said.

Headline: Ex-FBI agent charged with leaking sentenced to 48 months
Article: A federal judge in Minnesota sentenced former FBI agent Terry Albury to 48 months in prison on Thursday for leaking classified information to a journalist, according to the U.S. Justice Department.

Headline: Thousands in U.S. South may not be able to cast ballots in early voting
Article: Thousands of voters in Tennessee were at risk of being blocked from casting regular ballots when early voting opened this week, as officials struggled to process a surge of new registrations ahead of Nov. 6 elections to determine control of the U.S. Congress.

Headline: Mexico government says will ask U.N. for help with refugee applications
Article: Mexico's Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Thursday that it would ask the United Nations refugee agency for help coordinating with Central American governments related to people seeking refugee status at Mexico's southern border.

Headline: Democratic victory in November would put Trump under microscope
Article: If Democrats win control of the U.S. House of Representatives or Senate next month, nearly every aspect of Donald Trump's presidency could face swift examination â€“ from his long-elusive tax returns to possible business ties with Russia and conflicts of interest, congressional sources say.

Headline: Democrats question plan for new FBI HQ near Trump's DC hotel
Article: Five senior Democratic members of Congress have questioned what they say is a Trump administration plan to build a new headquarters for the Federal Bureau of Investigation across the street from Donald Trump's downtown Washington hotel.

Headline: Pompeo recommends giving Saudis 'a few more days' for Khashoggi investigation
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Thursday that he had told President Donald Trump that the United States should give Saudi Arabia a few more days to wrap up its investigation into the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Headline: Trump administration asks high court to halt climate change case
Article: President Donald Trump's administration on Thursday for a second time asked the U.S. Supreme Court to put the brakes on a lawsuit filed by young activists who have accused the U.S. government of ignoring the perils of climate change.

Headline: Emmet Flood temporarily appointed counsel to president: White House
Article: The White House said on Thursday that Emmet Flood has temporarily taken on the role of counsel to U.S. President Donald Trump, beginning on Thursday and continuing until Pat Cipollone takes on the post.

Headline: U.S. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin withdraws from Saudi conference
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Thursday said he would no longer attend next week's investment conference in Saudi Arabia, as the Trump administration awaited the outcome of investigations into missing Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Headline: Democrat O'Rourke winning the Hispanic vote in Texas - but it's not enough
Article: In a packed Texas convention center, Democrat Beto O'Rourke drew cheers last weekend with a blistering critique of Republican rival Ted Cruz's support for deporting young undocumented immigrants, part of a stump speech aimed at inspiring Hispanic voters in the country's most expensive and closely watched Senate race.

Headline: As tensions mount, Mattis seeks more resilient U.S. ties with China's military
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told his Chinese counterpart on Thursday that the world's two largest economies needed to deepen high-level ties so as to navigate tension and rein in the risk of inadvertent conflict.

Headline: How Democrats hope to obtain Trump's tax returns
Article: The U.S. Congress could request President Donald Trump's tax returns under a seldom-used 1924 law, which Democrats say they plan to invoke promptly if they win control of the House of Representatives or the Senate in the Nov. 6 elections.

Headline: Late brothel owner Hof will win Nevada vote: campaign manager
Article: A brothel-owning Republican candidate for the Nevada state legislature who died this week will remain on the ballot and win his election in November, his campaign manager predicted on Wednesday.

Headline: What the dispute over U.S. aid means to Central America
Article: More Honduran migrants tried to join a caravan of several thousand moving through Guatemala on Wednesday, defying calls by authorities not to make the journey after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to cut off regional aid in reprisal.

Headline: McConnell says Senate Republicans might revisit Obamacare repeal
Article: Republicans could try again to repeal Obamacare if they win enough seats in U.S. elections next month, Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell said on Wednesday, calling a failed 2017 push to repeal the healthcare law a "disappointment."

Headline: Trump to nominate former Air Force general as top Asia diplomat
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump plans to nominate former Air Force General David Stilwell to be the State Department's top diplomat for East Asia, a post that has remained unfilled for more than a year despite major challenges in the region.

Headline: Trump turns attention to budget cutting after slashing taxes
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump, faced with a budget deficit at a six-year high, on Wednesday told his Cabinet to come up with proposals to cut spending by their agencies by 5 percent, but he suggested the military would be largely spared.

Headline: U.S. eyes more Venezuelan sanctions, but oil on backburner: U.S. official
Article: The United States plans to turn up sanctions pressure on Venezuela but sees less need to immediately target its energy sector, given sagging production from the OPEC member's state-run oil company, a senior U.S. administration official said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. Treasury official charged with leaks linked to Russia probe
Article: A U.S. Treasury Department official has been criminally charged with leaking confidential documents relating to former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and others to a reporter from digital media company BuzzFeed, Manhattan federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump touts push to rescind government regulations
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday praised White House efforts to remove regulations that he sees as an impediment to economic growth, saying the administration had reduced regulatory costs by $23 billion in the year ending Sept. 30.

Headline: O'Rourke gets tough in U.S. Senate battle in Texas, but is it too late?
Article: Falling behind in the polls and running out of time, the Democratic contender for the U.S. Senate went on the attack against Republican incumbent Ted Cruz in a raucous debate in Texas on Tuesday night, calling him dishonest and resurrecting President Donald Trump's campaign nickname, "Lyin' Ted."

Headline: Chicago mayor skips over pension funding fix in final budget speech
Article: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel unveiled the final budget of his tenure on Wednesday, but put off addressing a pension funding challenge that will hit during his eventual successor's term in office.

Headline: Senate leader: Congress should not join 'pile-on' on Myanmar's Suu Kyi
Article: The Republican leader of the U.S. Senate said on Wednesday that civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi remains the best hope for Myanmar and that it would not be helpful for Congress to join an international "pile-on" against her over a military crackdown on the country's Rohingya Muslims.

Headline: U.S. courts abruptly tossed 9,000 deportation cases. Here's why
Article: Liliana Barrios was working in a California bakery in July and facing possible deportation when she got a call from her immigration attorney with some good news.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 18): Ted Cruz, August job openings
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: White House's Kudlow says Trump not demanding Fed policy change
Article: White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow said on Wednesday that U.S. President Trump was not demanding a policy change at the Federal Reserve after Trump heaped more criticism on the Fed on Tuesday, calling rising U.S. interest rates his "biggest threat."

Headline: Trump says U.S. asked Turkey for audio-video evidence in Khashoggi case
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday the United States has asked Turkey for any audio or video evidence it may have related to the disappearance of U.S.-based Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi but was not sure whether any such evidence exists.

Headline: Trump says does not want to move away from Saudi Arabia amid Khashoggi case
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday said he does not want to walk away from Saudi Arabia despite concerns about Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi and said he hopes Saudi's royal leaders were not involved in his disappearance.

Headline: Republican has narrow lead in Tennessee U.S. Senate race: poll
Article: U.S. Representative Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee, who has tied herself tightly to President Donald Trump as she aims to succeed one of his most vocal Republican critics in the U.S. Senate, has a modest lead in her election bid, a Reuters opinion poll found.

Headline: O'Rourke comes out swinging at 'Lyin Ted' Cruz in Texas debate
Article: Texas Democratic U.S. Senate contender Beto O'Rourke, slipping in the polls despite a record fundraising haul, went on the attack in a raucous debate with Republican rival Ted Cruz on Tuesday and resurrected the senator's nickname of "Lyin Ted."

Headline: Alaska lieutenant governor resigns over 'inappropriate comments'
Article: Alaska Lieutenant Governor Byron Mallott resigned abruptly on Tuesday in a murky scandal over admitted "inappropriate comments" as he and his running mate, Governor Bill Walker, neared the end of a tough re-election campaign.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 16): Saudi Arabia, Michigan, Elizabeth Warren
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Person claimed ricin was in letter sent to Senator Collins home
Article: A suspicious letter sent to the Maine home of Republican U.S. Senator Susan Collins had a note saying it contained the deadly poison ricin, the senator's office said on Tuesday, adding any affected areas had been cleared.

Headline: Trump administration touts effort to undo regulations
Article: The Trump administration said late on Tuesday it has withdrawn or delayed more than 2,200 regulatory actions since taking office in January 2017 as it vows to reduce the role of government.

Headline: Trump says former lawyer Cohen's testimony was 'totally false': AP
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that his former attorney Michael Cohen was lying when he testified Trump had directed him to break the law, the Associated Press reported.

Headline: Trump says Cipollone will serve as next White House counsel: AP interview
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that Washington lawyer Pat Cipollone will serve as his next White House counsel.

Headline: Heated U.S. congressional races on pace to break fundraising records
Article: This year's U.S. congressional campaign season is on pace to break fundraising records, driven in part by unprecedented hauls by at least five candidates from both major parties, according to a Reuters analysis of campaign finance disclosures.

Headline: 'Treason' remark stirs hotly contested Senate race in Arizona
Article: Republican Congresswoman Martha McSally accused her opponent in the hotly contested U.S. Senate race in Arizona, Democratic U.S. Representative Kyrsten Sinema, of "being OK with treason" as the two faced off in their only debate.

Headline: Special Report: The Trump trap - Republicans duck president in key House races
Article: Leonard Lance is a Republican congressman seeking re-election in a Republican district. But he has little to say about the Republican president.

Headline: U.S. administration unified in calling for Khashoggi probe: official
Article: The Trump administration is completely unified in calling for an investigation into the disappearance of U.S.-based Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, but it also has a significant relationship with Riyadh, a senior administration official said on Tuesday.

Headline: Senate will not vote on new North America trade pact in 2018: McConnell
Article: The U.S. Senate's top Republican said on Tuesday that senators will not vote to approve a revised North American trade pact in 2018, leaving the issue to the next Congress.

Headline: Leading U.S. senator accuses Saudi prince of ordering Khashoggi killing
Article: U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican close to President Donald Trump, on Tuesday accused Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of ordering the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi and called him a "rogue crown prince" who is jeopardizing relations with the United States.

Headline: U.S. Senate leader says needs facts in Khashoggi case before acting
Article: U.S. lawmakers need to find out what happened in the case of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi before taking any steps against Saudi Arabia, Senate Majority Leader Mitch Mcconnell told Bloomberg News on Tuesday, calling U.S.-Saudi relations "not great."

Headline: Trump tells Mattis he is 100 percent behind him after 'Democrat' jab
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said President Donald Trump has reassured him of his full support after the Republican president described his Pentagon chief as "sort of a Democrat" who could leave the administration.

Headline: U.S. government, but not Trump, can be sued over climate: judge
Article: A group of young Americans suing the federal government over lack of action to fight climate change can proceed with their lawsuit, but U.S. President Donald Trump cannot be named as a defendant, a federal judge ruled on Monday.

Headline: Ex-Senate staffer pleads guilty to lying about contact with reporters
Article: James Wolfe, a former senior staffer on the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee, pleaded guilty to a charge that he lied to the FBI about contacts with reporters, the Justice Department said on Monday.

Headline: Judge dismisses Stormy Daniels defamation lawsuit against Trump
Article: A U.S. judge on Monday dismissed adult film actress Stormy Daniels's defamation lawsuit against President Donald Trump and ordered her to pay his attorney's fees, saying a tweet the president had written referring to her was protected by free-speech laws.

Headline: Senator Warren, mocked by Trump as 'Pocahontas,' says DNA test backs her ancestry
Article: Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren, ridiculed by U.S. President Donald Trump as "Pocahontas" for claiming Native American heritage, hit back on Monday with DNA evidence she said supported her assertion, a possible preview of a bare-knuckles presidential campaign in 2020.

Headline: Exclusive: Facebook to ban misinformation on voting in upcoming U.S. elections
Article: Facebook Inc will ban false information about voting requirements and fact-check fake reports of violence or long lines at polling stations ahead of next month's U.S. midterm elections, company executives told Reuters, the latest effort to reduce voter manipulation on its service.

Headline: Retiring Speaker Ryan in campaign push for imperiled Republicans
Article: Retiring U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan on Monday launched a whirlwind tour of a dozen states, where he aims to pump up the campaigns of 25 embattled Republican members of Congress as the party fights to keep control of Congress.

Headline: Pennsylvania Republican candidate threatens to stomp on opponents face
Article: (In this October 12 story corrects third paragraph to attribute the quote to "Wagner," not "Wolf" as written)

Headline: Trump says he is 'comfortable' as president despite political battles
Article: President Donald Trump said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that he was "comfortable" in the White House after almost two years in office, despite political storms over immigration, tariffs and his nomination of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh.

Headline: In Tennessee, a Democrat scrambles to turn out voters as polls show slide
Article: Just weeks ago, Tennessee's Phil Bredesen was a bright light for a Democratic Party hoping to make inroads into conservative â€œTrump countryâ€ and secure a path to retake majority control of the U.S. Senate in November's elections.

Headline: Trump calls Mattis 'sort of a Democrat' and says he 'may leave'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said he is unsure whether Defense Secretary James Mattis is planning to step down from his post, but told CBS' "60 Minutes" in a pre-taped interview that the retired general might and that he regards Mattis as "sort of a Democrat."

Headline: Trump says family separations deter illegal immigration
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Saturday that separating migrant families at the border could deter illegal immigration and that he was considering several options to tighten border security.

Headline: Jared Kushner 'likely' paid little or no income taxes for years: NYTimes
Article: Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law and a senior White House adviser, likely paid little or no federal income taxes between 2009 and 2016, the New York Times reported on Saturday, citing confidential financial documents.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (October 12): Pastor Brunson, Ivanka Trump
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Mnuchin to attend top Saudi event, media exit over missing journalist
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Wall Street bankers will show up at an elite Saudi investment conference this month despite a growing exodus of top media companies and business leaders after the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.

Headline: U.S. weapons makers rattled over Saudi Arabia deals
Article: Major U.S. defense contractors have expressed concern to the Trump administration that lawmakers angered by the disappearance of a Saudi journalist in Turkey will block further arms deals with Saudi Arabia, a senior U.S. official told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: Trump administration kills contract for plutonium-to-fuel plant
Article: The Trump administration this week killed a contract for a project to convert plutonium from Cold War-era bombs into power, which it has said would cost tens of billions of dollars, after its supporters lost a legal battle.

Headline: Google tells U.S. lawmakers it is mulling options on China services
Article: Alphabet Inc's Google unit has told U.S. lawmakers it was considering "a variety of options" to offer additional services in China, but declined to detail plans for addressing Chinese censorship.

Headline: Texas Democrat O'Rourke raises record $38 million in U.S. Senate race
Article: Democratic U.S. Representative Beto O'Rourke's bid to unseat Republican U.S. Senator Ted Cruz got a major financial boost in the third quarter when he said he raised $38.1 million, a record for any U.S. Senate race.

Headline: U.S. intelligence watchdog says it will encourage whistleblowers to come forward
Article: The U.S. National Security Agency's top oversight official, Robert Storch, is working to repair the spy agency's reputation with whistleblowers in an effort to encourage staff to report wrongdoing internally, rather than go public.

Headline: Georgia lawsuit is latest blow in U.S. fight over voting rights
Article: U.S. voting rights advocacy groups on Thursday sued Georgia's top election official, Secretary of State Brian Kemp, accusing him of putting more than 50,000 voter registration applications on hold to boost his gubernatorial campaign.

Headline: Trump's lawyers preparing answers to questions in Russia probe: source
Article: President Donald Trump's lawyers are preparing answers to questions for the U.S. special counsel probing Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, a source familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

Headline: Dina Powell withdraws from consideration for U.S. envoy to U.N.: source
Article: Goldman Sachs executive Dina Powell has withdrawn from consideration to succeed Nikki Haley as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, a source familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

Headline: Pence promises U.S. backing for Central America if they strengthen borders
Article: U.S. Vice President Mike Pence told Central American countries on Thursday the United States was willing to help with economic development and investment if they did more to tackle mass migration, corruption and gang violence.

Headline: Hollywood rewrites its script to resist Trump in midterms
Article: On a recent Thursday night, more than 100 people in Hollywood turned their attention to politics. They mingled with Stormy Daniels' lawyer Michael Avenatti inside a hip piano bar lighted by a sign that screamed "OMG WTF."

Headline: Trump dossier research chief declines Congress subpoena
Article: The founder of a political research firm that hired former British spy Christopher Steele to compile a dossier on alleged contacts between presidential candidate Donald Trump and his advisers and Russia is refusing to testify to the Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee.

Headline: Congressman Collins gets February 2020 trial date
Article: A federal judge on Thursday set a Feb. 3, 2020 trial date for Christopher Collins, a Republican U.S. congressman from New York who was charged earlier this year with taking part in an insider trading scheme involving an Australian biotechnology company.

Headline: Kanye West defends support for Trump, in front of Trump
Article: (Editor's note: Paragraphs 7 and 8 contains language that readers may find offensive.)

Headline: Kanye West's meeting with Trump provokes scorn, sadness, support
Article: Rapper Kanye West's televised meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump in the Oval Office became the top trending topic on Twitter on Thursday, prompting a range of reaction from concern over the singer's mental health, to jokes, memes and political commentary.

Headline: Senate confirms Dreiband to lead Justice Department's civil rights division
Article: The United States Senate voted 50-47 on Thursday to confirm Eric Dreiband as the new assistant attorney general for the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.

Headline: U.S. senators asks Google to explain delay in disclosing vulnerability
Article: Three influential Republican U.S. senators on Thursday asked Alphabet Inc's Google unit to explain why it delayed disclosing vulnerabilities with its Google+ social network.

Headline: Justice Kavanaugh unlikely to heed calls for recusal
Article: Justice Brett Kavanaugh is unlikely to heed calls by critics to step aside from certain politically charged U.S. Supreme Court cases in which his fairness and independence might be questioned after a divisive confirmation fight, according to legal experts.

Headline: China trying to sway U.S. vote, poses threat: officials
Article: China is waging an unprecedented campaign to influence American public opinion ahead of November congressional elections and presents the greatest long-term counterintelligence threat to the United States, U.S. security officials said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Oct 10): Florida, Pennsylvania
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified personal Twitter account of U.S. President Donald Trump (@realDonaldTrump)

Headline: Pompeo says release of American pastor by Turkish court would be right thing to do
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Wednesday that the release of U.S. evangelical pastor Andrew Brunson by a Turkish court at his next hearing on Friday would be an important step and the right thing for Turkey to do.

Headline: Trump calls stock sell-off 'a correction,' says Federal Reserve is 'crazy'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said that Wednesday's stock market sell-off was in fact a long-awaited "correction," and that the Federal Reserve, which has been raising U.S. interest rates, had gone "crazy."

Headline: California man who sold stolen identities sentenced to prison in Russia probe
Article: A California man accused by U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office of operating an online auction service for stolen identities was sentenced to one year of incarceration on Wednesday in a federal district court.

Headline: Trump appointees hold keys in Supreme Court immigration case
Article: The outcome of the latest immigration case involving President Donald's Trump administration to come before the U.S. Supreme Court could hinge on his two appointees, conservative Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh.

Headline: Former adviser Powell just one of many being eyed for U.N., Trump says
Article: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday his administration was talking to his former adviser and Goldman Sachs executive Dina Powell about possibly succeeding Nikki Haley as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, but that Powell was just one of many people under consideration.

Headline: FBI chief says threats from drones to U.S. 'steadily escalating'
Article: FBI director Christopher Wray told a U.S. Senate panel on Wednesday that the threat from drones "is steadily escalating" even as Congress gives agencies new tools to address threats.

Headline: Man accused of identity theft in U.S. Russia probe sentenced to prison
Article: Richard Pinedo, accused of identity theft by the U.S. special counsel investigating possible Russia election meddling, was sentenced to a one-year prison term on Wednesday.

Headline: Bloomberg goes back home - to the Democrats
Article: Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg rejoined the Democratic Party on Wednesday, going back to his political roots weeks before the Nov. 6 congressional elections and amid speculation that he might run for the White House in 2020.

Headline: Kavanaugh vote changes few minds in close Missouri U.S. Senate race
Article: Democratic U.S. Senator Claire McCaskill's vote against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation appears not to have cost her greatly in conservative-leaning Missouri, where she is in a tight re-election race, a Reuters opinion poll showed.

Headline: Missouri judge blocks parts of state's voter photo ID law
Article: A Missouri state judge ordered on Tuesday that state election authorities could no longer tell voters that they are required to show a photo identification card in order to cast a ballot, blocking parts of Missouri's voter identification law.

Headline: Trump says next summit with North Korea's Kim to come after November U.S. elections
