Article: Two of Wall Street's largest Washington-based trade groups said on Tuesday that they were merging, as big banks rethink their lobbying strategies under the business-friendly administration of U.S. President Donald Trump.

Headline: Democrats want next U.S. secretary of state to be tougher on Russia
Article: Top U.S. Senate Democrats on Tuesday blasted President Donald Trump's stance on Russia as too soft and indicated that his approach to the country accused of meddling in U.S. elections will come up when they consider his nominee for secretary of state next month.

Headline: White House shakeup shows Trump tired of hearing 'no' for an answer
Article: Almost 14 months into Donald Trump's turbulent White House tenure, loyalists are in, dissenters are out and the president himself is acting on his own instincts more swiftly than ever to make decisions on policies from trade to North Korea.

Headline: Out in Africa? Tillerson trip leaves hosts nonplussed
Article: From the outset, Rex Tillerson's first trip to Africa looked half-hearted and token, but with the hindsight knowledge that the U.S. Secretary of State was fired just two days in, his African hosts who must be wondering why they bothered.

Headline: McConnell urges Senate to quickly confirm Secretary of State, CIA nominees
Article: The most powerful Republican in the U.S. Senate said on Tuesday there should be no undue delays in confirming President Donald Trump's pick to replace outgoing Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and filling the top job at the Central Intelligence Agency.

Headline: Greens fear climate backslide with Pompeo as top U.S. diplomat
Article: Several green groups criticized the Trump administration's choice on Tuesday of CIA Director Mike Pompeo to replace Rex Tillerson as Secretary of State, saying his past skeptical comments about global warming show he is less suited to run U.S. foreign policy about climate change than the former Exxon Mobil CEO.

Headline: U.S. general signals support for Iran nuclear deal
Article: A top U.S. general on Tuesday signaled support for the Iran nuclear deal, saying the agreement, which President Donald Trump has threatened to withdraw from, has played an important role in addressing Iran's nuclear program.

Headline: U.S. top diplomat Tillerson says to leave office on March 31
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who was fired by President Donald Trump on Tuesday, said he was delegating all of his responsibilities to the State Department's No. 2 official and that he would leave office at the end of the month.

Headline: Trump loyalist Pompeo faces North Korea challenge as top diplomat
Article: CIA Director Mike Pompeo may have developed personal chemistry with President Donald Trump by delivering his crucial morning intelligence briefings, praising him publicly and embracing his hard-line views on issues ranging from North Korea to Iran.

Headline: Factbox: Trump and Tillerson disagreed on key diplomatic issues
Article: President Donald Trump on Tuesday fired U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, saying the two had a "different mindset" on key diplomatic issues and "we disagreed on things" including the international nuclear accord with Iran.

Headline: Senate Intel chairman backs Haspel to head CIA, Democrats concerned
Article: Republican U.S. Senator Richard Burr, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said on Tuesday he looked forward to supporting Gina Haspel's nomination to be director of the CIA "ensuring its consideration without delay."

Headline: Trump dismissal of top diplomat won't improve things: Germany's Roth
Article: The firing of U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will not lead to an improvement in strained ties with Germany, Deputy Foreign Minister Michael Roth said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK looking forward to excellent relationship with new U.S. Secretary of State: spokesman
Article: Britain is looking forward to continuing good relations with the newly appointed U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday after the departure of Rex Tillerson.

Headline: Republicans shut down House Russia probe over Democratic objections
Article: U.S. House Intelligence Committee Republicans said on Monday the panel had finished investigating Russia and the 2016 U.S. election, and found no collusion between President Donald Trump's campaign and Moscow's efforts to influence the vote.

Headline: Senate panel to hold hearing on Pompeo in April: Corker
Article: U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee will hold a hearing next month to consider Mike Pompeo as secretary of state, the Republican head of the panel said on Tuesday after President Donald Trump fired his current top diplomat, Rex Tillerson.

Headline: CIA's Pompeo brings insider's touch to secretary of state role
Article: CIA Director Mike Pompeo, if confirmed as the next secretary of state, would bring a number of assets to his new role as the top U.S. diplomat: the confidence of President Donald Trump, government experience and an insider's knowledge of Congress and the federal bureaucracy.

Headline: U.S. farm group targets Trump with free-trade ads
Article: A farm lobbying group is spending $500,000 to air television ads on channels near U.S. President Donald Trump's home in Florida to encourage free trade, with the group worried recent metal tariffs could result in retaliation against U.S. agricultural goods.

Headline: Factbox: Five facts about Mike Pompeo, tapped for secretary of state
Article: Following are five facts about U.S. Central Intelligence Agency Director Mike Pompeo, who President Donald Trump on Tuesday announced will replace Rex Tillerson as secretary of state.

Headline: U.S. may lift travel ban on 'important partner' Chad, Tillerson says
Article: U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said on Monday that Washington was considering lifting a travel ban on Chad, offering an olive branch to an ally in the fight against Islamist militant groups in West Africa.

Headline: Conservative commentator Kudlow a contender to replace Cohn: source
Article: Conservative commentator Larry Kudlow has emerged as a strong contender to succeed Gary Cohn as President Donald Trump's top economic adviser, a source familiar with the matter said on Monday.

Headline: Trump on Twitter (March 12) - Wilbur Ross, background checks, Rick Saccone
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified Twitter accounts of U.S. President Donald Trump, @realDonaldTrump and @POTUS.

Headline: Trump to raise $5 million in California for re-election bid
Article: President Donald Trump will raise about $5 million for his prospective re-election campaign in 2020 and for the Republican National Committee at a fundraising event in Los Angeles on Tuesday, a party official said on Monday.

Headline: Trump ex-aide Manafort's lawyer to seek dismissal of oligarch's lawsuit
Article: The lawyer defending U.S. President Donald Trump's former campaign manager Paul Manafort against a Russian oligarch's allegations of fraud will seek to dismiss the case, he said on Monday.

Headline: Fiscal mess, tax hikes likely for New Jersey governor's first budget
Article: New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy is expected to unveil tax hikes for businesses or millionaires and the green light for marijuana sales when he proposes his first state budget on Tuesday.

Headline: In bow to NRA, Trump throws gun purchase age to states, courts
Article: Under pressure from gun rights groups, President Donald Trump backed away on Monday from raising the minimum age for gun purchases from 18 to 21, one of several measures he had supported after the latest U.S. school shooting.

Headline: Porn star offers to repay $130,000 in dispute over alleged Trump affair
Article: The adult-film actress who claims she had an affair with Donald Trump before he became U.S. president offered on Monday to return $130,000 that Trump's personal lawyer paid her in what she said was hush money to remain silent about the alleged relationship.

Headline: Tillerson says several steps needed for U.S. talks with North Korea
Article: Several steps will be necessary to agree the location and scope of talks between the United States and North Korea, U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said on Monday.

Headline: 137 House Democrats sign letter urging action against Russia
Article: Over two-thirds of U.S. House of Representatives Democrats urged President Donald Trump to enact sanctions on Russia, the latest push by lawmakers for a response to investigators' findings that Russia interfered in the 2016 U.S. election.

Headline: Steps underway should allow U.S. to lift Chad travel ban: Tillerson
Article: United States Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said on Monday that steps were under way that should allow Chad, an important American ally in the fight against Islamist groups in West Africa, to be removed from a U.S. travel ban list.

Headline: Trump pulls back from big changes to gun laws after Florida shooting
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will support a modest set of fixes to gun laws, stepping back from some of the more sweeping changes he had considered after the country's latest mass school shooting, senior officials told reporters on Sunday.

Headline: Trump considers ex-Microsoft exec as top economic adviser: official
Article: Chris Liddell, a former executive at Microsoft Corp and General Motors Co, is under consideration to become U.S. President Donald Trump's top economic adviser, a White House official said on Sunday, confirming media reports.

Headline: Trump to visit Boeing plant in Missouri to tout impact of tax overhaul
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will visit a Boeing Co plant in St. Louis on Wednesday to tout the impact of the tax overhaul bill signed into law in December, a White House official said on Sunday.

Headline: Trump unleashed at raucous rally for embattled Pennsylvania Republican
Article: President Donald Trump attacked his critics, promoted his steel and aluminum tariffs and tossed out an idea to have drug dealers face the death penalty, addressing a raucous rally on Saturday for a Republican congressional candidate in a tight race.

Headline: Mattis goes silent on North Korea ahead of Trump-Kim meeting
Article: U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said on Sunday he will not publicly discuss issues related to North Korea, deferring to diplomats and the White House, ahead of a proposed meeting between President Donald Trump and North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Un.

Headline: Clinton impeachment lawyer met with Trump about White House job: source
Article: Veteran Washington lawyer Emmet Flood is under consideration for a White House job assisting U.S. President Donald Trump with the Russia probe, according to a person familiar with the matter.

Headline: Tariffs should be part of U.S. trade policy, Trump foe Warren says
Article: Democratic U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has traded barbs with President Donald Trump, said on Sunday she's "not afraid of tariffs," but stopped short of endorsing his decision to launch steep tariffs on steel and aluminum.

Headline: Trump says he rejected Mexico request about border wall
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Saturday he rejected a demand from Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto that Trump should say that Mexico would not have to pay for a proposed U.S. border wall.

Headline: Trump's condition for Kim meeting is no nuclear, missile test: Mnuchin
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's condition for meeting North Korean leader Kim Jong-un is that there be no nuclear or missile testing, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin said on Sunday.

Headline: Trump says North Korea talks could fail or bring 'greatest deal'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Saturday his planned meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un could fizzle without an agreement or it could result in "the greatest deal for the world" to ease nuclear tensions between the two countries.

Headline: EU, Japan start push for exemptions from Trump tariffs
Article: The European Union and Japan urged the United States on Saturday to grant them exemptions from metal import tariffs, with Tokyo calling for "calm-headed behavior" in a dispute that threatens to spiral into a trade war.

Headline: Trump says North Korea talks may lead to 'greatest deal for the world'
Article: President Donald Trump said on Saturday that his planned-for talks with North Korea could end in failure or result in "the greatest deal for the world" that would de-escalate nuclear tensions.

Headline: Trump says North Korea to halt missile tests 'through our meetings'
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Saturday that North Korea has promised to halt missile tests "through our meetings."

Headline: U.S. eases way to more tariff exemptions under pressure from allies
Article: The United States opened the way for more exemptions from its steel and aluminum tariffs on Friday, after pressure from allies and intense lobbying from lawmakers, further diluting the measures just a day after they were formally announced.

Headline: EU says to hold more talks with U.S. next week on tariff exemption
Article: Europe's trade chief said talks with the United States on an exemption for the bloc from new U.S. tariffs would continue next week after a Saturday meeting had not brought clarity on the exemption procedure.

Headline: Japan trade minister calls for calm heads over U.S. tariffs
Article: Japan's trade minister sought an exemption from U.S. import tariffs on steel and aluminum on Saturday and called for "calm-headed behavior" in a dispute that threatens to spiral into a trade war.

Headline: Missouri aluminum smelter to restart after tariff, utility relief
Article: The owner of a shuttered aluminum smelter in southeastern Missouri said on Friday the firm would restart two of the plant's three production lines following President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs of 10 percent on imported aluminum and 25 percent on steel.

Headline: Five cabinet chiefs to testify before U.S. Senate on infrastructure
Article: The Trump administration will send five cabinet secretaries to a U.S. Senate hearing next week to tout its plan to spur $1.5 trillion infrastructure improvements using $200 billion in new federal funding.

Headline: Trump says Australia to secure exemption from U.S. tariffs
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday he has spoken with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and that they are working on an agreement so Australia will not be subject to U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum.

Headline: Trump's tariffs could hit U.S. state, city budgets: S&P
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports could result in economic growth that is slower than states assumed in their budget forecasts, S&P Global Ratings said on Friday.

Headline: How Trumpâ€™s tariffs morphed from 'no exemptions' to carve-outs galore
Article: In the space of a week, U.S. President Donald Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs went from a "no exemptions" plan to one filled with carve-outs for Canada and Mexico, and likely for other allies and hundreds of imported products not available domestically.

Headline: Florida governor signs gun-safety bill into law after school shooting
Article: Florida Governor Rick Scott, a staunch ally of the National Rifle Association (NRA), signed into law on Friday a bill imposing a 21-year-old legal age requirement and three-day waiting period on all gun purchases and allowing the arming of some school employees.

Headline: Trump's military parade planned for Veterans Day - without tanks
Article: A military parade requested by President Donald Trump will take place in November on Veterans Day in Washington D.C., but to minimize damage to roads it will not include tanks, a Pentagon memo released on Friday said.

Headline: NRA files federal lawsuit challenging Florida gun-safety bill
Article: The National Rifle Association filed a federal lawsuit on Friday seeking to overturn a new Florida law that imposes a 21-year-old age limit and three-day waiting period on all gun purchases, saying the move violated Americans' constitutional rights.

Headline: Ex-Trump aide finishes hours of Russia probe grand jury testimony
Article: Former Trump campaign aide Sam Nunberg emerged from a Washington, D.C., federal courthouse on Friday after spending some six hours before a grand jury convened by Special Counsel Robert Mueller as part of his investigation into whether Russia meddled in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Headline: China says U.S. soybeans 'prime target' over tariffs: trade group
Article: Chinese officials have said U.S. soybeans are a prime target for retaliation against tariffs imposed by the Trump administration on steel and aluminum imports, according to the American Soybean Association.

Headline: EU, Japan seek to be excluded from U.S. tariffs in talks
Article: The European Union and Japan are seeking to be excluded from U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs in talks with U.S. President Donald Trump's trade envoy on Saturday, with the EU warning it will retaliate if Washington does not relent.

Headline: EU to respond to U.S. tariffs within 90 days if not exempt
Article: The European Union expects to be excluded from U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs but will go to the World Trade Organization to impose its own measures if Washington presses ahead, EU officials said on Friday.

Headline: EU industry steels itself for U.S. tariffs
Article: European steelmakers are pinning their hopes on the European Union being able to negotiate an exemption from new U.S. steel import tariffs that have raised fears of a damaging trade war

Headline: U.S. should exclude EU from tariffs to defuse trade dispute: Merkel
Article: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Friday the best solution to defuse a trade dispute between the United States and the European Union over President Donald Trump's imposition of tariffs on steel would be to exempt the bloc from the duties.

Headline: Trump may exempt more countries from tariffs: Treasury's Mnuchin
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump could exempt more countries from trade tariffs, U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Friday.

Headline: Trump discussed steel, aluminum tariffs with Argentina's Macri: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump discussed potential U.S. tariffs on foreign aluminum and steel in a call with Argentina's president Mauricio Macri in a call on Thursday, the White House said on Friday.

Headline: American customers stockpile Canada steel as tariffs loom: sources
Article: American customers are stockpiling Canadian steel ahead of new import tariffs due to be imposed by U.S. President Donald Trump later this month, according to industry sources familiar with the matter.

Headline: Automakers and their allies call for more breaks in Trump tariff plan
Article: Global automakers and vehicle suppliers are pressing the Trump administration and U.S. Congress to exempt the European Union and other allies from new steel and aluminum tariffs set to take effect later this month, industry officials said on Friday.

Headline: Steel industry wants Mexico to copy Trump's tariffs, avoid dumping
Article: Mexico should replicate U.S. President Donald Trump's 25 percent steel tariffs with its own customs duties on the metal to avoid being used as staging point for third countries to export to the United States, the industry chamber said on Friday.

Headline: Democrats seek subpoenas for White House security clearance data
Article: Democrats on a congressional committee investigating the White House's security clearance procedures on Friday urged the panel's Republican chairman to compel the Trump administration to turn over records they said were being withheld.

Headline: Pennsylvania Republicans make case for scrapping new Congress map
Article: A panel of three federal judges heard arguments on Friday in the latest attempt by Pennsylvania Republicans to block a court-imposed map of voting districts that could boost Democrats' chances of winning control of the U.S. Congress this year.

Headline: Trump plans to offer Canada, Mexico 30-day tariff exemption: official
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump plans to offer Canada and Mexico a 30-day exemption from planned tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, which could be extended based on progress in NAFTA talks, a White House official said on Wednesday night.The move, first reported by the Washington Post, followed comments earlier in the day by a White House spokeswoman that the impending tariffs could exclude Canada, Mexico and a clutch of other countries "based on national security."

Headline: Trump tariffs could cost as well as create U.S. steel jobs
Article: Higher U.S. tariffs on imported steel will mean more jobs at some American steel mills but raise the risk of layoffs at others, industry executives said on Wednesday.

Headline: Detained immigrants separated from children in U.S. sue Trump administration
Article: Migrants separated from their children after they were detained for illegally entering the United States filed a class action lawsuit on Friday, claiming there are "hundreds" of parents in the same situation, and that the Trump administration is violating their due process rights.

Headline: Trump will not meet Kim without seeing 'concrete' steps: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump will not meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un unless he sees some "concrete" action by Pyongyang, the White House said on Friday.

Headline: Russia steel pipe firm TMK says U.S. tariffs to benefit U.S. unit
Article: TMK , Russia's largest of steel pipes for the oil and gas industry, said on Friday it expected new U.S. import tariffs on steel and aluminum to benefit its U.S. unit IPSCO.

Headline: Italy PM says EU will take common position on U.S. tariffs
Article: Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni said on Friday the European Union would decide at its next meeting on a common position in response to U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports.

Headline: Prepare counter measures against U.S. steel tariffs: Dutch PM Rutte
Article: The European Union must be prepared to take counter measures against U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs, Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte said on Friday.

Headline: Dutch Tata Steel says it should be exempt from U.S. tariffs
Article: The Dutch arm of Tata Steel said on Friday the United States should exempt it from new import tariffs on steel and aluminum, as it products were vital for the American economy.

Headline: Asia's biggest exporters bristle over U.S. tariffs, fanning trade war fears
Article: Major Asian nations reacted sharply on Friday to U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, warning of damage to relations amid industry calls for retaliation.

Headline: Russia's Rusal says its aluminum poses no threat to U.S. market
Article: Russian aluminum producer Rusal said on Friday its aluminum poses no threat to U.S. firms as its products are "not produced in sufficient quantity" by U.S.-based producers.

Headline: Trump's speech sounded protectionist: EU's Katainen
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's speech introducing steel and aluminum tariffs sounded very protectionist, European Union Commission Vice President Jyrki Katainen said on Friday.

Headline: EU executive to seek talks with U.S. over metals tariffs: Katainen
Article: The European Union executive said on Friday it will seek talks with the United States over President Donald Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs but stands ready to take Washington to the World Trade Organisation if necessary.

Headline: Germany backs EU decision to respond to U.S. steel tariffs: spokesman
Article: Germany on Friday urged multilateral talks to address overcapacity in the steel sector and said it supports the European Union's plans to respond if U.S. President Donald Trump presses ahead with tariffs on steel and aluminum imports.

Headline: Steelmaker Voestalpine may pause U.S. investments: CEO
Article: Austrian steelmaker Voestalpine will monitor the effects of new U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports and may not invest further in the United States until it has a clear picture of the situation, its chief executive said on Friday.

Headline: Britain will work with EU on exemptions to U.S. metals tariffs
Article: Britain will work with the European Union to consider the scope of any exemptions from impending U.S. tariffs on metals after President Donald Trump introduced levies on steel and aluminum imports, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: Trump sets steel and aluminum tariffs but exempts Canada, Mexico
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump pressed ahead on Thursday with import tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent for aluminum but exempted Canada and Mexico and offered the possibility of excluding other allies, backtracking from an earlier "no-exceptions" stance.

Headline: China metal producers urge Beijing to retaliate on U.S. tariffs
Article: China's metals industry issued the country's most explicit threat yet in an escalating trade spat with the United States, urging Beijing to retaliate by targeting coal and other sectors that are key to U.S. President Donald Trump's support base.

Headline: Tesla chief Musk says China trade rules uneven, asks Trump for help
Article: Tesla Inc Chief Executive Elon Musk took to Twitter on Thursday to call on U.S. President Donald Trump to challenge China's auto trade rules, which limit foreign ownership of Chinese ventures and impose steep tariffs on imported cars.

Headline: White House sets biofuel meeting; Trump will not attend: sources
Article: The White House has made preliminary plans for a meeting on Monday between rivals in the corn and oil industries to discuss potential changes to the nation's biofuels policy, two sources familiar with the planning told Reuters.

Headline: Trump tariffs to raise Hyundai Motor's raw material cost: South Korea government official
Article: South Korea's Hyundai Motor will pay higher raw material costs due to U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum, a senior South Korean government official said on Friday.

Headline: Japan steel industry concerned at wider impact of U.S. tariffs
Article: Japan's steel industry body said on Friday it is concerned that U.S. tariffs on steel will seriously harm Japan's steel exports, as well as the global steel trade, and could lead to retaliatory and protectionist actions by other countries.

Headline: Brazil to seek exemption from U.S. trade tariffs, minister says
Article: The Brazilian government will try to negotiate its way out of newly announced U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports but could take stronger action to protect its industry if those talks fall through.

Headline: How tariffs, trade war fears roil U.S. financial markets
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's plans to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports has rippled through financial markets since last week, when his initial announcement set off fears of a global trade war.

Headline: IMF's Lagarde fears 'tit-for-tat' escalation from Trump tariff move
Article: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde said on Thursday that she feared a "tit-for-tat" escalation of trade retaliation over U.S. President Donald Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs that would sap business confidence and investment.

Headline: Trump's steel, aluminum tariffs exempt Canada, Mexico
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports will start in 15 days with initial exemptions for Canada and Mexico and the possibility of alternatives for other countries, a senior administration official said on Thursday.

Headline: Japan to ask U.S. to be exempted from steel, aluminum tariffs
Article: Japan's top government spokesman said on Friday that Japan would continue to ask the United States to exempt it from Washington's plan to impose tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum.

Headline: States' rights rancher Ryan Bundy to run for Nevada governor
Article: Ryan Bundy, who was at the forefront of two armed confrontations between right-wing militia activists and the U.S. government over the past four years, said on Thursday he planned to run for Nevada governor on a states' rights platform.

Headline: South Korea trade minister says to consider taking U.S. steel tariffs to WTO
Article: South Korea's trade minister said on Friday that the country would actively consider filing a complaint to the World Trade Organization over U.S. steel tariffs, but would continue to ask for its steel exports to be exempted from the tariffs.

Headline: New tariffs should be narrowed, says leading U.S. lawmaker on taxes
Article: The top lawmaker on tax issues in the U.S. House of Representatives cautiously praised President Donald Trump's new aluminum and steel tariffs on Thursday, saying Trump had improved his original proposal by granting some countries and businesses exemptions from the levies.

Headline: U.S. judge questions whether Trump can block Twitter users
Article: A federal judge on Thursday expressed skepticism about whether U.S. President Donald Trump can constitutionally block Twitter users whose views he does not like from following and responding to his own Twitter account.

Headline: Trump ex-aide Manafort pleads not guilty again, faces July trial
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's former campaign manager Paul Manafort again pleaded not guilty on Thursday to criminal charges in the investigation into alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 election and will face the first of two trials in July.

Headline: Wall Street laments Cohn leaving White House but no one eager to take his place
Article: The departure of Gary Cohn as U.S. President Donald Trump's senior economic adviser has Wall Street pondering who would want to leave a well-paying job in the private sector to work in a White House marked by tension, turnover and legal troubles.

Headline: US tariffs risk serious consequences, no 'all clear' yet: Bank of Canada
Article: U.S. plans for steel and aluminum tariffs and rising protectionist rhetoric carry potentially serious consequences and it is too soon to call the "all clear" even with a temporary exemption for Canada, a Bank of Canada official said on Thursday.

Headline: Mexico says NAFTA talks separate from Trump's tariffs policy
Article: Talks to revamp the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) should not be subject to outside pressure, Mexico's economy ministry said in a statement Thursday, and will proceed independent of U.S. President Donald Trump's tariff policy.

Headline: Argentina to ask U.S. for exemption from steel, aluminum tariffs
Article: Argentina will seek to join Mexico and Canada in getting an exemption from U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, which President Donald Trump finalized in a proclamation on Thursday, the South American country's Foreign Ministry said.

Headline: Japan: U.S. tariff decision may have 'big impact' on bilateral relations
Article: The United States' decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum was "regrettable" and will likely have a "big impact" on economic ties between Japan and the United States, Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Kono said in a statement on Friday.

Headline: Trump discusses video game violence with 'Doom' maker, other execs
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump met on Thursday with the makers of popular video games "Grand Theft Auto" and "Doom" to discuss what the president believes is a link between video games and violent acts like last month's school shooting in Florida.

Headline: Informant had no evidence Clinton benefited from uranium sale: Democrats
Article: An informant whom House Republicans have said could reveal a link between a 2010 sale of U.S. uranium supplies and donations to the Clinton Foundation provided no evidence of that during a four-hour interview with congressional staff last month, Democrats said on Thursday.

Headline: France regrets U.S. tariffs, will assess response: finance minister
Article: France and its European Union partners will assess the impact of U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports announced on Thursday and look at how to respond, French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said.

Headline: U.S. Senate leader McConnell says concerned about scope of Trump tariffs
Article: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Thursday he was concerned about the scope of tariffs on steel and aluminum imports set by President Donald Trump.

Headline: Ross says U.S. steel firms to benefit from increased production
Article: U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said on Thursday that fluctuations in the share prices of U.S. steel companies were not important and the "real kicker" following the enactment of tariffs on steel imports would be in higher production.

Headline: EU is U.S. ally and should be exempt from tariffs: EU trade chief
Article: European Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom said on Thursday that the European Union was a close ally of the United States and should be exempt from impending U.S. metals tariffs.

Headline: U.N. says poorer countries are casualties of U.S. tariff move
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to impose steep tariffs on steel and aluminum imports will take a toll on poorer countries and could trigger takeovers in their mining industries, the head of the U.N. trade and development agency UNCTAD said on Thursday.

Headline: U.S. Commerce secretary says broad tariffs needed to counteract China transshipment
Article: U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said on Thursday broad steel and aluminum tariffs were needed to counteract China's transshipment of products through third countries.

Headline: Arming Florida school staff could expose them to suits: experts
Article: A bill passed by Florida lawmakers empowering some personnel in public schools to carry firearms to guard against attacks like last month's massacre near Miami could expose these employees to potentially costly civil lawsuits, legal experts said.

Headline: U.S. Republican Senator Flake says will introduce law undoing tariffs
Article: U.S. Republican Senator Jeff Flake said on Thursday he would introduce a law to nullify President Donald Trump's aluminum and steel tariffs, which Trump finalized in a proclamation earlier in the day.

Headline: Trump sets steel and aluminum tariffs; Mexico, Canada exempted
Article: President Donald Trump pressed ahead with the imposition of 25 percent tariffs on steel imports and 10 percent for aluminum on Thursday but exempted Canada and Mexico, backtracking from earlier pledges of tariffs on all countries.

Headline: Ex-U.S. House staffer sentenced for cyberstalking lawmaker
Article: A former staff employee of the U.S. Virgin Islands' representative to Congress was sentenced to a year and day in prison on Thursday for circulating private, nude photos and videos of the member and her husband, prosecutors said.

Headline: House Speaker Ryan criticizes Trump tariff plan
Article: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said on Thursday the United States should initiate "surgical" actions against China to stop it from dumping steel and aluminum instead of President Donald Trump's broader tariff plan.

Headline: All countries hit by US metals tariffs can negotiate exclusions: AP report
Article: All countries affected by proposed U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum have been invited to negotiate exclusions from the measures, which will take effect within 15 days after U.S. President Donald Trump signs proclamations on Thursday, the Associated Press reported.

Headline: Manafort pleads not guilty to second indictment in Virginia, wants jury trial
Article: President Donald Trump's former campaign manager Paul Manafort pleaded not guilty on Thursday to additional criminal charges ranging from bank fraud to filing false tax returns.

Headline: Trump criticizes Oakland mayor as 'disgrace' over immigrant warning
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump criticized the Oakland, California, mayor on Thursday for alerting her community to a pending immigration raid, saying her actions prompted federal scrutiny.

Headline: Trudeau confident about Canada's position over U.S. tariff threat
Article: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Thursday there was a "level of confidence" that the country's close relationship with the United States would protect it from U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports.

Headline: Canada minister says U.S. tariffs, quotas unacceptable
Article: CanadaÂ´s trade minister reiterated on Thursday the countryÂ´s stance that it will accept no duties or quotas from the United States, speaking just hours before U.S. President Donald Trump was slated to slap new tariffs on steel and aluminum imports.

Headline: U.S. not coordinating against Russian cyber threat: top general
Article: The top U.S. general in Europe said on Thursday that the U.S. government did not have an effective unified approach to deal with Russia's cyber threat.

Headline: Trump seeks balance with Canada and Mexico, U.S. energy chief says
Article: The Trump administration is trying to find the right balance with top trade partners Canada and Mexico as it considers tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum, U.S. Energy Secretary Rick Perry said on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox: Key sectors for Canada, Mexico as White House ties tariffs to NAFTA
Article: The White House has tied U.S. President Donald Trump's planned tariffs on steel and aluminum imports to a better NAFTA trade deal, offering a potential 30-day exemption for Mexico and Canada.

Headline: Trump says he is sticking with tariffs, may 'go up or down' with some countries
Article: President Donald Trump said on Thursday he was sticking to his plans for 25 percent tariffs on steel imports and 10 percent on aluminum imports but would have flexibility to change those for specific countries.

Headline: Trump says legal papers on bump stocks almost done
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday his administration was almost finished with the legal paperwork designed to block the use of bump stocks, devices that turn firearms into machine guns.

Headline: China's aluminum exports rise, steel down as Trump prepares tariffs
Article: China's aluminum exports grew more than 25 percent in the first two months of 2018, but steel exports fell by nearly a third, as the world's top producer of the two metals faces scrutiny amid U.S. plans to impose hefty tariffs later on Thursday.

Headline: Germany warns U.S. against setting bad precedent with tariffs
Article: German Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries expressed in a letter to her U.S. counterpart the fear that other countries could follow the United States in giving national security as a reason for introducing trade restrictions.

Headline: U.S. State Dept approves $467 million in military sales to Qatar and UAE
Article: The U.S. State Department approved a total of $467 million worth of potential foreign military sales to Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, the Pentagon said in separate approval notices on Thursday.

Headline: Europe has 'arsenal of weapons' to respond to Trump's tariffs: EU's Moscovici
Article: Europe wants to avoid a trade war with the United States over its plans to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum, but is preparing immediate counter-measures just in case, European Financial Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said.

Headline: Florida lawmakers pass gun-school safety bill three weeks after massacre
Article: Florida lawmakers, spurred by last month's deadly high school shooting, gave final passage on Wednesday to a bill to raise the legal age for buying rifles, impose a three-day waiting period on all gun sales and allow the arming of some school employees.

Headline: Trump administration seeks $100 billion cut in U.S.-China trade deficit: WSJ
Article: The Trump administration last week asked a top Chinese economic official for a $100 billon reduction in the U.S.-China trade deficit, the Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter.

Headline: No sudden moves - Canada sticks to measured tack in U.S. trade row
Article: Canada is sticking to its keep-calm strategy as U.S. President Donald Trump ramps up trade war rhetoric, convinced that no move is the best move for the country with the most to lose, but critics say it risks being a soft target if its strategy fails.

Headline: U.S. manufacturers touted by Trump count the costs of his tariffs
Article: When Donald Trump became president last year he vowed to make American manufacturing giants, such as Harley-Davidson and Caterpillar great again. But a year later, the two companies stand to take a hit from his policies.

Headline: Mexico says progress needed before president meets Trump
Article: White House advisor Jared Kushner left Mexico City on Wednesday with prospects no nearer for a summit between his father-in-law President Donald Trump and Mexico's President Enrique Pena Nieto, as both sides said progress on joint policy concerns was needed first.

Headline: U.S. special counsel probes Seychelles meeting with Russian: Washington Post
Article: The U.S. special counsel investigating possible Russian meddling in the 2016 election has gathered evidence that a secret meeting in the Seychelles in January 2017 was an attempt to set up a back-channel between the incoming Trump administration and the Kremlin, the Washington Post reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump-Pena Nieto meeting depends on U.S.-Mexico progress: ministry
Article: A possible meeting between Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto and his U.S. counterpart Donald Trump will depend on how much progress the two countries make on issues of mutual interest, Mexico's foreign ministry said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. Forest Service chief resigns amid sexual misconduct accusations
Article: The head of the U.S. Forest Service, Tony Tooke, resigned on Wednesday amid an investigation into accusations of sexual misconduct made against him.

Headline: Canada, Mexico will be temporarily exempted from U.S. metals tariffs: Washington Post
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is planning to offer Canada and Mexico a temporary exemption from new tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, the Washington Post reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Foreign banks carved out of Senate regulatory relief bill
Article: Foreign banks have been excluded from a key provision relaxing oversight of small and mid-sized lenders under a modified version of a U.S. Senate bill that aims to ease rules introduced following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis.

Headline: Factbox: Main provisions of Florida gun safety bill
Article: The Florida House of Representatives on Wednesday approved by a 67-50 vote a gun-safety package that would raise the legal age for buying rifles, impose a three-day waiting period on all gun sales and allow some public school personnel to be armed.

Headline: Trump spoke to witnesses about discussions they had with special counsel: NYT
Article: The U.S. special counsel in the Russian election meddling investigation has learned of two conversations in which President Donald Trump asked witnesses about matters discussed with investigators, the New York Times reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump says China has been asked for plan to cut trade imbalance with U.S.
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that China has been asked to develop a plan to reduce its trade surplus with the United States, without giving any details on how such a request had been conveyed.

Headline: Canada's Trudeau says Trump wants to move forward on NAFTA
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump made it clear in a phone call that he was focused on moving forward on NAFTA, and if he can get a good trade deal there would be no need for steel or aluminum tariffs on Canada, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Wednesday.

Headline: Some countries may be exempted from planned U.S. metal tariffs: White House
Article: Canada and Mexico, and possibly other countries, may be exempted from planned U.S. import tariffs on steel and aluminum on the basis of national security, the White House said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump expected to formally sign off on planned tariffs on Thursday: New York Times
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to formally sign off on planned tariffs on steel and aluminum imports at noon EST (1700 GMT) on Thursday, the New York Times reported, citing people familiar with the deliberations.

Headline: Congress struggles to find ways to plug infrastructure shortfall
Article: U.S. lawmakers on Wednesday said Congress must find a way to pay for a massive looming shortfall in funding to pay for crumbling highways, bridges and other infrastructure.

Headline: California governor says Trump administration waging war against state
Article: California Governor Jerry Brown on Wednesday accused President Donald Trump's administration of declaring war on the most populous U.S. state, after the Justice Department sued to stop policies that protect illegal immigrants against deportation.

Headline: Latinas lead Democratic rise in Texas primary election
Article: Hispanic voter turnout surged in the Texas primary election on Tuesday and two Latinas emerged as likely the first from the state to be elected to the U.S. Congress, offering Texas Democrats some hope of closing their wide gap with Republicans.

Headline: Treasury's Mnuchin backs U.S. Senate bank bill: Bloomberg TV
Article: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Wednesday passage of a Senate bill to ease rules on banks would be "a big step in the right direction."

Headline: Trade skeptics gain upper hand in White House as Cohn quits
Article: Economic nationalists appeared to gain the upper hand in a White House battle over trade with the resignation of Donald Trump's top economic adviser, Gary Cohn, on Tuesday in a move that could ramp up protectionist measures that risk igniting a global trade war.

Headline: EU ready to react to U.S. steel tariffs, still hopes they can be avoided
Article: The European Union is ready to react to U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs but still hopes they can be avoided, the European Commission's trade chief said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. refinery workers head to Washington to urge biofuels reform
Article: A delegation of workers from U.S. oil refining companies that oppose the nation's biofuels policy converged on Washington on Wednesday to lobby lawmakers to find a way to lessen the regulation's costs without hurting corn farmers and makers of the alternative fuels.

Headline: After tariff fight loss, Trump economic adviser Cohn quits
Article: Gary Cohn, the top economic adviser to U.S. President Donald Trump and a voice for Wall Street in the White House, said on Tuesday he would resign, a move that came after he lost a fight over Trump's plans for hefty steel and aluminum import tariffs.

Headline: Factbox: Cohn is latest in parade of Trump administration departees
Article: The resignation of Gary Cohn, top economic adviser to President Donald Trump, will be the latest in a series of high-level departures from the Trump administration.

Headline: Germany alarmed by resignation of top Trump economic adviser
Article: Germany sees the danger of an "escalating spiral" in the trade dispute between the United States and Europe, a government spokesman said on Wednesday following the resignation of the top White House economic adviser.

Headline: Trump administration to provide records on Obama-era gun-smuggling probe
Article: The U.S. Justice Department has agreed to provide congressional investigators confidential records on a failed gun-trafficking operation during the Obama administration known as "Fast and Furious" that long has been criticized by Republican lawmakers.

Headline: Senators ask vote machine vendors about Russian access to source code
Article: Two Democratic senators on Wednesday asked major vendors of U.S. voting equipment whether they have allowed Russian entities to scrutinize their software, saying the practice could allow Moscow to hack into American elections infrastructure.

Headline: Democrat turnout rise in Texas could help bid to retake House
Article: A jump in turnout for Democrats in the Texas primary election on Tuesday strengthened forecasts that anger over U.S. President Donald Trumpâ€™s policies could help the party flip congressional seats from Republican control in November.

Headline: U.S. steel tariffs send 'disturbing message', Siemens CEO says on CNBC
Article: Planned U.S. tariffs on steel send a bad signal on free trade but won't have a big impact on Siemens, the German company's chief executive said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump's tariff announcement on track for this week: White House
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's announcement on steel and aluminum tariffs is on track to come by the end of this week, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders told reporters on Wednesday.

Headline: White House adviser Navarro says he is not a candidate to replace Cohn: Bloomberg
Article: White House trade adviser Peter Navarro said on Wednesday he was not a candidate to replace departing National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, Bloomberg News reported.

Headline: Republican lawmakers in tight races now embrace gun control measures
Article: A majority of Republican lawmakers in the tightest congressional races are changing their message on guns, expressing new support for restrictions after last monthâ€™s high school shooting in Florida, according to a Reuters review of the candidatesâ€™ public statements.

Headline: Democratic surge in Texas primaries gives Republicans reason to worry
Article: Republicans have more reason to be nervous about the prospects of keeping control of the U.S. Congress this year after Democrats came out in force in Texas congressional primary elections.

Headline: White House's Sanders: Trump has number of candidates to succeed Cohn
Article: President Donald Trump can choose from a pool of people to succeed the White House's top economic adviser Gary Cohn, who is expected to leave soon, Press Secretary Sarah Sanders told Fox News Channel on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. Justice Department sues California over 'sanctuary' policies
Article: The U.S. Justice Department sued the state of California over so-called "sanctuary" policies that try to protect illegal immigrants against deportation, ramping up a confrontation over whether local police should enforce federal law.

Headline: Factbox: Trump on Twitter (March 7) - Bush, Trade Deficit
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified Twitter accounts of U.S. President Donald Trump, @realDonaldTrump and @POTUS.

Headline: Europe needs appropriate measures against steel tariffs: Tata Steel Europe
Article: India's Tata Steel is concerned about U.S. plans to impose tariffs on steel imports, a senior executive at the group's European unit said on Wednesday.

Headline: IMF's Lagarde says nobody wins a trade war
Article: No one emerges victorious from a trade war, International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde said on Wednesday, warning that the economic impact of U.S. import tariffs would be serious if other countries respond with their own barriers.

Headline: Britain 'very disappointed' at Trump's tariff plans: minister
Article: Britain is "very disappointed" by U.S. President Donald Trump's plans to impose import tariffs on steel and aluminum but will wait to see more detail on the proposals, a junior trade minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trump says will pick new chief economic adviser soon
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he would make a decision soon on appointing a new chief economic adviser after Gary Cohn said he was resigning from the post.

Headline: Australia's central bank chief slams U.S. tariffs, confident on domestic growth
Article: The head of Australia's central bank is upbeat about domestic economic growth despite a disappointing end to last year, but fears the specter of a trade war calling threatened U.S. tariffs "highly regrettable."

Headline: Kushner to visit Mexico after Trump tirades, testy phone call
Article: Senior adviser to U.S. President Donald Trump, Jared Kushner, will visit Mexico on Wednesday and meet President Enrique Pena Nieto, amid strained relations over trade and Trump's demands that Mexico pay for a border wall.

Headline: Analyst View: Trump economic adviser Cohn quits after dispute over tariffs
Article: Top White House economic adviser Gary Cohn, a Wall Street banker who opposes hefty steel and aluminum tariffs planned by U.S. President Donald Trump, said late Tuesday that he was resigning.

Headline: Trump says U.S. will counteract any meddling in 2018 election
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday there was interference by Russia and probably by other countries in the 2016 U.S. election, and the United States would counteract any attempt at meddling in the November 2018 elections.

Headline: U.S. Senate votes 67-32 to begin debate on bank bill
Article: The U.S. Senate on Tuesday voted 67-32 in favor of beginning to debate a bipartisan bill that would ease rules for mid-sized and small lenders introduced following the 2007-2009 financial crisis.

Headline: Report finds White House aide Conway violated law in TV interviews
Article: Kellyanne Conway, one of President Donald Trump's top advisers, violated federal law in two television interviews last year by using her White House position to weigh in on a political race, the U.S. Office of Special Counsel said on Tuesday.

Headline: Top U.S. Senate Republican says metal tariffs could lead to trade war
Article: The top Republican in the U.S. Senate said on Tuesday that many of his colleagues were worried that President Donald Trump's planned tariffs on steel and aluminum imports could spark a trade war and hurt the economy.

Headline: Linking steel and NAFTA will not get a better deal: Canada's Morneau
Article: Linking steel with the ongoing renegotiation of NAFTA will not improve the tri-country trade agreement and Canada will respond firmly but appropriately if the United States targets Canada's steel or aluminum for tariffs, Finance Minister Bill Morneau said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump sticks with tariff plan, warns EU on trade
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump reiterated on Tuesday his plan to slap big tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum, warning the European Union it would get hit with a "big tax" for not treating the United States well when it comes to trade.

Headline: Top U.S. intel official insists White House engaged on election security
Article: The top U.S. intelligence official insisted on Tuesday that President Donald Trump's administration is "actively engaged" in countering Russian efforts to influence the November elections, even as he warned of Moscow's continuing "malign activities."

Headline: Democrats turn up heat on EPA chief over contracts, moonlighting
Article: U.S. Senate Democrats on Tuesday pressed Environmental Protection Agency chief Scott Pruitt to explain how an agency contract was awarded last year to the business associate of a member of his personal security detail.

Headline: Actress Cynthia Nixon may challenge Cuomo for New York governor: report
Article: Cynthia Nixon, a liberal activist and a star of the hit television series "Sex and the City," is considering a run for governor of New York, challenging incumbent Andrew Cuomo in the Democratic primary, NY1 television said on Tuesday, citing unidentified sources.

Headline: Warren vows fight as U.S. Senate begins debate on Dodd-Frank rewrite
Article: Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren promised to fight a U.S. Senate bill easing bank rules introduced following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis as the chamber moved on Tuesday to begin debating the draft bipartisan legislation.

Headline: House to debate bill to reduce violence in schools
Article: The U.S. House of Representatives will debate bipartisan legislation next week aimed at preventing violence at schools following the shooting deaths of 17 people at a Florida high school on Feb. 14, Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy said on Tuesday.

Headline: Democrats will not use spending bill to force vote on guns: Senator Schumer
Article: U.S. Senate Democrats will not try to use a spending bill to force a vote on measures to stop gun violence, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said on Tuesday.

Headline: Ryan: Trump's planned steel, aluminum tariffs too broad
Article: The most powerful member of the U.S. House of Representatives said on Tuesday that President Donald Trump's planned tariffs on steel and aluminum imports are too broad and open the country to possible retaliation, adding that he encouraged the White House to more narrowly focus its approach.

Headline: Massachusetts top court weighs 20-day voter registration cutoff
Article: Massachusetts' top court on Tuesday weighed whether it should declare a requirement that people must register to vote 20 days before an election unconstitutional, in a case that could impact the ability of thousands of citizens to cast ballots.

Headline: Trial opens over Kansas voter ID law requiring citizenship proof
Article: A trial over a Kansas law that requires proof of U.S citizenship from people registering to vote opened on Tuesday, with critics calling it illegal and backers saying it was a necessary tool to fight fraud.

Headline: Factbox: Trump on Twitter (March 6) - Fake News, DACA
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified Twitter accounts of U.S. President Donald Trump, @realDonaldTrump and @POTUS.

Headline: Turkey could retaliate U.S. tariffs with duties on cotton: Erdogan adviser
Article: Turkey could retaliate against potential U.S. steel tariffs by hiking duties on imports of American cotton, one of President Tayyip Erdogan's economic advisers said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump faces pushback on tariffs but says he will not back down
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump faced growing pressure on Monday from political and diplomatic allies as well as U.S. companies urging him to pull back from proposed steel and aluminum tariffs, although he said he would stick to his guns.

Headline: Trump's trade tariffs: Long on rhetoric, short on impact?
Article: From Bush-era steel duties to the European Union's "bra wars" skirmish with China, global trade wars have often threatened but never quite gotten off the ground and President Donald Trump's planned steel and aluminum tariffs will likely play out the same way.

Headline: Companies, industry groups target Congress to derail Trump tariffs
Article: Automakers, business groups and farmers took their fight against U.S. President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on steel and aluminum to Capitol Hill on Monday, betting that Republican lawmakers would stand up to the White House on their behalf.

Headline: Trump to meet companies that use steel, aluminum to discuss tariffs: Bloomberg
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to meet on Thursday with executives of U.S. companies that use steel and aluminum to discuss his proposed tariffs on the imports of the two metals, Bloomberg News reported on Monday, citing two unnamed people familiar with the matter.

Headline: Japan urges U.S. to shun steel tariffs but makes no threats
Article: Japan on Tuesday stuck to its low-key approach to threatened U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum, reflecting a desire to keep trade fights from hurting security ties as well as lessons learned about how to deal with President Donald Trump.

Headline: Ex-Trump aide Nunberg says will not comply with Russia probe subpoena
Article: A former campaign aide to U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday he would not comply with a subpoena to testify before a grand jury in special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.

Headline: Florida state Senate votes against arming most classroom teachers
Article: Florida's Republican-controlled Senate approved sweeping reforms to the state's gun law on Monday that raise the minimum purchase age and add a three-day waiting period in response to the deadliest high school shooting in U.S. history last month.

Headline: Republican Senator Cochran resigning, opening Mississippi seat
Article: U.S. Senator Thad Cochran, chairman of the powerful Appropriations Committee and a member of the Republican Party's old guard, said on Monday he will resign on April 1, putting another Republican Senate seat in play in elections this year.

Headline: Fights erupt, 12 arrested ahead of white nationalist's speech in Michigan
Article: A least a dozen people were arrested on Monday after supporters of Richard Spencer clashed with protesters outside a Michigan college campus where the white nationalist was scheduled to speak.

Headline: U.S. pushes NAFTA talks pace, warns of political headwinds
Article: Mexican and U.S. officials pushed on Monday to speed up NAFTA negotiations, with the United States floating the idea of reaching an agreement "in principle" in coming weeks to avoid political headwinds later this year.

Headline: Trump administration backs states' bid to collect online sales taxes
Article: The Trump administration on Monday said states should be able to require online retailers to collect sales taxes, backing an appeal by South Dakota at the U.S. Supreme Court that could mean billions of dollars in revenue for state coffers.

Headline: Canada's Trudeau calls Trump about steel tariffs: official
Article: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday about proposed steel and aluminum tariffs and "forcefully defended" Canadian workers and the industry, a government official said.

Headline: Trump's tariff threat may be timed for Pennsylvania U.S. House race
Article: President Donald Trump has alarmed the Republican establishment and world leaders by threatening tough steel tariffs, a message that might be meant not just to shake the world trade order but to help defend a congressional seat in Pennsylvania.

Headline: Republican U.S. Representative Walker urges rejection of planned tariffs
Article: The head of the largest group of conservatives in the U.S. Congress on Monday urged the Trump administration to reject its proposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, saying they would weaken the U.S. economy.

Headline: U.S. trade envoy says tariffs are an incentive to get NAFTA deal done
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's proposed blanket tariffs on steel and aluminum imports are an "incentive" for Canada and Mexico to conclude a NAFTA trade deal with the United States, Trump's trade envoy said on Monday after NAFTA negotiators ended the latest round of renegotiation talks.

Headline: Trump should exempt 'fairly traded' steel, aluminum from tariffs: U.S. lawmaker Brady
Article: The chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee said on Monday that President Donald Trump should tailor proposed tariffs to exempt all "fairly traded" steel and aluminum, certainly from Canada and Mexico.

Headline: Planned U.S. steel tariffs not 'helpful': senior UK official
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's plan to impose tariffs on steel is not "helpful" and it is counterproductive to aggravate tensions between U.S. and European allies given more aggressive Chinese and Russian behavior, a senior British official said on Monday.

Headline: Canada's Freeland says any steel, aluminum tariffs unacceptable
Article: Canada would view any tariffs on steel or aluminum as unacceptable and will take appropriate measures to defend workers and industries if needed, Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland said on Monday.

Headline: Senior U.S. Senate Republican seeks hearing on Trump trade tariffs
Article: The U.S. Senate should hold hearings on President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on foreign steel and aluminum, No. 2 Republican Senator John Cornyn said on Monday.

Headline: Mexico ministers says NAFTA talks should pick up speed
Article: Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo on Monday said that negotiations to rework the North American Free Trade Agreement should pick up speed toward a conclusion.

Headline: Take up stalled self-driving car bill, automakers urge U.S. Senate
Article: Major automakers on Monday joined forces with tech companies and a variety of interest groups to urge the U.S. Senate to take up, before the end of May, a stalled bill aimed at speeding the deployment and testing of self-driving cars.

Headline: No joint written statement after end of latest NAFTA talks: sources
Article: The latest round of talks to revamp the North American Free Trade Agreement will conclude without a joint written statement from the United States, Canada and Mexico, like the last round, two sources with knowledge of the matter said on Monday.

Headline: Lighthizer raises prospect of bilateral trade deals instead of NAFTA
Article: The United States could negotiate bilateral trade deals to replace the three way North American Free Trade Agreement if needed, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said on Monday, adding that time was running "very short."

Headline: Trump declares won't back down on tariffs, does not expect trade war
Article: President Donald Trump on Monday said he would not back down from his planned new tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, creating a possible standoff with top lawmakers from his own Republican party who have criticized the planned levies for threatening the U.S. economy and possibly sparking a trade war.

Headline: Trump trade adviser sees business exemptions for new tariffs
Article: A top trade adviser to U.S. President Donald Trump said on Sunday a process will be in place for businesses to get exemptions from the White House plan to place steep tariffs on steel and aluminum, offering the first indication a tariff hike could be less broad than first thought.

Headline: Democrats ask Kushner Companies, White House for loan-related documents
Article: U.S. Democratic lawmakers have asked the White House and Kushner Companies, the family business of President Donald Trump's top adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner, for documents following reported loans from Citibank and Apollo Global Management, according to a statement released on Monday.

Headline: France's Macron urges WTO action over U.S. steel tariffs
Article: The European Union must take urgent action at the World Trade Organisation if the United States goes ahead with tariffs on steel and aluminum, French President Emmanuel Macron said on Monday.

Headline: U.S. tariff hikes may have effect on UAE's Emirates Steel sales: CEO
Article: Emirates Steel, the largest steel producer in the UAE, said a tariff on imports to the United States could hurt its sales, 5 percent of which go to the U.S., the company's chief executive said on Monday.

Headline: WTO chief urges states to stop first dominoes of trade war
Article: The head of the World Trade Organization told member states on Monday they must prevent "the fall of the first dominoes" in a trade war and warned of a real risk of triggering an escalation of global trade barriers and a deep recession.

Headline: Paul Ryan urges Trump not to advance with tariffs: spokeswoman
Article: U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan on Monday urged the Trump administration not to move forward on new tariffs on steel and aluminum announced last week, citing the risks to the economy.

Headline: U.S. trade panel backs probe into welded pipe imports
Article: The U.S. International Trade Commission on Monday voted to continue anti-dumping and subsidy investigations into imports of large-diameter welded pipe from Canada, China, Greece, India, South Korea and Turkey, it said in a statement.

Headline: NAFTA negotiators conclude talks on food safety: source
Article: Negotiators from the United States, Canada and Mexico successfully concluded discussions on rules governing food safety and animal health under a revised NAFTA trade deal, a Mexican source familiar with the matter said on Monday.

Headline: Trump's extraordinary tariffs
Article: President Donald Trump's plans for a 25 percent tariff on U.S. imports of steel and 10 percent on aluminum have created a global outcry. The following explains why the use of these particular tariffs is so controversial among trade experts.

Headline: Canada's Morneau: Terms of NAFTA discussion have been changed
Article: Canada's Finance Minister Bill Morneau said on Monday the country is negotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with a partner that has "changed the terms of the discussion".

Headline: Factbox: Trump on Twitter (March 5) - NAFTA, Steel
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified Twitter accounts of U.S. President Donald Trump, @realDonaldTrump and @POTUS.

Headline: Mexico should be exempt from proposed U.S. tariffs: economy minister
Article: Mexico's economy minister said on Monday that the country should be exempt from proposed U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum as the latest round of talks to modernize the North American Free Trade Agreement draws to a close.

Headline: Trump ties steel, aluminum tariffs for Mexico, Canada to NAFTA
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday appeared to suggest that Canada and Mexico could win exemptions to his planned sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum if the two countries sign a new NAFTA trade deal and take other steps.

Headline: Key U.S. lawmaker urges steel tariff exemptions for NAFTA allies
Article: An influential U.S. lawmaker said on Sunday all fairly traded steel and aluminum, especially from Canada and Mexico, should be excluded from President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs, as he sought to calm tensions at major trade talks in Mexico.

Headline: As Congress moves to drop tariffs, some U.S. firms cry foul
Article: Michael Korchmar was hiring. His family-owned travel-goods company was planning to make a new product, an insulated food bag, and he had put out help-wanted notices for up to 30 workers to run the sewing machines in his small factory on Floridaâ€™s Gulf Coast.

Headline: Britain still confident of trade deal with U.S.: May's spokesman
Article: Britain is still confident that it can reach a trade deal with the United States, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday after President Donald Trump unveiled tariffs on imported steel and aluminum.

Headline: EU executive to discuss reaction to U.S. tariffs on Wednesday
Article: European Commissioners will discuss on Wednesday the EU's reaction to planned U.S. import tariffs on steel and aluminum, the Commission said on Monday, adding that the root cause of problems for those metal sectors was overcapacity.

Headline: U.S.-Europe trade war must be avoided: German carmakers
Article: German carmakers said on Monday that a trade war between the United States and Europe must be avoided, expressing their profound concern after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to tax car imports.

Headline: UK PM May tells Trump of 'deep concern' over metals tariffs
Article: British Prime Minister Theresa May told U.S. President Donald Trump she had "deep concern" about the expected announcement of U.S. tariffs on aluminum and steel, May's office said on Sunday following a phone call between the two leaders.

Headline: As NAFTA weighs, Trump's tariffs drive new U.S. auto concerns
Article: From a hotel in Mexico City, Ann Wilson, a senior executive at the U.S. Motor and Equipment Manufacturers Association (MEMA), is fielding calls from American auto parts makers worried that President Donald Trump's metal tariffs will force them out of business.

Headline: NAFTA talks on autos eyed for next week: Mexico negotiator
Article: U.S., Mexican and Canadian trade experts leading efforts to draft new rules for auto content under a revised NAFTA trade deal aim to meet next week, Mexico's chief negotiator Kenneth Smith said on Saturday.

Headline: Investigators looking at whether Kushner business talks affected U.S. policy: NBC News
Article: Federal investigators are looking into whether Jared Kushner's business talks with foreigners, as his father-in-law Donald Trump assumed the U.S. presidency, later influenced White House policy, NBC News reported on Friday.

Headline: 'Trade wars are good,' Trump says, defying global concern over tariffs
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump struck a defiant tone on Friday, saying trade wars were good and easy to win, after his plan to put tariffs on steel and aluminum imports triggered threats of retaliation from trading partners and a slide in stock markets.

Headline: Businesses try to coax Trump from tariffs brink, aides quarrel
Article: President Donald Trump, after shocking markets with the risk of a global trade war, came under intense pressure on Friday from U.S. business interests and foreign trading partners to moderate his threat to slap tariffs on steel and aluminum imports.

Headline: The financial impact of Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum
Article: If U.S. President Donald Trump goes ahead with sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, it could lower profits for companies making everything from pickup trucks to canned soup, or result in higher prices for consumers.

Headline: Even if exempted, Canada steel industry sees dumping risk
Article: Canada's steel sector could be wounded by U.S. tariffs even if the country is exempt from the 25 percent duty promised by President Donald Trump, as cheap steel previously sold south of the border floods into Canada, industry leaders said on Friday.

Headline: Putin tells U.S. to send evidence of vote meddling
Article: Russian President Vladimir Putin told Washington to send him hard evidence that his citizens meddled in U.S. elections, mocking accusations to date as "yelling and hollering in the United States Congress".

Headline: Trump on Twitter (Mar 02) - Trade wars, steel, reciprocal taxes
Article: The following statements were posted to the verified Twitter accounts of U.S. President Donald Trump, @realDonaldTrump and @POTUS.

Headline: Canada retaliation in U.S. tariff row 'like grabbing your own throat'
Article: Canadian officials are bombarding U.S. counterparts with calls to secure an exemption on potential steel and aluminum tariffs and threatening retaliation, but Ottawa has limited leverage to counter the plan, industry insiders and analysts said on Friday.

Headline: Delta reviewing ties with all 'politically divisive' groups after NRA controversy
Article: Delta Air Lines is reviewing its relationships with all "politically divisive" groups, the carrier's chief executive said in a Friday memo to employees, following blowback this week from the airline's decision to cut ties with the National Rifle Association.

Headline: Ford Motor Co warns Trump metal tariffs may hike commodity prices
Article: Ford Motor Co said on Friday that U.S. President Donald Trump's announced steel and aluminum tariffs could boost domestic commodity prices and harm the "competitiveness of American manufacturers."

Headline: Outlook for Fed: Cloudy with chance of trade war
Article: The Federal Reserve digested the Trump administration's massive tax cuts and plan to boost spending with barely a hiccup, but Washington's sudden push for steep tariffs on steel and aluminum imports could saddle the U.S. central bank with the worst of both worlds - rising inflation and a slowing global economy.

Headline: Rust-belt Democrats praise Trump's threatened metals tariffs
Article: Republican President Donald Trump's market-jolting promise to slap heavy U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports has earned him praise from an unusual quarter - Democratic lawmakers.

Headline: Trump administration to crack down on securities, tax fraud
Article: Deputy U.S. Attorney General Rod Rosenstein on Friday laid out the Trump administration's approach to fighting financial crime, saying the government will focus more heavily on certain tax violations and that it is cracking down on securities fraud.

Headline: Trump's chief of staff admits errors in ex-aide's scandal
Article: U.S. President Donald Trump's Chief of Staff John Kelly on Friday conceded the White House could have better handled a scandal involving senior aide Rob Porter, who resigned last month after allegations by two ex-wives that he abused them.

Headline: Europe targets U.S. bourbon, bikes, blue jeans for trade riposte
Article: Europe has drawn up a list of U.S. products from bourbon to Harley Davidson motorbikes on which to apply tariffs if U.S. President Donald Trump follows through on a plan to impose global duties on aluminum and steel.

Headline: WTO chief makes rare warning of trade war over U.S. tariff plan
Article: World Trade Organization Director General Roberto Azevedo expressed concern at U.S. President Donald Trump's plan for tariffs on steel and aluminum on Friday, an extremely rare intervention into a WTO member's trade policy.

Headline: Brazil aluminum industry worried about trade war fallout
Article: Brazilian aluminum producers are concerned that U.S. President Donald Trump is launching into a trade war with China that will ricochet on the world market and depress prices if Chinese exporters have to find other buyers.

Headline: Canada's Trudeau says U.S. tariffs on steel would be 'unacceptable'
Article: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Friday any U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports would be "absolutely unacceptable" and said his government would continue to engage with U.S. officials on the issue.

Headline: Trump's aluminum imports tax will bite domestic industry
Article: U.S. plans to slap taxes on aluminum imports will make life more expensive for its manufacturers which use the metal to make high value products like cars, because the U.S. doesn't have the capacity to produce what it needs.

Headline: Brazil industry lobby defends right to retaliate vs. U.S. tariffs
Article: Brazil's main industry lobby, CNI, said in an emailed statement on Friday that U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs planned by President Donald trump violate World Trade Organization rules and called on the Brazilian government to fight them and retaliate if possible.

Headline: IMF warns that U.S. steel, aluminum tariffs will likely hurt economies
Article: The International Monetary Fund warned on Friday that U.S. import tariffs on steel and aluminum would likely cause economic damage to the United States and its trading partners, and urged countries to resolve trade disputes without resorting to retaliatory measures.

Headline: Wisconsin governor warns Trump tariffs will hurt Americans
Article: Republican Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin urged President Donald Trump to reconsider a tariff hike on steel and aluminum imports on Friday, saying the move will hurt Americans.

Headline: Canada PM warns of market disruption from US steel tariffs
Article: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Friday any U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports would cause significant disruption to markets on both sides of the border, but he was confident his government could defend the industry.

Headline: Juncker says EU must respond if U.S. finalizes steel tariffs
